This might be the best of the Total War games in my opinion. I did not enjoy it in the beginning due to the complexity but once you learn how to play it is very addicting. If you want to play as either the WRE or ERE and are new to TW Attila, I recommend starting the Last Roman expansion first. You don't have to worry about city management and can just focus on the basics of running an army and fighting battles. 

I am going through a WRE campaign now and like how the difficulty keeps the campaign from being a simple map-painting exercise. When you take over in 395 AD the cities are underdeveloped, armies poor quality and understrength, the emperor is a chump, etc. Meanwhile your enemies are ready to bumrush and take advantage of your weaknesses. It reflects the period well where various tribes saw the weakness of the Romans and sought to exploit it. I am used to playing games where the Romans are the strongest but here you find other factions have more numerous and better quality troops in the beginning. You have to work hard to improve your military technology to get better units. Even your maxed out units are not best in class (found that out the hard way when my Herculani Seniores tried to fight a few Uar warriors straight up). You have to rely on tactics such as defensive formation, picking the right ground to defend a settlement - Hint... try to limit the directions from which the enemy can attack, and using combined arms tactics with your archers. I found the large onagers and ravenna elite crossbowmen a bit OP though.

Managing the military and social challenges is difficult enough but then Attila spawns with what seems like a million stacks of high-morale, high-quality troops. Europe also undergoes a climate change event where provinces produce less food. All of these obstacles make completing a campaign feel like a minor accomplishment even though it's just a video game haha. I think TW did a solid job covering Late Antiquity which is a very underrated time of history imo.

The only criticism I have is that the battle AI can be very dumb even at the higher levels. I have won many battles due to luck where the AI failed to flank my outnumbered forces and simply charged head on.

Battles - 5/5
Naval battles - 5/5
Campaign - 4/5
Atmosphere - 4/5
DLCs - 4/5

- Yes this game feels like Rome 2.5 being built on the same engine with more or less the same assets. Yet there are many improvements in both land and naval battles and all nomadic factions have been significanly reworked. Playing as the horde or a migrating nation is a completely new total war experience.
- The campaign's atmosphere is unique, not at all like in Rome II. The Hunic horde is a real menace for every faction close to them or every bigger empire. You will also feel the slow descent of the world into darker and filthier times, as sanitation gets a greater role here and fertility level of the provinces will decreese over time. Yet again, I am forced to give the atmosphere 4/5 for female warriors implemented into the units. This time there are no purely female units, rather they have made some units mixed. I cannot consent to this in a historical game. But again I have to thank CA for allowing mods. Yes, many factions play similarely as this is reality not a fantasy game with mummies and lizard-people, but their starting conditions and location on the map with a combination of the unique traits make for a fun experience with all of them.
- The politics are similar in some ways to Rome II, but the political positions have been redone in more logical and fun way. Character leveling has also been made more comprehencible.

- The DLCs are awesome. The Last Roman and Age of Charlemagne are the best DLC content for a Total War ever.

Attila is my favorite TW game by a lot--I think it's the best historical entry in the series without a question. It's also one of the only strategy games where losing actually is fun. Running the Romans is less about world conquest and more about sailing a sinking ship. Although probably less impressive five years later, the AI was a massive step forward at the time of release, and this game also introduced a number of control improvements, like drawn movement orders on the battlefield. The time period also kicks ass.

This review is in English and Slovak language:
Táto recenzia je v Anglickom a Slovenskom jazyku:

Most games in the Total War series are very similar and have many positives and negatives in common. In my opinion, Attila is the best in the series, but the potential of the game is much greater and the game contains a few bugs and unintended things. The worst thing is the faulty mechanics of the game, which after the defeat of the Hun tribes immediately at the beginning of the next move will create a new fully armed army not far from the place of crushing defeat. I understand that Attila is a major part of the game, but the mechanics should either create an army in another remote location or create only a small and weak Hun army nearby. The historical significance of Attila is quite overestimated, because despite the enormous footprint they have left in history, they have spent most of their existence with only a small plunder of weaker opponents. Moreover, it was an ethnically diverse conglomerate of nations, where the Huns formed only a small socially dominant part. Additional campaigns purchased with downloadable content are even worse than the main part of the game in all the shortcomings mentioned. Downloadable content is not as expensive as other games, but its content are parts that I think should be part of the basic game (especially playable fractions). The company's policy in the Total War series is another reason not to buy any of their games. A series of Total War games has turned into a breeding farm! One game is not finished, it is full of mistakes and imbalances, but the company is already starting work on another game and no one will return to the previous one to fix it.

Väčšina hier zo série Total War sa na seba veľmi podobá a majú mnoho spoločných pozitív aj negatív. Attila je podľa mňa najlepší zo série, ale potenciál hry je oveľa väčší a hra obsahuje niekoľko chýb a nedomyslených vecí. Najhoršou vecou je chybná mechanika hry, ktorá po porážke Hunských kmeňov okamžite na začiatku ďalšieho ťahu vytvorí novú plne vyzbrojenú armádu neďaleko miesta zdrvujúcej porážky. Ja chápem, že Attila je hlavnou časťou hry, ale mechanika by mala, buď vytvoriť armádu na inom odľahlom mieste, alebo vytvoriť blízko len malú a slabú armádu Hunov. Historický význam Attilu je dosť preceňovaný, pretože aj napriek obrovskej stope, ktorú v dejinách zanechali, väčšinu svojej existencie strávili len drobným lúpením slabších súperov. Navyše išlo o etnicky rôznorodý konglomerát národov, kde Huni tvorili len malú spoločensky dominantnú časť. Dodatočné kampane zakúpené v rámci stiahnuteľného obsahu sú ešte horšie ako hlavná časť hry vo všetkých spomenutých nedostatkoch. Stiahnuteľný obsah síce nie je drahý ako pri iných hrách, ale jeho obsahom sú časti, ktoré by podľa mňa mali byť súčasťou základnej hry (najmä hrateľné frakcie). Politika spoločnosti v rámci série Total War je ďalším dôvodom, aby ste si žiadnu ich hru nekúpili. Séria Total War hier sa premenila na rozmnožovaciu farmu! Jedna hra nie je hotová, je plná chýb a nevyváženosti, ale spoločnosť už začína pracovať na ďalšej hre a k predošlej sa už nikto nevráti aby ju neopravil.

If you're new to Total War:
Recommend giving a different Total War a go first. This one can be a little spammy, and pretty gruelling - the campaign takes no prisoners. Try Rome 2 if you liked the visual style of this game but want a more rounded strategy experience, or Rome 1 / Medieval 2 if you want the absolute best of strategy this brand has to offer and don't care too much about the game being graphically impressive.

If you have played Total War before:
This is one of my favourites. It's not perfect by any means - the campaign can be gruelling, and it's frustrating to see the AI cheat quite so much sometimes (Doomstack of tier 3 units magically spawns 3 feet from one of your border settlements, can be a bit frustrating...). It can also be a bit spammy - often a gimmick spam army gives you better results than a balanced army, and the rosters are kinda geared that way. (e.g. the Alans are best played by just spamming cheap melee cavalry).
Pros though - the gruelling campaign captures what the developers were going for. It's meant to be dystopian. You're meant to feel the walls closing in. That doesn't take away from the campaign at all - if anything, it's much more interesting than the standard "Everyone starts a bit weak and grows from there" setup. You feel the desperation of being in a horde, or the chaos of the collapsing West. Is it truly representative of the death throes of Rome? Well, no, the year is all a bit wrong and it all happens a bit faster than reality, the 'norse' factions are just wildly out of place. (And the less said about berserking units the better.) But frankly, it's much more fun to play this way - it's meant to play like a mythical interpretation of the events, rather than to represent their reality. And Attila really captures the theme of dread and societal collapse. The music is excellent, probably my favourite soundtrack from the TW games, complete with throat singing to instill you with the mounting threat of the Hunnic Hordes. The visual style is also great, the darkness and gloom of the world you're in only ever broken by the bright flames of whole countries being literally burned to the ground. The battles are intense and swift, but also I feel give you more options with each unit than e.g. Rome 2 did. 

In short, if you enjoyed Rome 2, definitely give this one a go. It's a great follow-up.
If you enjoyed other TW games, give it a go if you're cool with pre-gunpowder, a bit of creative license doesn't bother you too much, you aren't a Rome 1 or Medieval 2 purist, and you like the idea of a more 'existential crisis' kind of campaign.
If you've never played TW, give a different one a go first. Rome 2, or Shogun 2, or maybe Napoleon.

DLC-wise, Last Roman can be alright, it's a fairly neat experience, whereas I found Age of Charlemagne to be a bit meh.

[h1]TLDR:[/h1]
Get Attila Total War if you want a unique entry in the franchise: grand strategy mechanics have been flipped from conquering to [b]survival[/b]. This change informs the bleak historical setting and audio-visuals of the game or perhaps vice versa. Mods turn a relatively rough vanilla product, by CA standards, into a great game. 

[h1]Positives:[/h1]

If Shogun 2 represents the quintessential total war experience, then Attila stands opposed to that tradition. Unlike Shogun 2 and other games in the franchise, Atilla does not want you to campaign and conquer--the game is not about unification or imperialism. Instead, the game is about [b]survival[/b], which is reinforced by the historical setting. The Huns are seeking food and glory; migratory tribes flee west of the Danube for shelter, Rome is fractured, famine and disease are rampant...

The historical theme of survival is well actualized in the gameplay. Eastern and Western Rome are vast, but your armies are few, and you will lose territory quickly to the migratory tribes and later the Huns. Migratory tribes begin as hordes that must colonize fertile provinces to survive. The Huns must survive by subjugating factions and fueling their armies with tribute--in turn gaining diplomatic penalties and constant hostility from everyone including their tributaries. The game is bleak and the design, sound, and setting reinforce it. 

[h1]Negatives and Troubleshooting:[/h1]

Conceptually this game is fantastic; however, I have to warn that gameplay heavily favors 'kiting' and is micro-intensive. Thankfully, there are several overhaul mods (with ongoing support) that balance and tailor the game to your liking. 
Also, the game needs some tweaking for optimization--mainly fixing framerate issues by lowering shadow quality to less than the highest and mods that edit the LOD ranges for units.

Honesty one of my least favourite of the Total Wars. Which makes me sad as I desperately want to like it. It has a lot going for it, taking the framework of Rome 2 (Which was dismal on release but eventually reached the giddy heights of basically ok), and sets itself at the fall of the Western Roman Empire. It does feel somewhat reminiscent of the old expansion pack for Rome 1, although more like a full fledged game rather than a mere expansion. It has a lovely dark colour palette, some amazing fire effects, and a lot of effort has gone into fleshing out the various factions. The Sassanids in particular feel a lot more like the rival empire they are supposed to be and less like a tiny faction struggling to survive at the edge of the map. Sieges are decent, you are actually reliant on siege engines and can't just swarm the walls with every infantry unit you have (please stop giving every infantry unit invisible ladders CA, it makes walls irrelevant) and even have random civilians running around throwing rocks at the invaders. The whole tone feels darker, and you even have to deal with a cooling climate on top of everything else. On a whole they have tried to make it a lot more interesting experience than the previous game. But maybe that's where the issues start.
Rome 2's biggest issue for me is that it's far too easy. It seems that once you get to a certain point fairly early in the game, you have reached critical mass and no other faction in the game can ever meaningfully threaten you again. You essentially become the order tide from warhammer 2, and the game turns into a "paint the map" simulator as a result. Attila seems to have been designed with the intent to counteract this, and they seem to have swung too far in the opposite direction, with pretty calamitous results. There are the Huns, but I'll save them for later, my biggest issue is actually the management. It legitimately feels as if the entire settlement management system has been reworked to stifle growth and to slow down the player as much as possible. Settlements don't have very many build slots, and almost every building that you can build will give you a negative buff, consuming food, upkeep or leading to squalor. The small number of build slots means that it's quite difficult to balance these effectively, and even in the event that you do you are going to be extremely limited in what else you can build. Public order seems to be particularly hard to manage (This issue was also very prevalent in thrones of Britanna for a long time) and this results in a vast amount of the game being you simply sitting your armies in a settlement, sometimes for twenty to thirty turns waiting for public order to stabilise, before briefly hopping out to fight a battle or two before turning tail and running for home. If you actually do manage to conquer a region, prepare for even more sitting around consolidating. There's always been an element of this in most total war games, but it feels like it's taken much too far in this one. I attempted a campaign as the Irish, and after conquering britain in the first 5 hours spent the next 10 sitting there doing nothing but maintaining public order and waiting, either for population to grow enough to build something, or for a plague to go away so I can actually move my army. End turn and loading times are obnoxiously long, either due to CA not wanting to invest time patching an unpopular game, or because Deathmaster Snikitch is in no hurry to deliver a potion of speed to the Ro-man things! Let them die-die! I think I fought maybe two battles in 7 of these hours, the last three were spent with the game's other big issue.
The huns. I hate Huns. My Father hated them too, even before they put out his eyes. 
The Huns are the midgame crisis (The endgame being the Sassanids and their twenty vassals who don't get attacked by the Huns and so always survive, then devour most of the map), and I hate their implimentation with a flaming passion that outmatches that of Attila on his wedding night. Remember the Warriors of Chaos, and how easy it actually is to defeat them? Well whoever designed the Huns thought it would be a sterling idea that, every time you destroy a Hunnic army, a fresh one will appear where it died the next turn. Stop, read that again. I wish I was joking. Kill the Hun, another identical hun appears where he dies. If that didn't already sound stupid enough, they also stop your troops replenishing when you are in their provinces, so there is seemingly very little point in fighting them at all, as you get very quickly worn down whilst they take no damage whatsoever. The only reasonably safe strategy is to defeat their armies but not destroy them, but CA also decided to give the Hunnic units absurdly high morale (as well as many giving your own units fear penalties) so this is a lot easier said than done. Even then the tattered army will only slink off, hire mercenaries and come for you again. The only way to beat this is to either pick Attila out of the 12 or so stacks and kill him four separate times (he can be assassinated some of these but not all) or hope to outlast him. Or play as the Sassanids who don't get invaded, have a sanitation bonus that means they are a lot less pemalised when expanding, so just sit on your backside then steamroll the ruined map. Needless to say it is the very definition of artificial difficulty, and it means even if you can get through everything else you get nothing but a very absurd and arbitrary challenge, and surviving it means nothing but getting steamrolled by the Persians.
So, in conclusion, of all the total wars, do not touch. It's the only one which I can tar with the dirtiest brush available to me as a random joe who writes reviews about games he plays. It's boring. The combination of the sitting around and the long turn times make it a chore to play, and the mid and end game just add nihilism and almost inevitable defeat, so you can suffer through all of that boredom for nothing.
However, I will say, the two DLC campaigns are legitimately quite good. If per say, you were to get it on sale to play the last roman or the excellent christopher lee simulator, that would justify the purchase. Stay safe fellow romans! It lives on in our hearts! ROMA INVICTA AETERNA!

Not a game for new players to the series, this game tests your skills you'd have learned from hundreds, if not thousands of hours playing previous Total War games. Restoring the Western Roman Empire is a feat that will have you fighting intense and closely contested battles every turn. Your only hope will be to dig into your deep well of experience, make the best use of whatever assets are on hand, and perform heroic acts of sacrifice. You'll spend hours cursing the many enemies that will arise from all directions, fighting a seemingly endless war of attrition across a vast border, slowly regaining your strength. It may cost your offline hours agonizing over mistakes and strategizing your course of action, it may even cost you sleep. But when all the hard work has been done and your Empire remains after an onslaught of everything that can go wrong, you'll understand the satisfaction of success under impossible odds.

Total War Attila (TWA) has taken a bit of my time recently because it offers a lot of good gameplay. However, after giving it close to 100 hours of gameplay, TWA is saturated in glitches and bugs. Like its host of predecessors, the game freezes multiple times in one game session. It freezes while scanning the campaign map; it freezes during battle setup and at any point during a battle – the worst being when it freezes right at the end of a big, crucial battle that one is on the brink of winning. Creative Assembly released this game over 5 years ago (February 2015), and it runs as if they haven't touched this game since its release date – except for its overpriced DLCs. For this reason TWA is the last game I will purchase from Creative Assembly; no longer will I support their “don't care” attitude for their overpriced, buggy products.

Great mechanics for Campaing even though the historical setting leaves great chunks of map controlled by single factions, the great variability in ownership over the provinces and the constant war makes this Total War a very enjoyable expirience.
Extraordinary Modding community with great overhauls and time setting changes such as Terminus: Imperium, Ancient Empires or Medieval Kingdoms 1212. 
Many quality of life mods around, people have some usefull collections to make even the original setting more interesting. 

Great dlc, generally the added cultures have strenghts and weaknesses that are remarkable and have an unique playstyle. Great expansions with Age of Charlemagne being one of the best campaing expiriences aviabale, very new player friendly in comparison to the vanilla campaing. If you are picking it up be sure to get either the briton or viking culture packs to have a enjoyable first campaing as most factions in vanilla are sorrounded by enemies and constant war, which can be overwhelming for new players, specially such complex factions like Western Roman Empire or the Huns.

CA should revisit this game and make official the import of Thrones of Britannia optimizations, which would fix 90% of the major stuttering and big battle problems that this game has. 

Second best behind Medieval 2, and its clear successor in terms of modding community, only shadowed by the incredible rise of the Warhammer games that have a modding community equally strong , and even bigger. Graphics and effects hold up to this day and there are many great modded texture packs that increase quality and variety even more.

I recommend this game to people who have already played other total wars and dont mind a more challenging expirience, with extraordinarilly agressive AI only matched by Rome 2 recent dlc and patches ( that take many mechanics from Attila I might add).

In short great game, underrated by many because of the time period it covers and the fact its way to similar to Rome II in some aspects, but the improvements in battle mechanics, collision and politics makes this game very entertaining and fun to play.

A divisive Total War title, with an emphasis on a dark and gritty portrayal of the invasion of Attila the Hun.

+ New gameplay systems make this one of the deepest TW experiences to date.
+ The gameplay experience of holding back the horde as the Eastern Roman Empire, while reforging the empire is one of the most intense campaigns I've ever done.
- The performance isn't really that great.
- The barbarian factions lack unit variety, except for the Huns.
The game is totally up to the level that one expects from the TW saga, plus some great minor details. It is addictive and entertaining like few others.

I bought this game to get an updated experience from Total War: Rome / Medieval / Shogun. I then spent all my time playing the Charlemagne sub-campaign. It turns out I have no interest in Attila, the mechanics his faction provide or this era of history. It could be said I bought the wrong title or should have waited for one of the newer installments.

I recommend the title because it plays fine. It delivers classic TW action. To have spent more than 100 hours without ever really playing the campaign tells me there's enough here to keep folks interested. If you love other TWs you'll love this one too. If you're new to the franchise there's no reason not to pick this one up unless you're more captivated by one of the other genres.

I suppose it could be said naval combat could've been done better and some graphic choices weren't entirely to my taste, but that's not enough of a knock to thumbs down this installment. It's a fine TW game.
I'm not sure what I don't like about this game I just prefer Rome 2 to this.... I am still going to give it a positive review because I love total war games.
It ain't perfect but it's damn fun.

tl;dr: retrospectively, mechanic diversity and hardware limitations?
It does what it says on the tin, like all TW titles I have played... the problem is that it's a very specific tin: "total war". So perhaps this is an unfair review, but on the long-term, having played RTW, M2TW, ETW, NTW, R2TW and ATW, I just got tired with the diplomacy, trade, etc. mechanics, which I found other strategy titles did better. I suppose my issue is that these are the mechanics that, for me, give the game replayability, rather than the real-time battles (that said, M2TW battles still feel much more satisfying than this or any other TW's). Many mods, of course, are incredibly fun, but even very polished ones like 1212AD seem to eventually hit a wall when they try to change key mechanics, or introduce new ones (and old ones, left unchanged, can still annoy the player from time to time). I should note I have been playing these games mostly on an old laptop, and I feel the new titles in particular (ETW-onwards) would be much more appreciable in a proper gaming computer, to show off unit design, scale, etc... so it would also be fair to say I haven't played the game "as it is supposed to be played", a bit like watching LOTR on a phone...

This game 1) should have been a DLC for Rome II, 2) lacks basic quality of life features such as a "select next unit" button in the UI, 3) gives AI factions massive bonuses/cheats that makes every campaign fundamentally asymmetrical, and 4) premises its strategic difficulty on the idea that everyone in Europe somehow stopped being able to farm after the fall of the Western Roman Empire.  I'm not here to tell you how to spend your money, but this game has serious problems.

Edit: the Radious mods make it more playable.  No excuse for a Total War title to require mods, though, for unarmored peasant levies to stop whupping armored, professional legionnaires 1v1.

Ah, Total War... the eternal series! Of fun, frustration and expensive DLCs...

The real struggle of reviewing Attila is that I really really love the game. But I almost can't get myself to say it because this game is so obviously a step in a direction that and old-school total war fan simply cannot appreciate. But let me get to the point. The reasons why I love Attila and why I'll definitely play another campaign or three:
- The map is huge
- Diplomacy is solid
- Unit roster is amazingly diverse, including a wide range of mercenaries
- Huns are such a dark and threatening menace. I always sh*t myself when I see their army of Devil Archers approaching.
- I LOVE razing and colonising settlements
- Battle AI is above-average
- Battle maps and battle mechanics are original and fresh. You can see how much ammunition enemy units have left. You can build barricades, set stuff on fire etc.
- Amphibious battles
- City building is good
- Interesting internal politics mechanics
- A very tangible era-ending atmosphere
- A lot of playable factions

Reasons why I won't play another five or ten campaigns (like I did in Shogun 2 or Medieval 2):
- Campaign AI is below-average (seriously, running away with your superior army into the hills and letting me take your cities?)
- Graphics has taken an unfortunate step back. Heck, even water looks worse than in Shogun 2!
- Just like in Rome 2, you can't have armies without commanders. Furthermore, the number of armies you can weild is capped. Can only weild 5 armies but have 6 border settlements? Sorry! You'll have to make do somehow. This is a slap in the face to any strategy game enthusiast. Why in the world can't I transfer units from one army to another without moving the ENTIRE army?!
- Traits development for characters seems even more random than in Medieval 2
- Weird agent development trees. Each agent has ten or more abilites, most of which are useless.
- Weird religion traits/benefits. Was Christianity really so useless back then?
- Nonsensical city building mechanics. Why in the world are fields lowering public order? "Damn, I'm so pissed at those f****g wheat farms over there!"
- Really, graphics is much weaker than in older titles! Zooming in on battles is far less satisfying than it used to be.
- DLCs. Want all the factions? Pay up (and not once!). Want blood in this military strategy game? Pay up. (To be fair, those burned corpses look awesome... but why do I gotta pay 5 euros for that?)

There it is. I'd give Attila a solid 8/10. Good game, but lacking. Lacking in things that could be very easily fixed.
Overall a good choice for any Total War lover who loves ancient era but can't stand Rome 2.

If you played 1500 hours of rome 2. You might want to consider rome 2.5: atilla.

It is nearly the same game beside some added elements and a lot of revamping visually, troops and buildings. Basicly a new campaign but a little extra. If it were a rome 2 expansion it would have almost been the same i think.

Tribes can now migrate somewhere else after being beat out of their settlements. Some tribes can resettle, like the huns. I beat 8  hun armies and they kept appearing, i beat 6 more. They keep spawning forever. The huns were hungry for me and i spent a million gold to keep them at bay. They burned down entire northern europe and the only thing standing was the middle east and some remaingin settlements in europe. I was the richest obviously and they woudln't stop coming. I had to quit that campaign for this reason. Infinite hordes isn't gameplay it is torture. I just play with tribes not located in europe to avoid the huns and now the game is fine. Quite fun actually. 

That's my experience so far. I think when i will play with europian tribes i will download some debuff mod for the hordes because impossible.

So, honestly in terms of game play Atilla is slow. And when i say slow, i mean as the Romans you're fighting at least one battle every turn. And if you don't fight those battle yourself and the odds aren't 3 to 1 you're gonna take stupid high casualties. The mod scene however, is one to rival Rome 2 and i mean that in a very good way. Fall of The Eagles is an amazing mod for the base game, and Radius is nice if you want a bit of an easier go at the harder factions. If you're looking for a conversion mod than i'd definitely say go for MK1212 because why not. All in and all a great TW title and really is the best historical title in terms of recent games 8/10.

Attila is a great game ruined by performance issues. The premise is interesting, the gameplay is challenging, the soundtrack is excellent. They also managed to make it a very immersive game, the setting, color palette, and music make you feel like you are playing in a decadent world that is just about to crumble.  But you can't really enjoy it much when every battle turns into a slideshow. You can improve it by turning down the graphical settings (specially shadows) but then it looks really bad. There are some performance mods that make it more bearable by tweaking LOD but it's not enough.

It's a shame because CA is using the same engine for Thrones of Brittania and they seem to have fixed these issues (that one runs smoothly on the same PC), sadly they never care about Attila to fix it's issues. 

So I do recommend it, but keep in mind that there are high chances it will run awful on your computer.

Total War: Attila is an underrated game. TW: Attila is unbalanced , ugly and not all that optimized. However, it is a unique game that is the most difficult in the franchise. 

TW: Attila is completely unbalanced. The game is supposed to be based around counters, but horse archers and shock units are the meta of the game. Charge bonuses wipe out units with only a few charges and horse archers can reduce most units to nothing. The meta is an insane competition between shock armies and horse archers. This however is undermined by the [i]Slavic Nations Culture Pack[/i] and its addition of poison arrows. Poison arrows have largely broken the fun meta by countering everything with a play-style that encourages camping. Poison arrows are not an issue in the single-player due to their obscure position on the map and proximity to the Huns. However, the meta of shock units and horse archery will dictate how you make your armies.

This game is ugly but that is not too much of an issue. The theme of the game's art style is degeneration and the ugly textures support this style. This theme of degeneration permeates the whole game and creates a strangely immersive experience. The ugliness of this game could be an issue for some people. 

TW: Attila is a poorly optimized game. Despite looking ugly, the game lags and crashes even on a system with decent specs. 

The most difficult challenge in Total War is featured in TW: Attila. The Western Roman Empire campaign can be cheated and cheesed, but nothing compares to defending the empire the way it was intended by the developers. Pretty much every faction in this game is challenging because every faction is threatened by roving hoards without settlements that like to raze cities to the ground. Climate change, sanitation and religion are not easy to deal with and cause economic troubles and chaos. Attila the Hun himself will spawn infinite armies until he is killed three times in battle. Very few Total War games are this challenging. 

TW: Atilla is a broken game but it's the right kind of broken.

I love total war and have played almost every game they have made. I loved this one too even with the challenging balances they made to city management. However, once I came across the Huns and actually had to fight them it ruined the game for me because the AI cheats as they don't have to pay any upkeep and can spawn infinite stacks. It ruined the immersion completely, made the game unplayable, and no longer fun to play. However I installed a mod to help with the cheating Huns and the game is way better. Perhaps with some additional experience I will remove Hun nerf and see how I fair.

If your looking at this to be a copy of Rome 2 Total War, stop right there, because its not. Its based on a different time period leading into the medieval ages and its got a whole different global setup. That being the climate shift which changed the soil a bit, and also the introduction of christianity to the world, where before it was pure paganism.

The city defenses are a lot different in this one because a lot of the settlements appear to share a similar layout, and that layout has a clear benefit to the defender, which is not a bad thing seeing as most places were built with defense in mind.

I do suggest playing with a few mods though, since if you play Rome it can be really brutal trying to survive the hoards of everyone throwing themselves at you mixed with soil that turns into wasteland irregardless of your irrigation and farming technology the Romans spent hundreds of years developing. So having a mod that adds buildings that increase fertility makes sense.

Troops wise, the Romans seem to have the advantage in terms of heaviness, however one thing you will notice is that regardless of your clear advantage, the game will say its even or your losing, when your really winning, maybe its a glitch in the game.

Overall, its a good total war game, but don't go in expecting it to mirror other total wars, its a different game in and of its self.

This is, without a doubt, the best [u]historical[/u] TW game I've ever played. Now before you start screaming "heresy" allow me to explain why:
Attila is a darker version of Rome 2, most of the mechanics are fairly similar between the two but with Attila instead of being a Rome conquest game its much more about the decline of Rome and that can be seen in the game: Settlement razing - You can raze enemy settlements or you can even choose to raze your own settlements in order to launch a scorched earth campaign against the enemies at the gates.
The combat feels really great, cavalry charges and flanks are devastating, infantry combat from the front is slow. There's no more magic satellite link-up guided arrows from Shogun 2. Ranged units just feel much better than Rome 2. The fatigue system is neat in that you can cycle units in and out of combat to rapidly return to fresh.
The long term fertility situation, sanitation vs public order vs food, politics, offices and other systems are involved and feel really fun to manage once you understand them.
There is also the horde mechanic which can make things interesting. The Huns are a purely horde faction who have limited economic prospects beyond sacking and/or razing enemy settlements or maintaining a large number of vassal barbarian tribes. The Barbarians can also choose to pull up stakes, abandon their provinces and migrate elsewhere to avoid the Huns and perhaps better attack the Romans who can be sitting ducks.
by the way, the 5th Century doesn't interest you? Try the Age of Charlemagne DLC or the 1212AD Mod. You don't like historical TW and for whatever reason you don't want to play TW Warhammer? this game even has Lord of the Rings mod lmao.
HOWEVER, why people are so negative about Attila you ask? Because it forced players out of their comfort zone, they don't like the lack of food penalties, the diseases and climate change mechanic, Attila (compare to other TW) is a survival game not an empire building game. If other Total War games are ''haha map painting go brrrr'' this game is "live to fight another [i]turn[/i]". (it can still be modded to your liking tho).

Overall, its a decent game. If you can get it on sale It's worth it.

A refreshing take on Total War games. Unlike the other Total War games where you have to expand, Attila puts you in a situation where you have to survive.

Mid-late game situation is also different where every factions don't just declare war at you, but instead you have to faced the army of Attila, a different mid-late event than the past Total War series.

Faction is also more diverse than the older series, one thing different is the migrating factions which are not required to own specific towns or cities.

Unfortunately, CA kinda never prioritized optimizing it or updating its mechanics.

Recommended if you want something different and a unique experience in the historical series of Total War.

This is a review of a naive fan of Total War; who has not been able to discern the corruptable forces of CA, until now.

If you are looking for a game of graphics, thank you Total War, this game will suit that. Rome II or Shogun II accomplish the same, and I find to be definitely better; gameplay-wise. However, there are some underlying factors that should steer you away from this game:

1. DLC is King! "No seriously.... Just give them your money. Its fine, all of our DLC's worth it!" (Says every CA spokesperson, who doesn't need to pay for it).

2. Random bugs. This is minor in theory, however when you start noticing the same bugs.... It doesn't feel minor... This is an another gripe against CA as I seem to find these bugs in their last 2 titles apart from Attila, and no Facks were given on any day to fix them... Look forward to Warhammer!

3. Pricing of this title. I would not recommend it, again, you can achieve feel and looks in past games, especially since they cost less than this.

4. DLC is beautiful, again! "I mean come on, we can release this shit like clockwork, and they'll [consumers] never know! Pre-release DLC and DLC just weeks after the game is released? With no differences amongst these packs? Fuck yeah! Additionally, we'll throw in little details like blood and vomit... That will make panties fall! People [consumers again] WILL LOVE THIS." Impersonated CA workers conversing at final release development. -- Understand that pre-release DLC is already made game content prior to release, which means that it was made with the base game, they only separated the two to make more money.

5. AI are about the same as past Total War games. Attila's AI... May be more dumb than the wiseguy at CA who thought DLC was a good idea. AI is not too difficult to beat, however you need to do it in certain ways, which eliminates certain play styles (unless you mod).

6. This is a conclusive observation. Although the graphics are amazing, and the ideas behind this game are interesting; this game is a reskin of Rome II at its finest. The multitude of redundant factions shows carelessness on the developers behalf. DLC prior to first day is something I have always been against (which is why I DID NOT pre-order this game (not that naive)), and should steer clear from unless certain criteria is met. That criteria is price; this is too much outright, so buy everything on sale if you are hellbent on being interested in this game.

Overall, I will still play this game, as I like the graphics and the time period that this game is set in. However, will I support anything else from CA and Total War? That will have reside on the outcome of what happens with upcoming games, such as Warhammer (which is not looking good from what I have seen).

Price point is a bit high, however for sure worth it if on sale, although I bought it at full price 6 months ago, and didn't really touch it a whole lot, was quite shocked by the initial difficulty when playing Western or Eastern Rome, and shelved until I had more time to invest in it, was never sure if it was worth the money. 

However having finally come back to it, and to play West Rome proper, I must say it's the best one to do date, and although I would suggest getting it on sale, I had no regrets getting it at full price, I would say it is even better than Three Kingdoms, and Warhammer 2, the latter game I have been playing a lot and really enjoying too. What makes it better is the combat in this game feels really really good, I would say even better than Shogun 2. 

You can have battles where you may only have a 10% chance of winning and tactics actually favour the victor, as opposed to other games in the series where even if you are smart morale debuffs are way too effective, in this game they are their but feel fair, fitting of a game where you are instantly put on the back pedal having to defend your land from a number of factions (if playing as Rome). Makes unlikely defences really fun to play, as opposed to just auto resolving and giving up, all be it that still happens once and a while either due to personal negligence of looking after land or just not caring about every single province.

Besides the combat, the feeling and setting is really unique, and for sure feels different, if not scary and lonely at times, but in a good way really keeps you feeling like each turn is another step in your factions survival during a period of change, eradication, and chaos. 

I can see myself playing this for quite a while, and doing coop with mates, for sure fun, and a nice continuation of Rome 2.

I'm a role playing type of guy with this game.  Pick your role - make the roman empire great again?  Follow history with building a new kingdom on the ruins of Rome?  Entirely up to you.  The mechanics of the game are not difficult to pick up on.  As you play more and more you can grasp a lot of more subtle mechanics, to become even better at building your kingdom.  However, you don't need to understand those to really get started.  
As far as total war games go, this is a great example of the classic turn based campaign with real time battles.  Strategists should pick this bad boy up.

My favorite modern Total War. Completely different compared to other titles and great atmosphere. It still pales in comparison to Medieval 2 and Rome 2, and I think the politics tree is a stupid gimmick with bad UI and just feels grating to use. (I have played this game long enough to just want to punch it every time I have to interact with it.)

Units are balanced well, there's overlap here and there but I honestly like it, since I hate the syndrome of having to memorize [insert local cultural name for spear militia] and then compare the stats to my units, it's somewhat straightforward. The only problem in my opinion is...

Well, the siege battles. They're amazing, the best in the franchise, but oh my God. You will fight on the same map 590 times, you will memorize the best way to deal with ANYONE, from MP to SP, and you will dominate, my favorite lategame strategy for defense being crossbow+barricade, which is just a fancy way to delete infantry units.

Cataphracts are awesome, and awe-inspiring. I don't care if they technically aren't "meta" compared to Tagmata, but roaming the Sassanid Empire and pulling an Operation: Desert Storm with two stacks of heavy cav is just damned sexy. Eastern Rome has probably the best unit roster just for aesthetic mods alone.

My only complaint is that while great, the game is poorly optimized and the Blood DLC... That's always a problem.

Attila has the most difficult (in terms of campaign challenges) Total War, campaign to date. The initial goal (especially as the Western Roman Empire) is just to survive, and keeping a larger area is practically impossible in the early game. Attila introduces for the first time, the razing of (realistic-looking) settlements after they have been conquered. The mid Game invasion of the Huns is an excellent challenge especially for the western Roman Empire who is beset by Rebellion and invasions on all sides only to get swamped by the Horse Hordes from the East when your defenses are already approaching the Breaking point. I give it a 10/10 would defend the gates of Rome again. As a side note, Slav DLC is best DLC

After playing the other total war games i can only say that this one is worse in every way. The mechanics, even the way a game can be one then some troops are rallied and they somehow beat your force 2, to 3 times larger. It makes no sense and it makes it so tedious to not be able to use the fast forward function with confidence. If your men are not all grouped together they waiver. So it eliminates a lot of the strategy. Not sure what the developers were thinking. The interface isnt easy to navigate. I wont be playing it again. Too frustrating.

So, what can I say about this game? In general, it's pretty interesting. The battles scales are actually impressive. It's guite amusing to develop your tribe, capture new lands, and so on. The politiccal system has both pros and cons. 

First of all, what the hell? If you have almost demolished an enemy state, its rulers in theory should give you their best to save the state. But enemies either offer pathetic 300 coins or refuse any your offers. 

Nevertheless, the system is actually good. You have a lot of options. You can conclude a non-aggression pact, make a defensive alliance, make an alliance, give money to other tribes, demand money from them and so on. And each your decision is very important. So, if you made a lot of unnecessary alliences, you will paid for this. You will have to fight with other tribes because of your ally. And the ally itself may not to fight, because it has unleashed a war with a tribe, which is situated too far. Why do allies do this? Nobody knows. But it has a bad effect on your economy and public order. So you should think before make an alliance. 

Secondly, the economic system. It's very strange. A region may have either surplus food or lack.. If a region has a lack, it's bad because people starve and it has a bad effect on the public order (by the way, an important thing). But when the state as a whole has an excess food, a region may have a lack. Really. For example, you have three regions. Two of them have an excess food, but the last one a lack. And extra food cannot be sent to this region because... because what? Nobody knows. So, each region supplies itself.

What about other aspects of economics? I like them. Have you found a source of resources? It's good. You can trade the resources you found. Moreover, the resources allow you to build some buildings. If a trade route is under attack, your tranding income falls. 

To sum up, this is a casual game. It might seem that the game quite difficult but actually when you play a bit, you will get used.

7 out of 10

Total War: Attila 

This game follows historically with Total War: Rome 2. We progress a few hundred years and see the fall of the roman empire after it has split between east and west. The game changes a lot for the series and many of the mechanics from this game have found their way into the Warhammer games.

As usual for creative assembly, a lot of the game is delivered piece-meal through DLC. Many factions are locked into DLC culture packs you have to purchase if you want to play anything beyond the bigger empires.

One of the best changes is the creation of Hoards or free-roaming armies that are not anchored to any city. The mongols are the best example. They can never settle in a city and must always stay nomadic. Then you have the Barbarians Hoards that are fleeing the mongols. These are the Ostro/Visigoths who invade and settle the collapsing roman territory. They are all about getting strong, then taking land. 

The units are interesting, but there is not a whole lot of difference in units between cultures. They tend to play more like re-skins and are class based, but there is way more variety than Shogun 2.

I think this is one of there best historical themed games, but it tends to be ignored in favor of Rome 2.

It pains me horribly to have hit not recommend for writing this review but I didn't have a choice 


I love this game, it was truly the last genuine historical total war. The game is fun and beautiful. It has one of the most groundbreaking and popular total war mods ever made for it. It's historically accurate and the graphics are still beautiful even by today's standards. However the reason I had to click not recommend is something I can't fault this innocent amazing game for. CA completely abandoned it. It is truly a shame, because this was their last great historical game before jumping the shark, but instead of continuing to work with what is arguably one of their masterworks, they dived headfirst into the pool of greed and left this on the diving board. If CA had continued to work with this, who knows what we could have gotten, instead they killed it and went on to make games solely for the purpose of making money for themselves instead of giving the fans what they want and deserve. It makes me really sad what happened to the creative assembly. This game is beautiful and is still worth playing but it's a testament to how horribly derailed CA has become and angered the fanbase by abandoning this poor amazing game.

I don't recommend it, even though I've only played it twice as the Western Roman Empire campaigns. Several reasons why I don't recommend it are.....
1. It isn't optimized well and the custom settings are somewhat confusingly named, which made it difficult for me to adjust them.

2. It makes my laptop hot when it shouldn't, RTW2 ran just fine, but my fans were constantly blowing at full speed while playing this.

3. It feels like too much of a grind. I had to constantly fight manual battles in order to make the attacking hordes take more casualties than they would have if I had simply auto-resolved. Doing that multiple times for the first 50 turns or so became annoying and felt like a chore.


4. It felt kind of pointless. I managed to kill Attila and received no cinematic or message, he was just dead. I destroyed the remaining hordes and simply got the message that the Huns had been destroyed, the same message that I got when the other factions got destroyed. 
It didn't seem worth it in the end. After I restored public order, rebuilt cities, got food and sanitation up in all provinces, secured the borders, destroyed enemies...It just seemed like it went from frustrating and grind-like to pointless to continue playing, all while my laptop was hot with fans blowing. 

Updating review: I've been playing it a bit more and have found the game somewhat more enjoyable, but I do not know how much longer this enjoyment will last. I noticed that if I put everything on performance or even max performance, the game runs a lot better. I guess performance is like saying "low settings." There were some other things that I unchecked like shadows that also made the game run smoother. 
All that being said, I assume the game has little replay value since the Huns are always going to be the main enemy, but I'm not sure how the DLC for Attila is yet.

As a fan of the TW series, Attila has by far proven to be one of my favorites. 
The campaign isn't quite regular strategy as it is 'survival horror'. People coming in from one of the other games be warned, thanks to the sanitation mechanics, climate change, and the Huns, it's the hardest in the series, so don't try something like the Western Roman Empire right off the bat.
The art style is great, the game nailed the grim atmosphere of the 4th and 5th centuries, and every campaign feels unique in its own way, starting position and good unit rosters helps a lot with that.
My favorites so far have been Eastern Roman Empire, Himyar and Sassanids, all of which I would recommend, but the Franks I would recommend for a beginner.

One of the best, if not the best, Total War out there. Amazing campaign map, awesome graphics, exciting and fresh time period, and great, deep game mechanics. Governors for provinces, fertility for regions, trade, royal marriages, two great empires versus the world of tribes, barbarians and eastern kingdoms... it's all here. Sadly, the game is super unoptimized, so badly that the latest games, sporting better graphics, run so much better. It's a shame. I wish CA would come back to fix this, because it truly is a gem, and gameplay wise, maybe their finest work yet, with a fantastic modding community allowing you to play Romans in the Second Punic War as well as kingdoms during the Middle Ages. A true diamond in the rough.

Recommended with a number of caveats. 

I'm a longstanding total war fan and started playing Attila just recently because I found myself captivated with the Late Roman Imperial period. It's a time of turmoil and tragedy for the Romans. A dying of the light, as darkness comes from both within and without. Fighting back against the darkness and halting the Roman collapse is what interested me here, and if you share that interest then this game may be for you.

As for the actual mechanics and content, it is very much Rome II with some interesting additions and some further polish. Compared to other total war games, the quality and variety of the battles is enjoyable. The siege battles are very interesting and cool, and it's certainly also nice to be able to play naval battles and have them connect to land battles. The characters system is also quite well fleshed out, and there are plenty of ways to get attached to your favorite characters with all their positive and negative traits.

The main issues I have with the game come in two categories. Firstly the AI issues and secondly the "Modern Total War" issues.

AI problems are easy to describe, basically this refers to the strange and stupid ways in which the AI will behave. In field battles this is less pronounced as the AI generally employs quite competent and aggressive tactics. The AI generally also defends settlements very well, but as an attacker it generally performs very poorly, getting its generals killed and armies routed. The campaign map AI is the worst failure in this category. In diplomacy and army movement it seems more interested in infuriating and annoying the player faction rather than building its own power, such as when factions refuse to trade or surprise attack you to sack one settlement only to then be crushed by your much more powerful armies. The only way to play is to treat every faction as a potential enemy and never leave a frontier unguarded. All of the AI's nonsensical campaign plays are facilitated by the bonuses that the AI gets to its finances and empire maintenance. It feels incredibly frustrating to be the victim of unfair AI strategies that would get the player killed if they attempted them.

Lastly we have a bunch of issues that irritate me as a fan of total war classics like medieval 2. In no particular order, these are: Building slot restrictions, army stack limits, shared province wide resources and public order, the politics system, the recruitment system and the technology tree. Some of these mechanics impose artificial and annoying restrictions, while others attempt to add depth to the campaign while only making it more tedious and time sink like. In my mind the game suffers from these issues to a degree, but thankfully not enough to prevent me from enjoying it.

So if you like the time period and are able to overlook the issues, enjoy this fun and expansive Late Imperial Roman sandbox.

I honestly think this would be one of the best Total War games out there if CA hadn't botched the game's optimization. The vanilla campaign can be very challenging. Mechanics like governorship and a more in-depth internal policy makes this more immersive than Rome 2, if you ask me. Siege battles are great, especially due to the well made custom/specific settlements (Yes, you can defend/siege the Theodosian walls of Constantinople). 

Overall, if you exclude the optimisation issue and the time setting, this is what Rome 2 should have been. It's a shame that CA didn't give this game the same post-launch attention it gave Rome 2, especially in terms of optimization.  

Lastly, the mod support is great! Two especially good mods are Medieval Kingdoms 1212 and Ancient Empires, which are set in the medieval period and the 2nd Punic War, respectively. 

The game has its flaws, like the previously mentioned bad optimization. Additionally, there are some strange design choices in terms of modability, like hardcoded music and non-modifiable settlement location. However, I would still recommend this game if you are a total war fan (especially if you prefer the historical titles).

One of my favorite games in the Total War franchise thus far, and a huge improvement on its predecessor, Total War Rome II. Attila takes essentially the same engine and incorporates a new set of mechanics and flavor that perfectly suit the transition from early to late antiquity. The doomsday vibe of the game's sparse narrative helps to ground its sandbox in the psychological space of its setting: the end of the Roman world and the beginning of a new era. This game is essentially a spiritual sequel to Total War Rome: Barbarian Invasion, with the migratory tribes and the Huns stealing the show in both aesthetics and mechanics.

If you played the Nomadic Tribes DLC for Rome II, you might have been disappointed at the lack of "Barbarian Invasion" style nomad mechanics, leaving them with the same city-based gameplay as sedentary civilizations. Attila makes up for this in droves, with a massively expanded nomad migration system that's tremendously fun to play compared to settled states. This is why the Great Migrators (think Goths, Franks, Alans, and Vandals) are at the center of the game, with the formidable Huns driving them westward into the ill-defended Roman territory. All these factions have no cities at the start, but instead carry their cities with them as mobile army encampments that can be packed up and moved on the fly (with construction pausing while the army is on the move and resuming when they encamp). Unlike the Huns, though, the migrators are not locked into staying nomadic: their goal is to raid their way into settled territory until they find a good place to settle down and create their own kingdom. This gives an otherwise sandboxy game a firm sense of goal and direction, whether you want to recreate the historical path of your tribe's rise to power, or change history and make them outlast their real-life counterparts.

The player who wants to face a near-impossible challenge also has the option of playing as the Western Roman Empire and trying to prevent its fall, but as they have a massive amount of territory to defend, they will have to pick and choose what parts of the empire are most important to hold onto. Eastern Rome (aka the Byzantines) is a more realistic challenge for players who aren't quite so masochistic, as for them one merely has to recreate their historical survival, though against they won't be likely to come out with their empire intact.

As for the tactical battles, Attila rebalanced the system of Total War Rome II to better fit the time period and make for more dynamic gameplay. Unit morale is much more of a factor, as all but the best trained units will rout under sufficient pressure from the enemy (or if you accidentally throw them into friendly fire), though they may also regroup and return to the battle if their casualties aren't too severe. There are more dramatic differences between factions as well, so for example migrating nomads cannot capture buildings, only destroy them. Overall, the battles in Attila feel more fluid than previous titles, and it's much more possible to snatch victory from the jaws of defeat, or vice versa...

Both battle and campaign maps are rendered in gorgeous detail even on medium settings. As the fifth century goes on, the map will actually change over time. The onset of climate change, which rendered the northern regions inhospitable during this time period, is reflected in the reduction of regional fertility and increasingly barren land. Speaking of which, the land is also likely to suffer from invaders razing settlements, which not only wipes them off the map but also burns and desolates the entire region with a glorious animation sequence that leaves the trees burned and the territory uninhabited.

Major political features have fleshed out the campaign as well. You can now assign governorships to your leaders (a feature appallingly absent from Rome II's unwieldy and unfinished politics system), and you can distribute other offices to worthy characters in your employ, so long as keep an eye on their loyalty to make sure they don't become too ambitious for their own good. Religion is also a part of the game's mechanics for the first time as well, replacing the culture spread from Rome II, and dynamically changing over time as you construct religious buildings and proclaim edicts. This opens up the possibility for the player to create their own goal of spreading their faction's religion across the entire map, or perhaps preserving a historically embattled religion from this period, like Arianism or one of several Pagan faiths. Tying into this, faction and unit voice callouts will often reference their faction's religion, which adds to the flavor of an era in which religious motivations played a large role in military morale.

There's definitely a lot more I want to explore in this game, but already it stands out to me as one of the most interesting titles in this series to date, and one that has aged relatively well compared to its predecessor. It's a shame there's only two DLC campaigns, compared to the massive number of interesting scenarios available for Rome II, but there are some excellent total conversion mods available on the Steam Workshop that help scratch that itch for more historical content. I would argue that Attila is the gold standard of comparison for future TW titles and fans of the series should definitely consider picking it up.

[b]Flawed masterpiece still worth playing for its innovative & challenging campaign mechanics[/b]

First, the elephant in the room: ‘Attila’ is poorly optimized, to the extent that it runs worse than its predecessor Rome 2 (or at least, worse than Rome 2 in its current, final, ‘Emperor Edition’ state).

We’re talking half the frame rate of R2 with equivalent graphics settings - and the Attila engine is evidently unable to take advantage of the brute power of modern graphics cards to get itself out of trouble - so don’t think that this warning doesn’t apply to you just because you have a modern GPU. 

At best, your Nvidia 2060 will allow you to add 8x AA and x16AF, SSAO, DoF and maybe distortion effects (i.e. aspects of rendering internal to the GPU) while the game waits for your CPU to compute shadows, unit detail, trees, grass, terrain i.e. whatever game assets are hardcoded to be handled by the processor only.

Having said that, ‘poorly optimized’ does not mean ‘broken’: the game is stable to the extent that I can’t recall any crashes. So it’s a question of what you as a player are prepared to put up with: this is a game that struggles to run its own internal benchmark - a short scenario featuring less than twenty units - satisfactorily on maximum settings; so it’s really no wonder that siege battles featuring four full stacks degenerate into slide-shows. 

As a result, I have found myself autoresolving multi-army siege battles that I would otherwise have enjoyed - a sad thing to say about a game in which epic confrontations should be the highpoints of a playthrough, not an ordeal to be sidestepped.

Ok, on to the game itself:

Attila was the first recent TW game to reintroduce the horde mechanic, whereby some factions don’t have any settlements but instead camp wherever the hell they like, a mechanic which increases scope for creative playstyles. Moreover it adds a new dimension even if you don’t play as a horde yourself, since dealing with hordes is a new challenge for settled factions too; and if you lose your last settlement, you may find yourself playing as a horde after all!

The new ability to 'raze' (obliterate) captured settlements also adds creativity, since the player (and the AI too) now has the option to delete entire cities from the map rather than overextend their empire by capturing them, or risk having to return at some point after merely 'sacking' them - now there is a more permanent solution available. 

This can be used to create buffer zones of inhospitable wasteland around your core provinces; or (Attila allows you to abandon i.e. raze your OWN settlements) in desperate circumstances you can employ a 'scorched earth' policy to deny an advancing enemy the benefit of the region they are about to capture.

The option to 'recolonise' abandoned/razed settlements, though costly in men and gold, provides a means for players with the necessary funds to snap up some of the devastated real estate left in the Huns' wake (providing, that is, you are confident they are really gone...).

And if you are playing as a horde and you capture a prosperous, fertile or easily-defensible settlement, you have the dilemma of whether it might not be a good moment to settle after all.

Food is now on a per-province basis so no subsidising your hungrier provinces from more productive ones.

Climate change may sound like it’s been shoe-horned in by politically correct developers but is actually a really solid game mechanic since it adds incentive for factions to migrate south to more fertile lands (as well as west, to escape the Huns).

The Huns represent a fascinating dilemma for the player: do you evade or confront them? Indeed the mid-game can feel more like survival horror than strategy if you find yourself isolated against multiple hordes: there's no doomstack like a Hun doomstack...

A raiding horde also 'steals' food from the host province, thus decreasing public order and preventing resident units from replenishing so 'hoping they just go away' is not a foolproof response.

Army integrity feels like it should always have been a feature of Total War games, particularly when combined with attrition when marching in snowy or desert regions (a mechanic missing from, say, Rome 2).

Army traditions were already in R2 but are even more valuable now, because you can spec your army to be, say, resistant to snow attrition.

Customizing your generals/governors (and indeed spies etc) is an interesting challenge but gets a bit tiresome late on when you have numerous agents and armies.

The politics system manages not to be obnoxious for once, not least because here, civil war is not ‘scripted’ (i.e. inevitable at some point). However the key mechanic (of striving for a balance between authoritarianism and lack of control) is somewhat counter-intuitive so perusing a community guide or two is highly recommended. 

I also like the crucial role that female characters play here behind the scenes, rather than appearing on the battlefield as they did in Rome 2. The versatility of influential noblewomen as 'fixers' (providing everything from loyalty boosts for wavering generals to outright assassinations) means that careful attention to the diplomatic marriage market can be even more valuable here than in other TW games. 

Diplomacy seems to work better than average, with factions for the most part seeming to act in their plausible self-interest.

Steam achievements are well integrated and comprehensive although the absence of specific recognition for completing a campaign on 'hard' or 'very hard' feels like a slight to non-legendary players.

The usual several victory conditions strike a good balance between challenge and fairness (at least, in my experience) and I particularly appreciate the absence of arbitrary time limits. Rewards for simply surviving until certain dates feel earned and the optional goals for each 'chapter' provide some ideas about what direction you might want to take with your faction whilst representing no great loss if you choose to ignore them and go your own way.

The tech tree is set out more logically than in R2 and allows the player to 'customize' their faction in a variety of directions e.g. do you go for elite spearmen before swordsmen? Or is sanitation (or eking a bit more food out of the increasingly barren soil) the better priority? Conceivably you could experience two very different playthroughs with the same faction as a result.

Faction variety is excellent, to the extent that playthroughs with, say, the Sassanids, the seafaring Danes or the snow-resistant Slavs provide very different challenges.

Unit variety is also very good and provides a particular incentive to recruiting exotic mercenaries when marching far from home. 

Attila also offers for purchase some of the best DLC expansions in the Total War series, namely 'Age of Charlemagne' and 'The Last Roman'.

Minor annoyances:

Why can’t I look at the initial post-battle screen for as long as I want? 

Why can’t I target an enemy siege tower directly, rather than only being allowed to fire at the enemy unit that is pushing it? Are siege towers protected by some Geneva Convention I don’t know about??

The sheer awkwardness of placing units on certain types of terrain (typically, ‘farmland’-style landscapes, frequently encountered around settlements) suggests that the CA ‘terrain-scaping’ team never actually played any battles themselves.

End turn times are long compared to later games e.g. TWWH. Here, you literally have time to go make a cup of tea.

[b]TLDR:[/b]

DON’T BUY IT if you are just looking for a graphically-improved Rome 2 that will run as smoothly as Rome 2 does these days;
DON’T BUY IT if you would actually prefer to play Total War Warhammer, Thrones of Britannia or Three Kingdoms but assume that an OLDER title will run better on your pc (it won’t);

DO BUY IT if interesting campaign mechanics are more important to you than game engine optimization.

DO NOT GET THIS GAME IF YOU WANT MULTIPLAYER GAMEPLAY.

I think Total War: Attila is a good game, it's by no means my favorite but a good game. I prefer over Rome II for it's time period, I've always liked it more. The default factions are great in this game. I also love the ability to burns down entire cities. I also love campaign co-op, I think they should expand upon it in future Total War games and even allow more players, also make it where you can be allies or if you want wage war, not forcing one or the other.

Now for the problems...

I love the factions, but Sega got scummy with selling so many factions in little DLC packs. They're already in the game, you're just paying for the ability to play them.

Sometimes I feel like the lighting looks a little off in the game, maybe that's just me, I don't know.

Unlike Rome II, changing the main city center culture is overly expensive for no reason. In fact I never liked the changing building culture system at all. It makes no sense. They're just dumb founded on expanding buildings because they look different? Very dumb.

Population get's angry way too easily, no matter how much you suck them off sometimes. This would be less of an issue if you could take soldiers away from generals, which leads me to my last issue with this one and all the recent games...

The general system is awful, only being allowed to have so many generals until upgrades, not being able to split your men from their general, all makes no sense and is a bad system. They should go back to Medieval II/Empire.

There is no ability to gift cities, which makes co-op a nightmare.

Overall it's a good game though, maybe I'm just a little bit of an old fashion Total War fan.

It is worth to buy this game for mods only. Modders and the fanbase are the only thing that encouraged me to buy it. Becouse only modded version is somewhat enjoyable for me. Im a Total War veteran. I enjoyed the most first Rome, Medieval 2 and Shogun 2. I also played first Medieval and Napoleon, avoided Empire and Rome 2 becouse of terrible AI and annoying mechanics. I thought that Attila will be better, and I was disappointed.

When I first bought the game I thought I will be enjoying a huge, interesting and difficult campaign. That I will be carefully planning my moves and military campaigns thanks to various and detailed maps, that I will be fighting in exciting and huge battles, protect cities, street after street, falling back to inner walls and barricades, that I will burn the cities and raze them to the ground, that I will enjoy great graphics, and overall gameplay. Oh boy, was I wrong.

In the campaign, I didnt have to plan anything. There was no military campaign that seemed hard and challenging enough to waste time on checking the maps and planning moves. The AI will not protect its territories and will do just random, sensless things. Did you want to have a nice historical experience of the campaign? Then you will not find it here, becouse, starting before 400AD, Rome will not hold for next 20 turns and will fall like a century before it historically did, it starts as theoretically biggest military power but thanks to incapable AI, Roman armies are always nowhere to be seen. You will see tribes wich in history did not do much to do a lot, and those that mattered in history to not matter at all in this game. Playing as Saxons I expected nice fights in British scenery with the Celtic tribes but little of that occured. The Celts were bothered with conquering Galia and Hispania, leaving their British territories defenceless, and the Scandinavians, who should also target Britain, did the same thing as the Celts. And this happens always, all the time.  Mainland barbarian tribes are doing nothing.  They do not care about their historical targets and territories they should want. If most of Roman territory is conquered, barbarians will not fight each other for it. When Galia was conquered by the Ebdani and Jutes, Franks, who still had one province, instead of fighting other barbarians for the nearest territory, seemed it fit to just try to invade Roman territories in Spain. Leaving their homeland defenceless, of course. I just steamrolled everything and everyone, even on hardest difficulties, and my skills had nothing to it. You will need no skills. You will just autoresolve most of the battles becouse situations when the chances are equal will be very rare - the AI will not bother to have any strategic advantage over you. And when that rare opportunity to have a big battle occurs there will be yet another disappointment. You will not enjoy any good graphics becouse optimization in this game is a joke. The game is just a slideshow without specific mods improving this matter. And after you get rid of terrbile optimization you will be disappointed once more. The AI will not bother with commanding units in a smoewhat organised and intelligent way. There will be no battle in which the AI will be a threat to you. There will be no interesting sieges too - the AI will just throw all of its units into a single alley and you will easily surround them and cut them down. And the public order system is as annoying as useless. It is almost impossible to keep your people happy, but after some time I realised that there was no point in it. The rebels that spawn when your people are angry have only some units on the first turn and are theoretically supposed to get more over time, but it never happens. The rebel AI, instead of gathering forces, attacks nearest settlement on the first turn, and gets smashed by the garrison.

In overall: The AI is terrible. On the maps I cannot look anymore becouse of bordergore. Battles are easy and disappointing.  Diplomacy is senseless and disappointing. Campaigns are easy, boring, and disappointing. The game is not worth its price. But the modders community is. If you want to play the mods - then buy this game.
