TL;DR version - my reccomendation as a empire building turn-based/RTS fan and Total War series fan. + 2x IF's below.

If you have not played a Total War series game before, consider this title suited for more experienced Total War series fans or those that enjoy more challenge. This review will be aimed to give an idea to those that played at least one Total War title before.
If you played Total War series before and you liked the empire building aspect but felt that you could use more challnege - this one is fr you. Especially if you consider 2-3 mods (see below).

Diplomacy - decent, for a Total War series game, but it isn't as good as in Three Kingdoms(the only one I have not played) nor does it have as much options as Napoleon/Empire.

Battle AI - aparat from the joint land/naval battles, where it's pretty clueless, it's decent for Total War game. It managed to beat me few times whlie I was only slightly overpowered. Note I am not a big cheese fan.

Campaign AI - active, far more than in Rome 2, at times I would compare it to Warhammer 2 AI. It frequently punished me for not taking precautions. The two biggest drag's/con's is that a lot of regions become unpopulated quite quick, and they stay like that throught the game and the fact that most of the AI factions do not work to achieve their goals(become an empire), maybe except for the Huns - but I leave them for last.

Faction/government mangement - quite obscure to start with, but ok, when you get a hold of it. The amount of options is about right. All of those available are usable (unlike some of those in Rome 2). Although I find it quite easy to avoid civil wars, unlike in Rome 2. Keeping all your armies loyal is a bit more of a challenge. It presents you with options that in most cases are meaningful gamewise. (eg. provincional edicts based on your state religion)

Empire/province management - this is the area that it almost shines, if you like a challenge. Optimalization of your kigdom is very difficult. You need to think about happines, squalor/sanitation & food. There are contributing factors, like fertility, religion and to extent culture. This game punishes you if you build what you want, where you want yet it doesnot forbid you from doing it. You can assign governnors directly, which gives you direct bonuses to a particular province and unlocks edicts there (improvement over Rome 2 and Warhammer 2 - empire faction). You can even see a governor in the battle if the province capital would be assaulted.

Other points:
- hun invasion. So it's done in quite a harsh way, where even Attilla respawns once. It's wery annoying to deal with and seems very unclear on how to deal with it. It is reminiscent of Chaos invasion in Warhammer 1 & 2, but more annoying if you are in the wrong place on the map.
-Climate change is implemented (increases the challenge).
-Every year has 4 seasons, that impact the gameplay (eg. snow attrittion) and give you time to know your characters. This decreases the role of children though.
-I suggest considering the following mods(even before first playthrough): 
--Hun Invasion related, to tune it to a level that you would like (requires a bit of reading or possibly a youtube video).
--AI resettling related - so that the unpopulate areas (be it due to hun invasion or other actions) will be a t least partially populated by the AI over time
--Fertility related mod, that gives small buff to the region fertility through sanitation buildings. It does not really decrease the challenge but increases the player options(replan the economy or invest more in sanitation).
--Few bugs remain, so consider community patch/fix bundle.

Hope this will help some of you guys, considering if you should buy this.

The game itself has great locations and starting factions most if not all the factions feel unique! Hands down my favorite TW game. Its much more brutal, but actually poses a strong AI and forces you to think very critically of empire management. Should you let your guard down to save money on maintenance and build up your infrastructure? How is fertility going to impact you in 10 turns? Is it better to subjugate and build a coalition, or build up your own internal strength? All these questions with the impending doom of Atilla arriving makes for an amazing survivalist campaign.

Total war: Attila is easily the hardest of the total war games. You have to subvert your expectations of how you usually play a Total war game. Its much more about surviving than thriving. The horde mechanics change the game in many ways, and you have to be much more careful due to the roaming bands of nomadic tribes that you will undoubtedly encounter during the playtime. Playing as one of the horde factions makes for an interesting play through since you have to raid and pillage until you find a suitable place to settle. Its also unsettling since the game revolves around Attilla and his campaign of destruction, and subjugation. Once you see his warbands approach your borders you better hope you have prepared enough to fight him off but dont expect too not have some losses he usually approaches you with up to 4 - 5 warbands that can easily beat your best troops. Other than that the music is wonderful, and the expansion age of Charlemagne is a worthy investment, but it is alot easier than the base game. I recommend that you try this out if you enjoy total war games and have some experience however if your a newcomer I recommend that you start with Shogun 2 which is an excellent starting place for newcommers.

One helluva time!   Playing the brilliant Medieval 1212 mod now - what an amazing piece of work!  But want to give a shout out to another absolutely amazing mod.

Love playing as The Huns - in the Attila vs Flavius Aetius Mod.  Of my 2,000 hours - 1,500 have been in that mod by Papeion.  I've now won it as the Huns 5 times.  It makes playing them much, much harder and more interesting. 

It's played on the Charlemagne Map, and you only have one province in Pannonia - and because there is no horde mechanic you have to be careful in what you produce and where. 
 
It starts with an epic battle Catalunian Fields - 451 AD and you're whole army is what survives that.  And it has hard coded when Attila will die all too soon - and other battles you have to survive like a massive Gepid rebellion - after he dies.

My favorite parts are that you can't lose a single battle or you lose the 'myth of invincibility' and have much worse relations with all factions and that you have to convert every single town/city you decide to keep into a Hunnic settlement - at a large cost of money and time.  It makes you be very selective about where you actually stay. 

I've now beaten it on 'easy' 'normal' and 'hard' settings, and it's truly been a blast each time.  It also really taught me about the importance of religion in determining happiness - and how to play horse archers - as you end up having to personally play most of the closer battles due to fair, but not always advantegeous auto-resolve calculations.

But overall it is brilliantly detailed and balanced.  If you haven't tried it out - please do!
The selfless work of modders is what truly makes these games shine.

PS - My favorite game of the past years   duh, given my play hours :-)
       And second all time... only to Medieval Total War 1, with Wes Med Mod.
 
Gotta get back to it - I've got at least another several hundred to go :-)
But MTW 1 was closer to 10,000 hours - 
so I guess you could say I like the Total War Series 
honestly, it's been 90 percent of what I play for decades, so I'm probably 'slighty' biased :-)

I saw potential in this title but the lack of long term support has left this something of an unoptimised mess, which is a real shame because the period/setting is interesting and rarely touched upon.  It feels like this was the game where they tried out the new engine and then abandoned it to work on more popular titles like Rome 2 and Warhammer.  There's the framework of a good enough game in here though but you'll really need mods to unlock the potential.

As it stands it's something I couldn't recommend, perhaps with a heavy discount you'll find an enjoyable experience where I could not.

It's worth noting that CA went through a period of locking dissenting threads on Steam, marked negative reviews as "abusive", told their consumers not to buy their games and had a period of installing Red Shell spyware with their games without telling you.  Not the greatest PR.

Total War: Rome 3, or at least that's what is should be called.

Other factions are cool, for a while. 

Hordes and migrating factions have cool mechanics and start off super fun but get old after a bit. You don't empire build as a horde, you just raze settlements and extract resources from factions until they eventually turn on you and you have to burn them down anyway. Migratory factions play the same as a horde except they have to inevitably settle down, meaning every turn you stay migrating is another turn you'll lose out on empire building for the hell that comes mid-late game.

The other settled factions vary. The Sassanid Persians are very strong and very isolated, making them by far the easiest faction, but they have enough diversity to make them interesting until you get too powerful to have any reprecautions for your actions and lose interest. The Celts/Norse/Germanic factions are all basically the same, with very minor differences in unit rosters, buildings, technologies, and locations/allies/enemies. The tend to be absolutely screwed mid-late game as the harsher climate starves them to the point they either cant afford to feed their armies or pay for the higher tier units. The Slavs are doomed from the start.

 Some of the desert factions are cool though. The Garamantians can start carving up Rome from get-go while the empire is distracted elsewhere. Himyar is the most unique faction in the game, with a unique religion, diverse and powerful units, buildings, and starting location. The Tanukhids are basically a migratory faction like the Germanic ones, except they have eastern units, bonuses, different horde mechanics, and can pick better locations to settle. Lakhmids and Axum are "meh", but still more interesting than the europeans.

This all might sound a bit negative, but none of what I said above matters. The heart of this game is about the Fall of Rome. One of the most important events in the history of the world is at stake, and the game wants you to feel it. Rome is divided, there's the rich East which would later survive for over 1000 years and become the "Byzantine Empire", and then there's the imploding West, perhaps the single most influential state that has ever existed, and its fucked in every embarrassing way you could imagine.

This game is meant to be played as the Western Roman Empire, saving it from impending destruction and rising above every problem thrown at you. 
*Every germanic, celtic, nordic, african, gothic, and nomad faction around you declares war on you one after another
*The Huns are traveling across the world explicitly to burn your civilization to the ground while its weak
*Public order is gone, and 30 or so provinces are on the verge of revolting from the first few turns.
*Nothing is prosperous anymore save a few areas in Italy
*Some are starving and wont even be able to feed your troops
*Religious differences tear you apart
*You have a pathetically small army compared to your neighbors with much less quality
*Corruption is robbing you of your taxes
*Plague and disease will break out unless you dump tons of money into sanitation
*Your Emperor is the most pathetic leader around. 

Turning this around and painting the map with a prosperous and powerful Roman Eagle is literally the most rewarding gameplay experience I've had quite possibly ever. Kudos to CA for making a game so polarizingly difficult and stressful that it ACTUALLY gives it turbulent historical setting some real justice. This game is not easy, its not relaxing, but it can be incredibly rewarding and immersive, so it gets a big thumbs up.

I've played around 160 hours of Attila so far. I understand that's not much by some standards, but I still think it's about time for me to write a review of this game.

This review will be very long. For those of you who prefer shorter reviews, you might want to find a different one.

Total War: Rome 2, contrary to popular opinion, added some very good ideas to the series. For example, it introduced a set of factors which you had to balance within your settlements (food, income, and public order). This meant you had to manage your settlements to a greater degree, which had two main effects:

1. It meant you had to ensure your owned settlements are stable before having your armies leave them to conquer other lands.

2. It added a city management aspect to the game.

Rome 2 also fleshed out agents, giving them their own stats and more options when upgrading them. Rome 2 introduced army traditions, giving your armies more meaning and a greater sense of history.

Why am I bringing up Rome 2 in an Attila review? Because Attila took all those ideas, and refined them. See, Rome 2's ideas were very good, but were often awkwardly executed. Attila was a fresh chance to take the community's criticism and put it into action.

There are a few Total War games I have not played. Namely, the original Shogun and Medieval and the games from Warhammer on. But even still, I consider Total War: Attila to be one of the greatest Total War titles ever (yes, right up there with the original Rome: Total War and Shogun 2: Fall of the Samurai). There are several reasons for this:

1. As mentioned before, Attila took the good but poorly executed ideas of Rome 2 and enacted them as they should have been.

2. There are a wide diversity of cultures to play, each with their own advantages and disadvantages in terms of both soldiers and buildings.

3. Attila introduced the horde system, adding a completely new style of play.

4. Related to 2, the differences between factions are deeply meaningful, especially in terms of units. This is something that cannot be said, for example, about Shogun 2.

5. The game is fairly well-balanced, and the AI is a little better than most other Total War games.

That said, there are several weaknesses to this game:

1. While the AI is significantly better than in previous games, it still isn't the best. The Total War series is not known for its stellar AI.

2, While the game is pretty well-balanced, there are still some over-powered and under-powered units. Huscarls, for example, are pretty hard to counter, while elephants, while useful under the right circumstances, are a lot easier to counter than in previous games.

3. Related to 1, the AI seems to decide whether or not to make peace with you based on how much they dislike you. This means that if you raze even 1 city, they will practically never make peace with you, meaning you have to actually HUNT DOWN EVERY SINGLE SETTLEMENT AND ARMY THEY OWN in order to 'make peace' with them.

4. The Huns are very difficult to play. You should be able to play the faction the game is named after without a whole lot of difficulty.

5. Again related to 1, increasing the difficulty basically gives the AI a whole list of cheats. I understand that it is difficult to craft an AI without doing so, but let me illustrate with an example:

With about 6 settlements, you should be able to field 2 to 3 full armies. On hard, an AI faction with only one settlement will be able to raise just as many armies as you, often even more. This is because the AI gets huge discounts to unit upkeep as the difficulty increases. This makes starting out very hard, and factions difficult to fight at almost any level of development.

If you're ok with that, then that's fine, but I and I assume other players are not.

6, Also like its predecessor Rome 2 the game is split up into several DLCs. You can't play the Nordic factions, the desert factions, or the Slavic factions without paying $27 in DLCs. This is a bad practice that EA is unfortunately in the habit of. 

So should you get this game? Yes. I would wait for a sale, but it is more than worth it even at full price. This is, in my honest opinion, one of the greatest Total War games of all time. If you are a total beginner to the Total War series, I would consider buying the original Rome 1 instead, so that you can see if Total War interests you and so that you can start off with a simpler game in the series. But this game still can appeal to all Total War players of all skill levels and experiences.

The base game is not too bad if you have never played total war before, or if you are just looking for a couple of campaigns in a different setting. But as you play the game more, the more apparent problems become. Siege battles have like 3 maps for each culture and are super repetitive. Units are completely imbalanced. By researching technology you often lock yourself out of cheaper more useful units. The diplomacy doesnt work too well. The bordergore is horrendous.  The turn times are super long. The AI makes the most random decisions on when to take or sack provinces. I remember Eastern roman empire losing constantinople and never occupying it back, even though it was in the middle of its land. The aremies would just stand around it sacking it every other turn!

Now Age of Charlemagne Campaign DLC fixes many of these problems, and is generally very enjoyable to play as any faction. But this just makes the base game looks worse by comparison.

Have you ever had an itch to be constantly invaded by barbarians from the lands of eternal chaos, deal with unhappy military leadership, be in a constant state of economic struggle, be on figurative and literal fire, but also maybe RP as Aurelian and restore the world? Then the Western Roman Empire experience is for you.

I recommend this game as a real challenge for Total War fans, especially playing as either East or West Rome. It can be a real struggle sometimes, as due to constant immigration, every other faction hating you, a religion that handicaps you and a near Immortal Atilla. The chances of snowballing like in Rome II are slim. This game does have its problems, Atilla and his death stacks can be a real pain, but also the Roman civ tech tree, as it kills your ability to build useful concrete structures in favor of a big church and palace.

Overall really fun game i'd rate it Three Hunnic Death Stacks out of two German chaos invasions.

I love the Total War series. In fact, Napoleon and Empire are probably my favorite strategy games ever developed. And after 40 hours of Attila, I can definitively say that this is the worst game in the series. I think this is mainly due to the fact that they changed many of the games characteristics to fit more authentically within the time period. The problem with that is that during this time in history life was incredibly difficult and things took a long time to do.

Total War as a series is already strenuous concerning how long it takes to accomplish conquest. This game takes that concept and ramps it up tenfold. This may be what some Total War fans enjoy about the series but as for me it feels like I am moving along much to slow even while playing strategically correct. That is unless of course you play as a like the Huns, in which your not conquering land but rather raiding or just down right destroying it. And this is where the main flaw lies with Attila. The purpose of a strategy game, to myself, has always been to creatively think your way out of a problem. In this game you feel like you are being forced to play a certain way to make any progress at a reasonable rate. I mean what the hell! I wanna conquer land when I play these games! Is that too much to ask for?

There are other reasons why this game is flawed and I why I am giving this a down-vote, however that is the main one. Don't waste your money on this title. There are better Total War games out there. Not to mention they are cheaper.

Well, I was big fan of Total war strategies, but this remake of Rome 2 is... well... a game that makes you angry all the time:
-Diplomacy: You want to trade with somebody? Well, good luck. They might like you, they might have profit too, but they will not trade with you, because they just don't want... You missed random war declarations from Medieval 2? You are lucky, because it's back in Attila TW... You defeated you opponent, razed all his cities and left him just with one unit of general. No problem they will gladdly fight you for another 150 turns till you make them disappear.
-Strategy Map: All generals have same range of movement, so 90% of time you will be chasing enemy army, that will raid you cities in front of you and then run away withou chance of catching them... Then you realize that there are other 3 armies on other side of your realm.
-Battle: have you ever tried to shoot the bow? Great if yes your are better that all archers in Attila TW, If they don't miss, they hit your own with poision arrow. Just on f**** poison arrow and you own units starts to die. Those f***** arches killed more own people than enemy. 
-Music: After hour of listening of throat singing you'll turn music off before your head explodes. It's much worse than in Rome 2... 
-AI cheating: Yes, that is daily bread in TW games, but in Attila it's... well... Have you ever wonder how can a country with one city have 2 full armies when you, with 5 cities has only 1 and half?

A goddam* buggy mess, Total War Attila is yet another step in the wrong direction. It strips out the best elements of previous Total Wars like Napoleon - epic empire-building, fair balancing, fantastic music, slick GUI, and lengthy battles - and decides to replace them all with s#itty concepts. Yeah, the AI was bad, but guess what? It STILL is.

Why do I need a specific general to move my units? Why is Attila unstoppable unless you kill him 4 times? Why are there more bugs than even Shogun 2 had? Why are battles fast-paced and instantaneous like an arcade game? Why does it take so long to gain any traction on the campaign map, thereby boring the player to death? Why is there so much overpriced garbage DLC? And so on and so on...

Skip this junk, folks; there are far better Total Wars out there.

Almost 5 years have passed since its release, and I have been playing this game ever since. There are  few historical games available with as many details about the early middle ages as Attila Total War. As your adventure starts in 395 AD with the Western Roman Empire on the verge of collapse, you will have a chance to either make a final stand for the Western half of the Roman Empire or deal it a lethal blow as you side with one of the many barbarian nations. 

From the perspective of a passionate historian, I can only vouch for the tremendous amount of research that must have gone into developing this game. You will find a comprehensive section on units and buildings in the encyclopaedia, which you can consult at any time during the campaigns and battles. Educationally, this is a great opportunity for gamers to learn about the onset of the middle ages while having fun in the process. 

Gameplay-wise, this ninth instalment to the Total War franchise retains the turn-based features of its predecessors with the addition of a few extra perks, namely food and fertility levels. From a historical standpoint, introducing these two concepts makes perfect sense as one of the driving factors leading Germanic and Hunnic tribes southbound was the hope of finding fertile lands. What this means in terms of the game is substantial difference between factions and their mobility. Unlike Western and Eastern Romans, horde factions like the Ostrogoths or the Huns can turn themselves into a settlement as they please. Conversely, these barbarian factions can switch back to hordes when they don't control any settlements (save for the Huns who can't take or occupy any settlement). In this respect, the game is clearly biased towards the barbarian and horde factions as controlling them will allow you to scout out southern lands while raiding and pillaging and settling the areas with the highest wealth and fertility to build your own state. 

Fertility levels are connected to the amount of food you'll be getting in your provinces each turn. Accordingly, food is everything in this game and you will really need to watch out for food levels or else you will find yourself on the brink of bankruptcy in no time. However,  some factions, such as the two halves of the Roman Empire, are almost ever able to produce sufficient amounts of food without losing much at every turn. Running out of food will cause your armies to suffer attrition and will prevent them from replenishing in all provinces, causing also substantial decreases in public order levels. 

Another cook perk is settlement burning. Not only can you now burn your enemies' settlements to the ground, but you can level your own settlement if need arises. This is something you may want to do if you wish to oust your enemies from a province or deny them lands. When you do that, you will destroy all the buildings in the process, forcing your enemy to invest a great deal of time and money resettling the area later on. 

Finally, there are plenty of DLCs which will no doubt enhance your gaming experience significantly. Moreover, if you consider that the latest addition to Rome II Total War was released a mere two years ago and that Rome II Total War was released a year before Attila, you might just expect newer DLCs even in 2020 - though nothing has been confirmed as of yet. 

The only downside to this game I can think of is the actual combat as little, if anything at all, seems to have changed since Rome II, making this game look a carbon copy of Rome II from time to time. I would have appreciated new tactics, or even better ways to control army units and possibly some mini-games. Other than that, just do yourself a big favour and get this game. You definitely won't be disappointed.

Great game! (However...) The Campaign for the most part won't be to exactly to everyone's taste - let me explain:

The campaign, just like the majority of the Total War game's is great. Build army's, fight battle's, Conquer territory rinse and repeat, you know how it goes with a Total War game. However, when you lose a settlement in Attila especially to any of the factions that adopt the nomadic horde type mechanic (i.e the Huns and the bleeding majority of factions in this game) there is a high possibility they will raze your settlement to the ground. This destroys the settlement (a sort of nuke simulation legitimately happens lol), takes it out of your control and if you want it back you have to pay a large lump sum of money (relative to the settlement size! For a city like Rome the fee can be astronomical and practically rights the city out of the game) to rebuild it all over again. Now, I can here you saying "get gud M8" but when you spend a few hours, a few days, hell even a few months on a campaign and out of no where Attila and his band of merry lads appear out of no where (and yes that is an actual mechanic, they just suddenly appear all of the god damn map at random!) and destroy one of your main settlements the game can leave you feeling infuriated due to the game feeling unfair; a game being a challenge, great, a game feeling unfair and unpredictable, annoying. 

Now although, this is entirely the premise of the game, Attila along with other tribes did this in real life, the game annoys the hell out of me. I do love the game and I would recommend it to anyone that has played any of the Total War titles, I'd easily say this game is an essential play to any Total War veteran, just be warned, watch your back - this game could have you smashing your keyboard right through your monitor at any second.

Total War series ended at Medieval 2 Total War... So simple. 
Instead of enriching the previous gameplay they chose to put effort only to graphics and dismantle the rest.

1. Disgusting city building system: From where did it come to the mind of the project manager to have only specific building being built in a city. How is it possible to improve a province's sanitation by building a bathhouse in another city one month distance away!!! There is no possibility for the player to form a proper line of defence with major fortifications in the border line. In Medieval Total War 2 you could choose to make a defensive line of castles and hold a position while you fight conquest war on the other side. This option is nowhere in this game. You can build up to 4 or 6 structures in a city...why????
2. Historically inacurate: major imperial cities turned into villages ready to by sacked. No walls. No gates. Some decorative pallisade walls and some stupid towers throwing 10 missing arrows before being destroyed and two units of 300 men at all in your position... I consider if the limitanei guards needed a general to be to specific territories... wonder... 
Romans did not build walls like these that you project. Roman walls were like these in Constantinople. Not a leveled ground keeping the mud with the wall...
Constantinople is a good effort. Very good. Though no double wall...But also the previous Total Wars didn't have it. 
3.  Sieges are the most stupid part of the game. Even in some major cities that remained as they were supposed to be, walls are simple fences. They climb them in no time and then you have a battle like any other. Archers doesn't even manage to throw two shots of arrows before enemies have already climbed the walls. Towers are also in major cities a joke. 
4. Economy: This is a strong part of the game. Very intelligent system of economy with products playing major role for the economic wellfare, surplus of bread spreaded throughout the state. Very good effort. 
5. Politics: Very good improvent. You have someting to say to what is happening. More freedom for the player. 
Overall I was fan of Total War. I don't know anymore - as I see that the same concept goes on. I do not recommend it.

Most Underated total war game out there

Pros
- Suprisingly good performance, compared to what most people say, on a mid end pc am able to run 25k soldiers with relatively good fps. This is twice what im able to run on games such as medieval 2.
- Great selection of mods - Rise of Mordor, 1212 ad, 7 kingdoms,nothern kingdoms , Ancient Empires and more, absolutely the best modding community out there.
-Incredible graphics, especially when compared to it's predecessor Rome 2.
-Decently Active Player base
-Intuitive and in depth campaign design
-All issues you find in game, once again can be fixed by smaller mods
-On sale quite alot
-Good dlc, Age of Charlegmagne is the best dlc CA released in my opinion.

Cons
- Bad lighting, can be fixed through graphics mods though
- Not as popular as the newer titles
- Campaign can be difficult at times for newer players
- Initial time period is not that appealing


No comparison, best TW game released when modded, please if you have not bought this game, give it a damn try, I still am not bored 1665 hours in.


P.S. Check out Rise of Mordor .... ;)

I am happy to say that Attila does not have the vast majority of the problems that Rome 2 had on release. 

There are things to like more or less about it, but overall it's a good Total War game, maybe even on the level of Fall of the Shogun. 
There are a fair number of factions with a good amount of variation. The game has a decent difficulty level, with some factions (Persia) being very easy, some being very hard, with the Legendary difficulty option for people who want to suffer a lot. 

The late game can get a bit stale because of the sheer size of the map - when you control 1/3rd of it it's hard not to succeed - but it's fun to play with late-game units.

Total War: ATTILA is incredibly unoptimized and feels odd when playing. Truthfully, as much as I wanted to like this game, I would say that Medieval Total War outclasses this poor game. Total War: ATILLA is overall uninteresting for its price, leading you to purchase other games in the Total War series instead. Like knights? Get medieval. Like this type of combat? Get Rome. Like ranged weaponry? Get Empire and Napoleon. There are other games that work much better than this one for the same price or cheaper. The maps themselves are nice to gaze at, however there are too many bugs in the game and 'features' that make the combat feel unfair and boring. Buildings can be easily burnt down however there is no technical advantage to this since you can't walk across the burnt rubbage. The sea battles are like any other Total War Game - uninteresting and stale. AI consistently forms a large 1-2 rank line with their regiments and charge all at once. (Not to mention AI always knows where you are, and if not, they stay still for ages forcing you to march to them). The maps are 'huge' however feel a bit empty since nearly no combat occurs in the outer regions, making there no need to include it in trade for worse performance. As I said, the game is poorly optimized. I get a low framerate with a 2070 graphics card despite my computer pushing hard and rocking medium framerates in other Total War games at high-ultra settings. As for gameplay itself, the game runs decently. Diplomacy is mediocre and advancing through the campaign is nothing special. Personally, I prefer campaign movement in the Total War Empire and Napoleonic games over what is present in the newer TW games. If you want to try this game, don't even consider getting it at full price for $45 USD. Only get it when it is on a major sale to see how it runs, because when the AI works right and everything runs decently, the charges do look cinematic.

Total War is a wonderful game from the series of total war. It displays the reason why the dark ages were called that. The brutality of war was a very nascent thing, and many great cities were laid waste in the fourth and fifth centuries anno domini in real life. With this game you can either be the nomadic hordes that destroy classical civilization as we know it, and replace it with their own cool stuff, or you can be the Romans, even the Persians, and lots of other cool peoples that existed in that time too. The flavorful events are always an entertaining, immersive and relevant facet to campaigns. As with other total war mods, the steam community has lots of neat modifications for adding detail to this game, as well as mods that enable you to choose other beliefs for your civilization, which allows for unique achievements as well as being really fun to try out and get to apply those benefits to the gameplay. Overall amazing game!

This game seems like it'd be very fun for a certain type of player, however this player does not include me. I am a huge fan of Medieval II: Total War, so I assumed this game would naturally be at least as fun. I realize M2TW has pretty simplistic city and kingdom management but going from it to a game like Attila is as intimidating as using your friend's shower. It should be easy to figure yet somehow it's just too different from what you're used to. The turns become extremely long very quickly especially when playing as the Romans (and let's be honest, we all want to re-create the Roman Empire). The game also comes off as more of an Empire Survivor than an Empire Builder. The goal of the game seems to be not to die rather than to dominate. I've tried starting many different campaigns on this game but I could never bring myself to get really invested in any of them. I've started and ended several games on M2TW spanning many many hours, so it's not that I'm not patient, I simply don't find the gameplay in Attila to be very fun.

I expected something better for battles after so many years. This title carries virtually the same problems that the first rome had. In siege battles it is somehow worse than rome II.

Also, after so many years one feels that is playing the same game all over again with the only differences being the enhanced graphics and some minor changes in details here and there.

Attila continues to deliver in surprising and unique ways even after all this time - and with the rise of fantasy Total War - Attila has some unique "dark" and "grimy" flair that make it appear the most bleak and difficult Total War experience. Modders have vastly expanded on the range of options for Attila as well!

developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

This is my 4th Total War title, the last one I played was ROME II and I probably put days of playing into that game. I bought a brand new PC and this was the first title I played. For the first 5 days I could not get into the right groove with this game, I'd loose battles and I'd reset the game, and repeat. It was terrible, it was enough to make my latethirties year old self question my age,  and it made me question me buying a gaming PC at late thirties. But then Stella got her groove back and I'm now great again. If this sounds like you, I suggest you try doing what I did. 1. Play Grand Campaign (Normal difficulty) 2. Try to play for peace as much as possible. Only fight when someone fights you (and if possible, end them and take their land). And again, play in peace, develop your buildings and tech. 3. Do not start conquering more land until you've saved up money. I recommend saving 30k-60k+ at the minimum but the more wealth the better, shoot for 100k and adjust as needed.

Much more fun than the original campaign (OC). I played as Belisarius and decided to be loyal to the emperor (you can choose to go a separatist route, which I suspect adds a lot more difficulty).

Pros:
- It has something like a plot. OC is sort of "make your own story" and it can be quite uninspiring, also the Huns and infertility mechanic there worked terribly. Here you have a real task, you're recreating history and your wife and boss give you missions with some interesting/funny background.
- The endgame feels achievable (and it is), the map is less chaotic than in OC
- The super-dull faction management is much easier to work with since you have much fewer characters - it even makes sense and you will use it to gain advantage
- Campaign AI can be cheeky sometimes, although you'll still easily outsmart it in battles
- Battles are fun - Eastern Romans have good and varied units
- Replayability is still here, I guess the other factions offer a very different approach
- 12 turns per year, finally
- Map is great - zoomed into North Africa and Italy/Gaul/Hispania, with more detailed provinces than in OC. There's 105 regions.
- Just one more turn and I'll go to bed...

Cons:
- My allies (e.g. Byzantium) were quite dumb. The victory conditions don't care, but you might have to return to quell uprisings against the cities you reclaimed, cause Emperor has 10 legions, but couldn't care less that thrice eradicated Ostrogoths are estabilishing themselves in Italy yet again.
- I reclaimed EVERYTHING and destroyed all the other factions, yet it's not a "triumph" cause that requires me to control 240 units and have income of 20k. Which means I'd have to sit and grind new buildings and armies for a week for the game to acknowledge my success
- Difficulty felt easy rather than hard, but that could be due to the fact I chose the easiest path/campaign.

I love this game. It is precisely for the same reason I love it so much, that many people may dislike it.  

  
Total War: ATILLA will kick your arse, and will spit on your spasming corpse for fun.  


Set in a period of time wracked by instability, migrations, collapse and environmental catastrophe, Total War: ATILLA is not about building an empire and flourishing. You heard me right - this isn't about building a mighty empire. The aim of the game is survival.  

The entire game has this gut wrenching feeling of treading water - your calamitous, messy collapse could possibly only be one famine or barbarian migration away. There’s no telling when a province’s food supply might fail, or when a tidal wave of Gothic migrations might wash away the civilisation you worked so hard to grow. Time is constantly in short supply as you race to patch holes in your sinking ship: as you plug one, two more emerge. Sure, you’ve crushed that major rebellion, but the harvest in one of your provinces has spectacularly failed, and the Huns have ravaged an outlying region on your frontier. The fleeing refugees are pouring into your towns and cities, fuelling the fires of discontent – it may only be a short while before yet more people raise their torches to topple your rule.  

In terms of time period, this era is an extremely interesting and (in my opinion) underrated choice. You have the big players of the Western and Eastern Roman Empires, as well as the rising power of the Huns and Attila, and the opulent Sassanid Empire in the east. Despite this, however, many of the great powers are in fact one punch away from completely imploding. While the Western Roman Empire stands as the prestigious bulwark against barbarian tribes, it is only a matter of time before it completely collapses – drowned in a torrent of rebellions, invasions, famines and plagues. You get the most fantastic contrast between the settled, civilised peoples of the world and the nomadic, ruthless, primal tribes in the east. Seeing Legionaries face off against Hunnic tribesmen, knowing that civilisation itself is at stake if they should fail, adds an unexpected layer of emotional engagement and anxiety to every battle – great or small. Certainly, this is one of my favourites eras in history, so perhaps I am biased towards this game as a result. Regardless of this, I believe many people can easily appreciate the themes which run so strongly in this game. 

I would like to share a story with you, because I was really impressed at how dramatic and emotional the fights can be in this game. I think it’s a testament to how well CA achieved the look and feel of the time period: 

In one battle I distinctly remember, I was playing as Western Rome defending Britain. The Saxons had unleashed a full-scale invasion, and my small local garrison was charged with a desperate defence of the region bearing the brunt of the enemy force. Reinforcements were nowhere in sight - in lieu of migrations across the Rhine and Alps, troops had been drawn elsewhere to halt the advance of barbarians into the Roman heartlands. In the foggy morning light, Saxon long ships were spotted approaching the shoreline. The fate of The Isles would be decided by this desperate bloody struggle.  
Come the afternoon, the field was littered with Roman corpses. Thereafter, control of Britain rapidly receded and ultimately dissolved under the weight of repeated Germanic invasions. I damn near saluted those dead Romans – the whole fight gave me a sad sinking feeling in my gut, the feeling that civilisation’s light was to be smothered in this part of the world for an unknown span of time. 
Truly, the lights had gone out.   

I understand why, to some people, this may sound positively awful. Some may wish to establish a flourishing kingdom, while others might wish to conquer all the lands they possibly can. Despite this, however, playing as an ailing kingdom or empire, barely able to keep it together, has a certain unique charm. It's strange to play a strategy game where your campaigns feel so hopeless – where borders are merely permeable barriers which will someday burst under the pressure of moving tribes. I haven’t played many strategy games where your military campaigns aren’t so much glorious conquest, but desperate attempts to retain control of regions of the map. Its brutal and depressing, and it perfectly captures the artistic and visual feel of the time period. This world is ageing, failing – soon, the empires of old will shatter and fall to a new wave of contenders. In Rome, the Goths will soon gain footholds in Italy and Spain, with the Franks wresting control of the region roughly equating to France. In terms of atmosphere, I believe Total War: ATILLA very effectively captures this feeling of decay and collapse.  

There are many issues with the game, as many others have pointed out. I despise the DLC policy that CA have taken with this game, and sometimes the game feels a little too brutal. Regardless, I can still wholeheartedly recommend it – despite its flaws, it is a great game. As an added benefit, the mods for this game are awesome, and many are still being uploaded/worked on to this day.  

This certainly isn’t for everyone, and is a rather unexpected departure from the regular formula of a Total War game (in my opinion). It may not be to everyone’s liking; however, if you enjoy a real challenge – and I mean a REAL challenge, or if you enjoy a constant struggle, and unforgiving difficulty, then this game might be worth your time.  

And who knows - you may be the one to save Rome.

Alright, so far this is the 3rd edit of this review. This time it will be much more balanced and informative.

Pros:
+Coastal Battles
+Combined Land and Naval Sieges (port assault)
+a variety of factions and units
+huge single player map

Cons
-melee engagements between individual soldiers (absolutely horrible)
-poor AI programming (relatively good at land battles, but very poor at attacking and defending settlements)
-a vast variety of siege games bugs (units do not know what to do if you order them to use the stairs of the wall, units won't assemble in the right way to shoot from the walls, especially if there is a curve on the wall etc)
-not many maps (i find myself playing on the same castles over and over again. Even if there are many land battle maps, I do not get to use them at all. In fact, 90% of battles commence in sieges.)
-towers in sieges (It doesn't really matter who owns the towers. In most cases, they will kill an equal number of soldiers from both sides. Their targeting is absolutely crap. You cannot control which unit the towers engage at all. They just shoot whatever is closest to them. In some battles, they kill hundreds of my soldiers even when positioned well, which is absolutely unrealistic and frustrating.) This could be solved, adding one simple button: On and Off. Additionally, if they decide to include a way to control which enemy unit they should engage, it would drastically improve the tower's usefulness.
-poor graphics for the time being (basically copy and paste from previous titles) If they don't want to change the graphics, lower the damn price. 

Overall, I liked the game. But that is just because I skipped Rome 2 even though I own it. If I had played Rome 2 and then purchased Attila, I would be absolutely mad. Attila is more like a mod for the previous title. It is still a good game and the single player is interesting enough to dive into, as well as the custom battles.

It starts off well. 

- Several diverse cultures
- Roman Empires are very unique factions for a TW game
- Managing sanitation, food, population, and more for EACH city is a new challenge
- Climate change is a bitch
- Mediterranean always a good map
- Reasonable victory end dates
- Naval combat may not be deep but it's fun, especially on same map with ground troops
- Internal politics to manage

But then the AI introduces you to the first crack in the seams. AI factions largely play the same, no matter their personality. They're obsessed with raiding/sacking and don't care about expansion. Within 25 turns, you'll be a top 5 power with anyone because you're actually building infrastructure. So every threat feels the same, which means you really don't need to diversify your strategies to win.

Then I realized how easy it is to manage sanitation, food, etc. They don't present extra strategic choices - it's just more busy work to make sure the numbers line up. The internal politics present no real challenge - it's very easy by midgame to maintain between 40-60% power. And some of the coolest units (like Sassanids elephants) aren't even that useful. So it's hard to recommend when a game like Three Kingdoms exists unless you just need something around this era (and I do think Attila is better than Rome 2).

I just wrapped my old VH Sassanids campaign (yes, they're very easy, I know) and went back to an old Legendary Picts campaign. By turn 40 it already feels like I'm in the mop-up stage of a late-game empire builder. The only "survival" aspect to this game is the climate change - which is admittedly cool. I just wish there was more to it.

Perhaps out of all the aspects of this game I would say my favourite would be the story/contextual setting that Attila uses. Many other total war games have nations starting out from single or a couple of settlements. The idea of playing as Rome (East or West) is fun and challenging - providing a unique experience that sets it apart from other total war games. The fear of hordes and expectation of the attack of the Huns constantly presents a fear that requires a large amount of focus and it quite exciting. 
However, i am utterly lost and confused when it comes to buildings - I cannot seem to balance public order. I have some provinces with positive food, almost 100% religion and high sanitation yet public order still declines. This i do not really understand - it makes playing the campaign incredibly difficult, more than necessary in my view. I find it really hard to extend my borders because rebels just appear constantly. It was so bad that i jut razed half the empire (West) and retreated all the way back to the Alps and Italy - and I've been pushing back out since. This has taken roughly 40 hours of game play though. The buildings are what I struggle most with, I just get so confused and cannot remember what to build and I end up building the wrong thing because there are too many options I think. Towers are just stupid - they wipe out my horses in like a minute, and the fact that you cannot capture them, they must be destroyed, is silly. 
Overall, It's immersive, fun, challenging and exciting to play but the building browser is over complicated for me which means I have to concentrate so much on planning what to build it takes a lot of the fun out.

Like, I get it. It wasn't a great time to be alive when the Western Roman Empire was in its death throes, but that doesn't really excuse the kind of gameplay that is evident in Atilla. 

Like no other Total War before it, Atilla is just [b]tedious.[/b] The strategic AI seems even more absurdly suicidal and willing to break treaties than normal, making diplomacy a complete waste of time, units seem to have way less variety, the game seems to have this weird concentration on city-building nobody asked for, and naval battles are an utter grind. 

The game isn't even particularly stable, but that's just peanuts compared to the game itself. It's just an unfun [b]slog[/b] most of the time, even if you aren't playing as either of the Romes. It just feels like the game heaps on a bunch of mechanics that get in the way of actually getting you into battles, or even worse, just throwing endless horde of enemies at you that feel like the game's cheating more than anything. 

It's just not that good, which is a shame, because the setting is kind of compelling, it's just too bad that the game isn't.

I am a big fan of the Total War series and was shocked when playing Attila for the first time, because it changed so much. I have to say, I didn't play Rome 2, therefore I refer to everything up to Shogun 2. 
The battles improved a little bit but are still very TW. The campaign on the other hand was too much of a change for me in the first couple of hours of game-play. A lot more aspects like complicated character and family-tree management where overwhelming. Also the provinces with three settlements each confused me. Now I have played lots of hours and have to say: I love it. If you are willing to take time to find your way through Attila, it will give you a lot of pleasure. Would be boring to have many TW games being all the same, now wouldn't it?

For a while I had huge frame rate and stuttering issues tried all sorts of suggestions to fix it including mods tinkering with cores on the affinity thing with no luck what worked was changing the amount of threads used in scripts preferences from 0 to whatever your cpu has look up a guide to explain it better then I can it's easier then it sounds if your not too savvy with technical stuff lol.
Anyway it's now running smooth and it's a great looking game it has a darker grittier tone in comparison to Rome 2s bright colourful artstyle there are lots of different factions to choose from and plenty of cool unique looking units including early vikings various catafracts and clibinari celts barbarians beserkers elephants ect. It can be very hard though but it should be remembered this is mostly an empire survival game and there are plenty of guides on youtube and such. Overall I would only recommend on sale because while the stuttering fix worked for me it might not for everyone and its frustrating enough to be game destroying.
Overall its good total war fun when it works especially if your keen on the time period.

A very solid Total War game.  This game is very different from every other game simply because everyone and everything works against you in this one.  You will lose and it will hurt.  Your response and overall long term planning will be tested at every turn.  

The siege gameplay is top notch for a total war game.  Every city is fun to defend and attack and is not a chore like in some of the newer entries (Warhammer).  The DLC (mainly Charlemagne) adds a more Medieval touch to the game and is excellent.  It is a 180 feel from the base game and adds a very unique and interesting viewpoint to a critical part of Europe's and Christianity's history.

This is not your average total war game and is not for everyone, but it does things that other total wars do not and the positives far outweigh the negatives on this one.  Give it a try (on sale of course) and get the Charlemagne DLC, it's one of the best DLCs ever made for any Total War game.

As a linux user, I really appreciate that so much of the TW series has been ported. I've read that the port of Atilla had very poor performance at release, but it seems to work great now though.

One slightly annoying thing before it worked as intended for me was that it didn't recognize all my vram at first, so instead of 4096 mb, it said I only had 512 mb. I had to edit a config file to correct this issue. Find the preferences.script file (in Linux, you should find it in ~/.Creative Assembly/Attila/scripts). Find the line "gfx_video_memory 0;" and change it to "gfx_video_memory -2000;"

No idea why this has to be made in order to make the game work correctly. So, while I recommend the game because it is fun to play, I'm still annoyed that CA can't make it run correctly out of the box so many years after the release.

And so we begin. Four years after buying this game, I feel like its time to give it a proper and insightful review. 
Total War: Attila. This is by far the hardest game in the whole entire franchise. One that we love and hate at times, but has steadily provided us with fun games to play.
So, what's different about Attila? What makes this game so complicated? First and foremost let's talk history. This game is set at the dawn of the Dark Ages. The Roman Empires are falling apart and the smaller but numerous tribes are picking apart at it's carcass. Whether you choose to take the challenge of leading a falling Empire or partake in it's downfall, you're going to have many enemies along the way. Playing as the Western Roman Empire is one of the most annoying, fun, boring, challenging and repetitive experiences. The adjectives used seem almost paradoxal, but its for a reason. You're going to repeat the same battles over and over again, you're going to lose almost all of your starting territories due to the fact that almost every existing faction will declare war on you, but once you finally manage to balance the Public Order and the Squalor, you're finally going to start having fun. Destroying the once smaller, but now slightly bigger tribes isn't going to necessarily be an easy task, but with patience you'll get there. And then, try this again but in Legendary difficulty. I'm sure you'll have tons of fun (you won't, trust me)!
It also has one of the best DLCs for the whole franchise, "Age Of Charlemagne" which is set in the early medieval periods.
Total War: Attila is a great and fun game to play, and if you're a fan of the franchise but still haven't acquired this game, I'd very much recommend you to do so.

I could post a massive review slating several aspects of this game (lackluster DLC, battle bugs, lack of variety etc) but you'll see that from other reviews here and I'll only be repeating what they've said. What ruins this game for me is the public order system; it's rancid, and I'm sick and tired of it. When a rebellion happens, the rebel army spawns next to a random settlement within your province, meaning you have to take a wild guess as to where it's going to spawn so you can move your army there. As the rebel army gets to act on the first turn it spawns, unless you have an army garrisoning the settlement it's next to, it'll take the settlement, loot it and reduce public order further, meaning there'll be another rebellion when you take the settlement back.

If this isn't the case, I'm either:
1. Sitting in provinces trying to prevent a rebellion when public order is -97 (-2 per turn) due to factors such as immigrants that the player can't do anything to prevent, or;
2. Chasing that one enemy army that's sacking your settlements and standing 1 movement point out of reach from your army, because the AI knows where your armies are at all times.
If you do play the long game and wait for instability and immigrants to go down so that your provinces can be SOMEWHAT stable (meaning they won't instantly rebel the moment you move your army) the AI will just get stronger and consolidate.
This is all without mentioning the countless bugs that are all over this thing. I've tried really hard to get into Attila, but I just can't; the gameplay is just tedious, frustrating and dull in comparison to other total war games. As a massive history buff, Warhammer II is better.

[h1] Total War: Rome II and Total War: Attila, These two total war titles are my current favorites. I have no hope for any new total war game I can expect to be as good as these two currently are. [/h1]

[b] This is not a kingdom or empire building and managing game unlike the other total war turn-based strategy games. This is a historical survival strategy game based on ''The Migration Period''. The game will rush over you once it gets the chance.  The game wants you to fail and die in pain. The hardest Total War game so far if you ask me.  [/b]

AI in this game is cheating. I mean it, It really cheats. For example, a neighboring faction in just one small town (which is one of the settlements in your province you're located in ) might end up having two complete stacks of army in third turn and you don't even have one with twenty and you must conquer them because in long term you will neither be able to secure public order in your province nor will be able to afford the units you need, to expand on the map. Long story short, The AI in this game is really capable of doing some impossible things any normal player, or even some total war experts can't do normally. This is the exact definition of the word ''cheating'' in my vocabulary. yeah AI in this game is really cheating in this level of absurdity.

The Huns, I want to mention them a little bit. They are the most cheating faction in this game I can assure you all as you take it from the title of the game that they are pain on your shoulders. It's hard to stop them and even harder to make them extinct. They spawn hordes in every corner of the map and raid into Europe. The worst thing about them is that once they attack one of your settlement, not only do they sack the settlement but also they raze the settlement so you won't be able to colonise there until mid or late game. They also cause fertility damage in your province where the settlement they razed is located. If you are familiar with Warhammer Total War, You might think that they are similar in attitude to the chaos faction in warhammer, yes they are. They will be the same throughout the campaign until you or one of the some other factions in the game kill Attila the Hun. but be aware that you can't kill him just in one battle, you have to kill him tree or four times. you can't get away from them. 

If Western Roman Empire in this game drew some attention from you, if you ask me, Don't jump into it yet unless you certainly know what you're doing. Maybe after hundreds of hours of playing this game, you might be good to go for it. It is really, terribly terrible, the whole world around you will declare war on you at the beginning of the campaign you just started as WRE. 

Despite the fact that CA abandoned the game long time ago, There is something better which keeps the game fresh and makes it more playable for hundreds of hours more. Of course, MODS. You will have access to the Total War: ATTILA workshop if you're willing to buy the game and give it a shot.

I have spent more time playing this game than almost any other. What can I say about Attila? The time frame is desperate and compelling. The mechanics are refined from Rome 2. The mods are fantastic - notable, Fall of the Eagles (for those who like the original time frame), Ancient Empires (hardcore classical era, think Europa Barbarorum from Rome 1 and Medieval II) and Medieval Kingdoms (campaign in testing and out soon I hope!). 

My only complaint would be optimisation, which was done for Rome 2 and Thrones of Britannia but skipped over for Attila. Still, I can play it decently with a computer from 2011 so everyone should be fine.

If you like Late Antiquity or the idea of Medieval 3 (which is what Kingdoms will be once completed), jump into it!

In all the time I have played Attila, I would not recommend it. The reasons are as followed:

1. Bugs, examples being when you order your troops to run down fleeing enemies, but instead decide to stand still, requiring you to endless give the order in some hope they will kill the enemy. Also boats have a habit of becoming one with the land and archers can just instantly volley the moment they turn around from running.

2. The game is often quite tedious, with the AI knowing where your armies are at all times and just showing up where you are not, making it quite a dull experience of running after a single army to stop it from sacking your towns, but you cannot as the ai knows the whereabouts of your army. Not even mentioning the endless Hunnic hordes until you kill Attila (which can take a while) and again, just get boring.

3. The Germanic factions are practically the same, same with the Slavic factions, meaning little variety. 

4. I would rather watch paint dry instead of playing a naval battle.

5. And finally, the game has a vast amount of uninteresting DLC, the only exception being the Charlamagne DLC. This is due in part to modders being able to do a finer job of adding extra factions, I mean the Germanic one just added yet more copy paste 'Germanic' something and a couple of extra units.

Overall the game is quite poor, and if you are thinking about purchasing a Total War game, you are better of with Warhammer II to be honest, as the factions are very unique in that game.

Before I begin I will say I spent most of my time with this game playing as the WRE as the game is meant to be played.

Total War Attila utilizes the traditional Total War formula in the best possible way. Newer Total War games use a different formula which might not be to the liking of every total war veteran. By combining Total War's aspect of limited strategic mobility with the struggle for survival and mobile playstyle of the Hordes an extremely rewarding and challenging experience is created.
Compared to previous Total War games calvary is much more powerful and unit upkeep is much more penalizing. 

The game occasionally experiences graphical bugs but these always are easy to resolve for me.

Not going to lie, when I started out on Total War Attila I HATED IT. Over two years, and I could barely bring myself to play the game, let alone enjoy it. And that's when I realized I had it all wrong. You're not trying to build an empire like what you did in Rome 2. No, this is a game of survival. Surviving against your backstabbing neighbours, against people you've never met, against the borderline unstoppable Huns, and against Mother Nature herself. It ain't easy, and its understandable if ya hate the game. But from my experience, once you start to get stuff rolling, it's what makes things all the more enjoyable ( like killing Attila in 427 AD. With Western Rome. With their starting Emperor)

I dislike the Eastern Roman Empires desire to sail armies and navy's back and forth between Greece and Egypt continuously... I dislike this very much because it cripples their ability as a nation to expand or even defend properly. I also don't care for the massive penalties for building certain buildings and the micromanagement required for each individual province due to massive squalor and public order penalties from said buildings. Beyond those to items though...? I love the Total War games. All of them. I love the style and I love the gameplay. I spent thousands of hours playing Medieval 2 prior to using Steam... And the amount of time that I've played Attila, Shogun 2, Empire and Rome 2 offline are all insane. So, ultimately I would recommend this to any player who loves a challenge, loves massive battles and especially to anyone who holds a special place in their heart for Rome, as I always have.

Great game, been a fan of Total war series for many years. Political influence in factions can be a bit skewed but adds another dynamic to the game play. Battles flow easily and are a joy to play win or lose. Mods available are diverse and interesting. 

Main Drawback: The AI spams troops in full 20 stack armies like there's no tomorrow, all the while you struggle to field more than a handful of decent armies at a time. Defeat one or two full stack armies of a strong nation and that's it...you destroy them utterly or your territories will no longer be safe. Attila's troops are the biggest pest in the game by far in this regard, as they should be, but it does get aggravating when you're trying to stay on two feet while fending off wave after wave of Huns bearing down on you. Having said this I guess that's the point...the Huns were full-on and drove many nations to the brink.

Overall: This is a fun game with varying degrees of difficulty and skill requirement.

I played a lot of Total War overall, loved the original Rome: Total War and I wanted to love Attila but I just can't. While the battles are great and the combat is really solid and fun the campaign map just sucks the joy out of it for me.  The gameplay there feels "annoyance"-based with always something bad happening (public order / squalor / war) that you only have few to none tools to deal with. Someone on reddit said it best: "the settlements look like you have choices but actually most of the buildings are noob traps". You have choices but they don't seem very meaningful. If you don't build exactly the right way 20 turns in advance you will get caught in a death spiral that you can't do much to get out of. Research and Characters are supremely uninspired. It feels like a very boring spreadsheet. Most of that stuff is just about very tiny percentage increases or decreases to things that are inscrutable and frankly hard to care about. To be fair the UI tries to give explanations for a lot of things but this just seems to have given the game designers carte blanch to create this zoo of stats. 

Overall the strategic level feels very contrived and inorganic as a result. The AI doesn't play their game so much as they play against you adding one more aspect of annoyance. I don't mind hard games and I think annoyance has a clear place in any game but TW just has that as their main game loop and that's too much. Nothing really good ever happens to you: you win a huge battle "here have 7% replenishment" LOL. Conquer a city: "here have public order problems for the next 20 turns". Raise an army: "you won't ever have money ever again". Sometimes the best thing to happen to you is that you lose a huge battle, freeing up your treasury while the AI just fucks of north again never to be seen again. 

I recently watched a long youtube series on Caesars life  and while he did have to deal with uprisings (mainly because he was being massive despot) strangely never once did he have to deal with reducing squalor in his provinces. He also became a billionaire by waging successful wars and conquered massive swaths of the known world in a few decades. He also could field 8 legions without ever going broke. I am just saying, CA has to go back to the roots and make the game far less gamey

The red-headed stepchild of Total War, Total War Attila is oft-neglected by both the community and the developers. Whereas Rome 2 has received several DLCs and updates long after its release and Warhammer Total War continues to be updated, Total War Attila has seemingly been forgotten. This is ironic as Total War Attila had many new features and returning features that many players missed from previous games: Family trees, in-depth politics, dynamic fire, and horde-based factions. Total War Attila takes place during the early Dark Ages, and reflects the transition from pagan to Christian throughout Europe and the Roman Empires. Religion plays a larger role, providing a host of benefits and detriments, and players can convert their faction should a better alternative appear. Furthermore settlements can now be razed, destroyed completely, either by the owner to deny it to the enemy or by attackers. All in all, a worthwhile game to play if you want a quality historic Total War.

The game does have a larger than normal learning curve, however they provide you with an in game Encyclopedia allowing each player to learn at their own pace. The game isn't very forgiving with mistakes *save often* you can truly end a career after moving units incorrectly and being outside of the range to join a fight. However the upside is massive with this game. Huge battles in diverse landscapes representative of whats visible on the main map. Meaning if you fight a battle in the city of Rome, You will actually see the city with its high walls & aqueducts.. Colosseum ect. Graphics are on par with when this game was released and are still visually appealing today. The combat system is unique and challenging yet rewarding and satisfying. Lots of different factions to begin a campaign, each with their own nuances. I was very excited to get this game when it first came out & am just as excited to play it today.

Guys, I thought I would take a moment to give a thumbs up to what has become the best Total War game I have ever played (and I have played almost all except Shogun 2),

Playing this using the 1220 medieval mod is simply gorgeous! My version runs very smooth and stable. The graphics and the game play of this game using this mod has generated a fantastic and very beautiful game but in a historic setting that I really like.

Here you get to play out naval battles, fantastic land battles together with gorgeous sieges in a medieval Europe.

Essentially Total War Attila plus 1220 mod equals Total War Medieval 3! It really is that good. I honestly have more fun playing this then Three Kingdoms.

Only downside is the greedy high prize they charge for this game and on top of that you need the DLCs to play this mod. Shame on CA to charge so much for a five year old game.

Cudos to the modders who created this wonderful mod and essentially made a new TW game set in the medieval times.

Highly recommended if you can stomach CAs ridiculous and greedy prize (shame on you CA)

Cheers

Nietzsche once said "God is dead and we killed him" but after playing Total War Attila I know now who really killed God.............. It was the Huns. From five turns in to a hundred turns out the world is constantly on fire. Empires fracture, rebellions lead to additional factions, famines are seasonal and FREQUENT. Nobody trust you, nobody even likes you. Tribes you ally with will betray you and flee in times of war, your enemies will seek peace three turns into a conflict because their general revolted. The entire atmosphere of this setting screams of bleak despair. The starting armies for most factions are simple peasants in rags, the facial expressions are dull and void of happiness. 


The broken and dying world

- It's hard to balance large empires, and unlike in previous total war games that expands to the AI as well. After roughly a hundred turns the world is unrecognizable. Every superpower collapses into anarchy leaving only a few regional forces behind. This is by design, you don't get large wealthy continent spanning powers that can send +7 full stacks of elite infantry / cavalry against you. At most you find a moderately powerful faction that's using its large armies to maintain domestic stability in its three of four regions. 



Contrast to Rome  2

- There's a few factors that always come together to make Europe slide into this  bleak battle royal. First migrating tribes such as the Huns don't capture settlements......... they raze them to the ground. meaning the population is slaughtered, everything is destroyed and no one controls it. (You need to send an Army to colonize these wastlands it its expensive). Second, there's a lack of food and the AI doesn't mange it well. if your people starve they rebel, if they rebel in times of famine they grow, if the growing rebellion captures a region it holds it and fortifies it Indefinitely. 

- If Rome 2 was the nerdy highschool prep kid that got straight A's, Attila is his older edgy brother that died from a heroin overdose in college. There is no glory, there is only survival. Units aren't dressed in shinny colourful armor but with crude cold hides and chainmail, but don't mistake this for lazy unit design they look great given the atmospheric nature of the world these battles take place in. 



Diversity 

- many nations to play as from all different corners of Europe. The map is huge, It contains, Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East spanning all the way into Iran and up to Eastern Europe. Each faction has its own culture group affiliation that gives unique units as well as the different types of mercenaries available in certain regions. You can be playing as a German kingdom but if you march an army into Arabia you can recruit unique Arab units and march them back. 

- many factions posses an ability to migrate, meaning they burn down there own settlements and become a mobile tribe. From here they can fortify anywhere and build mobile improvements before traveling. Or if you fuck up royal and are about to lose a war you can just tell your armies to dip and travel to the other end of the world. The AI does this too so you could see alot of tribes and factions in places were they shouldn't be. Migrating tribes can also conquer settlements and colonize should they wish to become landed again.



Naval
- Phenomenal 
- Catapult boats are amazingly OP as one hit sinks ships, they can be used during port sieges too.
- Your navies can help with coastal sieges and that is just amazing. 
- Unique naval units that can go on land during battles. 
- Your Land Armies can also become navies by transporting them over ocean..........however they are really weak. 



In short 
- Good game, 8.5/10.
- Also yeah it's bullshit that they charge $3 for blood dlc

With the success of Rome 2 Total War (Post patches lol), I was really looking forward to what was going to be next on the list for CA and Total War as a whole. Now, at first I was a little confused and interested at the idea of Attila total war, but then I started to have flash backs to Rome total war Barbarian Invasion an expansion that made Rome 1 more enjoyable and challenged the player to think differently. When I finally sat down and started to play Attila I was a little confused and kept losing major battles, only to take several weeks off of it because I was getting angry. Yet, when I came back to it later after watching tips and tricks I noticed that I need to change my thinking and tactics, it wasn’t about trying to conquer new lands or territories it was about survival. That’s what makes Attila so addicting is because your grand plans of trying to conquer the whole map might not be achievable at first because you need to survive and defend your territory first. That’s what make the experience of Rome 2 and Attila different but yet very interesting and worth putting dozens of hours in at a time. 

I would recommend this game to complete your total collections but as well to play a survival game set to a grand scale.
