I have every iteration of Total War that has come out, (sans the witchcraft tutorial), and I've always loved the unique intros, cut-scenes, and General's speeches, for each faction, that were created, and dare I say, expected in latter versions.

However, the lack of unique intros, or cut-scenes, and the total lack of quality in any of Attila Total War...has left me feeling a bit sick to be honest. I purchased the game about 36 hours before the fall sale(Apparently), for about $50.00...and don't even ask me what I think of that price, for a game almost half a decade old, the next day, it was $11 and change. I purchased all DLC, with the exception of the "red spatter effect" for less than $25.00, and I still feel a bit ripped-off if I'm honest.

I've been a programmer most of my life, so I don't begrudge anyone for getting paid for their work...but this, this DLC was just a way to keep working on the game.(And they should have just said so.) However; they didn't, AND, they really didn't work on the game at all, in all this time...the DLC's are just more factions piled into a half-finished game.

The "advisor" avatar looks like it was the wet dream-child of some 10 year old, who walks around in circles in the basement, mumbling "Something, something, something...DARK SIDE!" over and over.

Nothing is intuitive, EVEN to those who have played all the previous renditions.
Half the game is played one way...and then when you switch to one of the Roman factions...the ENTIRE GAME mechanics change. ??? (Unfinished anyone?)

I've played...OK..WORKED at, learning this game and its mechanics for (I'm guessing here)...almost 200 hours...and I STILL cannot make sense out of half of it. Farms cause sanitation, and cultural/public unrest??? REALLY? I've lived ON A FARM and never had to worry about sanitation...and never really got upset about it. OH, and for some really strange reason...now your cities are in clumps of three, and have an extremely limited number of slots. *Which is a nice change cuz, I can remember playing many other TW games and screaming at the monitor..."OH MY GOD, Why do I have so many construction slots to use?"...wait..no...that never happened...sorry.

All the while the "climate-change" is pushing fertility and thus food production down. So you can either spend 60 VERY LONG turns building up a "clump", just to have it be a pain in the pin-feathers in a few more turns, or you can just up and leave and head south and be the last "faction" to start the game 40 turns in...(Face-palm).

Enemies (especially early game), can run around destroying your cities, long before you can afford to field armies to protect them, and when you do manage to build an army, it feels like there should be some Benny Hill music playing in the background as you futilely try to chase them around, and around, and around. *Daaa, nut, nut, nanna, nanna...

My favorite Total War game of all time, has to be Medieval Total War.(I play with a ton of different mods.) 
This...THIS?...feels like I've purchased the 1980's beta to the first Total War game made. :(

Even with all the DLC this game feels like I'm playing a half-finished version, or DEMO, of a game that was destined to be great, but for "reasons/money" they just quit working on it. I mean for Pete's sake they didn't even finish the Encyclopedia/Reference/help manual material for the game. If it wasn't for the internet...I still wouldn't have a clue. Thankfully, all the "New" DLC just means that all that info I've found, is either out-of-date, or just plain no longer applicable in any meaningful way.

Your call.

great game

+ fantastic scenarios, from established but crumbling empires to migrating across the map to nomads carving out a place to settle down to just playing as the huns and burning the entire map until NOTHING is left
+ great expansions in The Last Roman and the Charlemagne campaign, the latter of which fixes several of the problems at the campaign level 
+ Western Roman Empire is a masochistic, "who the fuck is declaring war on me this time" survival horror where you abandon 1/3 of your empire, and another 1/3 becomes a 10v1 battleground with end-turns of over an hour of certain-defeat small-town battles and I LOVE IT
+ Climate change as an escalation mechanic across the campaign forcing factions into conflict as they stop being able to feed their provinces and have to move to greener pastures


- Climate change is a poorly-developed/explained escalation mechanic across the campaign leading to players making the 'wrong' choices especially wrt farms and province development, which can leave you in a game-restarting catch-22 scenario.
- runs like a steaming turd on the best of machines.  I did not have this on SSD initially and could do workouts while loading up battles
- city building/province management seems 'deep' but is 'complex'.  That is, there are lots of dependencies between buildings, eg farms generate food but reduce public order and squalour, so you need sanitation and happiness buildings etc, leading to many 'wrong' choices, one 'right' choice and cookie-cutter builds across every province.  I'm talking "plague-ridden hellhole that doesn't make enough money for the permanent garrison to defend it" vs "metaphorical gold mine" (the literal gold mines are a trap and actually aren't worth developing because of how much they fuck the province what in the actual fuck CA)


I spent way too many hours on this game, and not just in OCD province management making sure I'd upgraded everything.  Being the ludicrously-rich Eastern Roman Empire (or late-game WRE once you fix everything) and saying "I'm going to pay you 200,000 gold to fuck off and attack each other" every turn is immensely enjoyable.  Even with all the awful broken garbage and bad design choices (the province design should be in classes as an example of how NOT to do this) I still played several campaigns in this game and loved every one of them*.  

TL;DR buy on sale, look at Youtuber Yrridian to see why I played so much

TW Attila is good game. Its pretty much an un optimized Rome 2 with a few fixes and a hardcore campaign. Takes place during the fall of the West Roman Empire and the invasion of the Huns. Attila TW introduces playable hordes into the campaign with the ability to raise settlements to the ground. Battles remain unchanged when compared to Rome 2 with both land and naval combat and a similar albeit better looking matched combat animation system. Performance in this game is horrid even on a half decent rig so don't expect 60 fps. Overall I recommend this game but it has its weaknesses and could be skipped as Rome 2 seems to play,look and run better for the most part.

Ok here is my review. First time so take it easy on me. 

-Very challenging game, especially when you play either Roman Factions. 
-A.I. is kind of dumb in both battles and global map. 
-Huns are very annoying to play against.
-Game almost forces you NOT to totally destroy an army. In the case of the Huns, if you defeat an army of theirs, another full stacked army spawns the next turn. Might as well just take out the good units and let your boy Attila hire weak mercs.
-I have NO clue why it is so hard to get someone into a trade agreement with you. 
-Very diverse units, which in turn lets you employ diverse tactics. Rome is very structured and has hardy infantry, Slavs have very fast units which allow you to outmaneuver Romans. ect. 
- Soundtrack is pretty good. 
-Food is annoying, but a good mechanic.
-Ship battles are boring, but sometimes nice to change it up.
- Diplomacy mechanic kind of sucks. For example, I once subjugated the Franks to use them as a cushion against the Huns. The very next turn they declared war on me. Psh.
- DLC is pricey, but if you enjoy the game it is very worth the price. Especially the Desert Kingdom DLC. 
-Factions are very different from each other, but similar factions (i.e. the Desert Kingdoms) are the pretty much the same, with the only difference is one trait. Same buildings, units, tactics, ect.
- A.I. do very annoying things sometimes, like send a small army which you have to chase down for 5 turns as it attacks and beats your garrison and then sacks the town.

Pretty solid game

Pros:
+The new squalor system works surprisingly well. 
+Religion makes a return and it's really fun to try and speed-convert a certain religion. Each one is unique and provides cool buildings
+battles are a lot better than other games. Each city (for the most part) has a unique layout, and your developments can actually be seen on the battle map. 
+Fire spreading mechanic is really fun to use against your enemies' cities
+Tech trees provide a great sense that your faction is "advancing". Germanic units start with cloth uniforms and little training, but in the late game they all have heavy armor and more battle formations to choose from

Cons:
-Playing as the Roman factions can be fucking annoying. (With an AI playing) West Rome falls almost a century before it's supposed to, and East Rome doesnt put up a big enough fight despite being the richest faction in the game. The tech trees are nonsensical (I LOSE access to my best Roman techs when I research christian techs?). Plus you literally have to cheat to win battles. It's common to fight some 3-4 outnumbered battles a turn.
-Religions are not balanced. Most of the religions have obvious pros and cons, usually in the form of sacrificing one thing for another. The most widespread religion in the game, Christianity, SUCKS. Churches are too expensive to maintain and give few other bonuses besides big conversion rates. Ironically Roman factions are better off returning to Roman-paganism and building its unique temples. Even then, RP requires literally hundreds of food and is hard to maintain in the late game.
-Huns are overpowered and not fun to play as/against. Kill an army and they'll immediately respawn. When Attila comes of age they literally have 0% upkeep, and to stop the huns you have to kill Attila THREE TIMES.
-Fertility and climate change events are not handled well. There's no way to improve the fertility of your lands when climate change hits. I know it's supposed to motivate all the barbarians to travel southward but really it's more of a handicap so that youre forced to sit tight and defend against the Hunnic invasion for the next 20 years. Food gets really scarce to the point that you cant feed half your faction, even when the majority of them have 2-3 farm buildings.

TL;DR 
Attila total war provides a lot to the table, but most of it is too hard to chew. AI is unfair, new mechanics are broken,  early game is annoying and late game is boring. Plus the Roman campaigns are designed to piss you off

I have been waiting to review this for a while, especially since I have probably some 1000 h of this on my old computer. In my humble opinion this is the best Total War game up to date. Can't say for Three Kingdoms yet, I haven't played that one yet, but Total War: Atiila captured the essence of these series. It perfected the formula of Total War: Rome II, and added it's on atmosphere. The theme is collapse, the collapse of the Western civilization, mostly focusing on the Western Roman empire. For me, as a historian, this period in history is especially interesting mostly because we know so little of it compared to the earlier periods. Rome collapses, with the Church saving it's legacy as knowledge and similary this game echoes the apocalyptic feeling. And yet, not only is it possible to reform, save the empire, which I often do replaying this game probably once a year, but it also gives the insight of other nations. Just as it was historicly, some nations, or tribes, people, despite the climate change, not only survive but also thrive. I like to roleplay in such a manner, that I play one main campaign which I focus mostly on, thata always the Western Roman empire, and then I play some additional ones I have not tries before. I like to imagine, that somenof them would ally with the Romans in their last ditch effort to save the empire. For example, I am yet to finish the complicated Lakhmid campaig fully, but I ussualy run away from the Sassanids, they attack ERE, I betray them and from that point onwards fight them. Similary, as the Venedetians I fight the Huns in the teritories of novaday Eastern-Central Europe and when playing as the Romans I ally wih them. The thing is, this game makes it possible. It shows you these different perspectives, you can be a Pict or Norseman who relishes in the cold, or experience the might of the Persian/Sassanid empire, flank your enemies in the desert where Northern armies would die out. Point is, this game immerses  you fully. Therefore I plead to CA, please, optimize this game, maybe add some DLC alongsixe a huge commercial. It has the potencial to be so much more memorable and profitable than, for example, Total War Rome II, simply because it is so much harder but also rewarding.

Total War: Attila gives the unique opportunity to play not as an enlightening civilization, but as an apocalyptic horde. As the Huns, I swept across the steppe and through Central Europe, laying waste to all the armies cities in my path. I loved the opportunity to build armies consisting of pure cavalry both melee and ranged, and utilizing cavalry vs infantry like the real Huns and the Mongols who later succeeded them.

Unfortunately the game (on the default difficulty setting) grinds to a halt before any of the several major enemy factions have been destroyed. At least 6 armies are required in order to not be conquered, but at least 4 of them must remain encamped (stationary) in order to not go bankrupt. Generating income is too slow, moving is too slow, the enemy AI is far too slow, unit replenishment is too slow, and this all becomes unacceptably worse once the map experiences a mini-ice age. Fortunately, there is much fun to be had up until that point but it means any satisfying conclusion must be abandoned far too early.

My Specs: 
CPU - Ryzen 5 2600
GPU - RX 580 8GB
RAM - 2x 8GB DDR4 Corsair Vengeance RGB Pro
HDD - 2TB Seagate Barracuda 

My FPS? In campaign, 40-60 (depending on the location)
In Battles? 60 FPS. Unless the camera is positioned a certain way making the game tank because of poor optimization. I would refrain from playing this game until (or rather if) performance issues are resolved. It should also be noted that I can run ROME 2 on max settings and get solid frame rates in battles, and I am aware they are 2 different games. However, my computer is well above the specs recommended for THIS game.

Attila Total War provides a challenging survival experience that tests your ability to manage your nation & existing wars against an increasingly hostile environment. The game is fun, nice variety of factions and starting locations to try out, fairly intuitive regional management and ample territory on the map to keep your empire ever expanding. Definitely recommend this game as it brings to life the "Barbarian at the Gates" feeling quite well.

One of the best total war games in my opinion. There's a large variety of mods and factions to choose from, making every playthrough unique. I fell in love with the challenge, and I feel like most negative reviews are sore players who can't take the heat of constantly being defeated and pressured by factions much bigger than you. It's not an easy game to start, but once you get into the hang of how it plays then it's a piece of cake. 

Furthermore, it is a STRATEGY game. In other words in requires PROBLEM SOLVING and CRITICAL THINKING. Multitasking large armies also is crucial; I cannot begin to describe the amount of battles where I was focusing on moving my right flank forward all the while the rear of my left flank had been BOOTY LICKED by shock cavalry without me even knowing until it was too late.

As far as getting bored, most likely not going to happen. Every campaign is unique yet some aspects are predetermined (such as hostilities with factions of a rival culture or religion. Hostilities don't usually arise immediately, and in some ways they can be prevented, too. ). But as far as my 750 hours or so goes, I've never thought "aghh this is so predictable and easy to cheese" because it isn't. The AI is wonderfully fabricated and is almost like facing real players in the campaign, except of course the AI don't have human flaws such as the inability to micromanage 7000 units at a time and still maintain an offensive/defensive.


So yeah, the game is hard in the beginning, especially for me since I had never played a TBS/RTS game in my life besides halo wars. However, once you get into the swing of things it becomes very enjoyable laying massive sieges to castles while commanding THOUSANDS of units at a time. It's definitely worth the buy in my opinion, especially at a measly  $11.

Fellow linux users: In my experiance the linux version of this game works very well... but many mods are incompatible with the linux version.

The minimum operating system requirement may say Ubuntu, but I have had no issues running this on Arch Linux, and I generally experiance no serious performance issues.

I do occasionally experiance some crashes (even on vanilla) and I do sometimes experiance some lag (especially when using higher graphics settings), but this is not so frequent as to really be a problem.

It must however be said that I am unable to run some larger mods (in particular some faction unlock mods and mods adding custom units), while other mods cause too frequent crashes to be playable.
I personally don't consider this a serious issue, as I almost exclusively plays on the vanilla version, or using only minor mods, but if you intend to install this to play major mods like Medieval Kingdoms AD1212 or Ancient Empires, then you should properly get the windows version on a virtual machine.

Alongsid ethe fact that the Linux distribution is working, i also think the game is pretty good, so I do recommend this.

Absolutely mind-blowing of a game...


Let me start this off by saying that there is no perfect game, and there is no perfect Total War game. Each TW game offers its own set of challenges and gameplay. However, there is usually common problems among most TW games which are all similar to a point. I mean stuff like
-lack of end-game challenge (big with games like Rome II and Shogun)
-lack of a challenge in general for seasoned players
-average/non-exciting battles
-boring campaign map
and the list goes on...

The reason i listed these is because what every other Total War game gets wrong...this game does RIGHT.
For example, 

1. End- game challenge in this game is huge, especially with the Huns. I played as Eastern Roman Empire, and i basically owned 3/4ths of the entire map after steamrolling through 25 barbarian cities, but the Huns still managed to keep me on the edge of the seat, as i anticipated their moves and devoted 6 armies to fight them. Lets just say that you will NEVER get bored when playing this game (for the most part)

2. This game is arguably the HARDEST Total War game in the franchise. At time it feels like a survival game. For example, in Rome II, you would build armies, conquer lands, rinse and repeat. In Attila it is more like trying to defend your weak cities against a billion different hordes with their own unique systems and its just awesome. And for those who are new to the game, there are PLENTY of easy factions to play where you can just raid and pillage.

3. The battles in this game are insane. To put it simply-- the amount and variety of each unique faction and their units will always have you changing your strategies and tactics to keep the game fresh. If you try to use the same strategy against every faction, your armies will get obliterated. For example, you have heavily armored Cataphracts in the East, very skilled (and sometimes overpowered) horse archers from the steppe, Roman heavy infantry from the empires, Viking raiders from the North, and all kinds of barbarian troops from all over. Oh and Elephants still exist. The siege battles are also a big part of the game, which are also epic. Defender's advantage is highlighted in this game. Fighting on the walls, watchtowers, firing on advancing enemies, its all at the defender's advantage. You can't just march through enemy settlements capturing their cities with your countless cheap levies anymore. It requires much more strategy. Numbers wont mean a thing in siege battles in this game, and there have been times where i have held off a whole stack with just the garrison. 

4. This game does the campaign map right. Unlike other games where its always the same and stagnant, Attila changes it up a bit. The map is always changing. Fertility is a new factor which is dynamic and always changing. Climate change, razing of land by hordes, abandonment all affect this new feature. Another cool ability is religion. Now other TW games have had religion but this one is the best. First of all, the variety in religion is astonishing. There are 4 different types of Christianity if that tells you anything. And like 6 different types of Paganism. There are always events happening based on the year, which are always affecting your campaign. And diplomacy is badass. It borrows a lot from past games, but factions act more like themselves. The Danes are warmongering and always raiding. Huns are constantly sacking cities and obtaining tributes. It feels very real.

So like i said in the beginning, no games are perfect and this one has a few issues like:

Some units are pretty overpowered like Shock cavalry get a ridiculous 250 charge bonus which obliterated even armored spearmen
Javelins do WAY TOO MUCH damage
Huns cheat....just a bit...maybe more....ok maybe a lot.

But each of these can be balanced and fixed. like Shock cavalry have very little defense and will get slaughtered if they stay in combat too long. And javelins can be killed via archers, slingers, or cavalry. And the Huns cheating...well thats something you'll have to deal with or just use some mods.

So IN CONCLUSION, this game is good for newbies and experienced players alike, and offers a challenging and fun gameplay which will always keep you at the edge of your seat. 10/10 and DO BUY!!!!

Challenging, entertaining, deep, dark and probably one of the best Total War games released to this date.
I'm going to talk about the grand campaign map mostly so get comfortable because here I go:
Throat singing is op in this game, AI Attila is basically a cheater in god mode who only then manages to die when his mum cuts off his internet for obnoxious screaming in his room during a family dinner after he loses in combat 3 - 10 times despite his artificial advantage of being a unbeatable force. You can play as the man himself too, but don't expect the same kind of treats as the AI receives.
Best advice for beginners is to start as a small kingdom located in Scandinavia/Britannia/Africa/Asia as fast expansion and huge wide borders at the start are more than a crippling disadvantage and a major pain in the ass to manage. 
So for rookies, don't go for Western Roman Empire at the start, you find yourself uninstalling the game during the first 15 turns, it's really that depressing but you can get back to it once you're better at the game. 
Trade and diplomacy are really important, at first they seem overwhelmingly boring but as soon as you realize what advantage they bring, you get used to the system quickly. It's a fun system in my opinion, and sometimes the AI actually makes sense in their deals. Also, to really prosper in this game you have to learn how to micromanage your settlements. 
Planning ahead and balancing your settlements to be optimal as possible is crucial, as you can basically ruin everything for making just a few poor choices that didn't seem bad at first. You are able to migrate your people but it's really an escape button when everything goes wrong and you want to gain a second chance, or for situations where you want to cultivate more safe and nutritious lands than your current ones, maybe life off the land and surprise attack a kingdom you've weakened with your presence. You can fail at all of these, and it can cost you a new campaign start. Migration sure has it's ups and downs. There are even factions called 'great migrators' that have natural traits for being migrating people. 
Game also brings a scary message about climate change, and it shows as an exaggerated global ice age at some point in the campaign. So you REALLY need to plan ahead where to expand, how to manage resources, settlements, fleets and your armies. Keep an eye out for the nutrition values of the lands you own and plan to own as it gives an idea how big of an population/military you can sustain at the moment and in the future. Attrition warfare is brutal, make sure you prepare to use it in offense and defend your faction against it. 
The game also loves events and bringing plague to your lands so always have some food and gold in reserve. 
Family and court relations are important, always keep a guy in office you want and won't stab you in the back, be aware of their traits and skills and don't arrange marriages you won't benefit from, watch out for both women and men who like to perform adultery and make illegitimate bastards, it's bad for the moral. Plus make the best use of your governors skills in the settlements. Same goes with the generals, weed out the weak and unpleasant ones, get only the best men to lead your armies and prepare in advance to give your throne to a worthy heir. 
Make use of priests, spies and champions once you get them. Really, they are very useful.
With power and reach you become a threat to the other kingdoms. The bigger you are, the bigger the plots are going to be against you. 
This is where diplomacy comes to the action, don't make yourself a red glowing global target. Least you can do is to make yourself a valuable ally to some. 
You really need trustworthy allies beyond your borders so the front line won't be in your home, helping your allies defending is much more easier than fighting several enemies at once or trying to defend your lands alone.
You can try to be a lone neutral power but never a true one, as that requires trade and manipulation plus good luck that you won't get invaded just by the sole reason of existing. Get to know your neighbors, the game gives them random personalities and behavior when you start a new game so you can learn how to deal and work with them. 
Coordination with your allies is important too, AI can be dumb at times but it can help you greatly at times if you try to seek brothers in arms for your wars, especially when Attila grows to be an responsible adult and takes the charge of the Huns to fight global warming by waging war to every possible nation that crosses the terrible pathfinding of his armies. 
Attila focuses on bringing down larger empires, WR and ER being the first natural enemies so if you want to stay out of his way in your playthrough, don't ally Rome or be a large empire in middle of Europe, worst scenario is trying to provoke him as a small pagan migrator.
After you've learned the basics and advanced stuff of the game and at least finished one campaign where you have experienced the management of a large and wide empire, then you could try the WR and ER campaigns out with better results. But to be honest, you aren't given the most optimal start in either of those two. You ARE given the reigns of the two most powerful empires of that time, but at the same time you're given the reigns of two most powerful empires that are beginning to fall and degrade. 
You have to race against all odds thrown at you, in the WR one you're basically trying to damage control your overly expanded empire, with some of the lands completely isolated from your capital. Rebellion, famine, pagan lords and Attila are really testing you. Religion plays a big role in every playthrough, and if you're starting out as one of Romes I'd really check how much the church upkeep costs are and are they necessary while the very empire you're leading is crumbling down.
I'm yet experience the The Last Roman and Age of Charlemagne campaigns but at quick glance they seem to offer unique and interesting ways to play through them.
Tactical gameplay is very enjoyable and satisfying, UI is easy to use, everything works smooth and the numerous units that the game brings are fairly balanced, to a certain point at least. Learn hotkeys and how to group certain units together. Use their abilities and don't let your general sit far behind the lines where you can't use his presence to boost your troops combat skills. Be tactical. 
Naval combat is also a fun addition but it's not really where the game's strong sides are. 
The ground combat is great to be honest, and if you don't want to take part in every skirmish then the auto-solve works well enough to counter battles that are certain wins. Never auto-solve a battle you know you'll lose, you can do more damage to their numbers by actually fighting it real-time, sometimes you might even win against the odds. Never trust the auto-solve button when defending and attempting siege and absolutely never against Attila The Hun.
I recommend this game and hopefully this worked as both a review and a little tutorial how to approach this title, it's pretty different from other Total War games.
tl;dr version: Game is good in every aspect (minus the little swallow naval battles, artificially difficult Huns and some of the generic copy and paste kingdoms from the Slavic DLC), play and learn. Get good, then play some more.

I enjoyed the new horde mechanics, and this is probably the most difficult game I've played in the franchise. The increased unit morale also made for some intense battles as the AI would simply refuse to give up.

That said, the game has a couple of  issues. The cities seem kind of boring in their design, at least compared to some of the ones in previous games. Attila is also not well optimized for Linux. Using a GTX 1070 I was getting below 30 FPS at ultra settings and had trouble with flickering shadows that detracted from the overall experience.

Some say it's badly designed. Some say the Huns with respawn stacks are broken and a lazy mechanic. I say it's one of the few total war games where you can get royally F**ed if you are not careful. It is one of the more unique TW games in that respect. Horde mechanic and desolation were also something completely new to TW franchise.

Total war Attila is by far one of the most challenging total war games to date. The game is undeniably difficult and can and on many occasions cause you to reload a save or restart the game entirely. this is especially apparent when playing as the Western Roman Empire or Eastern Roman Empire.

The game is set in a chaotic period of wars, civil strife, climate change, political intrigue and corruption runs rampant. The Western Roman Empire is plagued by civil wars, corruption, wars, ineffective governors and poor administration. It becomes on the brink of collapse. Its made worst by migrating hordes of factions that range from germans, slavs, nordic and various nations running from the ever looming threat of the Huns that would later be lead by Attila himself.

The Eastern Roman Empire however, flourished well and have access to one of the richest provinces in its territories such as Aegyptus. (Modern day Egypt) Ruling from its new seat of power a new capital called Constantinople.(Modern day Istanbul)
Constantinople was considered a new Rome, a better Rome. While old Rome was neglected and its population reduced and nothing more than a cultural centre at best. Eastern Rome would be the more powerful Brother of the Western Romans. Even still your position is precarious as to the east, Romes's age Enemy, the Parthian empire is now under a newer management, The Sassanid Empire, and it seeks whatever opportunities to seize back the lands once belonged to the old Persian Empire, The Achaemenid Empire. To the north migrating hordes like the visigoth would sack your lands with ease if left unchecked.

You also get to play as African nations that had traded with Rome once before and yield to its power, now found itself with new opportunity to carve out newer kingdoms. 

Or play as the Huns led by Attila the Scourge of God. Renowned for their OP horse archer tactics they would cause terror to much of Europe. Surprisingly, the Huns have quite good infantry for some reason even through they're a mostly nomad horse faction.

The game focuses a lot on cavalry to win battles than before and the more emphasis is placed on your general not dying as a general dying would cause massive morale penalties that can cause a mass route. Spear infantry are also a lot more valuable to counter heavy cavalry tactics but spear infantry must brace well against the charge as collision without a proper bracing formation would cause mass routes.

The game is inherently more difficult you will find it rather challenging and you would realise that carving out an empire is a lot more easier than maintaining one. But if you want a more challenging total war game, this game would be great. Though for those who are not familiar with total war, its best to pick one of the easier factions as playing right of the bat the harder factions like The Western or Eastern Roman empire could overwhelm you pretty quick. I myself still struggle a lot with this game but its a challenging sort of fun.

I I was going to write a review of any game in my library at the moment, it would be this one. This game, despite minor performance issues with large battles and a serious lack of support from its developers, is an excellent addition to the Total War Historical series and its Late Antique setting is something that makes it unique and stand out amongst the myriad of military strategy games out there. It is enormous fun if masochistically punishing at times. Despite the lack of developer support in recent years, the community is broadly supportive and there are many mods out there that help fill the obvious gaps and inspire additional playthroughs. Don't play as East Rome though, unless you like getting shafted.

An underrated entry in the Total War franchise IMO. If only CA would come back to this game with one or two more updates to sort out its lingering problems, it would be a solid all-round Total War game.

Having been a customer and fan of the series since Shogun, I didn't hesitate to open the chapter of history that had most captured my imagination as a youth- the late classical era meets its demise when gladius and seax are drawn in desperation. This game is for the historical enthusiast who likes to daydream. 
Defend the Empire from the Godless hordes through means of bureaucratic and militaristic efficiency, or flip the script and lead from the front as a Barbarian Warlord, intent on showing those pompous Flavians that no border defenses will hold back the future... Seize the moment of opportunity as the ruling family of any number of long-overlooked satraps or kingdoms, and throw off the yoke of imperial servitude! Restore the glory of the Achaemenids as the House of Sasan rises to it's rightful place in the world. Or grab the reigns of the terrible and mighty Khans, and put the whole western world on it's heels. With an add-on or two, you can pretend you're Christopher Lambert as Vercingetorix.

The Western Roman vanilla campaign is an exercise in frustration, but it feels quite satisfying in the end to finally put an end to Attila and his rapacious huns. Not greatly optimized, but there are some interesting mechanics and town defenses are rather interesting (even if walled city sieges are decidedly toned down - half the time you feel like being in a big fortified city is more of a hindrance than a help - being able to turn off and/or direct the fire of automated defenses would be great as they are just as likely to wipe out your own troops as the enemy). All in all, not the best total war by far but if you are interested in the time periods on offer, well worth the buy and play time.

[h1]Average Score: [b]6.5/10[/b]
Personal Score: [b]B[/b].

Price: Worth, on sale.

[u][i]The Verdict:[/i][/u][/h1]
TW: Attila gave me a good time while playing, but it adds almost nothing new to the series. That, mixed with the essential content being thrown it sparse DLCs, I can’t recommend the game to anyone. There are cheaper titles with even more content and have similar mechanics, like Shogun 2 and Empire, and also there are newer better for casuals, like Warhammer 1 & 2 and the upcoming 3K, which you should be on the lookout.

[h1]I recommend buying it IF you...[/h1]
[list]
[*]Are familiar with TW series or have watched gameplay videos of this game
[*]Are looking for formation tactics based game
[*]Don’t mind a slower pace game that does not fit a work day
[*]Are mostly looking to fight rather than manage
[/list]
[h1]Dont buy it if you...[/h1]
[list]
[*]Don’t know nothing about these series
[*]Can’t stand CA bullshit policy on DLC
[*]Can’t stand scripted harshiness thrown at the player with a lack of level design plan
[*]Want an intricate, or at least good city management system
[/list]

[h1]Review averages:

General:[/h1]

[i]Note: I’m reviewing only the combat system of the game here. I think CA suck on city management, and Attila failed to deliver, as all other TW I’ve experienced, a good city managing system[/i]

[list][*][b]Mechanics: 8/10. I’ve gotta say as a newcomer to the series, battling was really addictive. [/b] I’ve played Medieval 2 before, but only on friend’s places. Decided to go for ATTILA after almost ten years later, and the combat system is something I’ve never seen. Choosing formation accordingly, building a balanced army and learning with your mistakes. It does it’s job here.

[*][b] Graphics/Interface: 7.5/10. Graphics are fine, and interface fits the game.[/b] It’s not exceptional though, and you need DLCs to have a wider range of variety, along with mods to get better textures.

[*][b]Content/Surprises: 6.5/10. While campaigns have some good challenges, the game feels too repetitive with a lot of different factions and settings.[/b] Also, there’s a constant need of scripted events to bring the “famine” and starvation feeling, hindering any concrete progress, leading to some frustration. Charlemagne DLC felt way better. 

[*][b]Lore/Story: 8/10. No complaints here, the game does have some historical accuracy, which fits my levels of exigency.[/b] Quests challenges you to change historical events, and scripted events try to follow their historical settings.

[*][b]Music/Sound: 6/10. There are some good SFX, but there are less speeches, and a lot of repeated noises. Music is bland and does not add to the experience.[/b]
[/list]

[h1]Extras:[/h1]

[list][*][b]Greediness: 4.5/10. This game is above average greedy. [/b]Instead of packing some good 2 to 3 DLCS, with a lot of content on each, the game breaks down into  8 DLCs, taking off basic features like BLOOD AND GORE, something you would expect from a game that it’s main factor is it’s realistic and immersive battles. Diversity of the game is only found after buying some good 6 DLCs. Really disappointing.

[*][b] Bugs and performance: 7/10. I have not encountered a single bug in my playthroughs, and that was a surprise.[/b] Maybe I’m much of a casual, but in my 60 hours of this game I have yet to experience a crash. 

[*][b]Worthiness: 5/10. DLCs could’ve been smarter, with a more fair content. [/b]The game is somewhat worth it, but I feel ripped off that I have to buy a separate DLC for blood and gore content. 
[/list]


[h1][i] Review Notes: [/i] [/h1]

Add that to the fact that the DLCs are money hungry, the overall game is just not worth it. Totally worth on sale though.

The game is great! The sieges are awesome, the combat is awesome and it is really challenging! The Ai cheats to make the game more difficult but if you are a good general you can win key battles. 
On legendary the battles are very agressive the enemy will rarely wait for you unless you are besieging a settlement, so the best tactic (on open field) is to always try to attract the enemy, with exactly 6 units of shock cavalry, I say attract because very rarely they will divide their forces, so their whole army will chase and you lead them to a position where your main army (infantry, archers) will be in formation and facing the enemy flank, then you push the flank and sacrifice 3 units of cav to hold the enemy cav and use the remaining to aid your infantry win the battle quickly. BUT if you have a decisive cavalry superiority eliminate the enemy cavalry first. Always try to have a supporting army with mixed troops close to you to change to the troops you need before entering battle. 
The campaign map is good but the problem that  ruins the game completely, fortunetely there are mods for this, is the population happiness, it is unreal the amount of rebellions you need to put to the sword. wich makes no sense because when I slaughter the rebels they keep coming back to be slaughtered again, I mean you should be able to put fear on the population, but no. It is in this types of details that the game really suffers, the lack of options, the lack of control you can have over your kingdom, wich is a shame because CA has the skill to fix this, but well, you cant always have everything right.

With ROME 2 having been a disappointment, ATTILA brings a second chance to conquer this era, and does it very well.

Diapers and wipes.

Nothing quiet soils your pants like defeating Attila, only to watch him return with an even bigger army.

Attila is, in my opinion, the best Total War.

A lot of people complain about optimization issues, I'm not saying they're lying, but I don't have these issues so it's not impossible to run the game properly.

What Attila does GREAT is giving you very different campaign experiences: you can pick from massive empires under pressure, small tribes with one settlement, small hordes that have to flee from the Huns and try to conquer some land and settle down, or as a massive horde that will grow, loot and pillage.

The battles are (or can be) rewarding as cavalry is super strong in this game, though also vulnerable, especially when pulling out of engagements. General deaths have a big impact here compared to most other TW's. Your tactics matter more than in for instance Rome 2 or Warhammer TW where the outcome of a fight relies more on stats and the stat differences between units are a lot bigger.

This is the last TW to date to have naval battles. While naval battles themselves are functional, but by no means excellent, joined ground- and amphibious assaults on settlements or simply land battles where the enemy is reinforcing from the sea are simply epic.

A lot of units have formations, special abilities or traits that are useful in certain situations, encouraging you to build a balanced army.

The AI is competent enough to be a threat (especially the Huns can be scary to fight), yet can still be outsmarted in ways that are rewarding to the player. The battles are fast-paced enough (unlike in Rome 2) to give you some challenge micro-wise, though it's certainly doable for less experienced players too on lower difficulty settings.

Settlements during sieges are very well-designed and protecting them as well as attacking them can be done in a variety of ways, and if you do it right you can avoid a lot of casualties. This requires some patience but can be very rewarding.

Setting buildings and trees on fire to demoralize and burn enemies is a thing unique to this Total War which I'm not sure why hasn't been implemented in future installments. Most importantly, it's fun here.

The time period is really interesting, as this is where the Western Roman Empire fell and Germanic tribes started carving out the kingdoms that eventually became the modern nations we know today. This plays off against the war in the East between the Eastern Roman Empire and the Sassanids (and their many vassal states), and the massive Hunnic invasion, which will be a good late-game challenge to keep your campaign interesting, since the AI isn't going to stop the Huns and as you grow your empire, they will almost inevitably show up at your doorstep.

I can also safely say that if you're looking for a challenge, you will find it here. Since they decreased the effect of corruption perhaps playing as either empire will have become easier since I first played the game, but in a lot of campaigns there is a lot you can do and the longterm strategic direction to take isn't clear cut. You have to carve your own path, make choices with pros and cons, and adjust according to changing circumstances (like decreased fertility or Hunnic invasions) throughout...

Family management is clean and simple, gathering and maintaining influence is important, encouraging you to use your faction leader and heir as a general (though also putting you at risk of losing them, which can have serious consequences), and you can take several actions within your court that can give you some advantages by spending influence. The only annoying thing here is that subjects can become really annoyed because you're appointing offices to 'lower ranked' people, and it's not always clear who's 'lower ranked'.

Generals have rewarding skill trees that help with upkeep, unit buffs, movement range etc. or (if they're governors) administration of settlements. Their effects aren't completely imbalanced like they are in Warhammer TW, though. While not immortal, their lifespans are long enough to get those heroic generals that create their own stories within the campaign, really become the standout characters in the story of your campaign, and potentially build a legacy (though, children die a LOT in this Total War).

The building tech trees are expansive and open up several options for maxing profits and generating the things you need (public order, sanitation, recruitment...). Religion plays an active part in the campaign as different religions each provide different bonuses.

The regular tech tree is split into military and civic improvements and is quite interesting because they give you useful advantages, but sometimes you might want to skip them to reach a more advanced tech faster. Again, your choices matter.

None of these 'extra's' are completely mandatory to do, but they can help you and they do add some depth to the campaign if you're looking for it.

The graphics are like a much more polished version of Rome 2, with darker and more realistic colours.

My one major criticism of Attila is that as you research units, the lower tier units become unavailable, and sometimes the upgraded unit is a very different kind of unit, and not necessarily better gold or efficiency-wise, and sometimes you just want some cheap troops. Their upkeep costs also tend to be quite high, often times more so than the unit can justify.

On the other hand, of course, this also helps keep your late game campaigns interesting since you will have stronger armies, but you can't spam endless stacks of elite troops and simply overwhelm everyone.

All in all I give Attila a 9/10.
The Total War Series is getting worse and worse...
The last great Total War game (actual RTS). Better than Warhammer 2 and three kingdoms.

Part 1
I tried out Rome 2 but I noticed I couldn't send units around the campaign map without generals. Sometimes I want to scout ahead of a main army with cavalry, or split up an army, or send a few units to a local garrison, or any number of things that require this ability. The inability to do something so simple, strategic, and historical boded so poorly for the game that I reckoned I wouldn't like it and had Steam refund it.

Part 2
Later I decided to try out Attila. I knew that horrible mechanic would be in this game, but I figured I could suck it up and maybe have fun. Nope. One of the first things I noticed is that there's yet another ridiculous, unfun, unhistorical, unstrategic, nonsensical, unrealistic, anti-freedom mechanic. This one has a name: "imperium", and it limits how many individual armies you can have at once. Good design would limit the number of troops you can field through mechanics like money, food, and population, not some vague, fantastical concept like "imperium".

Part 3
Months later, after a failed refund request, I gave the game another shot. I was going to play as Rome and try a strategy where I'd pull out of all provinces that aren't in Italy, and consolidate power there. Well guess what? You can't trade settlements in this game. You could in many of the earlier titles, but not here. So again I was told I'm not allowed to have fun and play the game how I want.

I must say I like this game a lot. Originally I purchased it during a sale, not thinking too much about it. For a long time, I expected it to be almost the same game as Rome II, but in a different time period. But how wrong I was... Yes, TWA is similar to Rome II in many ways, but it is also far superior in others. In fact, I would go as far as to say that this game is a direct upgrade of its predecessor. A lot of times, it feels as if someone took many the things that Rome II did in an annoying way, and fixed them.

First of all, let's just quickly go over the negative aspects, to get those out of the way:

[list]
[*] It's after all a Total War title, and naturally, there are a few bugs here and there. I won't (and quite frankly don't know if I even could) explain exactly what they are unless I wrote an entire book about it, but as far as I have been able to tell, it has not been anything game-breaking.
[*] Sometimes units don't quite behave like you would expect them to. And that applies both to the enemy AI as well as how your own troops seem to interpret your commands. Then again, it's a Total War title, and we all know that this is an issue with all those games.
[*] Naval combat feels overall lacking and not as immersive as you would expect. Contrary to that, I have seen people on YouTube praising the naval combat in this game, but personally, I don't quite see it.
[*] The game is quite hungry for graphics and performance, especially during large battles. It can of course be tweaked to improve performance, but it is worth to mention for users with a slower machine. I would probably not want to try this game on a laptop.
[/list]

Now, let's take a look at the positives:

[list]
[*] The political system is for once really interesting. Compared to Rome II's upgraded system, TWA has fewer options, but a lot more depth to each one. Instead of just pressing some buttons to increase your power and the loyalty of others, you must actually think a bit more about it, and balance things up. There are advantages, disadvantages and consequences from almost every action you undertake, and there is always a risk things will backfire at you.
[*] Building your cities will require more planning. Unlike previous games, where you only really needed to worry about public order, and later food, TWA also includes a measure of sanitation and squalor, which will affect the risk of disease outbreaks. In order to balance up those three, as well as maintaining growth, income and religious influence, you will quickly realize that you might need to compromise something.
[*] Siege battles in this game actually feel like sieges. For the first time ever in a Total War game, a siege will need actual planning. Your troops don't just magically receive ladders out of thin air. Furthermore, your towers will actually be useful in repelling enemy siege towers, battering rams and other siege equipment. Because of all this, the walls of your cities are truly useful, the archers work as a great defensive unit, and just as in a real siege, a smaller defensive force can be capable of holding off a much larger attacking force. Compare this with previous games in the series, where the city wall wasn't much more than a glorified obstacle.
[*] You have more control over how you manage your nation and your cities. Again, comparing TWA to Rome II, you can really tell how much more freedom you as a player have, to decide how events should play out. There are still certain limits based on which faction you play as, but to a lower degree than in Rome II.
[*] It's overall a more challenging game. For the reasons mentioned above, as well as a lot of other features that come into play, TWA has a much slower development and progression. After a certain number of turns in Rome II, you're likely to already be a full-fledged empire, dominating the whole world, with no threats left. After the same amount of turns in TWA however, you're likely to still be a small nation struggling to survive against your greedy neighbours and the migrating hordes.
[/list]

Best game in the franchise. It's complex and extremely punishing, but once you understand the basics it becomes addictive just in the attempt to survive for one more turn. You'll be chased around the continent by armies outnumbering you 5 to 1, you'll quell multiple rebellions every turn, you'll be declared war upon by literally the entirety of the east, and you'll love every second of it.

by the way optimization is absolutely awful and chances are that by turn 100 you won't give a s*** and go on to play 200 more.
Great game. I recommend this game if you love total war games, and also love a challenge.

This is a good game that is mired by unfortunate and persistent issues (AI, pathfinding issues, odd mix of units [some factions have a ton of variety, others are mostly cookie cutter units], among other issues). 

I had this feeling that the game was somewhat barebones in some ways that was not overwhelming/bad enough to steer me away from it, but was noticeable and annoying.

One major issue that plagued the experience was the seemingly useless/unnecessary variety of units that had identical stats. In other words, the "variety" was merely superficial, as units looked different/had different names, but were either identical or functionally were about the same.

Also, a huge annoyance was the seeming futility of ranged units. This really weakened the experience and made the use of ranged units unsatisfying/useful. Removing a core component like this was especially upsetting when so many factions are ranged heavy/focused (esp. the Huns).

However, the mod community has done a terrific job of building on the game and incorporating much needed features and tweaks. Age of Charlemagne campaign was MUCH better than the original game, particularly when modded (namely, Radious). 

Overall, I would recommend this (with mods, of course) to fans of the series, ONLY if it is on sale for $30 or less. I am very pleased with my purchase and enjoyed the game very much. However, this is partially because I paid less than half the retail price of $60 for the original, and maybe another $10 for AoC and the Desert Factions DLC.

Not much positive about this game. Some terrible design choices and mechanics in the game. Many positives about Rome 2 have been thrown out of the window.

Firstly the ranged infantry is stupidly powerful in the early game. Cheap slingers can rack up over a 100 kills each in a battle as if the levy shields are just holograms. Every volley decimates a unit and is even more extreme when javelinmen are used. In rome 2, which i like to compare, the ranged units work over time to get kills and slowly wear down the enemy. and would only be able to kill pikemen in the same way as standard infantry in attila. Part of the problem is the increased ranged infantry size to equal melee infantry while the cav has also increased. These 2 changes imbalance the game greatly.
   Some things make no sense. mercenary onager costs 1000 gold per turn but mercenary CELTIC onager costs 200?!?!
   Pikes are useless unless in very specific scenarios and 1v1 against standard units head on can actually lose, charging is always more beneficial than forming a shield wall.
   Public order is a nightmare to deal with. Ive had immigration penalties of up to -18 with -4 and -4 for tax and difficulty. Yet another unnecessary difficulty to deal with.

My main problem rests with the hordes and the huns. probably worst kind of difficulty i have ever experienced in a game. 
-I only discovered the counter late in the game which is large onagers. Other than skirmishers in siege battles the only thing that can touch the hunnic horse archers are explosive rounds; arrows and sling stones will maybe kill a couple of horses due to the extreme armour. These units are so OP its unreal. They fire like machine guns and a spam of them can easily defeat any standard army. Most foot archers are garbage
-Once you begin the inevitable war with the huns there will be 4 20 stacks in your land at any given time. Any army you destroy will be replaced with a new one next turn. Any army you damage will fill up with mercenaries immediately, meaning you are actually better off leaving some enemies alive. Most armies are identical in terms of units present. All units are tier 2 and 3 while early on all of yours are tier 1 and 2. Horse archers will each get 150 kills per battle without fail unless large onagers are used.
- There seems to be no way to defeat the huns once on the back foot. They do not play the same game as the player and just ruin the game, making the map a mess in the process. Unless you have a good start away from the huns on normal difficultly and have access to large onagers you will get in trouble quickly
- the army travelling ability is ridiculous. 1 army in ur land will outrun all your armies and all the while be razing ur land. ridiculously unbalanced

Edit- a few extra issues ive come across.

Rank experience system is awful. Somehow you can recruit units of 7+ XP but they will always decrease in rank no matter what it seems. Really frustrating mechanic which should be the other way round.
Converting enemy settlements costs over 10k every time, ridiculously expensive.
Rebels seem to get the best units including large onagers every time even if you arent capable of producing them.
Battles are based very heavily on counters and stat based- like chess with the matchups between certain units. Axe units get discriminated against in autoresolve far too harshly.

I've played Total War games for some time and I genuinely have not had as big an issue with their games as this one. The game has been out for sometime and it's still so poorly optimized that it takes several minutes just to go through a roll of one turn. The unit movements are clunky, the game lag somehow gets worse with each update, and CA seems to spend no time trying to fix the game, not improve, but fix. Overall, I regret purchasing the game based on its optimization alone. As a game its mechanics are great, the story line is crisp, and it has hours of fun packed in, which is why I'm so frustrated with how unplayable its become.

Pros
   -dark and gritty that fits the time period
   -basic total war gameplay elements

Cons
   Let me tell you a story about the game studio Creative Assembly. It was a promising studio. They gained the confidence of a customer by creating Shogun 2. It was an optimized and simplistic Total War game that was fun. As Todd Howard said "It just works". The next addition to the Total War franchise Rome 2, did not gain the confidence of the customer. He did not buy it because it was unoptimized and crappy on its release. The customer  had some confidence left for Creative Assembly and waited for the next release. Back at Creative Assembly, they thought of the next release. "Shit" said Creative Assembly, "Lets create a new game that is basically Rome 2 but with big baddie Huns and burning shit." And so they did.
   The unsuspecting customer was sold by this sales pitch. He bought the game full price at 60 dollars. "No way they would release unoptimized and unfun shit after the Rome 2 debacle." said the customer. When he opened it, he found it was unoptimized and full of unfun shit. The game looked horrible, Shogun 2 a four year old game, looked way better on lowest settings and its fps wasn't shit. Unit variety could only be described as a copy pasta. Battles were way too long and clunky. Sanitation was/is still an annoying mechanic. But wait a minute, with this new razing settlement feature you can burn the heathens who forgot how to take a fucking bath. Only its really used by the Huns cause resettlement takes too much time and money. Defeating multiple stacks of elite Hunnic armies gets rewarded with instant respawning of the same Hunnic armies. The customer said, " Jesus, have I really spent this many hours on this game? Well, it could be because of the long ass useless garrison battles and way too long kill times of units. Plus, I didn't even get to play the game for the majority of the time spent. I spent most of the time waiting out the end turn so i can get a win as one faction. " The customer revisited the game four years later and he saw this game was still an unoptimized and unfun piece of shit.

Please don't buy this game.

This game is an improvement over it's predecessor.  Family tree is a bit improved and diplomacy makes a bit more sense.  The ability to raze and abandon cities is a neat new wrinkle, adding a bit of excitement to the game.  The horde system adds a ton of flexibility. 
         It is still plagued by issues that the developers can't ever seem to fix.  Your units can never break contact without losing 1/2 of their strength.  Retreating, either at the tactical or strategic level, is effectively impossible (your men will withdraw in a manner that best ensures their deaths).  The family tree while improved, is chalk full of bugs.    They've also added a few bugs in the tactical level too.  If you order a charge, half the time your units will slow to a crawl (I've nicknamed it the 'death charge', it's as if your men have a death wish.)   But this is a Total War game and thus represents one of the best strategy games available. All in all I'd cautiously recommend this game, but only if it's on sale.

This game is my favorite Total War game behind several older titles like Medieval II, Rome the first, and there are several reason why.

The first of those is the fact that the HUD isn't really in aggressive tones of colors, unlike its counterpart of Rome II (I will draw a lot of comparison with that one). People might complain about the lack of color, but all in all I believe that a tame HUD makes for a less tiring experience visualizing your infrastructures and armies and immersing yourself in the game better.

The second is the unit cards, which are superior to the convoluted and vague one of Rome II. This is the big drawback in the Age of Charlemagne expansion, which pretty much killed my playing intent and made it very hard to visualize easily what my unit composition in my armies were; in Attila, you can directly visualize in-game engine rendering of your units on their unit cards, making it rather easy to read. The same can almost be said of the buildings. While some buildings are represented in-game, most of them have unique cards that are also rather easy to visualize, making for an extremely good, speedy time at managing regions, provinces, and armies overall.

All in all, the presentation of this game is miles better than Rome II, and while Rome or Warhammer fans have adapted themselves to the simplistic HUD, I can say with confidence that this game instead seeks to attract other audiences than the usual players by making the game more user-friendly; which is a shame, considering how lowkey it is.

The gameplay is what we expect of a Total War game, with some new features that are now commonplace as of Warhammer : Total War : settlement damage and horde mechanics. Hordes are essentially cities fused with armies : good offensive potential, but provide with a fragile economy and defense requiring you to always be at war and running from your more powerful enemies. Settlement damage reduces the moral of the defenders the more the settlement is "burned", with a completely destroyed settlement essentially insuring the defenders will break almost at contact with their foes.

The campaign objectives were rather fun to complete, althought I'm sad there wasn't a more casual mode without them. The meat of the subjects are the mechanics.

Attila is played on a span of fifty five years (from 395 to 450), divided in four seasons each (a turn in game term), and this timespan is divided in several "periods", which provide for faction objectives rewarding you with gold if completed, and a fertility decrease for every period reached in the game to signal the worsening climate :
WAR (They made ready for war) : 395-400 AD
This era is the prologue of this game. Fertility is at its normal value, you're introduced to the starting position of your and your neighbors factions, establish alliances (hopefully for the rest of the game, as the Imperium mechanic decreases your chances of getting any later on)), pillage the rich Roman cities for cash, or plain just develops and defend if you're far from Rome, or are Rome itself.
FAMINE (Darkness and Despair) : 400-420 AD
This era introduces you to the harsh reality that the world is changing and your starting province might not be the best to cling to after the fertility got down. This period will see players migrate en masse if they want to survive toward the rich fertility regions (Spain; Africa; Italy).
This period also sees the Huns grow from being a minor annoyance with three hordes to a growing problem. Huns will begin to actively takeover minors and devastate anything in their paths. While still not armed with the best units, their sheer numbers and horse archers make them hard to counter for the unprepared. Worse, the Huns cannot be destroyed until Attila is killed two times in battles, and Attila hasn't even grown to be general yet.
West Rome begins to fall apart during this time period usually.
DEATH (Abandon all hope) : 425-Basically until Attila kicks the bucket
This time period is what the game has been building up to. Tens of hordes of Huns move westward en masse, one led by Attila and a whole bunch of elite Hunnic cavalry and artillery that will smash any army not properly armed for the confrontation. East Rome will have a massive challenge trying to survive this period, and any Imperium you've built better have walls around each and every town, because otherwise only your large cities might remain in Legendary difficulty.
Killing Attila requires you to defeat him and wound him twice on the battlefield, after which the Huns will collapse under powerful debuffs. After the Hunnic Horde is destroyed, the world is basically yours to conquer. Knock yourself up, you've survived the Scourge of God, after all.

All in all, the campaign is fun times, even after you replay it.

SCORE
Overall I give this game a WARRIORS, EAGER FOR BLOOD! out of HEAVEN CAN WAIT, or in laymen's term, 9/10. Seriously, check the voice lines in this game, it's like you've entered a world of hammy boasts worst than JoJo's. This game is the only Total War game since Empire I can safely say that I've genuinely enjoyed, and I regret none of it. Has some excellent mods for people who are tired of the vanilla experience, but I'm not bringing them into the rating.
The campaign is more like just trying to survive instead of conquering the world. Which is the whole reason I feel in love with total war.

For background, I have thousands of hours across the older TW titles, but haven't purchased one myself since Attila, which is roughly around the time I began to rapidly lose interest in the franchise and its practices. In fact, I was so dorked out on the originals that I would even carry a notepad on me, where I could write down my invasion plans for when I got home from school/work, whatever I was doing. 

One of my favorite things about the older titles was the well-written essay you could get by right-clicking on any of the units or buildings in the game. As a history buff, these older titles were true treasures in my life. I legitimately felt like I was becoming a better, wiser, more knowledgeable, and more analytical person from playing them. It felt like I was getting a substantial history lesson of the given period all while having a great time, which was a dream come true. 

Rome 2 was the beginning of the end. Granted, I have 500+ hours in it, but from the start it was a buggy, un-optimized mess. When they eventually released the Emperor Edition overhaul I noticed a tremendous change in the AI, for the worse. The AI stopped playing by the game's own rules, imposing artificial difficulty into everything you did, and I'm almost certain cheating in the process. They tried to pass it off as 'balance', when in reality, just like in the real world, the country with the most money just happens to dominate much of the landscape. Example of the artificial difficulty: the card says some terrible event has a 1% probability of occurring, yet it fires every 3-4 turns like clockwork? I'm no mathematician, but isn't that a statistical impossibility?

In the past few titles and beginning with the release of Attila, it just feels like I'm that guy mindlessly sitting at a slot machine in Reno, where the house always has the upper hand, but lets you have just enough of a taste to keep you dumping money in. It's just so mindless now. Everything I considered beautiful about this series has been stripped out, and with no hope in sight of it ever returning until they get rid of their executives and start over. I'm sure I can speak for all of us when I say that we would prefer updated versions of old titles using the exact same mechanics. Just think, Medieval 2 or Empire more or less in their exact form, only with fully up to date graphics, and some new historical battles thrown in...

CA, Three Kingdoms is your last chance. Push the release back again if you have to, but don't miss the shot.

I just sunk another 80 hours into RTW and RTW:BI and loved them so I thought I'd give some of the post-MTWII games another go. I want to like the later Total War games so much, but I can't stand the region system, the HUD design is Byzantine and ugly, there's no way to game the AI to crush enemies even on the easiest settings (which I enjoy), the character pop-ups are hideous and confusing, the building system is trashy garbage, all of the fun historical information about units is totally hidden and peripheral rather than being an integral part of the game. Even the fonts are terrible. On and on it goes.

Sure the battles are gorgeous, but the thing that made the earlier games good to me was that, in addition to fun battles,  they ALSO integrated enjoyable RPG elements ("Oh, no My general has become a catamite/raging alcoholic/looney tunes!" rather than this dull, homogenous +/-% icon crap) , the city management was fun (the city actually opened up when I clicked on it rather than being this cruddy little box of icons at the bottom of the screen that hasn't changed through 5 games), and the map felt visible, rather than cluttered (it's a MAP, guys, come on! I don't need to see every tree, let's see the forest through the trees). 

Now the people are gone, the feeling of grand geography is gone, the feeling of specific cities is gone. The obsession with photo-realistic trees and proper unit movement on 3D terrain has completely obliterated any sense of good design and left no room for imagination. In the earlier games battles were a last resort, when I couldn't trust my AI general to wipe out 2600 Lombards with 150 horses--now they're basically the only thing that's left. You've got it all wrong.

I will never buy another Total War game until you go back to the roots of a well-rounded, uniquely rich world that crosses over between different genres (It used to be Civ+StarCraft with a splash of Final Fantasy and some wacky, enjoyable history lessons).

Seriously, take RTW or MTWII, update the graphics, don't change ANYTHING else, and I'm sold, over and over.

After several years and 400+ hours I suppose its fair to give a review.

This game is to Rome 2 what Napoleon was to Empire: A separate game that is basically an expansion/conversion of the original. A key difference between this and Rome 2, however, is that campaign plays significantly differently. Especially if you are playing as a roman faction, it is a weird blend of a survival game and grand strategy, as you fight off invading barbarians, infighting allies and the climate itself. Playing as Western Rome is a genuine challenge! I prefer to play as one of the smaller factions and build my way up, and some factions have very cool and historically relevant perks that differentiate them. My favorite are the Ostrogoths, who can recruit roman units from captured roman cities (the ostrogoths would go on to rule italy for a few hundred years!). When Attila shows up the Huns are a formidable challenge (Hun units are ridiculously OP in all troop categories, including heavy infantry, which is not exactly a hallmark of steppe nomads), and you have to kill Attila himself a few times before he actually dies and the hordes dissipate. If the huns come to your part of the map, expect an epic couple of turns. It is also possible to play as a faction that never encounters the huns due to map position - the Persians, for instance, get off scott free.

To touch on the battles, it terms of concept and controls it's the same as Rome 2, but the stats under the hood are quite different. Cavalry is extremely OP in this game vs. Rome 2, in part owning to historical reasons (the invention of the stirrup, for one thing) but mostly due to statistical spam. A low-tier scout cavalry unit with barely any attack or armor will still devastate most infantry, even in a frontal charge, because of the ridiculous amount of health and mass given to the horses. I get that cavalry was an important and dominant force, but it's too much. [In the course of its continual updates, CA decided it would be cool to give a certain Alani cav unit a charge bonus of zero, perhaps to reduce this effect, but that doesn't make any sense!] 

Meanwhile most infantry units have rather low attack values - Roman infantry is particularly weak, adding to the challenge factor!  - thereby putting a higher emphasis on armor and combined arms effectiveness. There is more emphasis on special troop formations to increase their unit's mass to counter the effects of incoming charges, which raises the stakes for troop positioning and battlefield selection. In a certain respect this is an improvement over some dynamics you'd see in Rome 2, where a few OP infantry units could mow down an entire enemy army if given the chance to do so. In Attila you need a more balanced army.

I'll save my hard criticism for the game engine. This game is TERRIBLY optimized. Most TW titles have their issues but this one chugs on a machine that can flawlessly handle Rome 2 at max settings at 60fps. They don't look that different! There should not be such a gap in performance. Also the lighting in Attila is sometimes broken - especially when you are in or near city walls! At this point, don't expect any fixes. It's been 4 years.

Overall I appreciated my time with this game. If you see it on sale I recommend you check it out if you're up for a total war experience with a different take on the campaign.

This game is a steaming pile of s**t. Its like a massive downgrade from Rome2. The gameplay is the same as R2 but thats where the equivication ends. The visuals are nasty, as despite technically having the same graphics as R2 they ruin it with a horrible dark orange filter and various overly dark daytime weather effects. While the aim of this is to create a foreboding apocalyptic atmosphere it just ends up looking like someone messed up the color schema. There isn't much variation in the way of unit appearances either. 

Now for the worst aspect of this game, the cities/settlements (or more accurately the lack thereof). Much of the beauty of R2 was its various unique and detailed, cities. The scale and layout of the various metropolis was a joy to play through and sieges where undoubtedly the highlight of the game. Attila is massive downgrade in this regard as it uses the same generic wooden structures/tents for most population centers, and merely reutilizes a handful of the same stone models for the major cities from R2 (only showing them in a decomposed form in order to be ''historically accurate'' and fit the ''atmosphere'' ect.). One could be forgiven for thinking that the developers used the era the game as an excuse to downgrade. In short, the whole thing stinks of a cynical cashgrab. Another zero effort project running off R2s frame that became successful through a massive ad campaign, connections to the gaming journalism cartel, rigged Youtube algorithms and innumerable fake reviews purchased from established PR firms (who hold a great many Steam accounts).

Thankfully there is a solution ie. the modding community. Download and install the 1220 medieval wars overhaul. Its essentially Medieval 3, with a plethora of impressive new unit models, revamped cities/castle forts and even its own soundtrack. The gameplay and campaign dynamics are also improved. Weather your establishing papal supremacy in Saxony or retaking Constantinopol is truly is a joy to play. The guys who produced it (in their spare time for free) deserve a massive pat on the back. They suprassed what the devs over at creative assembly where paid to do and should be working on the next TW imo. 

Unfortunately however the franchise seems to be in a downward spiral. The focus has drifted away from large scale projects and steady improvement towards the sporadic regurgitation of old material through rebranding techniques. Little originality has emerged since R2 or Shogun 2. The new Three Kingdoms game (which had massive potential on a conceptual level) looks to be little more than a cheap remix of Shugun2, just as Attila was a cheap remix of R2. This trend towards cashgrabs is also reflected in the constant stream of low quality DLC that we see emerging (much of which is inferior to the work of the modding community in the workshop). So in closing i would say dont buy this game unless you intend to use it for 1220, in which case its worth it.
