At first, I was extremely disappointed with this game. However, after several years of patching and dls's have passed I find this game an extremely entertaining experience. 

+ Very good music. Overall sound is so good I'd say it's easily one of the best in TW series. 
+ It runs pretty well in comparison with TW WH on gtx 1080. I never had more than 60, and most of the time less than 40 in WH series, and Rome 2 worked pretty underwhelming on high-end cards due to 2gb vram limit. This game runs on 4gb vram and is well optimized now, so I can have strong 50 in the most bloody city assaults with the entire map burning. 
+ It has a ton of cool mechanics (even revolutionary for the series, I'd say) on strategic map, like sanitation, climate change ect. It's a worthy addition to the game and I hope it will stay in further titles. 
+ It might be the best vanilla temp of battle I’ve seen since Med2 (set aside WH series, it’s whole another deal). It’s fast, but allows a plenty of room for maneuvers and strategy, no units seem owning too much. Though it’s debatable as 100% mounted armies of Huns and pikemen do deliver insane amounts of pain, they are very counterable with enough of skill and patience to sacrifice your best troops for a decisive victory (which Imho is pretty realistic). 
+Imperial campaigns are a very interesting experience, that’s quite different to what you’d feel in any other TW game. It’s the only time in Total War when you start as a late game steamroll machine and go deeper and deeper in meat grinder. WRE campaign is insane, ERE is somewhat calmer, but is quite far from boring as well. There’s no such thing as it was in Rome 2 when you’d just build several legions in your calm Italian corner and rectify the entire world with them 150 years BC. Now you have deal with deadly threats every turn, and the incoming hordes give you little space to breathe. For example, with prices only slightly higher than these in Rome 2, you’ll spend 10k at least and it would hardly provide for the basic survival. 
+ Carlmagne campaign is a very decent experience. It is pretty much a title in a title. 
- Dlc nations are crap. Most barbaric rosters are too similar, and northern roster is just a joke. That’s a HUGE – to CA.
- Graphics are fine, but no particular progress since Rome 2. Fire is cool though
- Ai is easy to stuck and gets extremely dumb. It works all right when it’s doesn’t bug, though. 
- Hordes are not as fun as I’d wish. They are mostly: sit until a date and then go rekt Rome.

In conclusion I'd say that It's now deffinitely a worthy addition to the title, but I'd save on those DLCs, as they don't bring that much content.

Poor coding aside (add all the dlc and take a nap waiting for a turn to end) the interface and gameplay are just terrible.  Having only played Shogun 2 (I'm guessing one of the top tier total wars since it's just good design) this is just pure torture to attempt to play.   Sloggy micromanagement, poor research trees, petty politics, dumb realism (vikings get seasick and lose half their health... wut?  are you f***ing kidding me?) and maps that are far too big for essentially a RISK type game of land management.  It just feels like they hired a very knowledgeable historian and 3 bad lazy coders with no art direction or interface personnel.  The actual warfare part, which is supposedly the selling point of this, is laughably rendered.  I tend to play for the tactical side of these but this is just bad on every level. In the game, since you cannot store food, you go from huge food surpluses to famine in one turn and this happens ALL THE TIME. Honestly the game is decent but there are so many things that need to be polished IMO and I would just get Shogun 2 instead of Attila.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

Total War: ATILLA is a game developed by The Creative Assembly and published by SEGA and forms part of the Total War series

The game offers some pleasant graphics and really vibrant colours, although some ugly glitches here and there, it is pleasant all the same

The game does suffer with some repetitiveness at certain areas of the game but a fun game nonetheless

Total War: ATILLA overall, however, is a fun game to play, yet sometimes flawed, but is a great grand strategy game to play in short bursts!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

[*] None

Great if you have loads of time. Although in 3 hours of gameplay all i have been able to achieve is taking 2 settlements then constantly defending my 3 settlements from attack with 2 armies. Never having any money to spend on improving anything because i always spend all the money i have repairing the 1 settlement which doesn't have an army defending it.

I'm sure if i persevered for another 10 hours it might level out but not sure i can be bothered.

Total war, that's what this game is about. the fall of the Roman Empire and the waves of armed migrants being pushed west on to lands where local populations are trying to establish themselves and expand. Then Attila is born...

This is a great game! Not perfect and maybe not even my favourite game in the Total War series (Medieval II and Napoleon are also in my top three). There is more emphasis on domestic management in this game, both in keeping finances balanced through city management, and making sure your family had enough influence to keep other nobles loyal through dynastic management. In order to build high level units cities have to be upgraded to high levels which is an expensive and time consuming endever, but almost essential to have late game. Religion plays a major role and converting new cities can sometimes be more problems than its worth. 

When it comes to the battles, they are solid but the balance for auto battles is sometimes off (in my opinion). If you like other Total War games I think you will like this game. I ended up loving this one and it is solidly in my list of my top three favourite TW games.
I guess this game is fun till you lose your first army and you quit the game and never come back

For me, this is one of the best entries in the Total War series. Haven't played Warhammer 1 & 2 though, since I prefer actual historic settings over fantasy. So can't compare it with those.

As the sequel to Rome II, it shares a lot of gameplay mechanics and features with its predecessor. Some improvements have been made, notably regarding family and loyalty management which isn't as frustrating as in Rome II.

The biggest difference for me, however, is the overall feel and difficulty of the game. Rome II looks nice and friendly and plays nice and friendly. It's only difficult at the very beginning, after that, it's a piece of cake.

Attila has this constant feeling of impending doom and devastation that comes with CA's interpretation of Late Antiquity (admittedly debatable). But it's good for the game. The difficulty is much, much higher and - depending on your faction - can last into the endgame due to the ever-respawning huns, the famines and massive immigration and religious difference penalties. This, of course, is especially true for the Western Roman Empire, which was the most fun challenge for me by far. That being sad, I thin I don't remember a single time I ever had to worry about public order in Rome II.

So if you liked Rome II but thought it was too easy and tame, try out Attila.

Compared to Rome 2, this game is somewhat better. But I do recommend since it has many features I do like. The survival aspect this game presents feels very unique. It is also very difficult when compared to Rome 2, and other releases, since the AI cheats more and is less cautios and peaceful than you'd like. My favorite feature this game offers though is the fact that you can burn settlements in combat and it affects the defender's morale. The Culture Pack DLCs and Blood & Burning DLCs do make the game feel more empty. But the Campaign DLCs do feel like actual DLCs instead of a lazy money making practice that devs. do nowadays, in which they make something that is a mod or a simple patch for the game and put a price tag on it. All in all, I recommend Attila as a TW game.

I don't think it's a clone of Rome 2, it settings feels completely different - dark, as if a storm is closing in; the fire, the devastation... It's much harder than Rome 2 and you can't just autoresolve all battles unless you vastly outnumber the enemy. I've won some pyrrhic victories with 3:1 chances against me, while autoresolve would give me decisive defeat. I also like new mechanics in politics and diplomacy. I like to take my time through the Grand campaign and manage and optimize my provinces to the best I can. It does make turns very slow as I play as the Easter Roman Empire and for over 30 hours of gameplay I'm only on turn 50, but I like slowly building up my empire. What I don't like at all and it makes turns even slower than they need to be is watching literally dozens of factions take their turn for 3-5 minutes. It really adds up. But overall I enjoy the title, just wish I had more time to focus and play it :/

It took me years to actually ease into this game and now in the year of our lord 2018 I have finished the grand campaign as the Western Roman Empire.

I hated the infinite stacks of tier 1 units from the Huns coming from the east. 
Until I learned to love the immersion. 
I realized a VIDEO GAME is making me stressed out from the threat of demons coming from nowhere. 

That is historically accurate in terms of fear of horse archers coming from the unknown steppe.

The ancient peoples felt the same except for real so like their gods abandoned them when the Scythians, Huns, Mongols etc. rolled around from nowhere creating mountains of bones and devastating entire regions that never recover.

With that mindset I took to the game in a colder calculated approach abandoning entire regions and retreating back to Italy. I cared little for the "barbarians" and less so for the rebels. I sold men by the thousands. 
I abandoned catholicism altogether and let the gods free for all under my pragmatic eyes. Let the dominant religion claim victor without bloodshed, let the real god reign I say. It matters little for the impending doom for any after life will undoubtedly have no room for any more lives when the horse arrives.

Suffice to say I clacked up some legions and held my forts against impossible odds time and time again. I even staged an offensive and reclaimed the iberian peninsula, gaul, and brittania. 
At some point in the game I only had rebels and the huns to deal with which was hilarious because that's when Atilla spawned and I spanked his bottom like a naughty little boy. I spanked his bottom red yes I did. 

There is little a horde of horse archers can do against artillery, and crossbowmen that hide behind the spearmen. It's a tried and true tactic that. 

The game is not easy at all but I hate my fucking life so I welcome hard games. And this one was really hard. But here we are. Empty once more. Good night Sweet Prince. Good night Atilla.

Most people hate the vanilla game, but I find the time period to be really interesting. You can play as a barbairian tribe and carve out a new kingdom for yourself or play as the Romans or Sassanids and try to survive the changing world. You can also get DLC that brings the game to the times of Justinian and Charlemagne. If that isn't your thing just get it on sale and then mod the living hell out of it. There's mods that take this game back to the Rome and Rome 2 era, the middle ages, and theres a Lord of the Rings mod currently being developed. I think that's a big reason why CA seems to refuse to optimize or update this game. Most of the community isn't playing content CA made for the game but content made by the community instead. I'd give this game an 7/10. Only becaue of the lack of updates and the confusion modding it sometimes causes.

This is probably the most challenging total war game I have played. 

Total War: Attila throws you into a world in turmoil where everyone's trying to survive and conquest is the last of your worries. Campaign mechanics are more complex where you have to manage religon, sanitation, food, growth, public order, army integrity, loyalty, political control and others that I've forgotten for now. 
This makes for a more enjoyable experience imo but it can make it super hard, especially with the AI doing stuff it perhaps shouldn't along with a few bugs that probably won't ever be fixed outside of mods. 

The graphics are OK but the performance is terrible, even for a total war game, and I feel this has dampened my experience somewhat.

Overall, I'd recommend picking this game up on sale if you enjoy total war games and want a bigger challenge but be wary of its many flaws and issues that CA has neglected to fix.

I haven't played that much yet,
but what disturbs me the most so far is, the taxes are controlled for the whole fraction, not for provinces or cities, but food is controlled only for every province and it seems you can't even shift this around. Meaning, rebuilding a ruin leaves you with negative food and thus, negative public order and you can't counter this with taxes properly, because you'd loose your taxes in other provices as well...
That's just plain BS.

I also dislike the whole campaign concept... tried the prolog and did what they told me, left the game with ~-90 public order, -20 food.. building more food production increases poverty, which you have to counter with sanitarity, but there are almost no buidlings for that...

Then I tried an easy campaign with the longbears, it was considered "easy". You start with 2 people liking you, but refusing any diplomacy with you. It's said, you should fight the vandals, which may give you a chance to form an alliance with the franks or allemanns, but yea, they are behind the allemanns border, and you're not allowed to pass it, genius.
You got no food income, and no real enemy at that point (which is probably the easy part).
Most buildings (at least beginning at lv2) increase negative stats, but you don't have any building to counter those, which mens you can't even improve. 
I then fought someone else, and conquered their city, it was in the same province as mine and I could produce food there, so yay, for that. I later accepted the peace treaty for some gold, and they plundered my province, because, they can do it?
Now, two or three 'enemy' armies are walking through my territory as they wish, and I can't start a fight with them, because they all have a defensive alliance with another fraction.

what's next is, you start out with Tier 0 soldiers, weak health, weak armor, half of them weak armor piercing or low arrow blocking. Some enemies start with Tier 1 soldiers who beat all my soldiers... I though the best start would be to get 2-3 of each different soldier, to have some varity, but I had a fight, where almost all of them had no chance against most of the enemies soldier, who also had a variety in his army.


I loved Shogun 2 and I'd like Warhammer 1 if it weren't for those stupid "random stuff happening(playing as a dwarf, you get random objectives like "fight fraction x" and this fraction is on the other side of the map..., playing as chaos, was fun, until that commander of Tzeentch spawned in the middle of the norscan area, with an additional army for each of my own) and 2, if those campaigns objectives wouldn't be so big (mortal empire: conquering I think 140/295 settlements)

But from what I've seen so far from this game, it's the worst I've played so far.

Don't buy it, the game is not optimized and runs like hot garbage. I have a 2700X and gtx 1070 and can barely crak past 30s. Get Rome 2 or better Shogun 2. 

Also I made the mistake of pre-ordering the game. Don't be like me, don't pre-order.

I recommend this game highly. I spent a good few hours conquering England as the Saxons and it was some of the best TW that I've ever enjoyed. However, when I watch a replay of some of the battles, it hurts to see so many women dying on the battlefield. Wait - I'm a semi-nomadic people struggling for survival in a brutal world - why am I sending women out to fight with my line troops? And not one or two but so many of them? In short, I recommend this game if you don't zoom in on your soldiers in replays or during battle for cinematic effect.

This is a very faithful recreation of Rome: Barbarian Invasion.  Its dynasty and office mechanics are remaniscent of Rome, but improved.  It's graphics are on par with the other TW's of this generation.  Unlike Rome 2, Shogun and Warhammer, where troops clump and then do nothing, the fighting seems improved (albeit not nearly as fluid as the original Romes... I know game development is tough, but given the resources I'm a bit surprised this hasn't been mastered yet.)  P.S. TW series would benefit from having difficulty levels effect AI competence, rather than increasing the amount of AI cheats.  To be a strategy game it should be a level playing field; allowing AI to create materials out of thin air is bullshit.

At release this game was like a massive patch to Rome 2. The campaign gameplay is probably the best in any total war game since it features a fully fleshed out city management and politics system. No idea why they completely scrapped it in the warhammer games. The battles are ruined by cavalry, which is both very powerful in this game and spammed by the AI, turning many battles into blobfests where my cavalry blob fights their cavalry blob. Graphics are great however they're only marginally better than those in Rome 2 yet require twice the GPU power.

Campaign Pros:
-Best campaign mechanics in a total war to date. 
-City management is fun and varied especially compared to the warhammer games. Coming back from those it was especially refreshing to have options other than a generic money building or generic public order building. 
-Politics is fully fledged out. 
Campaign Cons: 
-Razing mechanics and the approach of a mini ice age turn the map into a nuclear wasteland by midgame complete with a nuclear winter. The razing burning animation even looks a little like a nuclear fire.

Battle Pros:
-Infantry fights are slower paced and you actually have time for maneuvers. 
-AI is competent. 
Battle Cons:
-Cavalry is ridiculously OP, where any unbraced infantry unit will take 50% casualties in 10 seconds from a cavalry charge. 
-AI builds armies that are 50+% cavalry and 30% skirmishers. This turns the line of battle into the dots of battle since AI armies frequently have just 2 melee infantry units. 

Other:
-Music is underwhelming consisting of barebone instrumentals and tribal chants.
-Graphics are pretty.
-The burning of towns during sieges and the landscape being set on fire by incendiary weapons is cool.
-Setting is arguably less interesting than classical antiquity. That said it tackles a frequently ignored period of history so the novelty is definitely a plus.
Best TOTAL WAR game in the series (with the exception of the original rome total war, but that hurts my eyes to play nowadays).

Total War Attila is essentialy a resking of Rome 2, without the crushing bugs at release. The game has a few new mechanics over Rome 2, such as fertility and sanitation, (something Med 2 and Rome 1 had). 

My main problem with this game is that it does not play like a Total War game. Attila is not a sandbox empire builder with cool battle, it's a survival game. The game gets progressivly harder as the AI does everything in its power to ruin you, including choices that don't actually benefit the AI. Expansion is harsh since corruption punishes you severely, and there is no freedom in building cities, as you always end up building the same shit in every single town. The balancing in the game is way off, the new freelc faction, the White Huns, have horse archers with a 70% missile block chance, that's testudo levels of shielding. It's like CA unfortunately does not care about this game at all. 

Multiplayer is broken since nobody plays Attila and because of aforementioned balancing, graphics are too dark and dull and the campaign is unsatisfying. I would not recommend getting this game, and if you want to play it, buy it on sale.

I was really looking forward to Rome 2 total war but was unable to play it due to my lackluster pc at the time. so when i finally built a good one, i wanted to get attila. i thought that since rome 2 had some rough reviews i thought that attila would be a excellent choice. i was pleasantly supprised by the new machanics theyve added into the game. however, this game is so poorly optimized its actually a pain to play. ive had to turn my graphics settings to medium in order to run a smooth battle. i have the newer total war games and all of them run smoother than this game. its really disappointing to purchase a game for it not to run well. ive read multiple reviews on this problem and it seems that the game was just never fully optimized. which has led to certain users not having a good experience. i was looking forward to playing in this time period but unfortunitly its too much of a pain. i regretfully do not recommend this game as it is unfinished and the studio seems to have ended their updates for this title.

Total War: Attlia may very well be the scariest strategy game I've ever played. Balancing military might with money and food to keep your populace from starving is challenging enough at times, but factor the constant threat of an invincible Mongol horde, and you will truly learn to fear The Scourge of God.

The game takes place during the fall of Rome. The Roman empire has split into two different factions, and is beset on all sides by Barbarian kingdoms laying siege to their ancestral lands, punishing the imperial Romans for their complacency and decadence. The Sassanid Empire has risen in the East, reclaiming territories in Persia and Arabia. Above all, however, comes a far worse threat: a mobile horde of savage foreigners, looting, raping, and pillaging everywhere they go, deadset on a collision course with Rome itself. Playing as either of these major empires is difficult enough, but one of the most terrifying experiences is playing as one of these smaller tribes, just trying to survive in a world that seems to be ending. The snows of the north move further south, alongside many competing tribes. The sun is blotted out of the sky, and there are whispers of death on the wind, fortelling the arrival of a man who will set the very foundation of the mountains ablaze.

There is nothing else out there quite like the terrifying desperation one feels in simply trying to survive. You'll make alliancess with former enemies who are much stronger than you; hell, you may become a tributary of theirs, out of sheer desperation. You will abandon allies to superior enemies, and send in armies to put down citizens rioting due to starvation.

Rediscover that the world has undergone apocalypse before, and enter the brutal world of Total War: Attila.

One of the best total war games made in recent years. If you're looking for a good campaign total war game then look elsewhere but the battles in Attila are breathtaking.

Hey everyone!

So I will get right into it;

I began my journey in Rome and I was stunned by the concept. Back then the AI was, let me put this mildly, TERRIBLE, but the game was just so enjoyable that you didn't care. The balance was also not great, 1 squad of spartans could butcher thousands of peasants. But the map was large, controlling those large armies was amazing and crushing your foes made you feel like a god. Needless to say, I became hooked. 
Since then I've played them all, every Total War game that came out and I loved them all. But it was Medieval who held the crown of being the best. It was the undisputed grand strategy king in my books. 

Then came Attila and boy.... Medieval got the same treatment Oberyn got from The Mountain in Game of Thrones. At first I was unsure about it but after getting into it, it blew me away. Don't misunderstand me here, Medieval will always hold a place in my heart but over the years the game mechanics have evolved, the AI has gotten better and the balance has been tweaked. 

I have had no problems with performance in this game, although I'm running it on a mediocre gaming rig. It has very, very rarely crashed on me or froze and the FPS has been pretty stable throughout all my playthroughs. 

What I love most about Attila is probably the setting, it is the closest thing to Medieval times since, well, Medieval (especially if you have the Age of Charlemagne dlc). But overall I think it is a great mix of the old games and the new. The gameplay is still pretty much the same, the map is familiar but it's mostly the new features that carry it beyond Medieval. I am a big fan of the Province system which wasn't existant in the old games. The diplomacy works a lot better and like I previously said, the AI has gotten better. 

So in my opinion, this is currently the king of the Total War games. Of course there are people who would argue that other games are better but I believe there is a factor of personal preference included. I for one did not like Empire nor Napoleon and I wasn't big on Rome 2 either. --Please note that I am NOT comparing it to the Warhammer versions--

So that being said, all Total War games are buggy, none of them has a GREAT AI and while I don't agree with the DLC cash grab policy they got going, it seems that pretty much all game developers have gone down that road nowadays (Paradox, Relic, Wildcard and Bethesda to name a few). 

So if you are new to this genre and are looking at the copies and can't decide, I would recommend you consider what time period wanna play, as that will suit you the most. All of them are great in their own right and all of them are flawed too. 
Should you be an experienced Total War player chances are high you already have this game, if not, try it!

I have always been interested in the Dark Ages and this game offeres me a perfect historical experience. In one of the most grim periods in human history,  where the great empires were falling apart and barbarians tribes rose and thrived, we witness the dusk of those old civilisations and the dawn of modern Europe. Literally, the background of Atilla Total War is even more epic and vibrant than that of Rome 2 (I got more excited over the Charlemagne DLC, it comes to a crucial age that is usually disregarded by the gaming industry) .

However, the game itself does not provide a perfect experience. A few experiences so far: 1. some units are owerpowered such as Spet Xyon Archers; 2. terrible optimisation 3. Supid AI factions that don't even colonised razed cities 4. could be extremely tough if playing as Western Rome or the Huns 5. hasn't been updated for long, leaving a huge space to improve.

Anyway, highly recommended for history and Total War series fans, but not recommended if you are a beginner of RTS or TW games.

This game has some serious ballance issues. 

I come from Poland, I bought slavic nations pack, and ... I'm really underwhelmed. Slavic troops are so weak. I mean, come on. The most stark example are Slavic Archers, which cost 2x upkeep of Germanic Hunters, but deal 1/3 of their missle damage. Come on! They cost 200 for upkeep p/t and deal 14 (!) missle damage, while Germanic Hunters cost 100 for upkeep p/t and deal 38! Tf is wrong with this balance...? It's hard to amass a slavic army because of industry income debuffs, and each time they get obliterated anyway by germanic armies comparable in size, but with just so much better stats. I've seen lower tier germanic troops that beat higher tier-same class slavic troops. Slavic troops cost more upkeep, and are much weaker, compared to germanic. And winter resistance buffs don't really offset that. 

I'm a Total War series veteran, have been playing it since first Rome, I know what I'm doing.  But this is just too weak...

This is a much better game than I anticipated. Despite all the positive reviews, after Rome 2, I wasn't very psyched to dive into another TW game. But I can't get enough of Attila. Not since my first days of playing TW:M2 have I found myself losing track of hours upon hours, thinking ... just a few more turns.

With a more reliable diplomatic system, a nicely complicated building tree, and the ability to raid, sack, loot, or raze neighbors, the strategic depth of empire building in this game is definately the best in the franchise (and yes, I've played them all). I particularly enjoyed the fact that some empire-special-abilites drastically change not only combat, but how to optimally expand and fight. 

Family/political management and proper province building (for agents & troop rosters) have a bit of a learning curve, but are realy engaging once understood. The slow freezing of the world, and the addition of migration/horde mechanics really puts this game in a league of its own compared to other TW games.

Once you've gotten a grip on the new systems, if the game feels a little rushed to you, I strongly recommend picking up (at least) 2 mods:  12 turns per year, & x2 research cost. With these mods, the size of the map, and the veritable horde of factions, the game verges into almost grand strategy gameplay.

If you feel like Total War has lost some of it's magic over the years, and if (like me) you skipped this title because of Rome 2's lackluster release, you should give Attila a chance. CA found the magic again when they made this one. And however future TW entries fare, I'll be playing Attila for years to come.

Hey guys,
I am playing Total war games for a really long time now.
And i can say Total War: ATTILA is one of the best Total War games i have played so far.

1 Like = 1 beer !!!

First of all:

In my opinion Attila should never have been a stand alone full price title. Instead, it should have been an stand alone expansion to Rome 2, and many of it's "new" features and improvements(family tree, better UI, politics, etc) should have been integrated into the core game(Rome 2).
This is exactly the same thing CA did with Empire and Napoleon back in the days... Created a buggy, clustered and non-optimised game(Empire) and in stead of improve it they just decided to release Napoleon shortly after, a game that is basically a re-skin of Empire with a cleaner UI and less bugs.
To add salt to the injury, they keep releasing those unpopular "Blood and Gore DLCs" as well as "Faction Packs"(got to say that those are at least better than selling individual factions or Unit Packs like they did before)...


With that said however:

As much as i am displeased with CA and SEGA for their past mistakes and bad business practices, i have to say that Attila is actually quite a good Total War game, and looks like a step(several) in the right direction again, with new features such as a political system, a more fleshed out Horde Mode for several factions, and even the brand new ability to completely raze settlements to the ground.
Attila also ditched most of the bad things about Rome 2(terrible UI, magical abilities for units, among others), while at the same time took those features that were good(or that had the abiility to be) and made them better. The return of things like "several turns per year" and "family tree" are also very welcomed.

With some further patching and improvements and some further mod support, Attila could be on par with Shogun 2 and Napoleon in its level of quality, polishing and narrative.

Worth buying for both old and new fans alike of the Total War series,
Of all its DLCs however, the only one i would truly recommend its Age of Charlemagne, the rest can be easily skipped.

PS: While the vanilla game is quite good, i do have a few gripes with it and feel there is room for improvement.

Attila: Total War delivers a solid and somber game set during the twilight of the Western Roman Empire. The gameplay is comparable to previous Total War games, as you command your squares of soldiers to go do violence against your enemies, but one overlooked aspect that I think Creative Assembly nailed is the atmosphere. Typically the strategy games that I play are detached, and your choices to grow your empire or smash your competitors is a simple transaction. In Attila, as you raze cities to the ground or gradually wear down your opponent's hordes with desperate rearguard actions, the conflicts feel more personal. Your role in the fate of Europe is tangible, and your empire is more often than not quite fragile as you attempt to balance the climate change and the influx of invaders. I can see myself putting many more hours into this game.

I thouroughly enjoyed total war attila. There are several mechanism that have been deployed in this game.

Horde mechanism

Some factions own no territoty : they are called hordes factions. Playing a horde is a cat and mouse game. Some time you are the mouse and some time the cat. An horde can be easily crushed if left alone. Thereforce, you have to planned ahead. I usually send my spies ahead to spot enemy armies. My heroes also protects my hordes from ennemy agents. I like also sadistic pleasure you take when razing a province. Early game you don't earn a lot of money. So you really have to decide how what to build.  Horde armies as any armies gain tradition. As you do a lot of fight with hordes you will have lot of tradition: you army will move faster, grow faster lower enemy moral ... You have also a feeling of freedom with hordes. You don't have to defend territories. You go wherver you want and terrorize whoever you want. It's a great experience.

Diplomacy

Diplomacy has been extended compared to rome total war. You have a trend to know if will increase or decrease. You can really play a diplomacy game where you support your allies. As allies territories count in victory condition, you can win without owning much by using smart alliances. 

Playing the roman empire

My first game was with the roman empire. First thirty-fourty turns are of humiliciation. You cannot win and have to decide where to hold ground and develop your economy. You sufer so much from start game than it's really a huge pleasure later on to crush the armies which have humiliated you and restore roman empire. A new mechanism named immigration adds to the difficulty. Whenever a province is sacked or razed, people flee to other neighbouring provinces. It adds public order penalty. It kicks in around turn thirty when you have stabilized your border. So after attacks from everywhere you have instability whitin your own empire. Every turn from turn 1, you have that feeling : I cannot hold. 

The offices

Family tree is back and politics has been enhanced. You can assign an office to the different member of state. It's important as some office may really help to manage a town or an armee. You have to pay attention to loyalty of the different people. Stricter control of country leads to better incomes and a malus to public order. Loose control means less income and a bonus to public order. You have to equilabrate your power based on your income and level of public order.

My update on the 23/11/2017 is they have changed corruption mechanism. Because of that end game becomes too easy. Once you have more than 20 towns its a push over. Previous difficulty level was ok for me. It's better to go back to rome 2 where money management for big empire is harder.

Having over 900 hours on my last account and it playing for the past 3 years. It's time that I write a review for this game.

To start off, I bought this game when it released on feburary 17th 2015 and to be quite honest it's still my absolute favorite game. Anyone who hasn't played a Total war title, well this might be a good start if you're looking to enter on the foundation of historical accuracy and "Real Time Strategy". The campaign is set in The game begins in 395 AD, during what is now called Late Antiquity (the transition period from Classical Rome to the Medieval age in European history). While the title character will be able to become the leader of the Huns, he is not yet in power at the start of the campaign. Upon the death of Emperor Theodosius I in 395 AD, the empire is divided between his sons who each rule a half: Honorius in the West, and Arcadius in the East. Rome is divided. In the west, The Western Roman Empire Faces a barbarian riposte from the north. To the east, the Eastern Roman Empire boarders the Sassanid Empire. Playing as a Roman faction, it will quickly become a game of survival as Rome's legions are stretched to breaking point to protect a decaying empire. About a quarter of the way through the campaign, Attila the Hun comes of age, and with this Hunnic forces begin to rise in the northeastern portion of the map. Now, the choice is yours to either get on good terms with this man as he will be a thorn in your side for the douration of the game if you declare war (Especially early in the campaign as Roman).

Ah, now we get to actual gameplay... It's fantastic, The Campaign the multiplayer battles... It's overwhelming at times but that is the point of a total war game, especially if you take to multiplayer. The modding community for this game is still alive and well. And this might just be your go to title if you're a fan of Lord of the Rings, because a complete overhaul is just around the corner (Rise of Mordor). As well as numerous other overhauls set in multiple time periods, This game has become the centerpiece of multiple overhauls. This includes Medival Kingdoms 1212ad, Aincent Empires, Rise of Mordor, Attila 1220 and the list just goes on. Also don't forget the hundreds of units mods!

I can't really express how lovely the community is here and we welcome all those who wish to be a  pat of it, And how thankful we are for the devoted small teams of people making overhauls and detailed changes to this day for a game nearing 4 years old. If you enjoy massive ground and naval battles with detailed infantry and units, spectacular sieges and micro management. This, this is where you start.

TW: Attila is very similar to Rome2, but it has updated mechanics wich makes it better!
in this game you can now control HORDES , a "mobile settlement" , wich also has its own army. you can move that settlement/army around like you would move any other army unit.
that mobile settlement has a unique chain of buildings with positive and negative effects.

or for other factions who do not use hordes, expand your empire, upgrade buildings ( each with different positive and negative effects ), deploy armies to fight on Auto-Resolve, or deploy more tactical groups to fight battles live and command each units.

for those of you who will play hundreds of turns on long campaigns at high difficulties , rome may be defeated ,Attila's hordes may be defeated. but stronger alliances will show up. it is difficult to defeat.
total war games can be really difficult at high difficulties.

playing as the sassanid empire on legendary difficulty, at TURN 13 i was able to make both western and eastern roman empires become my puppet states giving me 15k tribute a turn for a total of 35k of tributes from all puppet states surrounding us. 
i was able to do this by declaring war to all enemies of rome, giving everyone many common enemies increased diplomacy between everyone and i became the richest king , leading over 12 puppet states with very good diplomacy.
sassanid empire highlights are on twitch , also visible in my steam screenshots.

A bit of an improvement on Rome II - but sadly not enough of an improvement. The interface is bizarre and not at all obvious or intuitive, just like Rome II.  There are some mods that make it worth playing. And the Last Roman campaign is quite good fun and more of a challenge than usual at the start (enemy armies full of high quality heavy cavalry better than yours) until it becomes boring and repetitive too. It is a DLC and you have to pay for it though.

As with Rome II the graphics are decent and the battles are ok, but unfortunately the campaign is full of faults that make it unsatisfying to play and in my case usually just end up giving up and turning the game off. Not because i couldn't win - i win a lot of battles (the battle AI isn't that great, though decent by Total war standards), but because basic features that should be in the game are missing (especially proper diplomacy).

Some improvement on Rome II in that you can build walls on any settlement, but still, for no good reason, only once they become a level 4 settlement. 

Most ancient settlements bigger than a village had walls - because it would have been too dangerous not to have any. And since Total War maps are only showing a tiny minority of the actual towns and cities that existed (because on that map scale you couldn't have them all in) any that are in should be major towns or cities - and have walls from the start. British Isles would be one of the few exceptions - and by the dark ages even many of its towns had walls.

Armies being able to embark on transports instantly isn't as historically inaccurate for this period as for Rome II - but it should be restricted to certain factions (Angles, Saxons etc) and unfortunately it's not. There's a mod for this but it doesn't seem to work (maybe not updated as they require updates after every new DLC and every patch).

As with Rome II you can only set one tax level to apply to every single settlement in your kingdom or empire. This is both needlessly annoying and historically inaccurate.

Diplomacy is the weakest point of the game. Without mods the only time anyone you're at war with will make peace is if you're on the point of wiping them out. The biggest problem though, as in Rome II, is being unable to trade regions. There is one mod that attempts to fix this but in practice at the moment all that allows is to offer a horde or enemy army in your territory a region that they are in at the time. And they generally say no. And the other mods that might make them reasonable enough to say yes are not compatible with the mods that allow region trading in diplomacy.

This is even worse for Attila than it was for Rome II, because if you are playing as Western or Eastern Romans, you are constantly invaded by barbarian hordes - and you can't do what the Roman Empire did historically, which was to offer them land on the empire's borders in return for defending those borders as vassals/ allies. You can, if they're not at war with you at the time, and if you have a general and army in the same region they're in at the time, recruit 1 or 2 units per turn from a horde, but that's not really the same thing.

This is, with a doubt, my favourite game to date. Although very difficult to understand at first, I have come to love the politics and complex mechanics. I can't stress how much I fell in love with the architecture of the towns and cities (particulary that of East Rome) and how much detail went into the design of the soldiers. A mod that, I found, made the experience better is the "forgotten realms" mod which creates a lot more variation between soldiers within units and allows you to play as previously unavailable factions. Bloody brilliant game... worth every cent.

I purchased the game inspite of all the negative reviews and boy there are a lot. I have been a supporter of Total War since the very first game Shogun, so I have seen the changes in gameplay and styles, and Attila is no different.

First of all, I love this game. I love it because its different. The game is not easy thats for sure but then it depends what faction you play. I started of with one of the Northan tribes (The Saxons) and sure it was tough going, especially considering your surrounded by strong factions. I wouild recommend playing one of the African factions as you can very easily and quickly expand your terratory against weak Roman occupation of towns and cities. This does allow you to master the new style of play were you can play Romans but they are not the primary faction, there is no primary faction which adds to the interesting change this game offers.

The game engine is roughly the same as Rome 2 on the campaign map, but battle map feels like a return to Shogun 2 although there are still some Rome 2 elements, I welcome the minor changes as the combat is more fluid now.

There is a random bug were every now and then the game crashes to desktop. Annoying? Yes, but considering the autosave function, getting back into game take you back to were you finished off.

I give this game a solid 8 out of 10, there is a tough learning curve which won't suit a lot of people and the bug looses points, but other than that, this is a solid game.

Attila is Rome 2 with a new skin. Very little is different and no lessons were learnt from the mistakes of Rome 2. As I said there, I say here. How do you go from Shogun 2 and Fall of the Samurai....To this?

In Attila TW, you can either play as a wandering horde faction or a traditional "start with 1 province/city and conquer the world from there" faction. While I welcome the new horde mechanic, bear in mind that unless this is your cup of tea, you'd likely prefer to just play one of the factions with a traditional start.

Overall, campaign map gameplay was way better in the earlier TW titles including Rome 1, Medieval 2 and Shogun 2. In Rome 1 for example, you had to decide whether to turn your settlement into a huge city or military recruitment center. Recruitment draws manpower from your population, so if you recruit too frequently, your population won't grow fast enough to progress to the next tier upgrade. But if you delay recruitment too long, your enemies might exploit this and attack early. By placing generals in cities, you can send slaves to that city from other parts of the empire to speed up its growth towards the next tier upgrade, but also need to balance the disorder that comes with a huge population by investing in happiness improvements. This is a brilliant and deep risk-reward mechanic that encouraged strategic thought and precise timing. In Shogun 2, your generals have a highly developed skill upgrade tree available and by constructing the right combination of buildings in each province, you can create powerful synergies to enhance your unit abilities. Such campaign mechanics have been dumbed down since Rome 2. Here, you just have to max out growth and rush research to reach the next tier and automatically unlock new improvements. Apart from certain advanced units that require specific resources, the entire campaign is just spam economic improvements, build up armies and conquer the world. While that's the ultimate objective, how you get there is just as important. 

Despite the addition of the horde mechanic and like in Rome 2, Attila lacks strategic campaign management where you feel like a governor as much as a general, which was typical in the earlier TW titles. An immersive campaign experience is just as important as spectacular real time battles. This is supposedly still a strategy game but its strategic layer is shallow. I won't comment on the WH TW series as I haven't played it, but as far as the historical titles are concerned, such campaign gameplay degradation has continued to this day. Unless TW goes back to its roots and brings back immersive campaign mechanics like those examples mentioned earlier, it seems the historical series will only go downhill from here. And I've not even touched on hefty price tags and controversial dlc practices.

I'm aware of the recent backlash from female generals and some dev remark in Rome 2, but see it as just the straw that broke the camel's back. Imho, it's not about female generals or even the remark per se but the fact that the TW series has since Rome 2 continuously denied players the one thing that made TW truly great, which was its mix of immersive campaign gameplay and real time battles. Yet instead of correcting this, the series since Rome 2 has focused on pricing and dlc practices hostile to players. Unless the series gets back on the right path, any future releases won't be worth wasting your time on regardless of all these "distractions".

Another thing is this game is poorly optimized even though I more than meet the recommended requirements. It takes too much time to scroll through every single faction's moves on the campaign map when you click end turn.

CA have reached a new low. I've played thousands of hours on other TW games and this is the pits. It doesn't even pretend not to cheat. Even on Easy, I cannot win battles and I've normally [play on Hard or Very Hard. I lose almost every one-on-one when enemy troops are no better than mine.  My morale is always the first to go. Unless I isolate and surround a unit I can't win and even then casualties are pyrrhic so it's pointless. I could win against RTW2 most of the time even when outnumbered. This game makes it impossible unless you have overwhelming odds.

The campaign game is equally munted. Sieges last forever so encircling and waiting for surrender is not a viable option. Playing Saxons on easy, I was wiped out in 10 turns. This should not be possible. What's the point of 'Easy' level difficult if you cannot survive 10 tuirns?

As for the tutorial, it has to be the worst in any game ever. A tutorial where you are guaranteed to lose is a sick joke. It's set up to make you fail at every turn. I have gathered that it's to force you to make a Horde but it feels like you've lost and who is going to play a game where you feel like you've lost the tutorial. It's nuts. Even in the early part of the campaign, it forces your regions to be starving and and have negative public order. WTF? 

As for the help system, it's virtually useless even more so than RTW2 which was bad enough. It is almost impossible to work out from your tech trree what troops you will be able to recruit. It's fine if the tech itself unlocks them but if the tech unlocks a building which may or may not unlock troop types you're in for a 5 minute hunt to find out what. Not only that, you can no longer even see what your troop capabilities are from the recruitment screen. It gives only a general idea and not the actual details which you have to use the help system for so comparing troop capabilities is utterly impractical.

Do not buy this game unless you enjoy being annoyed, angry, frustrated and screamiong at your computer. After about 10 hours of playing I can safely say I didn't enjoy one minute of it. I tried, God knbows I tried, but this game was completely resistant to my effort. If Steam had a fair refund policy, I'd demand a refund. As it is I've uninstalled it because it's not worth tyhe space and effort.

Total War: ATTILA.

That says about it, really. This isn't about the shogunate in Japan, this isn't about Rome. This is about the scourge of God, the crumbling Roman Empire, and the survivors in the East creating a Graeco-Roman hybrid that would continue to exist for nearly a thousand years longer.

ATTILA is truly apocalyptic. Nomadic tribes begin their westward migration, taking advantage of the Roman Empires' poor infastructure and lack of unity. Refugees flood Romes borders, her armies stretched too far.

It is impossible, when playing ATTILA, to not feel a sense of coming dread. The diluted colour palette and brutal warfare shows us that, truly, there is no hope. 

Should you play as a pre-established power, you cannot win every war. This isn't "Total War". This is "Total Survival". You must abandon provinces. Playing as the Western Romans, I was forced to abandon all regions bar Britannia, Hispania and Italia. 

And I barely managed to hold those too against the rising power of the Saxons, Alamans, Alans, etc.



The entire Total War franchise has been about painting the map your colour. For myself, and many other players, the joy is in the start - you play as a weak faction with tough rivals, through superior tactics you defeat them, but then you just snowball. The game gets boring. Sometimes CA will throw events at you to keep you on your toes - like Realm Divide in Shogun 2, or the Norman Invasion in Thrones of Britannia, but by then, you're so powerful.

ATTILA doesn't have an easy start, unless you're the Sassanids, and if you're playing Sassanids, get out of here.

This review is for real SPQR boys.

The early game as Western Rome is so brutal. There's no "Defeat this one rival then snowball" scenarios like there is in Shogun 2 (Play as Oda, defeat Tokugawa and Imagawa, snowball, gg ez). 

Instead you ARE the powerhouse, and you ARE a paper-tiger. You are weak. You can barely sustain two armies at this point, and you've dozens of provinces to defend. You will lose land. You will have riots and revolutions, religious anarchy as constant refugees flood your borders, and as your ally, the Eastern Romans get battered by Sassanids and White Huns, you will realize that your dreams of a Pax Romana are impossible, and that you must survive, reinforce your core, then, and only then, might you stand a chance when Attila comes.


Attila is the most brutal Total War experience. 
I've watched helplessly as countless legions are cut down by hunnic lancers. 
I've watched as testudos are shattered by war elephants. 
I've watched as the Eastern Romans shattered our bonds and used my weakness to annex my Balkan holdings.


Yet the Empire has endured. And that is the ultimate goal of Total War: ATTILA. To endure, to survive.


Once, or if, you beat the game as the Western Roman Empire, there's no challenge left. You did the impossible. 

Sure, you could play Huns and raid into Europe, destroying her cities and pillaging, but to me, there's far more joy in defending from an unstoppable horde than there is being a horde.


Don't buy ATTILA if you want a power fantasy where you win every battle and none can rival you. 
Buy ATTILA if you want a challenge.

As a player of TW games since the first Medieval, this game is a well crafted jewel. I believe CA is really doing a lot in order to improve the strategic map gameplay in each of their games, adding a level of depth and immersion that is highly appreciated. There's still a long way to go in order to match the grand strategic complexity of Paradox games, but they are manging to craft something unique. The maps are huge and gorgeous, full of small little details.
The tactical aspect in the batttles is just amazing, and manages to gracefully combine realism with arcade fun. You will have the chance to deal with epic battles in total uncertainty, and enjoy the late antiquity and high middle ages slaughterhouse unfold in slow motion.

Playing the main campaign with the Western Roman Empire for the first time is brutal. You feel the weight of centuries of slow decline upon your shoulders, while you try to delay the inevitable by all means. It's not just the barbarian pressure on the borders, it is also the internal turmoil, corruption and religious strife are rotting you from within. By far the most fun and mind consuming defeat I've ever had in a Strategy game. Loved it.

Of course the game has a lot of details and stuff that can be improved, but the workshop has plenty of stuff that can satisfy that. Personally, I prefer the game with less AI cheating, the spawning of hordes and hordes of Huns, can be monotonous, annoying and unrealistic at a certain point. Also, some fixes on the Eastern Roman Empire, which in Vanilla can be a bit too weak... specially considering that it outlived the WRE for just another 1,000 years.

All the expansions up to date are excellent as well, being Age of Charlemagne the perfect kick start so finally CA can launch soon the acclaimed Medieval 3. We the plebs demand it!

***To start off I recommend this game because I want to capture the attention of a gamer who is on the edge of buying it and I want to discuss the game and not the company. It is interesting how so many people review this game without talking about the game itself. Look I am well aware that CA and Sega have been making really dumb choices with every title that comes out but boycotting their old games that already came out years ago is wasted effort. Boycott the new ones so they will feel the affect where it hurts them the most; their wallets.

So for the actual game how is it? Weellll... its not great but its not garbage entirely. I'll break up my thoughts in 3 ideas, Campaign, general Issues, and final thought

Campaign is a mix bag of good and bad. The most fun in the campaign is early game like turns 1-100. You will have great moments, epic battles, great defense and seiges, wars will wage and all that is fun. I really like how many factions you can play as in the GRand Campaign and how different each one is. You can be a subjegated nation and that will be vastly different than playing as the Romans, then playing as a horde is very different than a settled faction. There is great replayability with all the factions having different mechanics working for them. Of course late game its all the same. Trying to build and maintain your empire is balanced enough so that you can focus on wars and battles without having to worry about the state of your empire constantly. However the worst most broken and frustrating aspect about the campaign is the agent system, by god this is the worst. When youre at war with a nation they will spam the hell out of the priest agent, this agent can disrupt armies and cause dissent in towns but what is so broken is that the enemy's agents are flawless. They will get critical successes every single time, it is a mad stroke of luck if they fail their task. But what is so broken is that once they get a success then they level up and then makes it easier for them to succeed and again then they level up again then succeed more. Eventually every priest agent is insanely OP and what is so game breaking is your agents are worthless. I cant ever get a single agent past level 3 due to some stupid critical failure. Every agent i recuit gets killed by a critical failure, never had an agent die from an assassination. I absolutely hate this agent system and CA never improves on it. Warhammer had the exact same problems.

So what other problems are there? Well the most broken aspects show in the custom battles. Well the main issue is that the game engine is not optomized for todays standards. I dont know how the game got release like this. If you do a custom battle with more than 2 armies, the game will lag to about a frame a second and Im using a 1080 card. During the campaign however I never had that issue even when I had massive 4 army battles the lag was never as strong as it is in custom battles. I dont know how it is exactly in multiplayer, I dont play multiplayer, but from what i've seen from youtube is that is it isnt as bad as a custom map but still exists. Then the AI is absolutely stupid. Again in custom battle its the worst and campaign isnt as bad but its still obvious. If you do a siege the AI will throw everything at you and at one section. Sometimes the AI will try to flank with cav but 90% of the time the AI will cluster in one choke point and you will most likely win a battle even horribly out numbered since when in a cluster the men can all break together. The AI for a custom siege battle with walls is 100% broken dont even try it. The AI will run back and forth outside the walls (which doesnt help the poor engine's frame rate at all) and wont ever use the siege equipment, the units drop the stuff to run around outside of the walls its absolutely pathetic and inexcusable that the game got pushed through play testing with such an obvious flaw.

So final thought; I put i recommend only because I want to reach the gamer who like strategy war games and let them know what exactly they are getting into. When I look at reviews for any game, if its done by a big corporation people just rag on the company which is understandable; personally I will never buy an EA or Activision game because I dont tollerate their business practices but honestly CA isnt forcing mircotransaction in this game, the DLC isnt completely nessicary like most games are now (I mean there is way to many and culture packs should be friggin free and paying for blood and gore is the most heinous DLC but you dont need them at all.) and bottom line it is a fun game and there are tons of mods to try.

***So i recommend strictly if it is on sale, and if you have fun with real time battles and grand strategy games. There is still a good amount of people playing online if that is your thing too. Its fun but how much fun you'll get out of it thats up to you and your play style. Just do not buy it full priced.

While CA has clearly abondoned this game the modders are picking up the slack, with mods like MK 1212AD and Rise of Mordor and Anceint Empires and some overhauls you can tailor the game to your liking. You can and will have fun if you want to.

I really love what CA has recently done, but this title is by far the most frustrating I have ever played with. I chose to give it a bad review for just one, basic reason: hordes are the worst factions to play with, which is paradoxical, since the game is litterlly named ATTILA.  Don't get me wrong, the armies they can field are incredible, yet the games's flaws ruin the experience in one simple way: agent spam. There are THOUSANDS of posts in forums that address this issue, but apparently the developers prefer leaving it as it is and letting the modders fix it. I think that being uncapable of moving across the map without an handicap of 60-85% at every turn is a big deal. My game experience with the White Huns has been ruined by the agents of three different factions that were constantly blocking my army until 3 armies came at me and crushed me. I have played with other factions and it is still manageable, it's like playing Rome 2, but playing as an horde faction puts you in a position in which mobility and swiftness are key to survive. Counter-spamming and fleeing is not fun or smart, it is just the result of bad game design.

Having said this, the game is decent, it's an improved version of Rome 2. I am honestly disappointed.

As you can see I have played this game a little bit. I have played as nearly every faction and have had alot of fun. Just like with any new total war game it took me some play time to get used to the differences that come with new total war games. I hate, as well as most people do, how much DLCs are waved in our faces instead of just being added to the game. I bought every DLC for this game because I liked it so much and I bought them during sales so I got them for 1/2 to 3/4 the original price. It got a little crazy paying .75 cents for blood and gore, but none the less I did it because it was something I wanted.

PROS: Campaign is fun for most factions and features somewhat different units accross the board. You get into some redundancy in certain areas like Northern Europe, Eurasia, North Africa and the Middle East. I know some people disliked the unlimited death stacks of Huns that flood Europe, but I kinda liked the challenge they gave especially on higher difficuluties they are damn near impossible unless you have a large amount of troops to send to the HUN MeatGrinder.

PRO: I really love the family tree and positions that they can attain. I really enjoyed having that back into the game after Rome 2. 

PRO: I also enjoyed having a playable game that I can actually enjoy and spend time on because Rome 2 was literally unplayable on both my desktop and laptop and that seriously bothered me.

PRO: The technology tree and diplomancy is alot better in my opinion when compared to older total war games. But some factions will completely hate you and refuse any sort of diplomacy at the smallest level, but for the most part I like it.

CONS: Having characters with low loyalty and the only way to raise it is to cut their balls off (thus not spreading their genes in the family tree) or blinding them. Both causing severe negative traits gained.

CONS: The diplomacy aspect where everyone absolutly hates you past a certain Imperium stage gained.

CONS: Constant diplomatic nagging from factions every single turn.

CONS: Corruption in towns/cities/provinces that render income basically useless. This is alot more prevelant when playing as Western Rome when corruption gets huge.

Other than these my other pros and cons are relativly minor. Excuse my spelling errors and I hope you all enjoyed this review. Overall I recommend this game even without buying the DLCs. I have had a ton of fun.

I'm trying to like Attila; I've liked all the other Total War games, but this is the first one I'm going to have to thumbs down.  First and foremost, this is a hog, it seems to run slower than Rome II.  My PC is fairly old, (My PC was top of the line 5 years ago) but I run this on lowest settings (even though it recommends higher for my computer).  Furthermore, it crashes ALL THE TIME.  It is so frustrating having to go through the slow loading of the campaign over and over again every time it crashes.  Then once you get deep in the campaign it eventually hits a point where it crashes every time you reload.  I can go back 4 or 5 turns- but then when I get to that point again it crashes again.

I've never had any Total War game crash so often.  Occassionally, yes, but not all the time.

Difficulty is much higher than other Total War games- but not in a good way.  You have to spend all your time dealing with keeping people happy rather than... well waging war.  Growing food- makes people unhappy.  WTF?  Why is it that every food improvement makes people unhappy. "Oh NOES! Farmer Joe is growing wheat... that makes me sad. I hate wheat fields"

Instead of Total War it should be "Total Sadness: ATTILA" because you spend most of your effort trying to keep people happy not fighting.  The balance of this games just seems off. This appears to be a very rushed and poorly tested or thought out addition to the Total War Franchise. This game isn't a battle and conquest simulator- it's just a tedious make people happy (or unhappy) simulator.  Why is my empire unhappy all the time? Is it because the citizens hate existing on the worst of the Total War series?

The migration mechanics are more annoying than they are fun or immersive.  There really arn't any good upgrades from this game over the others- everything seems to be a change for the worse.

Save your frustrations... buy Rome II instead.  If you already have Rome II - skip this one, it doesn't add any improvements, it just makes things worse.  

Atilla should be a hard pass.

Total war used to be fun!
Attila just gets progressively harder and more boring as it goes on. 

The changes aren't gradual either, every ten years you just wake up to find you have been kicked in the nuts.
So disappointed.

Total War, what criticism is left to level at this once groundbreaking developer? I've been with them since the very beginning when the Demo (remember those?) to Shogun came out. I remember how challenging it was at first to figure out their rock paper scissors approach to tactical battles and how satisfying it was to beat opponents more powerful once I did. But that was 18 years ago. Sure, their games now look better, but instead of investing in the Battle and Campaign AI, Diplomacy, Economy, faction management, etc., they went down the dead end of graphics. It's a dead end because with such scale they'll never equal the visual relish of console games and because their fanbase, strategy players and history aficionados, doesn't care about special effects (if they did they'd go for the many better looking console titles). 

They want substance. 

That, however, is severely lacking in Total War games in general. As for this title specifically, Attila is a really good idea for a period piece as major changes were about to hit the western world. Western Roman Empire would be torn apart by the invading Germanic tribes, while the Eastern half would eventually rise to unprecedented heights under the reign of Justinian. Why they went for climatic change that happens mid game and degrades fertility? Not sure. So far my readings on the late antiquity stemming from the research done over the preceding decades paint a picture of a vibrant world, not one, as so often is described, in decline. Sure, there are many changes brought about in government, culture, religion, but this did not necessitate a decline. There's several historical misfires that are built into the game (Churches draining Imperial treasury, division of Goths into Eastern and Western at the start date and having them at War with Romans as some sort of a horde, absence of serious usurpations, which the Emperors treated with more urgency than barbarian incursions, etc.) correction of which would improve the game balance (the phrase we so often hear from CA as they serve up another round of gruel) and add to its sophistication.

If Paradox, CA's most serious competitor, has shown anything it's how elegant sophistication in strategy games can be. Diplomacy, faction interaction, AI, is much better in Paradox games, offering a greater degree of control. It seems they have a better understanding of this niche market than CA. And with Imperator coming out next year, I hope this part of history will receive a generous treatment, it deserves.

Even though I spent over 500 hours on this game over 3 years (thanks mostly to the mods), and even though by far it's not the worst CA game, I can't recommend.

This one, I waited and tried to like it, because it looked like an improved version, but it is broken to a fundamental level just like its predecessor. For one, the engine is poorly optimized: I have a GTX 1060, i76700k, and it slows down at times of mild action, in a way that never before made me so angry. Barely 30 fps in a forest? Yeah no thanks. And how about the autogenerated terrain, which has holes in it? Yes, literal holes inside the maps. I once walked my army on a hill only to find it split open like cheese with a big glowing white void inside. Floating buildings are still a problem. No moddability whatsoever, as a matter of fact the tools for us modders are barely working and dont do anything specific other than the usual pre-Shogun2 era, or even less. Of courese they're still in beta and will be like that forever because CA moves on very fast as soon as the next title comes out.

This is a promising title created on an abortion of an engine (Warscape) which has plagued the series since Empire with bugs, freezes, stuttering, countless sound issues - there is a looping sound problem that was NEVER FIXED from Empire!! after 7 years!! - and very poorly managed overall, with mildly boring campaign and lackluster presentation for a game of this type, it looks like they tried to replicate Napoleon: Total War's success but failed to realize what NTW really has in comparison: a soul put into it, and arguably a much better AI composition for both campaign and battle maps, which is saying something seeing as this AI is probably the third worst in the series overall (after Rome2 and Empire).

So tl;dr save your money, dont buy it, it's an abandoned barely working piece of garbage that has some sparkles of creativity into it, but then again it's like pouring chocolate on a turd.

cav charges does minimal damage and archers have neglegtable effects. after a battle with my archers shooting 50% of their ammo against unarmored, unshielded targets they had 4 and 8 kills respectively. the enemy archer squads were no different with 8-15 kills.

it seamingly only boils down to who has the best infantry. with cav and archers doing minimal damage, a infantry heavy army is unstoppable unless you face them with similar infantry. that leads to honestly boring strategies and that is not an experience i seek from a total war game. 

with a total war game, i expect to win an unfavorable match if i outsmart the oponent, be that with practical ranged support or with smart use of cavalry. and mind you i see a victory not only as getting the victory popup, but also in case i manage to deal crippling damage against an expensive army with a cheap army, despite getting the defeat screen.

This game is awful. I've enjoyed every other TW game, but this was terrible.

The first thing you'll notice is that converting a level 1 city costs ~4-10x more than previous games. Converting itself takes ~10 turns. Even after disabling the show AI moves option, the AI takes 2-5 minutes every turn. Yes, it takes real life HOURS to convert a single city.

But it gets worse, because a full stack of 20 isn't quite sufficient to maintain order in a small, unconverted settlement. So you need to fund a full army to sit on its ass while you try saving up 17k to convert the town. Don't worry, the army comes in handy when the settlement inevitably goes into revolt every other turn. Then you discover it's cheaper and faster to abandon the town and rebuild it! Phenomenal.

So you're finally getting the hang of it. So what if the Huns are further west than they ever went even before Attila's born? So what if your faction has no units to counter horse archers until late tier III techs have been researched? Make up for it with micro and numbers.

But then the year 420 hits. The game creators watched one too many shows on HBO, and decided an eternal winter should descend upon Europe! Your food production drops by several hundred. You put all of your money into upgrading food sources. But the winter accelerates, and you fall even further behind!

Alt-f4, uninstall, write bad review. Unplayable garbage. Will not buy further total war games.

Although game gets better after 4-5 hours, it can't generate the enough momentum to keep you ongoing.

One last thing for soundtracks, I admire the musics in Total War series but this game made me dissappointed on that. Although Middle Asian themed musics are cool, there are no musics of other cultures in soundtracks and it doesn't make much sense to play a pagan nordic tribe with hun music. I wish that they'd have one special theme for each playable country as they used to do in Rome Total War.

Never buy it with full price. You can buy it with 80% discount if you are a huge RTS fan.

One of the best  Total War games hands down.

This game tells the tale of the Late Classical period circa 395-500 AD, a time when the conventional Roman-dominated world came to an end. The great thing about this game, and any total war game for that matter, is you get to decide how the history of your world unfolds compared to the historical record.

In my first play through I of course played as the Western Roman Empire on hard and damn does this game offer a challenge. Your armies are stretched thin, your economy is falling apart, rebellions are near constant, political infighting abounds, and to top it off, you are constantly invaded by barbarian tribes and the fearsome huns. 

My first encounter with the huns went something like this: " Oh hey they have an army in my territory, I have an army too, I better go fight them in the field to push them out of my lands. Ok got every one lined up, spearmen in the front, a few archers, don't really need cavalry. Oh shit all they have are horse archers, wow they are strong, oh crap all my men are dying before they can attack them. That's ok...oh shit all my men are routing. What the fuck just happened????" 

This is not an easy game. This game does not play favorites. In the end, most factions are going to have to fight the huns, and they (and the Sassinids) are no joke. Also the climate is constantly changing, disease is breaking out in settlements every few turns, allies are scarce, many territories are devastated beyond recognition by rampaging armies, and battles really do have a life and death feel to them. I can't describe the highs of absolutely destroying the Huns as the WRE with row after row of archers or the lows of seeing your best army get routed by stack after stack of reinforcing Sassinid battalions. It's an experience you shouldn't miss. For instance, when I started to expand again as the WRE into what was Germany, I might as well have been on the moon. Region after region, town after town, building after building, civilization after civilization destroyed by ravaging armies. There was little glory but definitely a sense of duty towards saving what was left of Roman civilization from the barbarians.

In fact if anything this Total feels more personal than most. You really feel like you are trying to preserve (or destroy) civilization from its worst impulses. When your meager settlement has run out of food, troops are deserting, and you have to make a quick capture of a nearby city or else you are toast-- this is the essence of Total War: Attila. The game honestly really made me think about what it was like to be some poor Roman soldier in 450 fighting the Hunnic hordes, what was going through their mind. What about the countless civilians who were probably butchered for no reason, the families torn apart, the dreams of a docile life shattered. Any game that can make such an impression is definitely special. 

There are some negatives however. To be honest in the Vanilla game, the Huns are completely OP, ESPECIALLY against the AI. They run roughshod over just about everybody except the Sassinids (who will be busy kicking your ass as often as possible too). Most of the map looks like a desert wasteland in a short time, which takes some of the glory of conquest. Also, the unrest/food/disease mechanic is a constant hassle. On the higher difficulties territories will constantly rebel unless you are some sort of Total War Legend who knows how to expertly balance the economy, sanitation, food supply, and public order. This makes the game frustrating at times and hinders your growth as an empire. I wonder however, if the developers wanted it this way and DIDN'T want you to be too successful too quick as to emphasize the gravity of the historical situation.

Either way the game is fabulous with a few flaws. One of the best Total War games and a definite improvement over Total War: Rome 2 in many ways. Buy it!

Despite the fact that they charge you three dollars for some cheap blood effects, Attila is actually really good, especially compared to Rome II.  It feels like Rome II if they had actually completed Rome II before releasing it.  It also has a much more chaotic total war feeling to it, especially playing as the Western Roman Empire.  The biggest problem is that the goddamn Huns literally cannot die until Attila dies, which is extremely annoying (you have to actually defeat him several times before he finally will even become mortal, until then he's invincible).  It's also pretty irritating that in your late game you basically are just looking at 60%+ of the map becoming desolate and all of the factions not doing anything (except the fucking Huns).  Fortunately, you can fix a lot of the game's issues with mods from the Steam Workshop.  It's still not as good as the old(er) TW games like Medieval II and Shogun II, but as long as you get Attila on sale, it's definitely worth the buy.
