So far. Best Total War Yet. Everything improved.

-Graphics are crisper (requires more PC grunt though, so much grunt required!). 
-Unit cards make more sense
-Battle AI improved greatly. Watch out if you leave a unit vulnerable!
-Battle Pacing improved greatly over Rome2 at release. Its probably around Rome2 patched speeds but units seem to move around faster.
-Campaign AI needs some tuning but it is quite good. No more catching the AI in foreced march all the time.
-Family tree fully fleshed out!

Negatives/Bugs noticed so far:

After 400 hours I think I can give a review.

IMO its not the best Total War, but it is a strong contender for 3rd or 4th place. 
The problems of Rome II are fixed, the campaign, all the events, climate change and marauding hordes, feel dynamic and are quite challenging. As always the game starts getting good only had difficulties hard or higher, but that is to be expected. The experience is much more like playing a survival game than a typical total war title.

The rosters are generally thematic, but varied, even though the rosters of some Germanic factions fall a little flat in diversity and distinctiveness. Instead, play style, starting positions and specializations (like the Naval Supremacy of the Vandals) influence and partially dictate your play style. The Eastern, Nomadic and Roman factions do not suffer from any sort of limited rosters and feel distinct from each other, as well as prior factions of earlier Total War games. In the end you will adjust the rosters with mods anyway, so it does not matter all that much.

The Migrating factions really are an amazing addition. 

The Huns specifically are menacing, but they behave very differently from the Mongols of TWM2. Instead of basically being a natural disaster, they start more like a band of bandits and and ruffians and as they accumulate wealth and have 6 to 10 elite fullstacks around the map they become a real threat to even the most developed empires.

Desolation is also a pretty great mechanic, however it should be adjusted with a resettling/ colonization mod, since otherwise whole swaths of the map remain empty until the end of the game. Which is interesting for some time, however it heavily favours the huns and white huns while other barbarians will die-off pretty quickly if the Romes don't fall.

The unit-balancing is fine, but cavalry seems a little to strong (which is "historically" accurate at least), missiles are very deadly, which is fine and adds a lot of momentum to the battles. Naval battles are actually very fun now and the Naval factions of the game are extremely fun to play. Instead of overloading every ship with an insane amount of commands they are now split into range-, ramming- and boardingships, so that even the AI knows what to do.

The modding scene has been very active, so that basically if you like the scenario and can run the base game, you will be able to adjust for all the major problems.

However, the game runs better than Rome II, at least for me, but still you will need a pretty strong machine to run it. Many people have complained about performance issues, I can imagine that is a problem of NVIDIA cards.

##A long word on Horsearchers##
Sure the game is named after the Huns, but the Huns and White Huns are way too powerful in the campaign. Their late-game stacks of elite-cataphract horsearchers can only be beaten in very costly battles, which would be fine if they didn't spawn endlessly after the birth and until the death of  Attilla. You will get sick and tired of beating them back pretty quickly. I suggest nerfing them with mods if you feel they are too annoying after a while. Alternatively get a mod which increases missile block chance. 


Verdict: Total War fans, with the capabilities of running it, should give it a try. It is basically a remake of Barbarian Invasion. A lot of work went into it and I think it has paid off.

Unfortunately it's going to be one of those reviews but any reasonable person couldn't let redshell slide.  I never gave the developers expressed permission to track what i am doing out of the game. The idea it's even remotely reasonable and is being defended is absolutely outrageous.
developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

review:
I am personally really enjoying this game.

As you can see on my account, 'am kinda used to the Total War franchise. And honestly do not really understand why this game is not more plebiscited.

I love its ambience, graphisms, colors, effects and the soundtracks go smoothly along. Time flies.
A variety of possible style of campaign thanks to a large panel of factions, but also brand new opportunities like razing down cities (which honestly is perfect. Why bothering occupying a settlement you won't care about right now and that can potentially give birth to the worst insurrection you've ever seen ?).
Battles are great. My impression is that they rely much more on your tactic rather than units. Also you can order units to move in a REAL arc, not a succession of straight lines. Fabulous.
The interface is great, I never had to look for anything, everything can be found easily.

But the victory conditions that are a bit too "big" if you do not plan to spend dozens of hours on the same campaign.
It also means that you won't complete all the tech' trees before long.
Also, when 2/3 of Europe has been razed and that the few remaining factions do not altogether reach your military power, it's pretty boring.

Cav is the center of this opus, which is normal regarding the time period. But I assure you you can conquer 2/3 of the Mediterranean Sea without more than 1/4 of your armies as cav.

Yeah, I definitely recommend this game. Too bad its follower, Britannia, is based on an utmost boring combinaison of period & country: its gameplay is what I would expect from the real follower of Attila.

i wasted too much time on this game. better mechanics than rome 2.

I definitely recommend this game for all strategy lover. 10/10 for charging with lancers on your enemies ranks and defending points with pikes against enemies who have superior numbers.

review: This is probably the worst TW game. It is like a miscarried DLC for Rome II. Not to mention the prologue... If you wannt to buy a TW game, chose any other, but not ATTILA. Absolutely not worth the money.
Love this game!

If I took a turd, rolled it in some glitter, and threw it down a hill, it would look better and run better then this PoS.

Honestly though, with a 1080 and 4.5Ghz cpu I had to turn most setting down to "maximum performance" (lowest), "performance" (low/medium), or "Off" to get it steadily above 60 fps. Also, it won't get better because they've dropped support for it.

C.A, my guys, what the hell are you doing? Shame it's one of the few decent antiquety period games around.

I would recommend this game for players who liked Total War: Rome II. A first item that has improved is your faction screen. By introducing a family tree, faction management becomes much more interesting and rewarding. Controlling influence and loyalty is a main aspect of the game that is better worked out than in Rome II. Also city management has become more complex (in a good manner) by adding sanitation. Not only is it necessary to keep happiness in order but also sanitation. It makes region control more complex and more fun. A negative point hereby however is food management. In Attila it became necessary to manage food for every region. Thus making it impossible to create 'granaries' in fertile regions and exporting the food to capital regions. Although the game places itself in a time of extended autarky this mechanism is too restrictive. (But the changing fertility as the climate gets colder is challenging and fun). Battles have remained largely the same (only the unit cards have changed). Regarding the different factions, it is possible to have a large variety of mechanisms between different factions so every game is different. Each faction group has its own building chain plus per faction some special properties. The possibilities to play as marauding Huns burning cities, Western Romans defending the Empire, Slavs colonising and defending and Eastern Romans surviving and prospering,... makes it a very diverse game with ample possibilities. A negative point is however the 'Hun spawn' mechanism. How they migrate and why they declare war are quite intransparant and makes the game somewhat inpredictible and random at moments. The almost unstoppable Hunnic force can make a game either annoying (for the control freak) or exciting (for the challenge seeker). In summary it is a fun and diverse game, also a good successor to Rome II but several mechanisms (food control and spawning) could be improved.

Red Shell issues with game and developer response.

CA statement: "Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware."

Concern:  Common defination of spyware goes as follow:  Software that enables a user to obtain covert information about another's computer activities by transmitting data covertly from their hard drive.


CA statement: "It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home"

Concern:  Again this fits well with common definations of spyware and its one of the most common uses for such software.  See http://www.bbc.co.uk/webwise/guides/about-spyware  as an example.  Red Shell is hidden 3rd party program that the user is not made aware of on installation.  The value of the data or what it is for has no bearing on this.  This also leaves unanswered the question of what Red Shell is capable of and if the third party handling it gathers any additional information that it does not share with its customer.  In an era of information leaks and data hacks this can be important and doubly so since this is software that piggy backs off a different installation.  Software installed without your knowledge is not the same as a cookie that you can block.


CA statement: "However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it."

Concern: This shows a clear lack of respect for CA´s customers.  CA maintains that they did nothing wrong and puts the onus of the problem on customers being difficult to reassure rather then on the fact that CA should have sought consent for this information gathering.  


If CA does not think there was anything wrong with this behavior, how are we supposed to trust them not to repeat it?

developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

review: total war attila, is a rts game set during the time of the collapsing roman empire, and other tribes/kingdoms struggling for survival across medeteranian. this games is by far my personal favourite from all the series. The game has intersting perspective than other games, in that is not about total conquest but survival of your factions. the game does this especially well, and that each decision you make, has an outcome. when i played as the saxons, i migrated my tribe across europe and make decision in choosing my battles and finding a good place to settler, as each choice is a risk. The campaign is by far the best its been, and keeps it intersting with different factions, graphics had improve over rome 2, and the map of the medeteranian is wonderful to look at. the AI has improved a bit but some of the issues of moving or setting troops. the battles are still a charm and seeing armies duke it on the battle field makes it as im watching a movie. the soundtrack is beautiful, captivating. multiplayer has been the same and getting freinds over to play is fun. diplomacy has still kept its system as rome 2 and by far still needs more improvement. MODS has really intice me to keep playing, as its comunity has some really talented developers that change the taste for this game from total conversion, popular medieval custom battles, campaign, units, graphics etc are very welcome. overall in my opinion, this is by far a new experince from the other series, a unqie, fun and enjoyable game. And i recommend any rts or new players to it. ;)

This game has a much better seige and combat system than total war rome 2 and everything combat is better. However, there is so much more annoying bullshit that goes along with this game that it is unplayable without mods and even with mods its hard. Infighting and politics is bullshit, the whole system sucks and does nothing but serve to piss you off. The disease spreads constantly, I have to deal with army loyalty, personal loyalty and more. This wouldnt bother me if it was occasional, but its constant. If I was really a leader of a faction I would have all the disloyal dogs families tortured, raped, and killed in front of them before doing all three to the traitor to discourage that kind of behaviour. You cant do any of that in this game, you pretty much just have to take treason like a bitch and wait for the civil war to kill anyone. I just wanted to play a combat strategy game, not play a corrupt snake politician and disease strategy game. Game should have focussed on combat more like all the games before, instead it delves into bullshit that only serves to benifit the keyboard industry from when players get so frustrated with the lack of combat and the excess of political bullshit that they smash it across their walls, tables, or heads. Total war warhammer is doing great, and is great to play as is rome barbarian invasion as well as rome 2 to a bit lesser extent, why? Because it focuses on combat like a fucking total war game should. Politics, diplomacy, and disease are all for pussies, give me war and if you have to add the foremention than do it in teaspoons rather than liters.

when I bought this game when it came out, I was very much afraid that it will be as buged as Rome 2 and will have the same problems. I have to say that Atiila did not disapointed me as much and was an awesome game all along the way

However, in the recent year, the game is going down hill with worse AI, un-wanted changes in the game (a very low number of soldier in every company, no mini maps, etc).

review: Attila is a good strategy game and is more than just some expansion pack for Rome 2 as some has accused it off. The game offers a lot of new features and strategies. For example, you can abandon your cites or play as a horde. The game also really makes you feel like this is the downfall of the Western Roman Empire and the beginning of the dark age. You can choose to fight for the Romans to try to preserve the empire, or you can play as the Vikings, Saxons or even Attila himself to destroy the Roman Empire and forge your own kingdom in the ashes of civilisation! All in all, I highly recommend this game!

My laptop exceeded the requirements to run the game, but it immediately started freezing up. Lowered all the graphics settings and spent a few hours trying to fix the problem. They won't give you a refund. I recommend buying an older Total War, unless you're 100% sure you're computer can handle it.

This will be a long detailed review so if you want a quick summary, if you're looking for a strong, enjoyable, challenging game [i]buy this right now[/i]. If you're short on money wait for a sale, although this game is well worth the base price.

To start, I've been a dedicated Total War player for years, sinking hundreds of hours each into Empire, Shogun 2, Napoleon, Rome 2, and now Attila. In my opinion, this is the best and most graphically pleasing one I've played so far. Granted, I have a thousand+ dollar gaming laptop that can run everything on ultra smoothly. Anyways, here's my list.

[i]Pros[/i]
Attrition- Developers have really enhanced this feature. Attrition, whether it be cold, hot, food shortage, swamp, mountains, or deep/rough seas, can quickly deplete your armies. Want to siege a city in the winter? Make sure you're force is strong enough to stand losing generally 20-30 troops per turn. Attrition forces you to strategize how and when in the year you'll invade a faction.
Combat- Combat has been overhauled dramatically, even based off Rome 2, to have many factors that can sway the tide of battle. Mastering the effects of the enviroment, weather, morale, and fatigue can dramatically improve your strength but if you ignore it it can be devastating. Battles now feel challenging and require attention constantly.
Generals- Generals are an importance in this game. Most factions you start out with a decent amount of generals and then they rarely become available afterwards. Generals alone can turn the tide of battle. Lose a general in the very beginning of a battle due to archers or an extremely lucky onager shot? Your troops will instantly suffer a dramatic morale penalty and will most likely rout soon after combat gets intense. On the other hand, having a strong general on the front line can significantly boost your forces morale and can win you the battle.
Seiges and City/Town Defenses- There are now archer towers and barricades available in almost every siege on a city or town. Archer towers have a huge range available to shoot flaming arrows at enemy forces. While they are pretty inaccurate at long range, they can rack up kills up close. I've even gotten extremely lucky and had enemy generals shot down by a lucky hit. The enemy will also usually set towards destroying towers first before pushing into the city so they can buy you needed time to defend. Barricades are somewhat useful at blocking off a particular street or entry but can usually be destroyed decently quick but can offer a crucial defense point in setting up bottlenecks on narrow streets.

[i]Neutrals[/i]
Archer Towers- While I listed them above as pros, they can also be an annoyance. You have no control over the targets and they typically shoot at whoever is closest. As stated above, they can be inaccurate and I've had my own city squares set on fire by missed flaming arrows. I guess it just depends on your luck.
Unit Rosters- While some factions such as Rome, the Huns, and a few others have huge unit rosters, other factions can lack or share almost the exact same roster. In the beginning of a grand campaign in mainland Europe, most factions will pump out Legio or Cohors and you'll end up facing the exact same armies from different factions. This problem is fixed though by hundreds of highly rated mods on the steam workshop that can easily diversify your gameplay experience.
Culture/Religion- While the game is host to a variety of different faction cultures and religions, they can be rather bare boned. Unit rosters are typically influenced by the culture the faction holds and this can result in multiple factions having almost the same roster, expect for higher tier units. Religion and culture does encourage you to focus on spreading your religion to newly conquered regions to avoid low public order and potential rebellions which in my opinion is a good thing. Having to put thought into how to manage newly taken territories is a good thing but again, they can be rather bare boned.
Politics- This is a big issue for many players. The politics system is something that must be paid attention to to avoid civil wars and rebellions but it can be difficult to understand. I had mutliple playthroughs when I first started playing end in failure because I neglected and ignored the politics. On the other hand, once you understand the poltics system and how it works you can prosper and reign over your faction.

[i]Cons[/i]
Diplomacy- While the diplomacy system works well and is really detailed, this is more of a personal matters. I've had multiple times were I would ask a faction for a non-aggression pact and gift them thousands of dollars just for them to declare war a turn or two later. While faction traits are a thing and can predict how a treaty will work with them, they sometimes don't matter at all. I've had factions with "Loyal" and "Trustworthy" traits declare war on me a turn after entering into a non-aggression pact. It's an annoyance mostly but still a con for me. On the other hand, I've formed extremely strong friendships and treaties with factions that wouldn't dare betray me. It just depends on your experience I guess.

My cons list is rather short as I'm extremely fond of this game. While the base game is great, thousands of mods increase the games potential and easily makes it one of my favorite games ever. I would definitely recommend it to someone thats looking for a challenging, exciting, thought-provoking game.

It's not the most optimised game but it still looks beautiful on lower settings. I'm running an i5 3470s, 1 gig GTX750 and 8 gig of ram. The game recomended Quality settings. But I still had to turn off some features of that were resource hogs and others down to a mixture of quality, preformance and max performance settings.  I turned up the unit size to ultra with unit detail on quality settings and the gameplay is as smooth as in Rome 2 running at 1600x1200. Though  I did notice a slight slow down when zoomed in but that was in a foggy battlefield amongst some trees. Rest of the battle was ok but be prepared for performance dips at times.

So be warned you might have to adjust your settings rather than rely on the game to tell you what it can run. Like I said before it still looks good on lower settings.

review: Even though I like the setting, this game's run like poo... Grab Rome II instead, at least it's run better.

Total War: Attila was my first Total War game since Rome Total War which I had played when I was a young teen and had loved. The enormous jump between the games left me feeling very confused and at first overwhelmed by the differences in the games. The difficulty of the game was ecspecially brutal and I had to restart the campaigns many time after I lost so many times. Yet this game is still one of my favorites I have ever played. The campaign really makes you feel that the world is falling apart around you as the Huns loot and raze settlements and the light of the Romans fade as barbarian kingdoms attack unrelentingly. But you have the ability to stop this and reform the Roman Empire to its glorious past. 

There are many positives: The family system within your faction means you will have to monitor your generals ad their influence lest a civil war starts, the climate change causes you to adjust and plan far ahead with food, the factions feel different with the Sassanids relying on a mix of archers, cavalry and some experimental units like naph throwers while the Romans rely on their elite infantry to win the day.

There ar of course negatives: The AI can be exploited as it is not the smartest and does not use great battle tactics. The public happiness of regions can be exploited by just building happiness buildings. Food prices for certain buildings such as barracks becomes outrageous when upgrading it fully. 

I would recomend this game however for anyone who likes Total War games or who is interested in trying these games, the difficulty may throw you on your but more times than you can count but it is a worthwile experience from beggining to end.
Laggiest game ever, 1FPs during end round on performance settings with a fairly new 1080TI graphics cards, would recommend any other total war game but this one.

firstly i dont have that much time logged on this title. ill be compairing alot of my observations back to shogun 2 where ive logged well over 1000 hours. 

lets start with the biggest issue, the combat. units feel clunky in motion. animations look a bit odd. units can act pretty odd when attempting to deploy them in a road between buildings by which i mean you cant actually stretch them out to their full length to either side. no this isnt an issue of hitting building hitboxes because the units can be redeployed to either side of thier initial deployment in the same width. as i said, odd.

in compairison to shogun 2, archers are all but useless. switching your archer to flaming arrows and targeting a tower is laughable, i thought to burn down a defenders tower and spent the next 6 or 7 minutes overseeing the melee only to turn and see the tower was still at around 40% fire damage, and still standing after id won the melee. the target is the size of a small barn or a large shed, after over 5 minutes of lobbing flaming arrows how did these poor poor archers fail to set the thing ablaze? and yes their about that effective firing into a group of enemy infantry...

unit compositions are pretty confusing. in shogun 2 you have 3 grades of units, monks, samurai, and ashigaru each for melee swords, yaris, naginata, bows, and matchlocks. in attila, rome has access to around a dozen melee swordsmen alone. im left stunned and speachless at the true variety of units, im not sure if this is good or bad as variety is always great but its going to take you a heck of alot longer than the 7 hours i put into it to even begin to grasp what unit is used for what and how good they are or not. spears, axes, and pikes have similar issues depending on what faction you choose to run, a massive variety that isnt uniform at all across the board (not a bad thing). this lack of uniformity gives the feeling that your truely fighting different culturaly inspired armies and is nice, however the complexity means you probibly going to need to drop dozens and dozens of hours to learn the units from each factions and figure out their strengths and weaknesses in order to counter them.

unit size and movement felt off in attila. in shogun 2 units moved in perct military formation with clear rows and collums of men moving as one. in attila units dont look to be anywhere near that professional. they looks to be nother more than a gaggle of civilians armed and formed into a militia in order to defend their town/city. they dont move in crisp clean formations but instead move like a large gang of people grouping together in an organic churning mass of flesh. as a former service member i much prefer the dress right dress, military formationed march from shogun 2 to the maurading clump of men i saw in attila.

destructible walls and field army fort emplacements look amazing! im sorry to say i havent had the privelige to try them out yet, but can only sing their praises from what ive seen of videos. maybe when i check back in a few month in the hopes some of the unit deployment issues are resolved (or mods are made to address them) ill get the chance to try this stuff out first hand.

siege maps are AMAZING! the maps are both large and spaced out allowing you to deploy gigantic armies without fear of having to cram all of your units into the top level of the keep where theire basically standing on top of one anothers shoulders to fit. this also means that you will need large armies to actually cover all the potential avenues of approach in a siege defense so take care, 4-5 units are no longer going to be able to hold all the passes into your city/town.

diplomacy and government. alright this is one thats going to be fairly contriversal. i loved the new changes. they are incredibly intricate and complicated. yeah i know, not a great start. but in shogun 2 one of my biggest pet peeves was in the late game in or around realm divide everyone and their brother declares war on you and your fighting a half dozen real time battles per turn. so each turn ends up takings several hours real time in order to move onto the next and slows your overall strategy and goals way down to the point you feel your making no progress. the level of infrastructure and governmental management u can bring to bear in attila may help to offset the feeling of the endless war when you get more than a hand full of factions declaring war on you.

graphics look a bit wattered down by compairison to the shogun 2 units. when zoomed right down to ground level graphics look fine, but when zoomed out the textures get muted significantly and it looks like your men are wearing simply tan t-shirts. for the record im playing will all graphical settings at their highest. the meshes for the characters are much more varied and comprehensive in attila which is a nice pluss. but the textures used to color those meshes just arnt up to the same level. in shogun 2 the meshes were all uniform, and the textures fairly simple but also uniform. at range when the units seem to become a bit blurry its fine because your likely looking at one end of the line and seeing them in full detail and your mind will fill in the lost details at range. this isnt the case with attila since each individual in a unit will have vastley different clothing textures from the person beside them. while the meshes are largely the same the textures coloring them mean that when a unit is further back you cant tell what it should look like, and it throws off your immersion.

the campaign map has made both improvements and had a few shortcoming since shogun 2. since shogun the campaign map looks much higher in textural quality. the areas feel far more open and you dont feel quiet so confined to specific developed roads. however armies can be difficult to spot on the campaign map, by which i mean in shogun 2 if u scroll accross the map, its almost impossible to miss the avatar of the enemy general/foot soldier, and their giant freaking flag denoting the size of their army. often the flags colors stick out in stark contrast to the surrounding lands. this isnt the case in attila. in atilla, there is a simple small circular symbol where the factions symble sits inside. the outside design of the symbol designates how "full" the army is. the enemy armies avatar rides a small brown horse and many of the avatars ontop of the horses wore earth tone colors, making it very difficult to spot them as the screen wheeled by as you pan around your growing empire. care will need to be taken to actually scrutinize your territories to avoid missing an army that just sauntered in.

overall i think the game has alot of potential. from what ive read, watched and experienced the ai is much better in attila than it was in shogun 2. i really REALLY wish i could somehow port over that increased intelligence but..... well guess ill have to wait for shogun 3. diplomacy/government upgrades are great if you want something other than endless battles to manage and the feeling of actually managing an empire. unit compositions are incredibly oversaturated giving you many degrees of each type of soldier to choose from, and the campaign map is more open and far more pretty looking with the beutiful textures they used.

at the end of the day i can neither recommend nor stear yall away from this game. i didnt personally like it because of the unit behaviour in combat, the overly complex unit compositions, and the odd looking unit textures displayed in combat. however others may see these additional units as simply more content and freedom of choice allowing them to customize their armies swordsmen to exactly the specific stats they wanted. i would say in its current state the game is a little bellow average. 

if u still want to try it after read this by all means. hope you found this review informative and helpful.

Total War: Attila was published in 2015. That's three years ago, and one might expect that major issues would've been fixed by now.

In 2016 I got myself a brand new rig (!) and installed Attila the first time.
I didn't play much, because the stupid game made my PC restart randomly. I am still experiencing the same flaming problem! And no, it's not my bloody GPU's temperature or whatever. I can run games on my rig smoothly, without any problems at all, that are newer than Attila and put a higher strain on the hardware (like The Witcher 3 and Dark Souls 3), but whenever I start TW: Attilla (IF it starts, that is) it still crashes when hitting the "End Turn" button.

I am not going to hunt for fixes on the internet (all they suggest is temperature related stuff anyway). I can live with some bugs, but I simply expect (!) that a game I bought for 50 EUR is running on my PC and doesn't wreak havoc on it.
Now, it's 50 bucks down the drain, but henceforth CA can choke on their bloody TW. I'm going back to play mods for M2TW.
This game has RedShell spyway bundled with it. I like the game but it will not stay installed with this.
developer_response:
Red Shell is a program we previously used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising – it’s not spyware.

It’s a marketing attribution tool that helps companies determine which of their adverts are most effective. It does this in a similar way to other analytics tools by using cookies to generate a unique token from device information, and comparing that with data taken from marketing campaigns and game activations. In this way, the companies that use it are able to see which adverts are more effective. You can find out more about Red Shell here: https://redshell.io/home

However, while Red Shell was only used to measure the effectiveness of our advertising, we saw that players were clearly concerned about it and that it would be difficult for us to entirely reassure everyone. As such, the implementation of Red Shell was removed from all Total War games that previously used it.

Total War Attila is a fun game with its many faction and their many elements that they each have. Campaign: This game has alot of different elements to consider such as the many factions and how the work. Let begin with non other than the Huns: They are nomads that use ALOT OF CAVALRY and the can only SACK OR RAZE a settlement to the ground so hard to fight against when you are the Roman Empires of Barbarian kingdoms. Next up none other than the Western Roman and The Eastern Roman Empires, These guys are hard o play as because you have a large empire to mange from Barbarian assaults To Attila the Hun attacking The western roman empire gets it hardest as all the settlement have low public order and you are being attacked from all sides. Next are two catagories: The Barbarian Kingdoms, The Great Migrators, You have (only counting base game factions) the Franks, Saxon, Visgoths, Ostrogoths, Vandals and, Alani or Alans. The barbarian kingdoms are at war with rome and they have many neighboring kingdoms around the like the Jutes which are masters of the seas and other smaller kingdoms but it geats easier to conquer and take more land as the Game progresses. The Migrators are the hard one of the 2 as the start out with no settlements to manage Exept your army is your settlment but you have to run aroun the 2 Empires or smaller kingdoms and you have to conquer and pillage until you find settlemnt to occupy, but this is where it gets hard as now you have more to mange and most of the time shaortly after taking the settlement it will revolt of you will be stretched to thin and will be defeated by other kingdoms. Battles and AoC, TLR: The battles are an improvment over Rome 2 and other recent games as they have a purpose and are fun to fight but unit selection for Barbarians is low mostly they have the same warriors. Age of Charlemange is a great Expansion for this game as it is different from base game completely as the nw kingdoms are all new and special in their own regards but it is the perfect expansion for this game. The other expansion is The Last Roman which adds a ton fo new features and the Roman expedition and how you can conquer for the eastern empire or make your own kingdom or the new Western empire and you have other factions like the Visigothic Kingdom, Ostrogothic Kingdom, Vandals, The Kingdom of the Franks. Overall this game is an amazing one in my opinion I would rate is a solid 9/10 de to all the new mechanics and features.

After putting hundreds of hours in Rome 2 and Shogun 2, I was pretty excited when Attila came out.  Was one of the few titles I purchased on release.  I bought it, installed it, and promptly neglected to put a lot of time into the game because, well, life. 

Now that I have more time, I recently reinstalled Attila and I can say it is my absolute favorite of the series.  And that's saying something.  The setting is great, the mechanics are respectable, and the game is a challenge.  Yes, it is a pig on resources, so you're not going to get 60fps on the highest settings on even the most capable setup.  But that doesn't matter - the game doesn't need 60fps (or more) like other titles.  My i7-7700, GTX 1070, 32GB, and SDD gets me around 50fps on high quality.  More than enough to play without jarring frame drops.

Currently I am playing on normal difficulty as the Franks.  I thought I was the cat's ass, expanded too quickly, and just got decimated by the AI last night.  Even so, I gave up a few settlements, retreated the armies, and still have time to rebuild.  It felt good to angrily raze the abandoned settlements into desolate land.  I'm sure there will be consequences, but I don't care.  If I can't have it, no one can!  I like that about this game - you can lose ground and still feel like you have a chance.

If you're a fan of Total War and haven't played Attila yet, you're missing out.  I plan on putting a few hundred into this one, then checking out the Age of Charlemange as well as the Middle Earth mod that just came out.  It's a great game and is definitely worth the investment.

Ok so I have just kind of started to write reviews mainly for just the Total War games because I only really play strategy on my PC and those games are mainly Total War just because I love playing TW. In my opinion there is just no other strategy game's out there to play that have the real time battles to control up tp 3,000 or even 10,000 man armies, and if there is it is not even close to the scope or mechanics of TW games. There are strategy games that definately do things better like in-depth city and settlement management with in-depth building chains and tech. But if you love strategy games because they force you to think out decisions and have a strategy of your own on how to win like myself then any Total War game will most definately peak your interest and give you hours and hours of fun. Now is ATTILA a good game to introduce yourself to the Total War franchise? And is worth the money? Is it a good game? Yes I do think Attila is a good game but definately lacks any real diversity in there units for each faction. After your first campaign play-thru you might start to find yourself geting boring with no real campaign mechanics that are special to that faction that you are playing as to make each play-thru something different. These TW games should have hundreds of hours of replay after the first campaign and Attila can get boring but the modding community for Attila has literally fixed the game into something much better then the vanilla campaign. I like the game but maybe i'm impartial because I just love CA because of the TW games I will pretty much buy any TW title they put out, it is a good game and as I mentioned with the Mods its a much funner one. You have Radious mods, Viking Age mod, All the reskins and overhauls  make the game fun as hell. I would definately get it on sale though I think the price is still at like 44$ but all the TW titles are on a crazy good sale right now. After the nightmare of Rome II, I put off buying this game or even caring. But I have to say, this is one of the best games in the Total War series. 

Attila has helped me better understand the history of the time period. The advance of the Huns forced entire nations to permanently migrate hundreds and thousands of miles away. The retreat of the Roman Empire left behind a power vacuum that many rushed to fill. This game does a remarkable job of recreating that environment. 

There is nice variety among the units and nations, too. And the soundtrack isn't bad, although Richard Beddow is no Jeff van Dyck. The flaws of Rome II have been mended and this is just a wonderful game. Buy it.

Attila is a interesting game in an era where the great roman empire is grasping for its last breath of air. This is the age where Germanic tribes began filtering into the once great Roman Empire borders as the Huns coming from the east increase their pressure on the tribes. Many would say it is around this time that the stars of the Western Roman empire begin to fall.

Attila total war allows the player to play many of the Germanic tribes of the day other than the Western and Eastern Roman empire. With the many DLCs added to the core game, you can be sure that players have lots of choices and each of the factions is unique and have their own survival goals and challenges. I find the game fun and recommend it.

Amazing launch which the last years rome II release should have been like past total war its taking the form of classic rome total war's expansion barbarian but with thee title Atilla so don't get mislead by its title. Its a solid game with next generation graphics with great texture and particle modification with the additional family tree and better environmental destruction.

Many new features were introduce back or new elements to shape this game are listed below majority greatly improves the gameplay and enhances the experience.

New Campaign Features

- Additional ability to raze and destroy settlements 
- Easy to identical unit cards compared rome II
- Additional barricade deployments additions
- Challanging historical battles according to historical timeline
- Bringing back family tree 
- Reinvented battlefield terrains camera
- Realistic settlement destruction 
- Emersive enviromental fire damage 
- Civilians added to settlement seiges and field battles
- Historical charactors play a pivotal role in the campaign

This game however requires a more modern powered GPU in order for the game to reach its full potential in graphical settings , personally if you were to purchase your first total war game this is simiply one that i recommend first . I have almost 700 hours and im sure there is more to come !!

[*]Family tree's return!
[*]Sanitation (how healthy/clean your city/province is)
[*]Fertility (how much food you can get in provinces, decreases over time)
[*]Hordes (Huns, Vandals, Goths)
[/olist]
[list]
[*]The family tree helps this game by making you care about your generals. I always have my king/prince in the main army, making me extra careful and therefore almost insuring I don't rush into battle, it's one of the best things about this game.
[*]At first the sanitation was kind of annoying, same for the fertility. Over time I started to like it, since it stopped the "mow through the A.I" type of conquest if only for a time. If you even cared about it, anyway.
[*]The hordes are basically like if you took a factions last territory in Rome 2, the difference lies in that the hordes have their own mobile camp and can also just burn anything in their way (any faction can but the hordes benefit more from it).
[/list]
Total War: Attila is pretty much a nice standalone expansion of Rome 2, tt has some nice expansions and seems like the perfect game to have mods changing the time-period both back and forth in time. Except for that though? Not much else.

I originally gave Attila an [b]8/10[/b], that was 2 years ago when literally anything seemed better than the train-wreck that was Rome 2.
Now though, I can't help but find Attila lacking in almost every aspect.
[h1]6/10.[/h1]
Fun game

this game is SH** worst campaign ever do not buy!!! this game tries too hard to be civilization, but fails so hard. I was expecting an RTS game... its so far from this. the campaign is so bad it is unplayable.

Very nice game but personally I believe it was saved by the MK 1212 ad mod.
Shooting arrows is my favorite part of the game as it can be such a satisfying experience with the different animations than TWR2.
It's good.

Long time fan of the series. This is a finely polished iteration of the game in a very interesting time setting. There are a couple minor gameplay changes i would make, like including some features from the older games, but overall the best historical entry in the series in my opinion.
I dig it

Yet another TW game that I sink my life into.
Lots of factions, plenty of tactics to employ, big battles and frustrating diplomacy.
Everything you sign up for in a TW war game.

Brilliant Base game (although not the greatest DLC) with a wealth of replayability with some amazing mods including the newest Lord of the Rings total conversion mod and my personal favorite: Medieval Kingdoms 1212AD offers a competitive multiplayer experience whilst retaining Attila's renown graphics but laggy engine.

Overall: A very good total war experience, some issues though. 6/10. I would wait until price falls to buy.


Graphics: Looks very good, especially if you have a good pc.
Gameplay: Pretty standard melee Total War. Unit collision is not very good though, large line battles quickly turn unto blob moshpits, can ruin the experience sometimes.
Story: There's not really a story.
Bugs/Glitches: I've had a pretty smoothe experience but a few random hard crashes have occured.
Gripes: Bad balancing, a lot of units like the Chosen Uar Warriors are completely overpowered and mow through almost every other unit. Naval battles are kinda boring. Archers are straight retarded sometimes, often firing directly into the backs of friendly units in front of them instead of in an arc. Artillery is way too effective against settlement walls, one onager (the worst artillery unit in the game) can take down multiple sections of wall and still have ammunition. Things like siege towers and archer towers have too much fire resistance, often siege towers can take the direct fire of multiple archer units (fire arrows of course) and have maybe 30% fire damage by the time they reach your walls. AI is meh at best. The game is three years old and still $45.
Extra: Modding community is very active and a lot of great mods are available to download.

Another solid entry in the Total War series. This game definitely has a different "flavor" than the other total war games with its turbulent number of events for a historical title. But I think it's interesting to note that veteran players might notice the combat feels somewhat comfortably similar to older titles like Rome: Total War. Make sure you have some decent hardware for full enjoyment. 

Some things you may/may not do:

-Kill or be killed by Attila's horde of 9999999999 cavalry units. (Obligatory)
-Think Rome is near defeat and then suddenly find a column of 40 heavily armored infantry at your door step.
-Raze that one pesky rebel region to ash because its not worth garrisoning it with two armies worth of upkeep.

Jokes aside this game is s p o o k y and challenging, I can't wait for the Thrones of Britannia so if you think you'd like this game it may be worth holding out.
I wish the launcher worked on Mac so I could use mods, but other than that great game.

The only attraction this game has is the real-time battles, and no matter what I do, I can never get my soldiers to actually fight when they are in battles. Since this leaves only the auto-resolution option, which will wipe out your entire army if you don't outnumber the enemy 80 to 1, there's nothing to do in this game, and I immensely regret buying it.

EDIT: Since this apparently needed to be explained in greater detail, when I enter a battle in this game, the soldiers under my command will usually stand in place and do nothing when I give them commands. On the occasion that they do follow commands, they move utterly without urgency, and when they do come into combat range of an enemy, they NEVER fight, even when their orders are to fight that particular enemy unit they are colliding with.

Add on to this the fact that, for every soldier I have, every other faction in the game has two or more of better quality, so even if my soldiers ever did fight, they would never be able to fair well at all.
Good game

Total War Attila, souly in my opinion, is one of the greatest Total War games. It brings the enviorment into a critical position, in which you cannot just cross the desert without fatigute and heat sickness, or march your troops in the cold in England. It also brings in a warlike vibe. Instead of already formed kingdoms, you can form a empire playing as one of the migrating factions. Diplomacy is also a essential factor to the game, in which you cannot go unpunished for invading a nation that is friendly with several others. Highly recommend this game!
should have been standalone expansion to rome 2
Spoiler Alert: The Hvns rape everything. Not as FVN as TOTAL VAR: ROME II.
I personally think its a very fun game, with hours/days of ocntent. Clocked in over two hundred hours and still find it enjoyable

[h1]Woth buying [b]ON SALE[/b][/h1]


This game contains of 2 segments- a clasical [b]Turn-based campaign[/b] where you can manage your provinces and armies; with an additional [b]Battle segment[/b] where you can command all your troops (up to 40 units) in real time- on both land and sea. Following ROME II this game introduced some new interesting units, nations and historical battles followed by playable [b]nomadic factions[/b] which instead of capturing settlements wander around the map setting the world on fire. With that in mind, the main object of this game is simple- [b]SURVIVE[/b]

Another in a growing line of insipid Total War games that followed the masterpiece Shogun Total War 2. The game looks fine, there's a very good tutorial, but the battles....why aren't Total War battles fun anymore? Just waiting around...moving too many units this way and that. Gone is the thrill of a calvary rush crushing troops instantly like Rome Total War (the orginal).  Province management has also lost its luster. Well, I gave it a try on sale at a very low price, and must eat the cost. If I want a TW fix I'll go back to Shogun TW2.

This franchise is on it's way down the toilet. It would appeear that we will never get back to the days of Medieval 2. This game feels like a hollow shell, churned out on a yearly release schedule. It's main purpose was to make money not a good game. Too many re-used assets and animations. Huge balancing issues. Most of the game locked behind day one DLC. Thrones of Brittania is looking to be the same as this too just crammed into the U.K. I think the developers need to go back and play their older games. They might realise how far they have fallen. I wouldn't even care at this point if we got a modern game as good as Medieval 2 that had micro transactions. Just make them fun to play!

I've been playing Total War for years and I can safely say that Total War: ATTILA is a complete piece of s***.

[h1]Cheating Campaign AI[/h1]
The AI in ATTILA don't have to follow any of the same rules the player does. You have to manage food, money and a constantly diminishing public order, while the AI doesn't. I've seen the AI pop up massive armies and fleets even though they only own a SINGLE town! The AI will pop up a massive tax free army out of their single town then sit there the entire game waiting for you to leave. You have two options, you either call all your armies and zerg rush them or you employ an army to babysit them FOREVER. If you ignore them they'll start raiding and taking over your neighbouring towns so you have to employ an army for every GOD DAMN SINGLE TOWN THAT DOES THIS! Seriously the campaign AI in this game can go f*** its self.

[h1]Public Order[/h1]
What the f*** were CA thinking when they added a constantly diminishing public order to the game. Nearly every building you build will give minus public order so you spend 90% of your time fighting off rebellions. A rebellion back then would of been a large group of somewhat organised peasants depending on whether they have a rebellious lord to follow, but in ATTILA a rebellious army has weaponry, equipment and logistics which makes absolutely no sense! One of my towns entirely comprised of a farm and a pottery store just rebelled and they're all carrying swords, sheilds and chain mail WHERE THE F*** DID THEY GET THAT FROM!?

I know this is an incredibly garbage 'review' I usually write proper reviews but my God this game blows. I'm going back to Medieval II: Total War.
If enjoy watching battles where about 80% of your army are watching from the sideline waving their sword in the air  yelling endlessely then this is the game for you.! -IGN 9.5/10

This review is by someone who has spent thousands of hours in the total war series. I have played almost all the historical titles and I can tell you this. Attila campaign is officially broken. No I am not talking about crashes on a PC. No I am referring to the gameplay itself. You try playing as any other nation and vs the huns, the game is broken. The huns will come with horse archers that can both defend against missile and shoot theirs very accurately and rapidly. And if you think you can chase them down, good luck as they can shoot you while riding at top speeds. I know they meant this to be challenging and I played this on Hard difficulty, not even the legendary difficulty and it is harder than legendary difficulty on many other total war titles. Unless they remove either the missile defense of these troops or the accuracy or the ability to rapid fire even while galloping away, I by no means can recommend this broken game. If you plan to buy this game then make sure to buy the DLC Age of Charlemagne, as this is the only DLC that makes this game worth buying for campaign.

As for multiplayer it is too bad they allow the same hun cav missile units in the game. There is the OP setup where you go mostly missile cav in the Hun faction and bring just a few melee units to hold them. The rapid fire is insane and it just breaks the whole game.
I like razing cities.

You want to raid and pillage the Western Roman Empire as its going down the road to impending doom? If so, buy this game! Plus if your a history buff, this game gives a accurate depection of the "Great Barbarian Migration" period on the European continent!
Worst Total War yet. Would not recommend at all. Purchase the earlier Total Wars if you're looking for a good game.

linux player don't have the same version of game so we can not play game with any windows player!

The campaign has no replay value because every campaign, you'll have Huns coming at you like a wrecking ball and WRE collapsing. The AI makes no effort at empire building, so you won't get any pleasant surprises like say a Frankish empire. Diplomacy is absolutely uninteresting because it's always everyone as part of the same "We hate Romans" crew and uniting on that point, until the Huns come along and then it becomes the "We hate Huns AND Romans crew. Then there is the fact that 99% of my battles are boring garrison defense battles, due to the AI's behavior.

And then there is unit diversity/faction playstyle diversity. The lack of it in Attila hurts the singleplayer but ruins the multiplayer for me, which is a big part of the game. Battles also happen too fast and it's more of a click fest dependent on who has the faster cav charge click than on overall strategic/tactical planning.

Also naval battles suck and I do all my fighting on land, even with the viking factions, if you create a boat in your towns harbour , the next move and turn u have all the AI boats in the game storm to your city to destroy that 1 boat emediatly... i mean what a complete joke and useless AI i have never seem in any games yet , u cant even build up some boats , they AI wont allow you and they detect if u just make 1 boat right away and comes attacking you from all over as soon as you build one.

The political system kinda sucks to control but it basically boils down to dominion bring controlled by the influence balance of your generals (you can keep this fairly neutral by not having just family members or non family members as really active generals. The control seems a bit of a crapshoot that you can influence with either the "gather support" action or with those random events that pop up when you try and do other politics actions.

Worst graphics so far in any total war games.... , still uses the same graphic engine since Empire Total War, they just darkened everything to get out more contrast. You see nothing, everything is too dark, don't know who is foe who is you, its impossible to see who is the enemies or your own troops during a battle.

Worst camera... still uses the messed up camera of Empire Total War, where when you zoom in, it slows so much down, you think you move in slow motion

I tend to get overwhelmed by different factions and I don't have the ability to defend my territory, IE I'm spread too thin. On top of that if I ever have to fight a naval battle, 9/10 times in absolutely screwed.

I find Attila's UI and art style ultimately depressing, dark and heavy compared to the Rome II's one...
After I came back to Rome II I was shocked how clear and light everything is.

The game overall is kinda trash compered to other games like the rome total war , medieval total war series.... the AI is behaving so redicules and bad its a joke... i never get to build up any settlements , all i get are AI constantly sieging me , over and over and over untill im dead or just tired of defending the same city killing off hordes of invaders by setting my self up at a chokepoint with pikes..... even if u are about to get on top and ahead in the game , random troops pops up that dont belong to any factions and destroys you , they even team up with your enemies and go 2 and 3 v 1 on you , with 3-4 full forces each , so ur basically fighting 4x3 armies at once , the whole game is against you .... trying to make your game experience a living hell so u cant progress what so ever , neighbour factions refuse any kids of diplomecy or refuse to help u against other factions even if u offer them all u have and then some , its just a hot mess and a joke , this game is so bad i cant understand how people manage to play it.
I have over 400 hours currently invested in this game and it's been sick watching the boys fight it out.

CA did listen to the fans and this game really feels and plays like a superbly modded version of Rome 2

Attila feels to me a massive return to form.

This is why:

CA did listen to the fans and this game really feels and plays like a superbly modded version of Rome 2 that wasn’t so lame. 
I even played a Seleucid campaign in Rome 2 recently and confirmed that Attlia is way better not just in terms of graphics but also the distance between settlements that results in fewer sieges and more land battles which is a very good thing.

You have a family tree to you can see who relates to who, who is loyal, who needs to have their loyalty improve or removed, who needs to be married and who to side line. – I must say I have am loving this bit of the game, especially sending off disloyal family members to raid faraway lands and keep them out of trouble.
Politics has improved as you carry out actions through influence rather than paying money making it challenging when you have a young inexperienced faction leader.

It has two Huge Roman empires to sack pillage and grind into the dust.

Combat seems way more dynamic with the need to co-ordinate spear, melee and cavalry to win but also adapted to the different enemies fighting Germanics, Romans and Huns does feel like a different experience. Hunnic horse archer is very difficult to fight against if you do not have powerful bows in you faction but can be countered if you use the shieldwall ability to soak up their arrows and then crush them when they are out. In all combat feels a lot more balanced and makes more sense

You can turn off the awful 3d animated portraits.

The coming winter puts a pressure on food and squalor preventing you from just playing like risk and sitting on one area building up and rolling forward like a wave.

The dynamism of migrating peoples making it hard to develop water tight cordons around your lands.

I know people have complained about razing settlement but if you use this mechanic to create a buffer zone you can then build up behind it can be superb. I also like the fact that if you have had a particularly bloody and agent heavy war with assassination and counter assassination of family members you just want to raze them and not rule them!

The campaign feels more fluid and challenging with fighting off and dodging the Hunic hordes and other factions.

In all I think Attila is a great Total War game and one that really deserve its place in the series.

Thank you CA for listening I fully appreciate what you did with Attila.

This one is interesting. I like the campaign mechanics but the battles are akward . . dont knowthe pace just does not feel right. Overall a pretty good game and a major improvment over rome 2. The setting is not as interresting for me but its a nice change.
id say 8/10 because the battles dont feel as good as they should

As Napoleon was an improvemt over Empire, Attila is an improvement over rome 2. The good and bad as per below:

The Good: 
- Many factions to play as (if you own all the DLC) 
- Great graphics (if you have the computer power to run it)
- Battles are fun, with a mostly varied unit roster 
- New/reintroduced game mechanics (family tree, horde mode etc...)
- Easy to learn
-Mods, endless mods

The Bad:
- Questionable DLC policy (again, same as Rome 2)
- Diplomacy still is a pain in the A** to deal with 
- Still some bugs and not very well optamised
- AI  can sometimes be very smart or stupid, and still gets lots of buffs (cheats)
- Some factions feel like rip-offs of others ones, not really any diffrerence between a few of them 

Its a good game, hopefully it gets some more TLC as Rome 2 is at the moment with patches/content, and it could be a great game.

I've played a ton of TW games, but this particular one makes me feel it was rushed just like Rome 2. At lease R2TW still received patches and support. The AI completely sucks in pathfinding and executing orders, imagine in a siege battle you tried to get a rear charge with your cavalry but more than half of the unit run into the wall instead of a blob of enemies, or they just flee in the opposite direction, or just ignoring your order and stop,sometimes they just take a relaxing walk instead of rushing by your order. As I remember this was fixed and it's much better in R2TW, TWWH1 and TWWH2.

Secondly, the artificial illogical hidden AI buffs in Legendary/VH difficulty, I can live fine with AI's campaign buff but the battle buff ruins it all when some enemy levies can go toes to toes with your elite infantry, or even better. Your general dies with half of his body guard alive, when their general is one of the last 5 be killed, Huns troops would fight to the last man and never rout if you killed their general. (srsly hunnic horse archer/uar warrior often fight with one man even if morale is -32 already). Changing battle difficulty in settings does not get rid of it at all. On campaign map, if you managed to destroy one Hunnic army but let one unit away, he will replenish full of a stack in the next turn on your own territory without encamping (WTF?) and immediately gives vengeance on your weak and withered army. AI agents buff is annoying and unreal, they can kill your 9 stars generals/agents easily with a level 2 spy, while your 10 stars Champion gets Critical failure with a 80% positive outcome, your agents will fail most of the time I'm sure with you.  CA you are trying  too hard to make your game stupid. Gold and silver armor/weapon/chevron upgrade do not make any changes in your unit stats, only bronze give a small boost, I tell you chevron and upgrades are just decorations.

AI's missile accuracy in a nutshell: "pinpoint and fast reloading as hell". AI's attilery NEVER MISS,they know your movement pattern and will aim for that, the only thing to trick it is carefully micro your horses after they fire. one unit of small ornager can destroy a standing cavalry unit in 2 volleys, they just need one volley to destroy a tower and snipe your onagers before they realize something,like is was taken from Empire TW's cannon codes, meanwhile your  large onager needs to fire at least 2-3 and more volleys to get one tower. Your archers and crossbows are stupid as **** firing in a straight line spreading and do team kill even you managed to micro to the back of a blob of enemy,their missiles still spread in a triangular shape. AI's crossbowmen fire in an arc upward in total accurate style and twice faster than your archers standing on the wall, destroying them. DON'T buy archers in this game as WRE, they can't even kill horse archers or enemy missile units standing still doing tiny damage and miss too much. I have seen a Hunnic horse archer ate 3 arrows and still alive. ANNOYING KITING AI, the devs gave the AI a supreme cheat whenever you click to chase enemy missile unit, it immediately gives them the code to run away! when you click stopchasing, they comeback and shoot right after. It is not related to skirmish mode as they run away at certain distance anymore.

The fertility mechanic which makes the weather colder nonstopable, that lower your food supply and all. at least we can use a mod to fix it.

Horrible unit design, you cannot say which one is higher tier units by their outer look, the Roman Empires design looks really bad no matter historical accuracy. (luckily one of my countryman created a mod named "Elite WRE ERE" and brought the game very close to Barbarian Invasion)

Stupidly low garrison troops, as WRE you have only one spear, one melee, one cavalry and one javelin unit(even for capital!?), they are all low tier until level 4 building (what?) and 100% defenseless agaisnt horde of barbarians early game, you hardly build a watch tower  because there aren't much more units until late game and it takes one building slot which is necessary for public order and food. The babysitting is real and frustrating.

Overcomplicated game mechanic,counting fertility one. Diseases that spread from neighbor factions that trade with you,despite your sanitation is good, but upgraded armory and weapons cannot be shipped to Legionaries in the front,Instead they have to go back to the region which has upgrade buildings,or excess food in one region cannot be used to help starving ones? ; Total food supply is positive but if one specific region is not a bread basket, you are screwed. Buildings which you never touch because their negative effects are more than its income. Loyalty mechanic that fucks up with the office given to subordinate trait. Don't bother to use office boost in this game,your generals loyalty will be no more, for example you give an office to a 2 stars general, the 2-10 stars in the pool will get mad which I can understand like in real life. If you give a 2 stars a lower rank office and a 5 stars the higher one, the 5 stars and all others waiting in the pool are still pi*sed, wtf.

AI that overaggressive and does "wallhack" on campaign map, you barely see ahead but they find and kill you suddenly with two full stacks. They'll try to avoid your towns with army and rush through the unprotected ones behind just to sack them, even when they know you will hunt them down in the next turn to kill them all, But when your troops and number are more superior than theirs, they will cowardly leave their settlements empty and run away,they don't even defend their large settlements. That's pure annoying and I have to delete the game. Luckily it's much better in Warhammer, even campaign mechanic is closer to Rome 2 and its predecessors.

Unit spacing problem in siege/forest/ fence, obstacles.

Many people may say I need to play on normal then but I always play on Legendary/VH because I like challenge, YET not the fake stupidly overwhelming one, it takes away the game's immersion and fun aspect, replaced by stressful and unreal gameplay. This game has so much potential and the concept of game mechanic is great, but It was very poor executed and lazyly refined. 

P/s: Instead of deleting the game I'll continue to play to exploit flaws and to write in this thread. Only one plus point I have seen so far is Generals and Agents change their appearance leveling up, and now there are factions that like powerful empires. Don't get me wrong I beat the campaign on very hard as Western Roman Empire, still doesn't feel good at all.
Some of you guys need to get friends so they'll give a shit about the multiplayer aspect of this game.

I love this game. There are a lot of great features about this game. I have 2 pros and 2 Cons

Pros

The Horde mechanic is  great! Every game can be so drastically different from another game as you are free to take your people wherever you want and found your civilization in any region. 

The Family tree is great. In all honesty, I hated it when I first started playing this game. As of now, I love it. It makes your faction, along with the others you interact with in the world feel so much more real. You are not just a faction, but a kingly lineage within your faction. This feaute also also gives diplomacy more depth. As a total war player, I always felt like alliances were a waste of time and would opt to choose to just kill those potential allies for their land. Sharing land with a ally for a military ally at the cost of being able to use a provincial edict was absolutley not worth it. Now with the family tree, you can make someone a govener of a province, enabling the use of an edict even if you only have a single cty in the province. With the family tree, you can also marry off the daughters of your family to strengthen bonds with another faction or vise versa. In my most recent game, I was the king of Mercia. Rather than just kill everyone in England, I united England under the banners of Mercia, Northumbria and Wessex. The Kings of Ireland declared war on me, so I strengthend the unity of my nation with my allies by marrying off a daughter to each country. After taking Ireland, all of England was unified. I then went to war with the Vikings while also organizing a marriage between myself and the Kingdom of Charlemange. After all of Engalnd and France was unified, all of the remaining Christian nations allied themsleves together. Like a wave we crashed upon the Muslim and Nordic empires . We won a Domination victory. This game woke me up to the usefulness of diplomacy and alliances that are now possible in Attilla that I found lacking in previous titles.

Cons

The graphics it requires is too much. I could run Rome 2 on ultra no problem and I can run the Warhammer games higher than Attilla. I definatley need a new Graphics card but still damn boi.

Faction diversity. The expansions dont really have this issue as much imo but still, this franchise has had this problem for a couple titles now. Factions just feel to similar when it comes to units. This is my own opinion.

I would reccomend this game, but wait for a sale, it goes on for a good prices often!

oh wait.

Edit: 500 hours later, I like it now.

Attila takes everything good about Rome 2 and fine tunes it. The combat is smoother, grittier, and makes more sense. Naval battles finally have depth and factions have culture specific ships. Setting cities ablaze in battle becomes a tactical option as opposed to a scenic side effect.

The primary campaign, in my mind, plays out in one of three ways: either you're a major empire trying to staunch the bleeding as your territory gets eaten at from all sides (Western Rome, Eastern Rome, arguably Sassanids), you're a barbarian empire trying to build a kingdom off of territory taken from Rome (almost everyone else), or you're the Huns and you're there to move around the map wrecking as much as possible without picking the wrong fight, All three workflows are equally entertaining.

The expansions provide further variety; The Last Roman offers a "two ways to play" choice for its titular character, either remaining an army on the move and reclaiming everything for the Emperor in Constantinople, or declaring your independence and rebuilding the Western Empire for yourself. Or you could be the barbarians, for some reason. In any case, it's peppered throughout with interesting pseudohistorical missions from different sponsors that often find themselves at odds with each other and leave you to figure out the lesser of two evils. Age of Charlemagne is in many ways a fantastic callback to Medieval 2 and even sports a different, Bayeux Tapestry-esque art style.

The long and short of it is, there's something for everyone here-- fans of Medieval and Rome alike will find endless hours of dynamic gameplay and near-infinite replay value. A well-rounded milestone in the Total War series.

This game is frustraiting and pointless to play because they kept what ultimately ruined Rome 2(Which makes them making it a separate title only Redundant), kept out BASIC and in the case of the migration era ESSENTIAL features like Being able to move or even at the very damn least select a new capitol should your capitol be lost for whatever reason. The diplomatic system is just as broken as ever if not worse than Empire Total War. It's clear to me this game was intented to have more complete features based on the number of seemingly half done features. The difficulty is fractured, despite there being easy, normal, hard, very hard, and legendary the reality is that you are met with only two distinct difficulties that is either AI doesn't Cheat by being immune to ALL financial diffiulties but is functionally retarded in the literal sense, or the AI does cheat by being immune to all financial issues and actually thinks to my surprise as advertised back in rome 2's infamous false alpha test. There is no middle ground despite there being a normal difficulty. I honestly understand why no real Total War fan acts like this game exists. With that said this game does have 2 good things about it. Everything else is either broken or incomplete, those two things are. 1. The Storyline in the Grand Campaign is beautiful and cinamatic despite poor optimization, I have to turn off all other sound in the room and sit back and enjoy the ingame videos. And 2, the battles, despite having an inferior engine for melee combat, the battles and clashes look and feel solid, I thought they restored the old engine for melees or had a hybrid engine until I zoomed in to see the um scripted gliding that had to be done to initiate an animation. Unfortunately with all the essential and basic features of previous good Total war games removed like say stand-your-ground, you have to babysit every unit. It's a mess, a mess that sadly pisses me off to the point that the games second and only redeeming quality overshadowed by what comes off as an irritatingly unfinished game. The migration mode is interesting, however overrated despite my initial like for it. I think this is the last Total War game I ever by, until CA lets the developement of these games actually be completed or TA developers actually give a dam for this series like they used to, i fear we're just going to be continued to be sold 60$ unfinished and cut for individual sale copouts. I loved this series. I even like Empire Total War, but this I just can't like, I'm sorry but i prefer complete games that the developers actually care to complete.
