I must admit that my hours in this game are not many, however I think I have  gone through enough different gamepays and forums know that I can review this relativey accurately. 

Because I realy do like the total war series I will start off with whats good about the game so that I don't just come off as a hater

Positives: 
-Nomad factions are a great fun way to play I and I really enjoy that added versatility 
-graphics on the battle map are decent(running on max) its the campaign map that realy looks good though. 

Negatives: 
-Its just like Rome 2, like honestly it is a re skin pretty much which isn't bad, but there is no reason it couldn't have just been a DLC
-The campaign AI is complete shit(honestly this is what ruins the game)
-Greedy devs rather than productive devs

Now of course I will elaborate on the negatives, the first is pretty self explanitory, but the campaign AI is the big one, if you're like me not only do you play this game because of the big armies and people killing eachother, but for the historical realism and being able to replicate and change things in history in the form of the total war campaign, well kiss any historical realism goodbye in this game, you just aren't gonna get it. For example my first game I went as Visigoths and Was enjoying myself raiding the undefended roman cities, by turn 20 or so I had gotten down into rome and had succesfully sacked it, at this point I was thinking it was a little too easy, I had not even met and roman armies, only garissons. My next goal was to go down into spain and sack those roman cities and just continue being a nuisance. On my way back up north through italy I find what was missing the whole time, 4 full stack armies are right above florence which I don't have any prayer of beating. Now here's the big surprise, those 4 armies weren't even Roman, they were all Hun armies that decided that fuck history they only want to attack the visigoths now, so of course they chase me south into italy and since I I am nomadic I do'nt have time to make a fleet to sail out and they kill of my people in the corner of Sicily and that is the end. Now I realy woudn't have minded al that much if those armies had been roman, because at least that would be semi accurate, although there still should have been resistance going into rome, but no its dmaned Huns. I of course go onto forums and find out that this problem has been happenning since 2015 and Devs have done nothing to fix it, which brings me to my 3rd point, which is that the Devs for Tota war, do not make updates or patches or any kind of improvment to the game, unless you have to throw down the big bucks to get it, and of course all they release are DLC. with added campaigns and more stuff that doesnt matter as long as the AI is still trash. Medieval 2 is what I have played the most and the AI in that is horrible as well so I coming into Attila, a much newer TW expected some improvement. So what did I find, I found that it was different... But it was still so bad that this game is pretty unplayabe to me if I actually want to enjoy it to the ful extent that I should be able to. Most people would say they will change their review if the devs fix things, but you don't have to worry about that with TW because you know they never will.

This is one of my only negative reviews.

Bought the game on sale, still requested refund. Denied, since I have 14 hours of empty play-time from having to restart the campaign 4-5 times and having to wait glitched battles out until the timer forces a draw (that's 20 minutes every glitched battle).

I feel like I have been cheated. The game's AI is in such an abhorrent state that you need to constantly save games like back in the day with Fallout 3. Otherwise, you risk losing your entire campaign to a game-breaking glitch, like AI ships refusing to attack in a siege battle with unlimited timer (leaving you in an eternal stalemate) or your ships bugging out while boarding so you lose control of them (again, potentially leaving you in an eternal stalemate).

Some of these issues can be"solved" by not playing with an unlimited timer, but I don't exactly consider it a fix to wait 20 minutes every other time I'm besieged because the game is holding my computer f*cking hostage. I have found plenty of other players echoing these issues, some of which CA has responded to, some of which are from 2013. This is apparently not a new problem, and they know. They just didn't give a f*ck when they sold me this sh*t, and haven't bothered to fix it since then.

I love the Total War franchise, but this is unacceptable. Apart from the AI, the game is filled with obvious last-minute wrap-ups, like half of the portraits being lazy CGI screenshots (as opposed to hand drawn images like the rest). Some of them are even the same CGI environments, just zoomed out (look at the Amber Trader and Amber Market portraits). Another good one is rain falling upwards or sideways on half of the art-assets during battles. This is not to optimize the game, it doesn't save space or CPU, it saves development time otherwise spent on fixing it, so they can churn out some more faction or f*cking gore DLCs, that should have been in the game to begin with. Of course, this isn't game-breaking, it's just indicative of how little of a sh*t they give about the consumers or the product they're selling them. If these were the only issues, I'd happily recommend this in a heartbeat. However, spending 2 hours of my afternoon staring at my screen, waiting for stalemated battles to time out, somewhat soured my opinion.

Considering how many iterations the TW series actually have, it's a pretty bad strategy game. Over all these years TW hasn't improved much: retreating armies is still totally random, the big campaign strategy mode doesn't offer much indepth gameplay mechanics like e.g. logistics, siege is still buggy as hell and the wayfinding of units on the tactical level is terrible.
 
Overall I can't recommend this game for any serious strategy gamer in good conscience.

I would most certainly reccomend this game. while it sticks to the classic formats that made other games such as Total War: Rome and Total war: Shogun, the addition of the great migrators faction type and the hunnic tribes faction type spice up the gameplay in a way that adds something new to the game while not straying to far from the normal format, making it accseible to Total War veterans and new players alike. The setting of the game,detailing the rise of the huns, remains as historically accurate as possible while still creating a fun  and interesting game for those who do not wish for full on accuracy. for those who wish for real time strategy historical battles, the game still has those to offer for history buffs. the game has a wide variety of factions to choose from, from the more popular and well known factions like the eastern and western roman empires, as well as lesser known factions such as Aksum, the Suebians and the Garamantians. this game truly has much to offer for all types of strategy players from new to old, and was certainly worth EVERY DOLLAR.

Definitely worse than its predecessors. The atmosphere making them great is missing here. Attila is more complicated but this does not make it more enjoyable, quite the opposite. There are always pressing issues, difficulties are always mounting to the point where it simply becomes annoying.  Graphics is so-so, the units look simplistic, even unfinished. I always liked to  look at my units  in previous TW titles but not here. Did I mention women "fighters"?

In terms of an interesting campaign, this Total War probably takes the cake. The blood and gore DLC makes battles especially entertaining. I've spent 145 hours playing and won two campaigns (Visigoths and Geats, both H/H), and spent other hours trying different factions.

On the pro side:
- Vastly different campaigns depending on what you're interested in; nomads bent on killing and destorying, barbarian kingdoms starting small and creating empires, and vast empires fighting to retain their incessantly raided borders.
- Blood and gore DLC, plus battle mods from the workshop, make battles realistic.
- Friendly fire exists.
- Tactics appear to be more essential in this title vs. others.
- Interesting dilemmas.
- Family tree, intrigue, dominion, and control are great features for controlling inner politics.
- Traits for generals and governors add another interesting element to the game.

On the con side:
- Glitches... there was a glitch in my Geat campaign where a whole portion of my family tree (including my heir) were listed as other nobles, so I couldn't use normal family intrigue with them--had to declare a new heir in fear that giving the crown to a potential non-family member could wreck my campaign. Very minor stuff outside of this.
- Siege battles tend to get repetitive. I got bored of the DLC with the Roman Expedition pretty quickly, because every siege battle started looking exactly the same--same garrison, same terrain, everything. Probably a coincidence, because I've never encountered this before.

Creative Assembly really went overboard with Attila. For Rome 2 I had such high expectations, and was thoroughly disappointed due to the lack of features. As such, perhaps I wasn't expecting much from Attila - after all, it had a rather quiet release (in comparison to Rome 2) and was 15 dollars cheaper at launch. My low expectations were blown away, just with the gameplay elements alone.

Attila combined many of the great elements of previous Total War games and squished them all into 1. CA brought back the much-loved Family tree, the ability to assign members of the court into political positions (similar to the cabinet feature of Empire), and expanded on the disappointing, but novel political features that debuted in Rome 2 - such as court influence and imperium.

As for the actual "war" aspect, battles are still incredibly fun. When playing as either of the Roman Empires, holding back the barbarian hordes as they are chased by the Huns is a wonderful game mechanic. The Romans have a great arsenal of units to deal with any threat from barbarians or the eastern empires.

[h1]A Word about City & Village Battle Maps[/h1] 

The whole idea of burning cities and villages in Total War: Attila is pretty cool! 

Trying to perform even the simplest type of unit redeployment inside of a city or village, however, will, in two out of three cases, drive you, as the human player, freaking mad due to the complexity of the new and fairly detailed city and village battle maps that are cluttered with random little objects - junk, scrap and what not - which all interfere with your ability to position or move your units around like you would normally expect in a real-time battle of the Total War series. It is now, in comparison to Rome2, almost always simply impossible to navigate through or reposition your units inside of a city or village without getting instantly foam at your mouth when there always seems to be something - invisible - that is obstructing or hindering your units from changing position!

You can honestly never be sure that what looks like an obvious position for your units to deploy or path to move along is actually useable terrain, and it's seriously freaking painful to manage even if you're enthusiastic about TW: Attila.. 

And to add insult to injury, the game even starts to hang inside of city or village maps whenever you try to drag a square to redeploy one of your units thanks to all the fancy, new city and village [i]decorations[/i].. I think it's fair to say that this is evidence for Creative Assembly mindlessly adding new features to an old and never really convincing game engine without actually playtesting what they were doing.

TW: Attila is in a lot of places a solid step forward compared to Rome2, but in other ones, like the new city/ village maps, an obvious step back.. I never ever had such a bad time ordering my units around inside of cities or villages in Rome2. The only thing that remotely resembles my bad experience in Attila are Rome 2's ramparts where the game starts to severely drop frames whenever parts of a unit get stuck somewhere.. 

Buy if you're willing to fight Attila's city and village maps instead of the enemy!

Total War: Attila

"You built an empire beyond imagining. The pinnacle of human achievement and the envy of the world. Did you think it would last? The eternal city. That glorious monument to power, culture and learning. But the Old Wolf lies wounded; surrounding by jackals; circled by vultures. Worried to death by a thousand, tiny vicious mouths— brought low by your own arrogance. These are the death throes of Rome. The light of civilisation dims and gutters. And if such precious time was left to hide your women, for your children to cry, even at the moment of your final defeat you would still take no comfort in oblivion. For I am coming for you. I RIDE WITH A MILLION WARRIORS! I BRING THE END OF DAYS!!. I AM!! THE SCOURGE!! OF GOD!!!. And I will watch your world... Burn. “

These are the words that Attila greets you with into the world of Attila Total War. His world, so it would seem.

Total War: Attila is the installment in Total War, a franchise of turn based strategy games. Total War's unique selling point is combining turn-based campaign management in the continental scope, with real time battles with a potencial of many thousands of troops battling it out in a map, with you in total control of one side. After a mostly failed launch of Rome II installment, plagued by performance issues and bugs, the developer, Creative Assembly was focused on fixing Rome II and developing Attila. Not only they managed to redeem Rome II from its technical issues, but they also managed to churn out an excellent upgrade to it, which is what we should regard Attila Total War as. It is a great improvement in both the game mechanics and climate.

The Setting

“The walls shall shake at the noise of the horsemen, and of the wheels, and of the chariots”
- Ezekiel, XXVI, 10 

The year when the campaign starts is 395 AD and the grim and cruel promise by our friend Attila could not have hit a better time. Years of mismanagement and the subsequent splitup of the Roman Empire, has brought its western half down to its knees. The Eastern Roman Empire fares only somewhat better. Internal struggles tear the Rome apart. As if it wasn't enough, the climate changes. It gets colder and not only the fertility of the Roman lands will fail, causing famines and further disorder, but the barbarians that once lived beyond Rome will be compelled to move out of their homes, right into the falling empire. And on top of the food chain of the desperates and hordes, admits the smoke, blood and cold, the Huns, will come. With them, death, war, pestilence and hunger. Above them, Attila. Flaggorum Dei.

Regardless of which faction you pick to play as, the Total War, up until now being all about ascending into great and soon sole power in the world, offer you much different prospects, both in theme, and in situation. The game slogan puns Rome II's “How far will you go for Rome?”, going “How far will you go to survive?” And indeed, the first choices you will make will not determine your ascendancy: Just your survival as a realm.

Otherwise, the game does not differ much from the usual Total War deal. Settlements with buildings, armies that you lead to your own and enemy territory, all on turn-based, good-looking map. The two primary aspects of the faction you play as on the campaign map, are its settlements which make you money as you develop them and its armies, which are raised from your cities. The said armies can move out on the map to defend your possessions and to expand them. That's a very basic description.
The Campaign

“Nothing happens to anybody which he is not fitted by nature to bear”
-Marcus Aurelius 


Much like Napoleon Total War was more or less a fixed Empire Total War, this can be best described as an upgrade to Rome II system. The food mechanic actually matters now, with the introduction of provincial fertility system: Some provinces will yield more food than others. Fertility decreases overtime, giving you that sense of the nature itself turning against you and conveying in a perfect way what drove the Great Migration that was a nail in the coffin of Roman Empire. For if you are non-Roman, your land stops supporting you and you are faced with prospect of a famine (or when the Huns start molesting you), you have an option to become a migrating horde: The star and prime mechanic of the game.
When you start a migration, all your settlements are razed and abandoned (provinces can actually be ownerless now), but your armies are given the additional aspect: The transition to nomadic lifestyle is manifested in the armies being given population and ability to make buildings, essentially becoming mobile cities. However, unlike static settlements, those cities would be lost for good if their army was unmade. They have unique building chains and will be on the move until they can find a place you deem worthy of conquering, upon which you lose your city aspect of your armies. Or stay mobile forever. It's up to you.

The user interface can be a bit of a pain to learn to control, espeically if you're not familiar with Total War. Perhaps such is the fate of interfaces conveying the amount of information that Attila one does, but it's still compounded by a relatively high difficulty level. Every choice will have to be weighted carefully, unless you fancy reloading saves as often as some do in XCOM games (read: often.) Nonetheless the game does not condemn you to that gloomy apocalyptic feel of the call to migrate being a matter of life or death. Depending on what you choose to play as you could start out as a migrant horde, or be Sassanid Empire, living it up in the ever-hot and fertile Middle East. Or you could lead Huns and eventually, the Scourge of God himself. Or, if you are up for an ultimate empire building, no, empire survival challenge, you can place yourself at the helm of Western Roman Empire. Can you turn the tide of history and make the Rome great again? Or will Attila watch your world burn? It has its issues, though: major league micromanagement being one of them. It's also nigh-impossible to win while maintaining Christian temples, which are all very, very expensive in upkeep. Seriously, I understand that excessive Church spending is what brought down the Byzantium and that Catholics like me love their church bling, but this stuff is extreme. Get a mod that buffs Christianity if you're going for Western Rome.

Speaking of religion, its relevance is further fleshed out and manifests itself in tensions of heathen populaces and diverse bonuses provided by religious buildings. A realm that accumulated enough populace of a certain faith, can make that faith its official religion, which will influence the aesthetics of its army and what its troops talk about, further boosting the immersion in the culture you lead.

Politics were a painful aspect of Rome 2 that were too irrelevant unless something really started to break the order. Attila fixed them. Now, the low and high power balances bring along both benefits and disadvantages,with absolute political dominance coming with high debuffs, making it justifiable in only few select situations. Even armies have integrity value: losing battles and not resting in friendly territory will cause them to revolt against you.

Each general and family member is now of certain loyalty, which is a variable that handles rising of civil wars from now on. Total political balance is influenced by A: How much influence (sort of political mana) your family as a whole has compared to other generals/characters and B: By level of control, which is a static value influenced by the political events. Your ruler can also have children. Male children will eventually become generals or governors, depending on your pick, whilst female children can be sold... eeh, married, to powerful non-family member characters to shift the political balance in favor of your family, or sent to marry abroad, to gain you a foreign ally.

The Battles
“Nation will rise against nation,

Attila is probably the most underrated TW game. It's an excellent game, chugs a bit even with good hardware, but is a fun experiece. Good amount of content, more complex than R2 for sure, good fun. This game is a slight improvement on Rome 2, but is overall a shortcoming in the Total War franchise. Its battle repeatedly pressure you into the same scenarios while you fight the same clunky AI on the same of about 3-4 battlefields (Mainly due to the repetitive nature of towns) and inevitably either win, or are cheated out of a victory by morale penalties that force your men into breaking.
 There is no significant improvement in the franchise and the game feels as if it only has less features. Added buildings don't appear in the cities the way they did in earlier Total War titles either. This is a lazy repolish of a much better game with added resource management based on arbitrary numbers that were not properly balanced (referring to food and public order) Naval combat is still as simple as spamming artillery ships. Hadrian's Wall has no impact on gameplay. You still cannot control the direction your army routes. Towns and forts inexplicably decide not to add gates so as to speed up the gameplay. Diplomacy is as lacking as ever. About 5 random events will be cycled through to give the (false) impression of depth to politics in the game.
 If you want Rome Total War Barbarian Invasion with updated graphics and no soul, this is your game.

Intriguing and as addictive as any other Total War games.
8.5/10
+ Stunning graphics depicting the early Dark Ages: Fire, Sword [strike]Magic, and Dragon[/strike]. Building destruction features more smoke and particle effects, and for the first time arrow shots boast a clearer trajectory, as fire arrows could possibly light up the night sky, certainly to impress.
+ Epic battlefield simulation, especially when intense AI combat between a desperate Roman soldier and a blood-thirsty Gothic warrior feels so hardcore and real.
+ Featuring unforgettable-as-always soundtracks perfectly suited to every frame during the game, also with impressive exotic Nomadic (especially Hunnic, inspired by Mongolian Hoomii), Byzantine and Persian-style melodies.
+ Typical hardcore Total-War experience as there are no eternal allies, no constant economic booming nor continuous good luck, it's only War that never changes, and CA has added some new elements to the politics, where being in power depend no only on pure-influence anymore, and they introduced a brand-new nomadic system, with settlement-destruction now an available option. But to some, this broader focus on political intrigue or city ravaging rather than pure war makes Total War Attila less of a warm welcome than previous titles, Shogun 2 and Rome 2.
+ Perfect units overhaul, especially with the help of Steam Workshop for enhanced accuracy on history. When playing Shogun 2 I would always remember, in some 80 percent of gameplay, watching identical spearmen and bowmen fighting on both sides of the battlefield, and some clan-typical units are just too expensive even after you manage to clear the whole map.
+ Enjoyable experience playing as the Huns, as both the morale debuffs on the enemies or simply improved Parthian Archery would guarantee a unique decisive-victory experience, which is only realizable in Attila.
+ Good War logic. In Attila, morale would play an important role but just no so decisive as in previous games, where it would take forever for multiple groups of infantry units to cause great casualties to each other, while in Shogun 2, a group of samurais with their flanks exposed to ashigaru militias would quickly scatter and be slaughtered. And more importantly, Total War Attila has kind of made cavalry units great again, where generals are no longer ridiculously vulnerable to spearmen, making them again good victory-claimers by simply going round and biting the enemies' tails, [strike]and making Attila a game of the horsemen[/strike]. It's probably because of the rise of "stirrup" as well as shock cavalry around that time, which appears no later than the famous Charles-Mattel's Victory of Poitiers.

- Elaborate in-game CG animations are now nowhere to be seen any more, with Shogun 2 being the last title to date to feature tons of incident animations.
- Frame rate optimization is poor, making Attila a qualified hardware-killer in 2015. 
Some would regard Attila as a mere content expansion to Rome 2, but to me it is always worthy of the test of time.

I got into Total War from the Warhammer franchise so when I started playing this game, I was shocked how much complexity the game offers compared to Warhammer. I now know what they meant by "streamlining". Therefore this review is for people who have played Total War: Warhammer and not any previous installment. 

TWA has what TWW doesn't have.

= Weather Conditions: Rain, fog, dryness determines the battle a lot. The fog of war as well as flamability can be affected by these.

= Varying Tax Rates: You can set the national tax rate to different values in addition to exempting regions from taxes.

= Flammability: You can set stuff on fire and it can affect the enemies morale. Some people (like Atilla) want to watch the world burn.

= Court Intrigue: You can have heirs, wives, court system.

= Varying arrow ammunition. Heavy, Normal, Fire, Whistling Arrows all have their special uses. You can switch during the battle. Fire boulders and normal boulders for artillery.

= Sea Battles and Naval Invasions: Something that TWW cannot have unfortunately.

= Better Siege Battles: You can actually surround a city as well as having actual towns in fights.

= Disease (Not like the Skaven disease)

So far, I'm having a blast with the game but I did prefer playing AoC due to the setting.
I got the game on sale so I highly recommend you do the same as the price can drop hard for this title. For that reason it isn't worth $45 as you can get it on sale for cheap.

Alright, so I've played several Total War games. Played Medieval and Medieval 2 when they came out and honestly was never very good at the games. But I enjoyed myself no less. I've poked around at a couple other Total War titles, Rome 2 felt weird and I saw a lot of peopple didn't like it. Total War Shogun 2, I haven't touched much, so can't say much there either. But Attila is what hooked me. That said, let's get on with it.

Total War Attila has several layers to it. But nothing horribly overhwelming, at least in terms of actually learning the game. Figuring out the way dominion, power and such balance out is a bit of trial and error, but once understood it's an aspect of the game easily controlled. But when taken advantage of and using politics as a means of gain over just battle and territory gain can come at a massive advantage later in the game. Especially when the star of the game shows up, Attila the Hun and his Mongol horde. But we'll talk about the horde in a moment. Other gameplay elements remain very similar to the other Total War titles I've played. A modest but fleshed out variety of units with a great unit-counter tree with a somewhat clunky UI that can feel like it's throwing a lot of information at you. It's another trial an error thing, but hardly confusing, just requires practice to the uninitiated.

Graphics look fantastic for it's time and still look good. However the game can have it's slow downs and sharp drops in fps. I'm no coder 'nor do I understand computing language. So whether it's just poor optimization or the game simply requiring a bit more processing power than it says is a mystery to me. I'll drop my PC's specs at the end of review for comparison. But for the most part, things run fairly smooth and I think it should be expected for things to chug a little bit when there are over 4000+ units on the field engaged in battle. If you've ever played major 4x games like Civilization 5 & 6 or Sins of a Solar Empire, I'm sure you'll understand the late game struggle when your fps slowly but surely drops due to the sheer amount of things going on at any given time by that point.

I do feel some of the game was chopped up for additional content, but I honestly feel like the base game still has a modest wealth of content. Nothing mindblowing, but it hasn't left me wanting, considering a single grand campaign can potentially take twenty hours at the bare minimum, but of course, I'm hardly an expert at this game. But I suppose the developer/publisher needs that little extra revenue stream if that ensures we get more great Total War games in the future, if of course, that is the intent.

Now, the horde. And one other thing. First we'll talk about the issue with the horde. They've overpowered a bit. At first it's not so much, be given about sixty or so turns in the game, they turn into not only a force to be reckoned with, but depending on several variables, they become just short of unstoppable. Though this isn't entirely the development teams fault, as they DO give the option for quite a bit of diplomacy and even forewarn that only your struggling barbarian empire or divided Roman empire cannot hold back the horde alone. But even then, the Huns have the uncanny ability to just roll over almost everything in sight. So it's one of those cases where they are in fact overpowered, but can be overcome with strategic planning and not overextending your empire.

I'm not doing very good with this review. So let us talk about that other thing. Difficulty. The AI is really only so smart and from what I can tell, will usually use the same tactics no matter the difficulty. I'm not sure, but I highly suspect the change to difficulty only modifies the amount of money other empires get, giving them an edge against your empire, which, mid to late game, becomes almost traumatic and tremendously difficult. Especially the Hunnic empire, which will have cash bleeding out of every orifice. 

Now I haven't even touched multiplayer yet due to both a lack of confidence in myself and my general distaste of playing multiplayer games in general. So my opinion there is a blank, sorry.

Now a quick note involving the dlc packs. One of which is garbage and should be made free for the game. A dlc that adds blood and dismemberment, along with some other animations that would steep this game into the Mature rating. This content wasn't added to keep a Teen rating which is ridiculous and outright theft. Now that may be a bit of a leap and really isn't terribly damaging to reputation, but a very stupid move by the publisher to reach other demographics while alienating others due to highly questionable business tactics.

Not much else to say I guess. Game looks good, plays good and overall has a nice fit to it. Though it still sells for something like $45(USD) I think it's almost worth it's price. If you see it on sale and have enjoyed the Total War series before, get this game without hesitation. I know at this moment, on sale, it's about $12(USD) which is quite a discount. Though to be honest, I feel the base price should be lower due to the overpriced DLC which comes with the game, but doesn't do anything truly interesting. But yea, I'd recommend this game. Just buyer beware and pay attention to what the DLC has to offer and check out other reviews. It really is a fun game, but it's certainly not for everyone.

Rome is weak. The Empire is divided, with enemies around every corner. The world is changing, the days grow dark. The Huns arrive from the East. The horsemen of the apocalypse have come to drown the world in blood. Take the reins and lead your horde to the Eternal City or forge an empire deep in the desert, balancing your finances and military, all while your family tries to depose you. Will you become the Saviour of Rome, or the one to bring about it's demise?
If you love grand strategy and/or commanding old-style armies in large scale combat this is a great game.

-The map is massive! So much to conquer
-Interesting theme, with the roman empire falling and germanic empires taking over
-Fights are good, with lots of good troops (Though melee cav is now op like melee infantry was in Rome 2)
- AOC is an amazing DLC! Totally worth the buy.
- The workshop opens so many possibilities, with many people making overhauls with new factions!

Cons:
-DLC, so much dlc. Although the AOC is in my opinion a good dlc, the others, especially the ones to get factions in the main game, is insane. DLC should not be allowed in a 40 dollar game, or not for factions that you should have.
- Politics is useless. I mean you get that extra 2% but you can easily win without it.
- God damn spies. The AI cheats a ton, with ways to make absurd amounts of money when they should clearly not be able to afford to obtain so many troops and armies. 
- The AI, along with cheating are pretty easy to deal with, mainly being annoying (especially being able to make so many armies and send like 20 spies and champions)
- I don't get how fertility becomes so bad in such a short amount of time, it's incredibly unrealistic of how fertility actually was in the 5th century, and it is difficult to recover lost fertility.
- Imperium stops you from making more armies, with now instead of money allowing you to make more armies, it is regions that decide how many you can make.
-Campaigns are often long, unless you set your own victory goals.
-Christianity sucks. If you are any nation with any form of Christianity rid of it immediately.

"Total War: Attila" is a perfect game for players who enjoy strategic games and history (like yours truly).

I can only recommend this game when it's on sale. Big total war fan overall but it seems to be getting tedious. They brought back the family tree (why did they ever take it out?) and a few other features, but it seems that with every step forward it's 2 steps back.

The campaign AI is generally pretty terrible, siege battle AI when attacking is bad as well. When doing open field battles I have had good experiences though. It feels like I'm dragging myself through the monotony of the campaign for those few awesome land battles. The long turn times don't help either.

The only campaign I played through was the Franks, and the unit variety was disappointing. Waiting that long to get research done in the tech tree to get a unit that is a few points better in a few stats but otherwise exactly the same. I only made it up to Minor Victory - and I really wanted to continue but I had to ask myself how much fun I was actually having. Half my time was spent waiting on turn timers and figuring out the balancing act of food/order/hopefully some income.

I hope to play through some overhaul mods and Age of Charlemagne in the upcoming months and will update my review after finishing my next campaign.

developer_response:
Hi DinoMight

Nico here from the Creative Assembly community team. I am  sorry to hear that you have experienced such issues during play. Could you please provide further details about the configuration you have been using?

If they match with the minimum/recommended specs, I would suggest that you make sure you are using the latest drivers for your graphics & sound cards and that all files have been installed properly. If the game hasn’t been installed properly (i.e. missing or corrupted files during the installation) or if you are using outdated drivers, the game won’t be able to run nor start properly.

If you need assistance to update you graphic and sound drivers, it is best that you contact the manufacturer of your graphics card / sound card directly.

If you are still experiencing those issues while playing the game, do not hesitate to contact our Support team on our official forum (create a new thread):
http://forums.totalwar.com/forumdisplay.php/213

There are several workarounds that have already been published on the official forums. You’ll find everything in the link above.

Regards

Nico

I have purchased and played every Total War game since the beginning, and I think that this is mechanically the best game they've made to date.  One of the major feature additions has been a rich faction and family interface where your decisions here have great effect in the game.  I have been waiting for this.  

My only complaint is that THIS GAME SHOULD BE MEDIEVAL 3!!!  Why not make this game Medieval 3 with a raider/nomadic Attila "like" raiding army?  I don't believe the market was clammoring for an Attila theme, and yet, when I read on line, Total War/CA makes it sound like there is no demand for Medieval 3.   But there is demand for Attila?  THEN, CA cranks out 2 Warhammer games in a row, the first of which was so terrible, there is no way I'll buy the second.  I'm confused by the choice of an Attila theme, and then 2 Warhammer games.  Warhammer was a good idea, but the game was so watered down and simplified, it barely resembled a Total War game.  The Attila theme was too confining, it doesn't have the grand campaign feel with diverse factions that Medieval, Empire, Rome, and even Shogun boasts.

After 160+ houres into it i have to admit - this is simply not a good game. It certainly has it's moments, but frustration is a permament aspect of the game and seems to be more of a "feature" than anything the developers would want to change. On easy you will wreck all other faction within 20 rounds but on hard the AI starts cheating so much, it simply isn't fun anymore. Insted of improved strategic abilities the AI simply doubles (and later triples) their income, allowing even factions with only one, or two cities to gather massive armies so they are practically invulnerable.

That is absolutely not fun to play because you will always get fisted by even the weakest of all factions.
Oh yeah and it crashes every half an hour.
One of the better total wars.

An excellent version of the Total War formula, a bit darker than previous titles (winter is coming for realz).

As with all Total War titles you are looking at hundreds if not more hours of fun an mayhem.

First off this is an entirely different game then any of the others. While the original objective had always been to conquer, the objective in Atilla is to survive. It does the era great justice in illustrating how difficult it was to achieve even an ounce of cooperation. As a history buff I loved this title (despite how goddamn frustrating it can be, I've rage quit an entire campaign at least 25 times). 
Pros:
Mechanics are almost identical to other total war titles
Graphics look decent
Different approach to battle, management and diplomacy yet still behaves like a total war game
New fun, rewarding details (like army stances, sanitation, and ambush mapping)
(Opinion): 
I like the combat style much better than previous war titles and diplomacy is much more intriguing

Cons: 
Sometimes your dealt a very bad hand early on and just have to start over.
Limited units
They make you pay for DLC that should have been in the game anyway (this one really annoys me)
Tech tree is just used to unlock new buildings pretty much. No advancement is very significant or changes okay style.
The Huns are super OP (but if your a history buff like me then you may not mind this as much.)
(Opinion:)
The limited tech tree and units really frustrated me. I wanted to gain an advantage over my opponents in at least one area of the campaign (battle, economy, etc) and I was unable to. Plenty of new technologies arose in the middle ages and weren't seen. The ones they did include didn't help much.

Overall: this game is a niche game. If you like history, enjoy a challenge, and don't mind rage quitting just to return later then this game is for you. You either like it or you don't. That's how it seems to be.

I personally think that creative assembly has created a masterpiece here. WIth no more than 8 or nine mods installed, its hard to stop playing and actually be productive. With out mods its still very addicting and surpasses the total wars in almost every aspect. (with the exception of Shogun 2). the only thing that i would change is the hun spawning. They are able to spawn full armys in sclavenian territory from the get go which makes it hard to play as the sclavenians, even with their faction and cutural traits. The imperium mod is a must. check my screen shots to see some of the units you are able to play with if you need any more convincing.

Long turn cycle times and being forced to watch those repetitive auto-battle result animations means a game of much idling.

I don't enjoy the campaign map portion of the TW series yet I feel it is necessary to give a story to the battles themselves.

Riding at the head of the army in battle is however a great experience.

really great game but poorly optimized and not enough modding capabilities.

Currently the definative Total War and if a player was considering any of the the series to buy, the one I would recommend.

Basically everything that was wrong with the immensely solid Rome 2 is fixed in this game, agents are more useful (although AI does spam their actions big time), campagin is just more solid, AI occasionaly make decisons on the map a cognitive human might, overall the campagin map has just been tightened up.

The reall improvements are on battle game play, finally everything is atually how I would expect it to be. It's little refinements like, how a moving unit is immesurably more vulnerable to arrow fire than a static unit. Battle cohesion and moral play much bigger roles. In rome 2  for instance you could have a quiality unit go full 300 while utterly surrounded and take a good few untis with them just beacuse their base stats are sky high. I'm not sure how the negative bonus is applied in this, but if you are surrounded, you are going down pretty quick.

Overall just the most solid Total War game there is in terms of gameplay (and I include warhammer in that). The only thing I would say it suffers with slightly is the era. As it's a transitional period between Rome and the empires that came after (the dark ages) it's very much play as the vikings before they were viking, play as the Anglo-Saxons before they were English, so a lot of the big name identitys most will know from History just aren't there. The Age of Charlemene DLC moves this along into a better known era, but then this is a far more restrictive campagin (The danes don't even have cav).

But if you want to play multiplayer campagins, or straight up fights, this is my go to TW. 9/10 for game play 8.5/10 overall, so very close to being perfect!

This is a really polished experience and a well put together game as would only be expected by now with the TW series. Always next level as far as large scale military strategy games go, and this one adds soo much content and detail compared to anything in this genre. I have a 1070 gtx and have everything maxed out on highest res & modded with graphical and animation enhancements with only light moments that dip to 30fps. But I also must add though; for all those complaining about needing to play on lowest settings with 1080ti's is that cpu is king here. Games like this which have countless calculations to make need more than a beasty gpu behind a long bottle neck and a cork processor to do the to maxed settings and res. While there is much to like in this game, there are bugs in the game that haven't been fixed since being first reported in 2015, and these will eat away at what enjoyment there is to be had in the game. Parts of the family tree can disappear when characters re-marry, making it impossible to interact politically with them. Agents +/- effects on public order/corruption/etc are as likely as not to have the opposite effect (not an intended feature). Items/The General's abilities/The Army traits/Office bonuses to unit level on recruitment will seemingly randomly subtract rather than add to a units level. I've had a General with +3 to infantry level from gloves, +2 to all recruits from his own abilities, +2 to infantry from Army traits give a +4 bonus in total, and when I put him 'In Office' so that he got another +3 to infantry, the level of the same troops, in the same city, that he could recruit DROPPED 3 levels. Naval recruitment is a crap shot.  Building naval docks might unlock the units it's meant to, but don't bet on it, and chances are you'll be able to recruit naval units that require the naval dock in a provence that doesn't have one. Landing naval units brings it's own nightmares, with limited landing spots that can't be used if the other side has sent ships to them first (which the AI will do in an instant), irrespective of how close your ships are relative to theirs.

Game support post release? Not from this lot.

Huge fan of the Total War series, and gameplay wise, it stands with the best games of the series.  The problem is performance.   Running a GTX 1080 and an i5 4th gen, and I can only get framerate into the 30s by running close to the lowest settings.  With a brand new rig with a pair of state of the arts graphics cards, you could probably actually play on large unit size, provided you turn the other graphis options on low.  If you want to play it on high settings, better get a job at NASA and steal some time on a supercomputer.  I'll be really excited to play this in another five years.

i love total war and historical titles of video games in general. i am also a big early middle ages fan and have to say that this time period, fall of the Western Roman Empire is my personal fav to study. ill split this up in pros and cons and also have the historical pros and cons on top then gameplay 

Pros- historical
-Amazing historical accuracy with units
-very good unit and city naming 
-pays attention to many historical details that are small
-DID NOT group the persians up. instead had client states adding better gameplay
-units look very well to the time period. 
-the strongest faction is the eastern romans which makes sense
-could include many small things but i feel they did well on this part
- the buildings are all very fun. each faction has different buildings and you do feel it when playing. and i love the quotes they put in. i think its on a sewer system or something and it says "I thought they smelled bad on the outside" 
- the wiki is very well done. it gives you enough info to understand the building or unit as well as not giving you everything so youll want to research it on your own. do that, very fun to find this stuff on your own. 

pros gameplay

MODS 
-MODS again. i felt that the armies rosters were very weak so i got mods that expanded all these. Oh gosh they are so amazing. with unit mods each faction feels sop different and although not historically accurate in some cases they are very fun. i recomend playing with mods
-amazing gameplay map
-very fun battles
-units dont all feel the same
-cav is powerful as youd expect but can be beaten by well trained forces. this is very historically accurate as cav died around this time and didnt come back around till about 600 or 700
- its always fun to use elephants to smash people
- my fav factions to play are Eastern Romans, Aksum, Geats and picts. all very different with mods as well
- that campaign map is very fun. you can see which regions worship what god, the income, growth, natural resources ect 
- its funny, my second fav time period is Charlemagne times and i have to say that DLC is like the base game. really fun but again, mod it. However, youll really like it because its fun to make the Holy Roman Empire, lets face it. 

cons historical
-alright. one thing that pissed me off was that Stilicho is made out to look like an asshole who is corrupt and taking the Rome for himself. so inaccurate. In real life he was right hand man to Theodosius and served at frigidus and many other battlegrounds. He was the reason rome lasted another decade and defeated Alaric the Visigoth on 3 seperate occasions. he was beheaded as a "Traitor" later on.
- Slavic Pagan armies will have names like "Sons ofr Odin" which is crap
- the Western Roman Empire falls too damn quickly
- on the total war wiki, modders who make units cant make a custom page for them. i understand why but at the same time. i wish they had another way of doing this. like an offline wiki only for that mod because i love reading about the units 

cons gameplay

- Spearmen feel useless 
- without mods, all germanic factions feel the same, all celtic factions feel the same and so on. they are okay and different in campaign mode but not battle.
- OMG western rome falls too damn quick. every faction i play as, by 401 rome is gone. its like a land grab for the first 20 turns then turns into boring petty kingdoms fighting. the fighting between the franks and visigoths should be fun because they both fought each other under clovis but its drawn out and boring
- I know this is supposed to be historically accurate but as the eastern romans, you start off with visigoths in greece and no armies nearby. 6 turns in greece is split between mutiple kingdoms or all destroyed. 
- Persians are too annoying to fight. its the same old battles after a while
- oh my gosh, either the enemy armies bring all spearmen or slingers. 
- in custom battles, choosing a map is so hard. its supposed to let you choose anywhere in asia and europe but i always get hills, deep forest or pits. i just want some damn flat land
- cant unit test and pit 2 units agaisnt each other. you always need a general unit in custom battles
- i was not here for rome 2, but the limit on armies and navies is annoying. 
- have to pay extra money for factions that should have been in the damn game.
- have to pay for blood and gore

Rome's glory has ended, her days are numbered. A large power vacuum is created as a result. This is basically a game of carving up the Rome-cake between the rest of the world and forging new, powerful Alliances. Attila is moving on Eastern Europe, do you stand and fight? Assymilate or Flee? The choice is yours and this will be your Epic "Story".

If you want to play the Rome of post Gaius-Marius reforms, buy Rome 2, this will not give you that experience. This is set a few hundred years after this time period, which in my opinion makes it a more even playing field if you are wanting to play Factions other than Roman. 

Multiplayer only increases this games appeal to me, being able to bring a good friend along the windy road of Empire building is truly the cherry on the cake of an already fantastic game, And i much recommend this to anyone wanting a decent Co-op experience. Not to mention those wanting PvP Strategy.

Very fluid and intuitive controls in battle, UI can be a little confusing at first if you are used to another TW's UI, but overall very good.

Breath taking graphics for the machines that can put a little more Horsepower through it, i run on medium settings and it's more than acceptable. 

a bit miffed on the DLC's as i think some should have been shipped in the base game, Nonetheless they are worth a grab on sale.

The way to really make this game sing is with Mods! Fantastic modding community and easy execution with Workshop integration for quick and simple mod installation. Just click + Play.

Overall, Delivers exactly what you expect from a Total War game. If you enjoyed the others then this is definitely for you, Just don't go in to it expecting Rome 2 Clone. This game is about the Underdog's of European history... The Tribes, The Religions, The Hun!

Despite not displacing Shogun 2 as the best total war game in my books, Attila combined with its DLC campaigns is really good to the point of competing with the original Rome and Medieval 2.

Something that really stood out to me was the entire Medieval 2 vibe that emerge when you start the game. Like Medieval 2 there's an army walking past in the background on the main menu. Age of Charlemagne further hammers this point in to the point I think it's safe to say this is as close to a Medieval 3 we'll get until the official Medieval 3 is released.

Now, the game has some very serious optimisation issues. I have a fairly beefy computer but the framerate grinds to a halt when more then 2-3k troops participate in a battle. There are also a problem where unit animations become choppy with too many troops on the screen at the same time.
The battles though are excellent with many small touches here and there that brings the battlefield to life. Like the peasants walking about that really doesn't add anything but still is a really nice touch.

The campaign though is where the largest changes have taken place. Some factions start as hordes or can form hordes when chased out of their last province. The hordes wander around looting and raiding in the search for a new and safe homeland. This essentially cuts out what could be tedious campaign gameplay and letting the players focus entirely on the series trademark battles. On the negative side I still can't get behind every army needing a general or the province system. I think Shogun 2 had it perfectly nailed down and Rome 2 tore it all to shreds and for whatever reason Attila has to repeat many of the same mistakes.

Another thing I can't get behind is the skill trees of agents and generals. It doesn't lead me to remember their names and characteristics the way the original Rome did. Agents also feel more useless then ever and I can't recall myself ever thinking that I need anything other then priests to keep the ludicrous barbarian late game public order issues in check.

At least they brought the family tree back. Good on you CA.
It's a mixed package. I'd still say this is a must have TW title very well on par with Medieval 2.

-First build up an economy(farms,cultural building or trade with your local neighbours) the money you gained build up an army but don't dismantle your units becuase you might get attacked!

-The difficulties easy,normal,hard,legendary Easy your economy is stronger than the enmies,moral bonus for your units and so on.normal it's almost like easy the ai is the same but you don't get bonuses,hard is harder a little bit better ai,legendary you can't save just auto save when you click on the next turn button.

This is probably the best historical Total War.

Unlike other total war games, this one features very robust strategic view. Each faction starts in very different conditions. New players would be better playing more traditional empire building game as someone like Garamantians - start small, eat other small nations, then take on bigger fish. There are advanced stars as migrating European tribes or Hun horde or defensive crumbling Roman Empire. The world gets worse and worse so you have to be careful with building up your economy. There are some internal politics and family management but it's obscure and doesn't have visible effect on the game.

Combat is supposed to be the most important part of Total War but it's underwhelming. First AI is usually not opportunistic and if you chose your battles well you won't ever need to see battle map: one of the sides will always have an overwhelming advantage. Battles themselves are not that fun: yes, the roster is diverse but even all cavalry Huns are all about hammer & anvil tactics, harrassing enemy with archers and so on. AI doesn't go for anything complex and there are no pre-made scripted battles so every battle is exactly like the others. Maybe it's better in multiplayer, but unlike TW Shogun 2 there's no MP progression mini-game.

The game also have technical problems - runs worse than TW Warhammer. It also doesn't look good. It has lots of nice models but it is not beautiful the way TW Shogun 2 or Napoleon was: those games had specific aesthetic they were going for and music, sound and graphics all worked for it. Attila is schizophrenic: there's an apocalyptic theme here so everything is grim and that's about it. It's like back to 2000's brown shooters.

It may be the best TW game gameplay-wise (at least before Warhammer) but I don't find it that enjoyable after the first campaign. It felt fresh and interesting but starting new one is boring: battles are unfulfilling, internal politics and agents have miniscule effect on a big picture and require too much attention, the spectacle isn't there. Get it if you fan of the era or just want one relatively short and saturated campaign. Only buy DLC when you've played several campaigns in the main game and crave for more, those DLCs add new factions but do not enhance the base game.

This is not a normal Totalwar game... this is Totalwar turned up to 11!

Pros
Family tree and factions issues, a great addition to the roleplaying, you need to fight to keep your faction from infighting and disloyalty and great little bit of realism, similar to Crusader Kings.
No steam rollering! In the previous Totalwar games you could quite easily steamroller AI, but not now, its added a little more realism to the game.
Lots of different objectives, so its not just point the map your colour - which is refeshing.
Hoard mechanic, a great idea to play as one and to deal with them these act as viruses rampaging around and settling at times.
Its finally a challenge! Play WRE to see what I mean! When you build an empire or defend one it feels like a real achievement.
The graphics, and AI, sound all brilliant!

Cons
Its not easy - lose a settlement or battle and it will hurt your plans.
Not a quick bashathon - if you want to quickly take over Europe look somewhere else.
Naval battles - missed out - a great shame.
Limited armies - there are limits based on your Imperium, which can be annoying if you can afford an army there are times when you cannot raise one - however its a extra challenge!

Overall - a great game - but expect to be spanked from time to time!

As a neckeard who only buys games supported on Linux, the prospect of a Rome II port thrilled me and I patiently waited for years. Alas, it seems that day will never come and Linux was forgotten...

Unlike the abberant abomination that was Rome II this game is a magnificent comeback. I forgive you CA. There are a lot of things that CA have improved or introduced that I can bestow praise on but in the interest of brevity it will suffice to say two things. 

Firstly, the difficulty of this game, while not universally appreciated by everyone, is a critical factor in my personal enjoyment. 

Secondly, is the improvement of the campaign and battle A.I., while not without flaws, has improved by many degrees. Anyone who has done a Game Programming or Artificial Intelligence 101 course at university can appreciate the difficulty of making expert systems for a game of this scope.

My main criticism of this game is directed at two things. 

Firstly, the ingame encyclopedia was a terrible idea. This is clearly a product of over-engineering a simple problem or a design-by-committee idea or both. GET RID OF THIS ABOMINATION.

Lastly, is substandard quality of the flavour text that ingame (i.e. details with anecdotes, history and amusing prose about units, buildings and technology). Did CA fire the professor that did this for Empire: Total War, and Rome I? Please re-hire this gentleman scholar dude because he was awesome (and educational and interesting and amusing).

This game looks slightly worse than Rome 2, but somehow manages to run even worse.  The 55-60 FPS you managed to get in Rome 2?  Yea, reduce that by about half if you're lucky.  I was able to just get by with running it on average at 1920 x 1080 resolution and get 28 FPS with a 1050 ti and an i5 6400.  That should not happen.  To make matters worse, for some reason, when you launch it through the Rome 2 launch app, it gives a 6-7 increase in average FPS.

Add on top of this the identical gameplay of Rome 2, and you see very little has changed in terms of battle-level tactics or strategy, save for the over-powered BS of crossbows, along with the broken siege AI (when they were defending, the AI managed to seal themselves all off in the harbor with a wall...a wall facing them, so when I took the city, I merely lined up my crossbowmen along it and slowly but surely killed every single unit....), and the unnecessarily long turn times and you have a game that's a step back in both design and execution than the previous one.

A fun game that provides hours of fun, a large step up from the burning pile of trash that Rome II was on launch. Yet it still felt like an expansion as barbarian invasion was to the original rome tw game or like napoleon to empire tw. It just felt lacking in the diversity of factions, we were given romans, germans, huns, and middle easterners. In every other game there were factions and faction groups that covered every fighting style we wanted. In Rome II there were the greeks with spears, nomads with horses, romans, carthaginians, germans, celts, iberians, etc. However, what happened in Attila is that there are hoards of copy and pasted germanic tribes. What CA should have done is what they did with the two halves of the roman empire, having some shared units and some unique ones, not a shared army and one unique one. Also, unrelated, the huns, a nomadic horse based faction, have terrible cavalry but one of the best infantry units. Meanwhile, the romans who could not ride a horse have lots of good cavaly like cataphracts. Despite this ramble here, I still found myself lunging hours of life into this game. It was fun and with some issues that aren't worth thinking about.

In all honesty, it's just an updated version of Total War: Rome II - Emperor Edition.   Naval battles, unit abilities, units, and a plethora of other things are if not identical, very similar to the beforehand mentioned game.   One difference is that food, religion, sanitation, and political figures have a greater affect on public oder.   This makes for a more strategic game!   Another difference is that you have more control over your families choices such as adoptions, gaining political support, embezzeling money, and several others.   This is what makes Attila so much better than Rome II in my opinion.

However, because these two games were released ~16 months apart, I feel creative assembly was holding back intentionally for obvious REA$ON$.   It's a good game, I just can't stand how greedy these companies are getting nowadays!

Would give this game a neutral recommendation if Steam allowed it.

Total War: ATTILA is an excellent game with faction-specific starting contexts and diverse unit rosters.  The mechanics are some of the most complex ever utilized by a Total War game, and the game went a long way to redeem The Creative Assembly after the Total War: Rome 2 disaster.

1500+ hours on Rome II, 150+ so far on Atilla. 

Used the Celts to invade the Saxons, altered history and funneled money into WRE to keep them alive. 10/10

So, after a 2 years i decided to change my Review from positive to Negative. 

Its not like i dont like TW:Attila, its not like its a BAD game.... its just lost potential and broken promise of trully epic gameplay. TW:Attila still remains one of my favorite total war games, somewhere at 3rd place after Shogun 2 and first Rome, regardless to all problems with this game what i did encounter.

Lets do it proper way with pros and cons list

--------------PROS:--------------

- Graphically one of best historical TW games, Art assets are only better in Shogun 2 in my opinion. Loading screens, map and city designs looks very pleasant for eyes and soul

- Audio is definitely on top level. It surpass most of TW games.... except shogun 2. However here i would point, that for me Medieval 2 had best audio. 

- Optimisation is better than in last TW games, however more about it in cons

-  Major DLC Campaigns are actually worth their price... mostly. both Age of Charlemagne and The Last Roman are very epic and challenging extensions, even for TW veterans like me. 

- Game design actually fits historical period. Game is quite... dark and brutal. 

- Game can bring loads of fun and plenty hours of gameplay even without DLCs, Most of mine i got in later stages

- Achievements are actually hard to get, and are not bound to progress in story lines or doing simple tasks. 

-Multiplayer didnt get worst than it is in Rome 2, and MP in Rome 2 got better after endless patches.

- Battles are actually quite satysfying, and being more tactical player,  "CTRL+A, SEND THEM ALL" way of playing will lead you to loosing battle even if you outnumber the enemy.

- Diplomacy is almost as good as in Shogun 2.... -

- Building cities, and upgrading them require strategical planing for 200-500 turns ahead. Region system and public order is well planed for me. Every building have its purpose, pros and cons and importance. You need to ballance your regions and their specializations in order to run effective economy in later stages of game. 

- Mod friendly

-------------CONS:------------

-  DLC POLICY, DLC PRICE TO CONTENT RATIO, AMOUNT OF DLCs, 

- Optimization and performance. there will be sub-points:
a) Game shutter and get FPS drops even on hardware which should be capable to run it easily. 
b) Even if game start to shutter and have FPS drops, none of components are actually under heavy load. Due typical battle i get between 20 and 60 FPS, while my CPU is used in no more than 60%, and GPU is at 50% load. From 8 GB of ram game dont take more than 3. So its engine issue, which cant use properly avilible resources
c) Preformance issues are mostly linked to number of units on field. setting lower unit size and decreasing terrain detail on medium or below (causing bodies and blood to dissapear) mostly will fix issues with shuttering
d) Battles are way better optimised (less drops, less shutter) in capital cities (o_O), and generaly in Campgains. Custom SP battles with more than 4k units on field can be unplayable in some moments

- Game gets more simple, than it used to be. For some people it can be counted as Pros, because old total wars could give a headache to many casual players. 

- After so many years on same engine, AI is still kinda stupid. Its better than in most of games except shogun 2, however, its unworthy, boring and time wasting to playing this game on lower dificulty level than Hard. 

- Difficulty level NPC cheating. Instead of making AI more complex, AI gets more gold, and shorter training time + unit boosts. On Very hard you are just flooded with 9lvl agents who preform COSTFUL IN GOLD FOR YOU actions every turn, Artillery gets sniper abilities, NPC armies can travel longer. 

- To be honest vanilla game gets boring and annoying after 20 hours. To make gameplay better, i needed to download multiple mods, including changing colors of units in factions, battle rebalance to fix super short ranged unit range, fix armor and impact damage, which almost not exist for cavalary, and shields or armor literally do not give protection from ranged attacks. In the meanwhile archers are useless, and slingers can devastate heavy armored top tier unit in testudo/shield wall mode..... Without adding any new content i needed 9 mods to reballance gameplay... mostly on battlefields.

-Animations:
a) So, where da f.k are thoose vomiting and wounded soldiers, crawling in agony on battlefields? i didnt seen even single vomiting soldier, even if they are in Blood dlc trailer. 
b) why general's mouth remain closed, even if he is the middle of speech towards soldiers? What about squad leaders, captains, simple soldiers etc... you can hear them, you cant see them talking. we had it in shogun 2, and Rome 2 first trailer with Carthago siege... never after that. Animations get stripped, and we got speachless soldeirs with glued mouths. 
c) this faces... they was differend on trailers and in all what devs said... they supposed to have feelings, they have not. We been promised "human" soldiers on field... we didnt get it....
d) combat animations still not great. Can be partly fixed with mods....

- Grand Campgain turns takes literally AGES. Wihle 8c/8t 4ghz CPU is used in 30%.... I understand there is almost hunderd of nations... but most of them are small

- turn based map Faction AI in meaning of territorial control is crap. There is milions of super-small cities-states, and almost none of large kingdoms. Without mod AI wont recolonize burned/sacked cities. It will remain ruin until you wont rebuild it. After Hunic invasion there remains wasteland with single color spots in form of city-state.

- from siege engines we have small and large catapult. Nothing else. Oh, and scorpion/polybos, which are not exactly useful, if not mounted on walls

- Walls, gates and Towers of cities are paper. they crumble and fall so quick, that sieges always end in streets. Again, Without mods forget to see epic sieges with siege towers, ladders, Rams and fighting for every inch of battlements 

--last words--

After having game on same engine like 5-6 times in a row, working on exactly same principles, there is no improvement in issues, what are a pain in TW games from ages. Both Rome 2 and Attila, even if are great games, giving fun for many hours, are big step back from what we had in Shogun 2, or even in Medieval 2. My opinion is, that TW:Attila is good Tw game, not perfect, but good one. i would give it 7 out of 10, however, not for current price with all DLCs. Wait for discount, get it then. And be prepared, that you wont enjoy 1080p ultra details and 10k units on field with stable 60 FPS. Only very short range of PC hardware can run this game smooth all the time, and it possibly will be same hardware, what been used for CA beta tests in studio.
Very good game. Different take on the Total War series but definitely enjoyable. Im a fan of cav so it was very cool seeing them shine again

Most of Total War games are generic and don't offer much new and this is one of them so I am going to compare it with other Total War games. 

Firstly positives, this game has some unique mechanics which are quite interesting. Previously once you lose every city the game is over here, however, if you have any units left (army) you become a horde essentially a government without any cities. Secondly, once you've captured the city you can completely destroy it (raze) which means if you find a razed city you can settle there. At the start of the campaign, there are some blank spots on the map so you can conquer new provinces without invading a foreign country. Also, there are lots of nation which have different difficulties to play, so this game can provide potentially hundreds of hours of gameplay as each campaign takes around [u]10-15 hours[/u] to complete.

Now it's time to talk about negatives. The biggest one I found is horrible starting menu. Actually even before that game has a launcher which is insanely small and cramped. Main menu buttons are small and located on the side so I didn't like that either. Finally, you can't upgrade units often which is a small negative but still. They gain upgraded equipment and exp like in 'Total War: Rome' thought.

[b]You should get this game over others if you like the time of the ancient Rome, but played or didn't like 'Total War: Rome', otherwise, I think it's better to get other Total War games.[/b]

A terrific game set in a terrific time period! Each faction has its own large roster and unique units, the game has very impactful mechanics not seen in ROME 2 & the graphics much nicer.

The most interesting factions would be either-

The Sassanid Empire: The last in the line of truly Persian Empires that has stood firm against the Romans for centuries

The Eastern (Byzantine) Roman Empire: Set after theodosius separated the empire in two, You can play as the Eastern Romans and face of Persians or Hunnic hordes alike!

The crumbling Western Roman Empire: A challenging faction, While the Eastern half of the Empire had riches the western half had little, play as the disadvantaged, overextended and crumbling western Roman Empire and struggle against hordes of germanic and Gothic Tribes.

This might be lengthy, but I'll do my best.

I've played every Total War game ever.  Ever. I still have the Shogun 1/Medieval 1 disks in my desk. 

This is by far, *by far*, the most frusterating Total War released.  I'm not sure how I feel about that, perhaps it's something I could speak to my psyciatrist about...anyways.

It's based on the Rome 2 engine and system, with many changes in gameplay and how things generally work.  It's basically a giant mod of the origional structure.  There is lots of variation, with each culture being generally well fleshed out.  Aside from the DLC qualms everyone complains about, the unit variation is solid, as are the tech trees.  This is prob my favorite part of this release, as it seems that every time I run a playthrough, it's completely different each time.  I haven't found that in other Total War titles.  

On to the frusterating parts, and really the big parts of this game.

It's called Attila because of Attila the Hun.  No ****, right? Go figure.  And go figure, **** the Huns.  **** them.

They're incorperated into the game in a way that can make it impossible to win.  In fact, amongst the group I play with, not one of us has successfully completed a campaign, but only stopped and started a new one once it became stale.  

The AI cheats like no other, with full 0 upkeep stacks of Hunnic Horse Archers spawning who mercilessly mow your troops down with near infinite arrows, as you're left helpless sitting in a ******* field in close order shield formation, just waiting for death.  Thousands of high tier infantry and whoever else just lost in a heartbeat.  Can't charge, can't hold, just have to pray they run out of arrows and charge you, in which you're probably still royally *******. 

While I'm on about armies...the AI movement is bonkers.  Sometimes they stay just outside of your own armies range, as the AI knows exactly how far you can move and try to engage.  That can get very annoying.

The sanitation, public order and food system is far from perfect, with values swinging wildly from turn to turn.  One turn you have 120 food, the next turn you have -10 and horrible plagues ravaging two of your cities.  I'm very tempted to look up a workshop fix for this, but I feel I shouldn't, as the final product *should* have this already taken care of.  Some buildings add onto the Squalor value so harshly, it doesn't make much sense.  Want to build a basketmaker?  Too bad! The citizens are pissed and are going to go **** in the streets, they're SO pissed!   **** that basketmaker!

Because this game is so challenging, and the other Total Wars, after some time, have been a complete compstomp by late game once you get the hang of it, it's actually quite refresing in a sort of sick, self hating kind of way.  I do recommend it, but truly not for the faint of heart.

CRITICAL ERROR IN THE MIDDLE OF GAMEPLAY!!!

This is an absolute load of bullshit! SOme of you may end up experience a damn runtime error with this game! I want my fucking money back!!! Not recommended at all.

how are you going to win a battle if your more than retarded units give up when they are nowhere near the battle and defended by towers? the creators of this game have left the ultra-stupid moral rules intact. why would a thousand soldiers give up when they are not in danger? stupid f*ckers. 
instead of paying software engineers to build a smart AI, they impose an overpowered moral killer whereby all of you unit defended by towers just give up when the time is almost out and the enemy cannot possibly get to them in time. pathetic programming, ret*rds.
also, why do i get bothered with 100 battles i cannot win...they make you watch stupid animations that you see 1000 times and cannot skip. game developers are getting stupider by the year. everything should be skippable...or havent these retards ever played a f*cking game that they took years to develop?  you have to click 3 menus in stead of 1...why? did i mention the sh*t storm that is moral? it is created by a person who i presume is now homeless. do archers matter...no. they are less than useless. why does threat assessment mean nothing? oh, right, there is no one competent at the helm of development of t his franchise. i find games like these a fair bit of retardism as i was a software engineer years ago. i would feel is personal insult to put out sh*t like these titles.

the game looks nice and should be fun to play...but i give a low low review of the developers and publishers as no professional company should put out something so pathetically un-optimized as this game.

The bugs are the reason I absolutely cannot give this a thumbs up. Just trying to play through the prologue I've encountered numerous glitches and bugs that completely prevent progression or severely hinder it.

Small list of bugs I've encountered in the prologue alone:

1) Advisor gets stuck. You do what is asked but for whatever reason the game doesn't count it and you can't do it over. Essentially game ending.

2) Rebels are supposed to sack a city that you can then capture. Except every single one of the rebels failed. Can't declare war in the prologue, game is stuck. Also game ending.

3) Randomly the End Turn button greys out despite all requirements from the advisor being met. Similar to first issue. Forces you to leave and come back to a previous save. Can result in moderate progress lost. Probably 10 or so minutes if you're not spam saving.

With the Roman Empire being split apart, The West unable to support its finances with poor administration, aswell as barbarian hordes invading your last scraps of lands, The East, having to fight both migraters up north, and the sassanids in the east, The Roman Empire struggles to hold its own. Will you play as a doomed empire, having its remaining scraps being taken? Will you play as the barbarians, which are being forced into Roman territory by the huns?
