Preface: I've only put in 32ish hours so far, I've played as ERE/WRE/Huns/Sassanids all past 400AD and played a handful of multiplayer battles. Total War: Attila is quite likely the best game in the total war franchise. Maybe not the best for its time but by a close margin I'd put it just ahead of M2. 

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Amazingly diverse campaign playstyles (empire in decline, migrators, conventional start and safe empires)
[*]Battle mechanics are improved (fatigue and morale are more intersting, units return to the fight more and you have to give more thought to fatigue (tired quickly but you also recover faster, makes running more tactical).
[*]Balance so far feels very good, nothing is insanely OP (that I've discoverd yet)
[*]Unit diversity is huge, there are a wide range of factions and faction styles which makes the game intersting and I predict will increase replayability.
[*]Battle AI (including siege) is substantially improved from previous games, it now makes logical decisions (I've found they're a tiny repetitve however.
[*]Family tree is highly immersive and complicated which gives greater depth to the game (especially in the long run)
[*]The economic system is a fair bit more complicated than R2 and is more interesting as it changes over time (climate change) and involves an increased number of relevant variables (immigration, religion, desolation/raiding etc.)
[*]Diplomacy feels similar to R2 but slightly more polished, the ability to gift factions to migrator factions is a nice addition. Overall small improvement here.
[*]Siege escallation is great fun and adds more complexity. Gladly the AI also makes good use of this most of the time (at province capitals)
[/list]

[h1] Graphics/Performance [/h1]
[list]
[*]Played on a GTX970, i53570k on a 4k monitor.
[*]Textures etc. are a small step up from R2, they aren't amazing up close though.
[*]Good detail in units
[*]Game performs above 30FPS at 4k on 'performance' (with some max performance mixed in), drops to high twenties when I zoom in with a large number of units.
[*]Overall performance is okay but could improve, the forward looking approach of the 'extreme' graphics settings is comendable to help ensure their game lasts.
[/list]

[h1] Meta Stuff [/h1]
[list]
[*]Day 1 DLC is annoying but common in the industry, neither a negative or a positive
[*]The fact that they've made the improvements that the community have made (on the whole) is highly commendable. They appear to have learnt from their errors.
[*]If you liked R2 you'll love this, if you didn't like R2 you may find some enjoyment in this game but it won't amaze you.
[*]I haven't encountered any game breakings bugs, the new path drawing system however is a little bit unreliable though.
[/list]
Burn all the things!

Altough it might not be perfect,
Total War: ATTILA is still a huge comeback from Rome 2 
and the people who worked on the game earned the according credit for it.

Battles run way smoother and feel authentic in a unprecedented way, without any glitches or ridiculous AI issues. 
In fact, so far, the AI actually proved quite impressive in a few ways, notably that it truly feel as though each single soldier of a unit is independent whilst charging or breaking it's way through enemy lines.

All the new family, political, cultural and historical facets of the game also make it that much more addictive 
to play and rediscover one turn at a time as you realise this is what Rome 2 should have been and felt like upon it's release.

Some things are litterally copy-pasted from Rome 2 but I guess we can't really blame them for that. It's litteraly what they did previously with Napoleon in order to save their Empire period title.

The Campaign map could be better optimised as it tends to get laggy, even though it does look prettier than ever before and that my processor and RAM could obviously get a little improvement as well.

For a launch it seems like the developpers finally did their homework and gave the players what they wanted and expected.

We can now only hope upcoming updates or patches will make this little strategic jewel even better.
I also wonder if the developpers will once again go on a DLC mayhem in order to get sell more content because I must say even with the Viking Forefathers pack, I felt like a few additional playable factions would have been nice to have in the original game download.

Overall, for a relatively close release to their latest franchise title, ATTILA proves us that this franchise has, once more, earned the right to perpetuate it's legacy into a new generation of gaming.
Family features are a nice return. Makes your empire feel more personal. overall feels more engaging than Rome 2. great fun!

Since the game is mostly great and a massive improvement over Rome 2 I'll just name cons. Non-gameplay/Business related cons appear below. Won't mention performance/lag/technical bugs.

Cons:
-3000 base income ruins the game balance, Garamantian tribesmen armies larger than the Roman army... Can be a good thing if you love fighting battles since you get to fight more but if you're into the grand campaign then bad news for you.
-Combat is A LOT faster than Rome 2. More about fast reaction times and less about decisions.
-Diplomacy AI still poor, getting a trade agreement is hard, random war declarations without reason by very friendly nations, marrying your daughters to barbarians have a low chance even if they're young and have a beneficent trait. Also getting peace treaties seems to be impossible unless you're massively stronger over whoever you're offering peace to.
-Politics are slightly confusing although definitely an improvement over Rome 2
-Most stances are still useless
-Can only gift regions under very limited circumstances,  for example you can't give the revolter Egypt his land back so he remains as the random Libyan province it revolted from.
-Although the building tree is definitely an improvement over Rome 2, some buildings are useless (For example tier 2 is 400 income, tier 3 is 400 income, -2% build costs and -4 food, +4 squalor). If it was say 700 income, -50% local build costs and -30% regional build costs I'd consider it.
-Speaking of useless, several character traits/ancillaries/etc are useless (-10% sanitary building costs, really) although it's still an improvement over Rome 2 considering there are now 3 ancillaries.
-Resources aren't as useful as they should be. Rome 2's DeI had it right by limiting almost all buildings past tier 2.
-Apparently several people on the steam Attila forums have reported that while migrating as the Saxons, Danes, Juttes, Gothes, Franks, etc. they were pursued all the way to their destination by random neighbouring nations which proceeded to kill them with full stack armies. I played as the Saxons myself to test this and while migrating to Greece I had 3 neighbouring German tribes declare war on me and follow me all the way to Constantinople with full stack armies just to kill my horde.
-Imperium increases exponentially for no reason even if you haven't expanded, giving massive relation penalties with everyone and eventually resulting in the whole world declaring war on you.
-Very minor but generals don't move their mouths while giving speeches

Non-gameplay/Performance/Bad Business practice cons:
-No Blood and Gore on release day even tho some previewers stated they had it. They basically didn't want to have 'Day one DLC' except their pre-order bonus.
-No Steam Workshop on release day.
-Turns take at least twice as long, similar to Rome 2 on release.

you ensure loyalties and that your family line doesnt come to an abrupt end.

      First off, I hated Rome 2 because no matter what I did, the campaign map was going at about 10 fps. 6,000 man battles were fine, but the campaign map just wouldnt work. well, the moment I turned this on it was smooth and 100 times better than rome 2's campaign map for me. 
      Not only that, but the setting is way more interesting than I expected! I was ready for basically the roman empire with the same tribes around it and maybe some huns, but I was really excited to see some different and historically accurate factions and units. Really great game, far better than Rome II's launch. The whole mood is way different, which I think is the biggest improvement for me over Rome II.  In Rome it felt like each battle was meaningless; you were probably going to win, and even if you didn't, the only consequence was losing out on some meaningless conquest in the corner of the world.

In Attila, it is entirely different. Playing as the Eastern Romans, if you do not meet the enemy in the field and win, the barbarians will raze and pillage your cities. You are not fighting for glory, you are fighting for survival. I get nervous for each outnumbered battle I fight, because I know that if I lose, I am opening up my heartland to irrevirsible destruction.

So far the only bugs I have experienced involve pathfinding issues, which occurred when a fortress spawned on a slope, and despite the walls being buried underground, I could still not send units over them. However, this seems like a minor issue to me.

On the optimization side, I have experienced no problems whatsoever with my year-old graphics card. I'm pretty sure that all the people complaining about crashes/low framerates are too ignorant to update their drivers, so... sucks to them?

All and all a great game, and a worthy contender for being my favorite Total War game yet!
A big leap in the right direction for the series.

* This is a review in progress, for it's too early for me to review this game fully*

Total War: Atilla is almost nothing like its Predecessor, Rome 2. In my opinion, Rome 2 was not a terrible game. Rome 2 was just plagued with bugs that got ironed out too little too late. Rome 2 was overall a good game. Atilla is taking a good game that is Rome 2, and making it great.

Pros:
- The graphics are a step up from Rome 2's, and the color palette is more realistic, with a bit of Early Dark Ages thrown in the mix.

- Migrations and Hordes work marvelously. You can scorch the earth so your enemies get nothing, and become nomadic, looking for a new place to call home. This is what makes the Huns and the factions among The Great Migration so unique and frankly fun to play as. Also, the Huns can't capture territory, but they can Sack, Raze, Subjugate, and utturly destroy their enemies.

- Make no mistake, Total War: Atilla is unforgiving on the difficulty. You thought playing as the Eastern or Western Roman Empires would be easy? Think again. They have numerous enemies, overstretched borders and overstretched militaries. But that's the fun of playing as them. Maybe you, the player, can rewrite history. This can be a Pro or Con depending on the person, but this is a hugo Pro for me. Rome 2 was way too easy.

- Grand campaign is a lot more interactive than Rome 2's. It sort of reminds me of Total War: Medieval's grand campaign where historical events would happen (i.e the rise of the Mongols). Objectives are not useless either in Atilla, in Rome 2 they were somewhat useless, and the objectives can be challenging depending on the player.

- Political intrigue has been overhauled as well, sort of going back to the Shogun 2 way of doing things, which is great. Whether it be royal marriages, embezzlement, promoting a statesman to a position of honor, or a family member to goverern a province, you can find ways to pass time while at peace.

- The overhauled Raze option after taking a city is awesome. You can obliderate a city, watch that section of the map burn with fire, and it is uninhabitable without recolonizing it. So fun to use in Campaign mode.

Cons:
(most of these issues are fixable given time)

- I don't know why, but for me I occaisionaly have screen tearing occur in Atilla. It happens rarely fortunately, but it can get annoying while seeing the screen start to get cut up. Restarting your game gets rid of this issue, for some reason.

- while waiting for your turn to begin again, or even right when it begins, the game has a chance to freeze, or crash. It's happened to me about 4 times already. Hopefully this is another issue that is to be fixed.

In the end, Total War Atilla is worth 45 dollars, and I give it two thumbs up. You'll be occupied with Atilla for many hours to come, as I already am.

After Rome II, I was fairly sceptical of Attila, but it turned out fairly great! Love the improved forms of faction management with governors and such, and the return of the family tree is a welcome sight too. The Horde system was a very positive surprise to me, because I felt that that of RTW:BI didn't really catch the true feel of nomadic horde life. The AI doesn't seem overly different from that of Rome II, but it does operate noticably better, both on the campaign and battle maps. In general, a great majority of flaws Rome II had have been mended in Attila. The period and peoples seem rather well historically researched, and I'm surprised to learn of several new tribes I never knew of, good on ya CA! That being said, I did notice (as IGN mentioned) a lack of 'proper' celtic troops. The Caledonians, Picts etc. don't seem to field many celtic troops. Hopefully a later patch might fix that. The atmosphere in the campaign map is solid, there's a genuine feel of impending dangers and unstability. Finally, the soundtrack is very well done (as are most of TW ost's). The 'hunnic/mognolesque' feel some of the tracks have gave me goosebumps. 
To be honest, I was hoping for a TW game focusing on an entirely new historical setting, but I can't really complain. Attila is proof that CA can still do a strong TW game, definitely worth it.

I'm writing this review early because I wanted to share my opinions just in case anyone has had my problems aswell.

I'm playing on a laptop. Here are the specs:

4700mq I7 @ 2.4ghz
12gb RAM
GTX 765m with 2gb VRAM

I was not expecting to play this game anywhere near ultra quality as I could only play Rome II on high with AA and SSAO off. However upon launch of the game my GPU wasn't recognised. Instead the game picked up my integrated chipset at 1gb surprisingly (Is it common to have 1gb of integrated VRAM?). Anyway I followed my usual protocol for when this happens, which included messing with my control pannel setting and making sure I had my current drivers.

Unfortunately the game still didn't recognise my GPU. I had to use the Nvidia Inspector to manually change some settings to remedy the situation, specifically:

"Enable application for Optimus" -> SHIM_RENDERING_MODE_ENABLE, because for some reason this setting defaulted to " SHIM_RENDERING_MODE_INTEGRATED" Which is highly annoying when your control pannel specifically says that the game will utilize your high performance GPU.

TL;DR : Use the Nvidia Inspector, NOT NVIDIA CONTROL PANNEL for any problems with your GPU.


Once those problems were over I was able to mess with my quality settings to get an OK average framerate without having the NPCs look like polygons and the ground look like 1x1 mud swatches...

Once I booted up my first game as a Celtic nation HOLY SHIT this extension is so much better than Rome II, and so far I haven't experienced any bugs. So much has improved from Rome II, but without playing much into it I really don't want to make any solid statements about the improvements. This looks a lot like what CA used to make as far as Total War is concerned, definetely look into picking this up if you're a Total War fan.

There alot to say about this game..

   --Let me start here. It IS worth the money.. IF you don't own Rome 2 or if you don't expect drastic change. 
While I think this game is great so far I can only say that it seems like rome 2 but with a few extra additions. This could 100% have been a addon from Rome 2 (minus a few extra effect and additions the game made) 

      


       Now you might ask "What changed"..let me tell you...
-Lot's of Faction Diversity
   Now each Faction in Campaign and in battles have their Strong Suit.. Now you can argue that that has been in the game forever, but to the scale that it has increased since the last games has strongly improved. What might Work witht the Saxon (i.e Mass Melee Infantry) may not work with Huns (Reallly sucky Melee Infantry) and vice versa. There is lots of more pre-game planning now in my opinion.

-Extremely good balance
   While some might say that Huns are completely op I say "Have you played or do you suck..." THere is NO ONE SUPER-Power Faction in this game. Everything CAN be countered. You just need to either time something right or setup the correct army or whatever you need to. For the most part, this is in my opinion the most balanced Total war in a while. (P.S. If anyone says that the game is unbalanced they are lieing. They just suck and probably don't know that Sword Infantry can't beat Horse Melee... that's like trying to destroy a tank with a rock... it doesn't work XD)

-Seige
   They took a mode I dared not play a second time on Rome 2 and made it into one of my favorite modes in this game. The escelation system is amazing (because I cried for it for years). That and the Barricade system is really intresting. You can divert forces by putting barricades in their way making them either try to destroy it or have to go on a path you set for them.


     That's the biggest changes to the game, but there is one problem that I feel almost makes me not like the game (but I got over it fast.. but some might not)


IT LOOKS VERY IDENTICAL TO ROME 2!!!

  With all the changes they made it still seems to have a Rome 2 vibe and look. Trust me it will annoy you for a hour or two, then you should be fine. But for people looking for a game to look completely new. you might be a bit disapointed.


   Besides that issue there is little to nothing I don't like about this game... again, COULD have been a addon for Rome 2 in my opinion, but for the things they added it's worth the money. 

Thanks and let me know what you thought of this Review...

Your troops can climb siege towers along with the newly released feature of getting off the siege tower at the top.

10/10 Huge step up

Total War: Attila at first seems like just an expansion to Rome II. It does, in fact, take place directly after the events that transpired in Rome II. The gameplay looks similar and I had no problems getting down to business. Mostly getting my Vikings slaughtered on the field of battle, but that’s just Total War for you. As I said, the map movement, UI, and combat operate just as Rome II did. That is where the similarity stops. The political system has been overhauled and offers a bunch of different options from marrying off your kinsman, assassinating them, or gaining their support. Similar to Rome II after a couple of patches, but this system feels much more refined. It also allows you to see if your cousins and uncles are going to come chop your head off because you made some bad decisions, i.e. civil war. The battles seem to be very much the same, but additions like the icons that indicate which directions your soldiers are facing were much needed, and a welcomed improvement. The unit tiles also give you a little extra information regarding their strength and demeanor. I have seen many people complaining about performance, and yes there is a bit of stuttering when you end turn. Just like every other Total War game that’s been released in the last 2 or 3 years. They just like to future proof their products, and I can’t blame them for that. I look forward to the future of this game, and for all of the TW's to come. 

9/10

I have played every single total war game ever, I started shogun 1 when I was 4 years old. I have a minimum of 10 hours on games like empire... and hundreds and hundreds of hours on games I really enjoyed, like Shogun II and Medieval II (and Rome II after the Emperor Edition...) So obviously I have had a lot of experience with the games. But good as those games were, they have nothing on Attila. Now, I find it a bit of a stretch to say it is the best total war game yet, but if it isn't, then what is? Medieval II was great, but it's time is past. The graphics are almost painful to play with in this age where technology is so advanced. Attila is just a step forward in so many directions, it's ridiculous. The graphics are slightly better than Rome II, and certainly better than any other TW game. The campaign mechanics are phenomenal, they bring all the good parts of past campaigns back, and add in new, better parts. For example, the horde mechanic is SO fun to play as. You can lay waste to the empires, and there is a small chance the nation will be able to deal with you as they have many problems on their hands. However, they are still a force to be reckoned with and you'd better run if they come your way. 
       Also, the battle mechanics are amazing! the seiges are AWESOME and each city has stellar work put in to it to make it unique, ending the problem in Rome II how every city in a district looked the same, making defensive seiges very, VERY boring. But even the random cities in Attila have been changed. Also, Attila has finally dealt with a problem in all tw games... the damaging affects of the battle on the terrain. Now, everything you do can affect the battlefield; from accidentally (or purposefully) burning down a forest to scorching the earth with your catapults. No other Tw game has come even close to this (I'm not counting Rome II's pathetic attempt where trees with brun for a couple seconds then fizzle out). 
       There are a few problems, however; things they removed that I didn't appreciate. For some reason CA thought it would be a good idea to remove the bar at the end of a battle that showed you how many kills you got. This is not a problem in 1v1, but in 2+v2+ games, especially multiplayer, it removes a sense of achievement; that you cant figure out who had the most kills. CA, if you are reading this, PLEASE ADD IT BACK IN!!! Also a minor problem, they removed the function to duplicate units in custom battle. This is a really small problem however, and the amount of Pro's in the game overwhelm the small problems I have. GREAT JOB CA!!! I think this is hands down an amazing game and I recomend you buy it.

Attila: Total Waste of Money

The lastest chapter in the Total War series launches this week with "Attila". In this game you pick up as the Roman Empire begins to crumble and the Huns are inmvading from the East. Blah, blah, blah. What we really have is an expansion of the Rome II game that the Creative Assembly wants us to pay full price for. And what do you get for your extra $45? Not much.

• The same European map 
• Only 10 out of 56 playable factions  
• Basically the same gameplay
• And of course the opportunity to pay for more DLC

There is a new feature that Attila adds: The ability to be a nomadic faction, or "hordes".  More than just fortifying your army, you become your own mobile city with buildings and such. It IS a cool new feature, but it only works if you don't own a city. Once you "settle" and quit migrating, that option is gone.

This is a better game than Rome II was at launch, but I for one am sick of buying basically a game skeleton and then having to buy all the pieces to play the full game. Just wait until everything is relesaed for Attila and buy the "Special Edition" with all the DLC.
Great game with a bit high of a learning curve, more difficult than past titles in the series, I reckon.
Horde mechanic very fun to play, though I miss the days of Medieval 2, where factions were unlocked, instead of bought.

I've logged about 15 hours since Atillas relase and I'm having a blast! I was a little nervous about the state of the game at release, because of Rome 2's, but i was plesantly suprised with Atilla. The game has yet to crash and I've only experienced one bug, (I tried to auto resolve a battle but there were no choices) but it was nothing major. I love this campaign because It is compleatly different from rome 2's in that just surviving is a huge challenge especialy as the Romans. The family tree is a very welcome addition to the game and makes you care for your generals and faction leaders unlie in rome 2. All in all this game runs very smooth with minimal bugs and crashes and is just plain fun.

+ Heavy apocalyptic atmosphere, you can feel that some dark shit is happening in the world.
+ That atmosphere is supported with great non-gimmick campaign and combat features. Dynamic fire, hordes, migrations, famine, deseases, decimations, political intrigues, land fertility (you can pretty much burn the shit out of your enemies and left nothing but a desolate lands). Game forces you to do some gruesome stuff to survive - sending troops to plunder distant enemies, razing their settlements (or even your own if shit gets heavy). Your good old plain vanilla map painting might work at some point, but it wont be as enjoyable as using those cool features. It is a great thing just by itself.
+ AI and Diplomacy are surprisingly manageble, still a subject for improvement though.
+ Proper family tree, character development, military tradition, technology and management systems.
+ So far you have 3 factions archetypes - big empires, barbaric kingdoms and nomadic people. Factions Inside those groups are very similar to each other, but groups themselves offer you different gameplay styles
+ Siege battles seem OK to me, the best ones in series for sure. Dynamic fire, proper defences and morale system are doing good job here.

- You could already see DLC money sucking. Buck gets ten it will start with Blood and Gore DLC, then cancerous culture-packs will follow. Take a note that i dont have any problems with cool campaign packs.
- Still cant play online campaign with more than 2 people. Why CA, why?!

Still requires some polishment here and there, but overall it is a great and feature-rich Total War game. 7\10 right out of the box with a strong potential to become 9\10.

Now - this doesn't mean we are not allowed to point out faliures - there are balancing issues and still those crashes you get. - And I don't like how very much alike the viking factions are...

This game is overall slightly better than Rome 2. If you like the previous games then get this or wait for it to go on sale if you don't want to dish the $45. I rate this 8/10. The game has a great framework just needs some DLC and a few patches.

- Improvements to the hud in campaign map/battle
- More complex political system (Select providential governors + more) which Rome 2 skipped over completely
- Better research tree
- More cinematric scenes/back story
Cons
- Needs optimization patch if you don't have 3 or 4 gbs of GPU RAM you probably wont be satisfied with the graphics
- Dayz 1 DLC unless you pre-purchased
- Needs a bit more content
- Building structures in cities is unnessicarily complex and hard to understand (at least at first)
Great game but keeps crashing. Windows Update tells me I have no driver updates to do...yet crash crash crash....Game looks great but crash.
Can't tell if this game is great or not. Another DOA Total War Title. I have spent several hours trying to just get this game to work. Hasn't launched successfully yet. Buy at your own risk.

I've played most every TW game in the series since the very first Shogun. When Rome II came out I have to say that I was a bit disappointed with the strategic layer of the game vs prior games. It felt like they simplified many aspects of the game to make it more accessible for new players, but in the process stripped the game down so much that I felt like I was only building cities or fighting battles, with not much in between. It didn't take long for boredom to set in once I reached some positive momentum in the game.

I was a bit hesitant about Atilla for this reason. Luckily many of the other user reviews tipped my decision to buy Atilla and I'm glad I did. Atilla fills in all of the holes that Rome II opened when it simplified the strategic layer so much. Atilla brings back some important game concepts (governors) and introduces some exceptional new ones (hordes & in-depth politics). While much of the game will be very familiar to veterans of Rome II, there is plenty new to Atilla that makes it a worthwhile purchase.

So far, I've enjoyed the game a lot. The AI does from time to time make stupid moves. Which is a good thing, since players are bound to make some mistakes during the game as well.

There are some performance issues, but so far I haven't encountered any issue that would've turned the game unplayable. There is room to improvement with this game, but same applies to other games as well.

The only thing that I can't justify is the day-one DLC Viking Forefathers. Now I don't mind a game having DLCs and the Viking Forefathers is fine by me. What I don't like are day-one DLCs.

There's nothing that can be done about this game, but I wish they wouldn't do this in the future.

After all that's said and done, I would recommend this game for those, who like this type of games.

UPDATE: I have come across an issue with the grand campaign. End turn phaze sometimes freezes the game for a good 15 seconds after it has gone through the AI movements. It also seems to like to crash during the end phaze from time to time. Still would recommend the game, but I recommend waiting for a few patches.
Would recommend waiting till a patch comes out as I receive the 12 files cannot validate error.
Still a few error, but almost perfect.

So far it seems like Napolean, Shogun 2, and Rome2 mixed into one game.

Basically a re-skin of Rome2 with a major overhaul. 

Not impressed yet but maybe after I play it a tad bit longer than 2 hours my mind will change.

For the most part tho, you are better off buying Rome2 if you want a solid game and are new to the Total War series.

Everything you weren't expecting following Rome 2. 

Great new UI, political system is revamped with the return of the family tree, the game looks beautiful and plays well (only crashed once in 4 hours of continuous play, Version 1.0), interesting new factions with cut scenes and generally tons of new features. 

Would highly recommend, CA is back on form.

Total War-The strategy that has been chugging for quite some time-Hitting bumps along the way some causing only slight bruises others causing a trip to the emergency room "COUGH ROME 2"COUGH". But besides these bumps the series has survived and is still on its road trip. Now as Total War is setting out on another trip it has taken Attila to be its transportation.Does it hold up ? Hell yes it does. Where Rome 2 was some sort of monster that ran out of gas and had all its wires cut everydamn day like some band of nutters were following you Attila is stable and the nutters have stopped cutting the wires in car. Attila overall looks like Rome 2 but better. The GUI looks very nice and gives information in a nice fluid way. The combat system is much better since Rome 2 as it seems the Ai has grown walnut size brain and knows how to move 2 large bodys of units so that you have to work out which threat deserves more of your troops. Overall the combat and the ai seems that its stable for now. In closing even though I have only been driving this car around for 4 hours Attila already feels great. So for a score i would say with the amount of time spent with it i would give it a 8/10. Happy Driving everyone.
Game is amazing, i love XD. I am playing as the Danes, and it is just beautiful. Highly recommend this game to anyone.

So I am a die hard Total War fan.  With that being said, I am once again disappointed in the latest and greatest from CA.  Don't get me wrong It is a good game so far even though I haven't had a chance to dive to deeply into it yet.  My (personally) biggest irritation spot is the art work.  I am a history buff and CA really sucks at researching what a time period looked like, example rome 2...  There are some problems with the combat engine for example a half group of archers (very light missile infantry) murdering my full strength cavalry (medium meele cavalry) in meele combat 1 on 1, and a few other quirks but these seem to be isolated events and not a normal thing.  Overall I am sure that the total war modders will not let me down on fixing small issues like these and giving awesome reskins etc.  The tech tree took a minute to get used to as well as the political system but they are fairly solid and comprehensive.  I do absolutely recommend this game and recommend playing the western roman empire as I feel that it completely achieved what the developer interviews said they aimed to do by making you feel like you are fighting for your very existence even before the Huns arrive!

So after the catastrophe that was the release of Rome 2 everyones wanting to know if this is better. Well, I think getting run over is better than Rome 2's release, so obviously it is better. Rome 2 did get fixed up but it took a hell of a long time to get it right. But yes, this is better than Rome 2.

THE GOOD:

In fact, the campaign is absolutely fantastic, it's got the best atmosphere of any total war game I've played, obviously I am likely to edit this review as I sink more hours into the game, so far my first campaign as the Geats (a DLC Viking faction) has been enjoyable, sailing around, plundering wealthy coastal settlements and generally not giving a f*ck (stealing money, send it to strengthen my capital and smoke weed everyday). 

However, I dabbled a little bit with the other factions campaigns and there is a so much diversity in the general feel of each group of factions. You can feel playing as the Romans that their days are numbered and it's damage control from the get go, the  Sassanids are the new big power and are ready to rise up and become a dominant force and replace the old, frail empires in the west. The barbarian tribes have a fight for survival, scrabbling to hold their lands against the behemoths that are both Roman Empires, but the threat of hordes coming and destroying your lands and your people is ever constant, so you always have a lot to think about. The hordes are well, hordes. You are what keeps the 'civilised' people awake at night, especially as the Huns who can't settle, only loot and raze. 

Sieges are an absolute delight as well, the defenders being able to craft barricades in the street really adds another dimension, the fire spreading throughout the city is great to watch, while the defeneders have the strategic advantage behind their walls and barricades, fire weakens their stats and morale, creating a better balance of gameplay. Each main faction looks great as well, this belongs in the bad section but since Im already talking about it I should mention that some of the unplayable barbarian factions are too similar, there's absolutely nothing to distinguish them from each other apart from their faction sigil. However the Roman soldiers look great, a far cry from the glorious looking legionaires you had in Rome 2, these legionaries are much uglier and darker (but in a good way).

The family tree is a welcome return, however it doesn't cast off everything that Rome 2 implemented, taking some of the good things like influence and political occurences. What was a disorganised mess, but a good idea in rome 2 has now been refined to something which is much easier to get to grips with.

THE BAD:

Mainly technical, but the one gameplay flaw I can spot right now is the razing mechanic, while it is a great thing they've put in the game, once you raze a settlement, the land in that province is now classed as 'desolate' and inhospitable. This certainly is an interesting mechanic though I fear that as a campaign progresses there is a danger of too many places becoming 'desolate' and there being not enough towns and cities to take. This is yet to be seen of course but it seems all too likely a problem.

Time between turns is unforgivably long, I've gone and made a nice brew (cuppa tea for you Americans) in the time it takes for turns to finish. Not to mention loading times for battles are huge. Once it gets going, its great, but have a book with you to read between turns, perhaps an encyclopedia on Roman history? 

Graphics optimisation is once again, poor. I can run Rome 2 fairly well at medium-high settings but it's very difficult to run this game anything higher than low settings. This wouldn't have bothered me so much if there was an increase in visual quality but it all looks the same as Rome 2, albeit a bit more brown, dark and gritty. For so little difference in visuals yet a huge decrease in performance it really is an irritating situation. Check your specs before going into it to make sure you're able to run it well as on low settings it does look pretty pants. 

Technical issues aside, the game has fantastic gameplay mechanics and is a bloody good job by CA.

So far I'd give this an 8/10, great work.

What happens when developer admits their mistakes? What happens when they listen to their fans? I will tell you, what happens is Total War: Attila.

Allmost every issue was sorted (note i said ALLMOST) but we need to be realistic because there no way that the game(s) will be 100% flawless. But the point is this game improved on everything 10thfold. Improved, Expanded and even bundled old favorite features that have been gone for years. 

Release state is quite a surprise, its very stable and totally playable (same level as shogun 2 release) and that alone is very positive, when we assisted the rome 2 release disaster that matched empire total war flop release state..... At least i can enjoy my 40 euros right out of the bat with Attila.

Value wise,this game is cheaper than rome 2 (release price) and yet offer ALOT MORE content just as "vanilla" state. Has depth, Has atmosphere, Has variety and has beauty and has alot of replayability.

only 6 hours into Attila and a few things hit you early on, firstly depth, there's layer upon layer of detail and strategy to this edition of TW.
All the usual aspects are there the research, city building, armys, deplomacy etc etc but all of these are given extra depth when you add in the people and power struggles within your faction they develop personallities like never before, a general thats your strongest asset can soon become someone to undermine to retain control.

graphically the game is much better, the terrain is detailed and a pleasure to look at, the new styled menu's can be a bit confusing early on but worth sticking with till you can find everything you need.

the battles are epic with the added detail and sounds.

one one gripe and its been there for a few TW versions, troop movement.. (especially noticed once fighting inside a cities walls), a hoard of Hun barbarians given a movement order will still form up into napoleonic style columbs etc to march off..that's the only bit of poor scripting IMO.

A must buy for any TW or Strategy fan, the depth and variety of strategies is going to keep you hooked for months if not years of reply value.
Incredible, a huge huge leap forward in the total war series after the disaster that was Rome 2! Very indepth family tree/politics which is entertaining on its own let alone battles!

Bravo CA, a far more solid game that Rome 2 was upon release. While I do love the current version of Rome 2 this new addition to the Total War series really brings the shine back to the series. I look forward to the first few patches which will likely improve its performance, but even in its current state this is a beautiful game. I am sure I will find something to criticize later on, but for now it looks to be a solid contestant for a good chunk of my holiday time. 

The re-addition of Family Trees are a beautiful thing to see returned, allowing you to have more control of your [strike] treachery [/strike] rise to power. The decadence of Rome having led to its current weakness is almost as equally beautiful to those of us who enjoy playing as a Barbarian conqueror, with the hordes taking all they can see and turning it to an empty wasteland of desolation (On retrospect I probably should not have decimated nearly so much land, but it was very tempting - and there was an achievement for it).

Fantastic remake of Babarian Invasion. The campaign/battle difficulty needs some reworking. Family tree I missed you. Attila is the Crusader Kings of Total War, and I love it. Good job Creative & Sega!!! Looking forward to 'Total Warhammer'! :D

A great game and an excellent addition to the Total War series.
 Difficult and engaging in equal measure, probably something of a baptism by fire for anyone new to the series but likely to be more rewarding the more you play.
 The return of a (vastly improved, and I say that as someone who loved the older family tree systems in Rome, Barbarian Invasion and Medieval 2) family tree and more numerous personality traits really helps to both create a sense of attachment to the characters and a feeling of narrative. 
The politics system is good but could maybe do with a little more in terms of hints on how to balance things as this felt a little unlcear to start with (that said I skipped the tutorial and had the Advisor option turned off so maybe this is my own fault :P ). Once you get to grips with it though it is simple to understand and the need to balance the influence of various characters adds another dimension to the game.
This might not be a good game if you are looking for instant gratification, it not only rewards attention to detail but tends to punish rushed or badly prepared actions quite harshly. 
Battles compare favourably to Rome 2 and feel challenging but not frustrating. 
The game is quite demanding and I suspect if you were using the recommended specs from steam the graphics would look less than impressive, I would recommend having a look at review sites or youtubers and seeing what specs they were using. 
There a great deal of variety between the factions in terms of the starting positions with everything from small settled tribes, rootless nomads, great empires on the verge of collapse and rising powers with strong starting positions. I also greatly enjoyed Attila's atmosphere; the soundtrack and the overall aesthetic of the game really drew me in.
Definetly a step in the right direction. I think this may be the best Total War game yet.

After 10 hours of play I can already say this game is a lot more than just a "this should have been a DLC". It has everything Rome II lacks and more. 
The new city razing mechanics is awesome, you literally destroy the city and the region becomes desolate. On this point I will say it seems the AI uses it too much. On my campaign map I have tons of regions desolated. You can resettle those but it cost money and food, and it seems the AI considers it too expensive because I have not seen them settle one. But that's just some tweaking stuff, no big deal. 

Faction politics is much better than before, not only thanks to the family tree, but you also have much more options available with characters. Choose wife, embezle money, raise support, assassinate (of course), choose your heir, and plenty more. The offices system is more visual and intuitive, governor mechanics is very useful (saved me from starving more than once), and the blend between dominion and control resulting in faction power is a nice expansion on the simpler Rome II system.

I don't if it's just me but the game feels more balanced, battles feel better and more dinamic. Units rout to come back later if not totally obliterated, in Rome II once they routed you pretty much lost them. Here you have more second chances if you play your strategy well. It really matters how you engage the enemy and the AI seems more responsive. 
Battle maps are also much more detailed, really beautiful to look at, and have more strategic values.
I still miss having more landing points for navies. It can be a pain to fight mixed battles because of that. 

Naval battles feel pretty much the same, no big improvement as far as I know.

Overall the game is very good. If you come from Rome you will notice the difference. Especially with loading time, Attila is much faster. Not with the turns though, ending turn is still a pain, but when faction numbers start to drop (even by just 4 or 5) speed increases a lot.

I've been playing with the Jutes and it's a lot of fun. They have some powerful units and traits. I'm playing on normal difficulty and the campaign seems harder than rome's normal difficulty, AI is not afraid to declare war just when I'm weaker on their side, catching me completely unaware, while they cooperate with my other enemies to take me down. It is much easier to get people angry at you in attila, as soon as you get big, everybody will hate you for it. 

I was reluctant to buy this game considering Rome II was a fail (still a very good game though, just not what people expected) but I have no regrets, this is a well done Total War successor and I hope it's the perfect test ground for Medieval 3 (fingers crossed).

PRe-ordered and didn't let me down thank god!!! Me and my best friend we're playing all night (and he is euro and had to work in the a.m.)  Can't wait to see what the DLC bring ... guys pay these men! ... when you go to work you want money right?!

Attila is the major AAA game that we should have gotten from Creative Assembly when they prensented us Rome2,

The campaign map feels so gloomy and apocalyptic that the scenery makes you feel quite powerful our weak depending on the faction you will be playing its as that much impact for me total immersion.

The campaign feels so good as if each faction can have a real meaning in the gameplay in the campaign exemple if you play romains you will have a more defense focused game early and then try to take back what you lost, franks & saxons will be the early starters and expand while playing the huns will make you wonder around the map attack who the hell you want and cause utter terror that is what this game is about immersion and roles that they did pretty god damn well.

oh and the raze ability that makes you feel like a fu%?&!$ badass!

Now for the in-game combat : just wow the combat in this episode feels refreshing because it does not deal whit horrid combat that rome did i think and i may be telling bs but i think they took de combat systeme of arena which is more combat focused and as huge impacts, when u see your men fight u see how well and responsive the combat feels flanking attacks feels great and gives the impression of a huge impact in the enemy, leaders feels less overpowered that in rome 2 making a bit more exciting then just for exemple rushing your rome 2 spartan champions in 3 stacks not giving a fuck and cutting them to pieces now there good but you cant be ruthless whit them as before.

For now whit what ive played i would give it a go if i where STR player and for the long timers who are regulars to the total war series give this a go i cant wait to continue this vanilla version and see what people will mod for this a great episode in the series. ps you can burn the sh$! out of the world 10/10

Pros:

The new horde mechanic is really good.  It forces you to adopt a different style of play and seems to be very well thought out.

Battle AI seems somewhat improved.

The game looks stunning both on the campaign map and in battle.

The sound is very atmospheric.

Cons:

Limited range of factions available.  I anticipate multiple DLCs to unlock them all.

Day 1 DLC.

Some graphical bugs, lines across the screen after alt tabbing. Fixed by restart.

High system reqs.

I may update this review later once I've played more

Great game in the TW series, feels as amazing as Shogun II but with the gritty and dark theme of Roman destruction.

Compared to Rome II there have been a bunch of new features (re)introduced that improve the gameplay a lot too, like family tree and assigning governors.

Overall I would say that for any fan of the TW series, this game will give you a lot of enjoyment. Goodluck playing the Western Roman Empire though, that stuff is as hard as Duke Nukem's balls.

I've only been able to play the Prolouge battle but it seems very good so far. Feels a lot like Medieval 2 mixed with Rome II.
 THE GREATEST THING IS THAT THEY FINALLY OPTOMIZED IT. I have a GTX 780Ti which is one of the most powerful cards out there and i still couldnt play a seige map on ROME II without extreme lag. But in this one. no lag, yay. I would recomend buying this game if you are a true Total War fan. if you are unsure about it due to ROME II's shitty release i would wait a few weeks to see if the game is broken in anyway that makes in un-playable. 
   Hopefully with anyluck, Sega won't order any shitty patches or money grubbing DLC. Good luck, and happy Waring

A stellar step up from Rome II. On my rig, it is virtually flawless as of release, in terms of bugs and crashes.  All the added features were sorely needed and deliver. Not to mention the period in history is so interesting and the gameplay truly unique in the series with the migratory factions. 10/10 Do buy!!!

Score: 8/10  
"Going back to the bare basics and borrowing from the closet of Crusader Kings, well done"

Pros:
-The vibe of the game.  What I mean by this is how I felt when I loaded up the game for the first time.  The game feels dark, gritty, tense.  Playing as the ERE, I adopted a death ground strategy and felt tense the whole time.  Good job.
-The feeling of impending doom.  It's subtle, much appreciated.  At first I was like, "Where is Attilla? I don't see the Huns as that scary, what's going on here?"  You then realize (or remember) he was not born yet
-The unit balance feels good enough out of the box.  I say this because the inevitable mod or compilation will come by and fix it all anyways, but out of the box it was playable and I didn't feel like it was too arcade-y.
-the UI and "Paradox"-like feel to it all.  Fellow fans of Paradox games and Crusader Kings will appreciate the intrigue, the family trees and other little bits that make up the generals and family tree(s).  Nice touch on actually assigning the family members as either generals or immobile governors, thanks for that.
-The Map.  This is a nice map.  Look at this map.  Look at this motherfucking map.  Love the medieval esque touch to the font and paper map look. well done.  Too bad the graphics look so... jagged.  Modern games need true SSAO, HDR and blah blah, good shadows and soft look to the whole deal to look nice.  It's all a trick to the eye, too much detail looks weird.
-The 2D Portraits.  Love it.  Simple change adds something ROME TW1 esque that is great.  Hated the 3d models in Rome2.  Maybe you can go back and remove them and add in some 2d portraits?
-The family member skill tree.  Awesome.  Feels good, like the HoMaM feel to it, or maybe Shogun TW.  RPGlike, well done.  ALso like the ancillaries and how we can choose them.
-The conclusion of battle.  Genius.  You can now END BATTLE anytime after winning.  Your end credits to a battle can be chasing down those damn German axemen. Good.


Cons:
-the graphics settings even on Max Quality look ugly.  No, before you say anything, or roll your eyes, or sigh, or facepalm... I have a good computer, it's not that that, so just sit down and "don't even". We want to enjoy the artwork you created, but it doesnt look very good right now and we all know it's the engine.  We all can tell you have talented art teams, so give them a new engine for Attilla's sake.
It's frustrating, the warscape engine is close to exploding.  Stop kicking it over and over, it's dead, ok? CA, with all that cash money, please for god sakes make a new engine and bedazzle us for the next TW game. Enough said.  Just do it already.
  
-The UNIT and FACTION names are soooooo vanilla, it's so terrible.  Surely you can hire a dude to get some historical names. Come on.  Hunnic levy.  GOD.  Stop it. Comitatenses, is enough don't put spears on the end! Ugly.  Latin and english looks lame together.  Same with adding Borderguards and the end of Limitanei. Don't. ok? Ugly and cringe worthy.  If the players don't know what that unit is, they will look it up and be glad you kept all the nomenclature correct.  I remember those historical descriptions ROME1 units had.  That was awesome. Why did you ever get rid of that kind of unit view window, anyways?

-Funny and Bad that you used the same voices and unit recognitions but then threw in Christian slants to it.  Like... "Heaven can wait" Instead of Hades.  Except that Hades is the greek Hell, so. Anyhow.  I would have hoped you would have gone the route you did in Napoleon where units and such had their native tongue.  It kicked ass and added that layer that was needed.  I think it's tough to figure out what a 5th century hunnic language would SOUND like, hey, I get that.  Could have tried? We all want to hear Latin and old Germanic, that's a no brainer.  Make a DLC for it, make us buy it.  Who cares.  Just no DLCs about women warriors, clowns, unicorns that shoot rainbows or stuff like that.  Keep the Hollywood weird shit out please. Thanks!

-Same Boring Elevator Music.  Would have thought you guys went Hollywood and given us an epic track with Hunnic/Eastern music.  It's there I guess, but it's boring.  It takes away from my feeling of the impending doom that will befall the innocent people of the ERE. Hire a composer and score your games properly, like the old days.  I still get chills when I hear the old Roman March theme from ROME1.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HmM_rlnYnmw

P.S. It's time to rekindle a relationship and get Jeff VanDyck back composing for you.  Or have him come back and rescore the game, make us pay for it in a DLC, whatever you gotta do.

Take note of the comments, listen to those drums and let the nostalgia flow.  Thanks for reading friends.  


Random Items:
While you're at it, make the next TW game a Victorian era game.  Go ahead and take my cool title too, TOTAL WAR: BLOOD AND IRON.  I'm going off topic and I don't care. It's what I thought as I looked at the new menus and UI for Attila. Or... do a good Medieval 3 that transitions well into renaissance/exploration age with maps and colonies to build like you have with the desolate regions after a burned/razed city.  Nice touch btw.

More to play before writing a complete review but so far if you're wondering what this 'expansion' is like here's some info. Creative Assembly is pumping out these and I'd almost call these mini expansions to Rome 2. Attila so far looks very much the same as Rome II, obviously a new setting though. So far it looks like they've improved on things, added more depth to politics. Is a little more complex. Shifted buttons around but it is very much just the Rome II game, muddled around with and improved. So far AI seems a bit better and not as much 'blobbing of units' going on in battles. Still much swarming ants style though, kind of a arcadey feel. The combat is essentially exactly the same as Rome 2, and not like Shogun 2. I preferred Shogun 2 style of combat definately. Swords clanging. Arrows felt like they were being drawn back and fired/lobbed and actually heard them fly, made an effect on each individual man within a unit. At the moment in this engine it just looks/feels/sounds like they're throwing lines of smoke at enemies that make no sound unless zoomed right in. That old engine is dead and done with, it was great for battle lines being held and individual fights going on, cool to watch but that engine had terrible performance. The Attila game runs very fast and well. It definately seems Creative assembly is going for a more arcadey feel like Rome 2 seemed (to me). I'm interested in the history of this Era and like it more so than the Rome era but, essentially I think this is going to be another cash cow for them with more mini exps like they did in Rome 2. They've done a good job of the Prologue(Tutorial) in this and I'm enjoying it.

This however will be the last Total War game I buy for a long time though. Just not happy with the battle map feel anymore. The campaign map is pretty good though.
don't buy this game it keeps crashing.. thanks again steam!!
developer_response:
Hi dava943!!,

Nico here from the community team at Creative Assembly.
I’m sorry to hear that you have experienced crashes during your play. You might want to make sure that your graphic drivers are up to date. In fact, outdated drivers may prevent the game from starting or running properly.
If you require assistance to update the drivers of your graphics card, do not hesitate to contact the manufacturer directly, they will be able to provide the adequate assistance.

You can also check that all game files have been installed properly. To do so, do a right click on the game from the list, Properties > Local Files > Verify integrity of game cache…

If you still experience difficulties starting or running the game, please contact our technical support via our official Total War forums in order to receive further assistance regarding this matter:
http://forums.totalwar.com/forumdisplay.php/213

Regards

Nico

review:
[h1]So Far So Good. [/h1]

[b] The Goodside [/b]
+Political System is improved
+Family Tree is confusing at first, but fluid
+The Battle and Campaign AI have been improved
+More Difficult
+Apocalyptic Feels
+Flames, flames, and more flames
[b]
The Badside [/b]
-Units rout/die a bit fast 
-There probably will be another Blood and Gore DLC
-Day One DLC

Expecting patches to build upon this already solid start. 
Overall, a step in the right direction.
What Rome 2 shoulda been. An adult total war not for 12 year old console kids.

Good: Total War: ATTILA is one of the best entries to the Total War series yet, Creative Assembly has definitely picked up their act since the disaster/disgust that was Rome 2 and presented an authentic experience of the dying days of the Roman empire(s). Battles are greatly improved and almost on par with the first rome and barbarian invasion now, the camapign draws you in much more with more immersion, more features and greater replayability thanks to the dynamism of the migrating peoples that are the hordes and the steady climate change. The prologue campaign is engrossing, much more so then Rome 2's Etruscan one, I am still yet to finish it yet enjoying it so far even as a series veteran. 

Bad: Kinda bad performance at the moment, get some stutters, way lower FPS compared to Rome in general and big blobs fighting kills the FPS. This can be fixed by patching and driver updates from Nvidia so I'm not too fussed. Overall I feel like i got my moneys worth and would probably even buy the DLC at this rate if as much love is put into as the main campaign, as there are so many interesting dark age period conflicts that could be touched on by CA. (Muslim invasions, Saxon conquest of England, Charlemagne) 

Nutshell:
Good - Better then Rome 2, on par with the other great warscape games, Napoleon and Shogun 2.
Bad - Performance on launch.

System at time of review: i7 2600k, Gigabyte GTX 660 Windforce OC 2GB, 8GB DDR3 RAM, Windows 7 Service pack 2, latest Nvidia drivers. Installed on HDD.

This really is what Rome 2 should have been! Similar animations and basic game mechanics to Rome 2, but they have improved nearly all aspects of the game, the most noticable being the campaign map AI.
if you liked total war rome you will love this so much and you get to kill anyone in your family tree :)

Pretty amazing.
Well coded.
AI way better.
Villages, castles/forts are alive, with farmers and normal citizens that fight for their lifes, that run away.. way more realistic.
Buildings now have substance, interior lights, way more realistic.
What a game..

I get that rome is OP and you guys wanted to make it more challenging but I think you overdid it a little bit. 

Also diseases spread in Attila worse then in a low budget porn shoot. The rest of the game is great except for the performance which is shit. And if you going to have a shieldwall ability then the units should probably look like there making a shieldwall. :)

In almost all aspects this game is what Rome 2 should have beeen. However, Because the campaign map is narrowed down with the Western Roman empire taking almost all of europe, the campaign is actually less interesting for me. 

Some key issues they fixed are:
1) Blobbing/moshpit. Finally the unit interactions are up to par with previous Total War games
2) Graphics that don't run well and look like @#$%. Now they don't run well, but at least actually look better than Shogun 2 and much better than Rome 2.

Some issues remain:
1) Battle AI is still dumb
2) Price leaves a sour taste in mouth, as this is really a Patch+DLC.

My recommendation is based on whether you have something better to do with $40. If you like the series and you have $40 to spare, you should get it. If you're just looking for a strategy game, and looking to make a good purchase, you'll probably be somewhat disappointed until modders fix the game.

This review, until I update it is based on first impressions of the first four hours. So bear that in mind.

Total War: Attila is the game Rome 2 should have been. That's a rather bold statement straight out the gate but it's definately an apt description. Immediately the game introduces you to a ton of new elements that either are returning favorites or brand new ideas. Everything has a much more in depth coat of paint to it and an apocalyptic dark ages feel. Make no mistake either, This is truly the Dark age being depicted here.  

The gameplay feels responsive, far more so than before, and there's a weight to every click and push. It's very punishing for stupid mistakes but rewards brilliance. The interface is somehow streamlined while being even more in depth. The unit cards have much more 'at a glance' descriptions of traits as compared to Rome 2's graph and stats clusterfuck of comparing making much easier to keep track of which units are good for what and why. The tech trees are also much more simplified as you can clearly see them spread out all in one big tree instead of the multiple pages you had to go through in rome 2. Returning from Previous games is the family tree system, it combines with the Rome 2 factions system to make politics much more in depth than ever before and much more engaging. the ability to assign governors and people into positions of power in your society also add much needed depth to the experience. The level up system is also dramatically improved for named characters back into a tree of abilities rather than simply going by the cards that didnt tell you what came after that in the tree without dragging back up the clunky encyclopedia every time. Overall, everything feels much more intelligently designed. 

As for optimization, lolwat? there's very very little of it. I found several bugs that were atrocious and hopefully will quickly be patched, driver issues mostly to be honest.
EDIT: As it turns out these optimization issues were mainly on my end as my drivers were outdated, once my drivers were properly updated it seems to be running fine

Visually the game is stunning, It's gorgeously presented, the detail is incredible and the whole thing is much more detailed and real looking. 
The AI is frustratingly unforgiving even on the easiest settings you'll be carefully managing your provinces and struggling for funds if you're playing as one of the smaller factions or the viking forefathers faction. The Diplomacy is extremely difficult as most factions refuse any proposals I have without even looking at them despite us being on good terms, Even the most reasonable of ones like trade it seems no one is interested in. As a result I find myself constantly strapped for cash to upgrade provinces, and buy more units which despite having a possibilty of fielding 8 armies according to my imperium I cannot even afford 2 full armies and this change is one I do not like. Perhaps it's intentional? But it feels like it's a crapshoot between trying to position your armies to predict your enemies movements. And the amount of movement range seems to be absurd on ships,forcing the pathfinding to take unnessecarily longer routes preventing you from reaching an enemy ship that should easily be in range giving them time to launch a sneak attack out of no where across a river within 2 turns of their last army being destroyed. Almost as if the AI is cheating to make the game feel more difficult and hectic, it definately works but as a result leaves me frustrated as cheap shot doomstacks come out of no where and lay siege to my towns


Overall, I reccomend Attila if you're a fan of Total War, and were burned by Rome 2's dissapointing start this is the game for you.

Watch out huns the Geats are comming! JAG VILL LEVA JAG VILL DÖ I NORDEN. 
Total War:ATILLA is a breather in all the hate that was Rome 2. With new functions
in the UI that was in older TW games and new building/units pictures the game became 
more interesting to play. And the idea that its in 400 AD makes it cool since its early medieval times mixed with Roman cultures. 
If you have played Barbarian Invasion i recommend this game since it got the Dark cool feeling in it.

$45 is very steep for this title, and origionally may be off-putting for many. Despite it's price tage, this game is extremely worth it. This game is what Rome 2 should have been it has its flaws which I will get to, but the many positives make this game a definite return to the quality of the total war series.

cons: This game does have performance issues. Cutscenes are laggy and will freeze. The turn cycle has crashed on multiple occasions. Yet this game has not yet been out for 24 hours at the time of writing this review, so it is very likely that these problems will not persist for much longer.

pros: DOMESTIC POLITICS AND FAMILY TREE ACTIONS! The addition of this feature not only makes the game exactly what fans of Rome 2 had wanted, but the manner that it is added means it is not only a fun side-feature like the domestic politics added in Imperial Edition; it is a crucial aspect of the campaign. Being able to see exactly how each family member relates to each-other and the exact actions that can be taken for each member is the perfect combination of the family features from Rome 1/Medieval 2 and Shogun 2 with several new features added.
The single player campaign is outstanding so far, I already am running multiple campaigns as the Sassanid, Ostragoths and a video series as the Geats. The dynamic enviroment and the flavor that Creative Assembly has given to the campaign world makes Total War: Attila one of the most enjoyable total war games in a very long time.

The price is very steep and heavy, but ultimately I feel that it is worth it. Total War: Attila is the game that fans of the series wanted Rome 2 to be. People are disappointed that this was treated as a stand alone rather than an expansion for Rome 2, but I feel that this game is the future of the Total War series, so many different elements in this game are perfected and refined into a game that just feels solid and right. I would even go so far as to say that people who are deciding between buying Rome 2: Imperial Editon or Total War: Attila should absolutley go for Attila. As a long standing fan of the total war series, this game is absolutely worth it.
The game Rome II should have always been! Plus you will have more illegitimate children then you could ever have hoped for!

Let me start by saying that I have owned every single Total War game since the first shogun and have been playing these games since I was 10 years old. That being said, I think this is the freshest Total War game in a long while.  

The Ai is the smartest in the series thus far, it will flank, it will outmaneuver you on the campaign map and it will kick you around if you are not paying attention. The best part is that the AI will no longer sit by as you rain death upon them with ranged units (usually). It is still not perfect however, they will still do stupid things every once and a while, like build an army with 10 war dogs units or put their siege engine in a stupid place.  I have also noticed that for the first time ever, I have seen the AI take a lot of Mercenary units to flush out its ranks.  

Where this game really shines is in the sieges, they are beautiful. Fires destroy whole villages, smoke effects are top notch, and projectiles look incredible for the first time in series history.  The AI also shines here, using choke points and barricades to beat me up and keeping ranged units in just the right places to fire on me.  

I have always found myself becoming bored with the battles in other Total War games after about 40-50 turns and using auto-resolve whenever I didn't need to fight a close battle because they all started to blend together and loose the excitement. This has not been the case in Attila. Every fight feels fresh, each encounter I feel challenged, and I often found myself being emerged in the battles in a way I never had before.  There is a strange cinematic experience in Attila that has not been there since the first Shogun and Medieval, I am not sure if it is the AI, the graphics, or the sense of desperation in every move that gives it what so many of the recent games have been lacking but I am glad it's back and I hope it is here to stay.  

When you win that battle there are now several options for what to do with the newly taken settlement. Most talked about is the ability to destroy settlements, this removes them from the map and leaves a little marker where the settlement was. You will gain some cash from this as well as food.  Be warned however, rebuilding settlements is extremely expensive, a small lvl 2 town was going to cost me 13,000 cash and 600 soldiers to rebuild. One of the lesser publicized features is the ability to pillage settlements. This will damage all the buildings, and give you some cash but leave the city in the control of the other faction.  This is useful for when you send a small army (or navy!) to attack an unprotected settlement but don't have the army to fend off the attack yet. Then you have the pillage and settle option which is a combo of the settle and pillage actions, meaning you damage all the buildings and get a lot of cash but also settle the town. Last you have the regular settle and subjugate options. 

Winter is coming. Winter will kill men if you get caught without protection, the attrition is pretty steep and I love it. 

City management is improved here too, all city’s (villages, towns, ect.) can have a governor who will both act as a general if the city is invaded (using the garrison troops) as well as allow you to place edicts on individual towns.  This makes owning one piece of a region a lot more bearable, and doesn't force you to invade people just for that extra bonus.  

I am trying to keep myself from getting to excited from this game, I really do love it but I also don't want to seem too fanboyish. I am just extremely happy to have a very good Total War game for the first time in a while.  As of this moment I don't want to give a score of the game, I will save that for my first update after I have many more hours in game. I will say that if you are a fan of the series and you are worried about another Rome II, don't this is everything Rome II should have been.  

I will keep this review up to date for at least the next few weeks incase something crazy comes up and ruins the game.

attila is certanly an improvement over rome 2, when playing it is clear that alot of the groundwork for this game came from rome 2 but i wouldnt go as far to say that its a reskin, attila is (so far atleast) a very nice feeling game that has had some well thought out changes and tweaks, the only negative thing i would say is i get very poor performance when ending a turn usually it sits below 10 fps but as this isnt gameplay it is only really a small niggle.

Attila is remarkably better than Rome II. The bugs are minimal and none that I personally have experienced, and the game play is smooth. The Game runs quite well with the battle load times being a little long though, that is likely caused by my computer rather than the game itself. The map diversity is good but not as great as expected. The Fire Spreading system is a big over powered in my opinion, though I must admit it is quite nice. The start positions for the nations are hordes are all interesting and offer a good opportunity for large range of options. The battles are interesting and the units are much more dependant on local superiority and quality rather than simply throwing them at one another. 

Now onto the bad. The Unit Rosters are thin, and the units themselves are quite bland. No more professional Legions for either the WRE (Wetern Roman Empire) or the ERE (Eastern Roman Empire) which is quite sad. Honestly they look like hired barbarians clad in chainmail with rough shields rather than professional soldiers, which I guess to a degree is accurate for the time period but those beautiful Legions will be missed. Though I believe the modding community will fix these lacking points in time. Over all the game to me has many possibilities and I look forward to the community expanind the Game like in Rome II. 

Worth every penny I spent.

They also removed a couple key things like, easy unit duplication for custom battles and the ability togo first person into each individual unit and experience the battle from their perspective. Hopefully mods and game fixes will turn this into the game it was supposed to be. 7/10

I played initially as the saxons and while I held my own for a long time, eventually I just took on too many enemies at the same time and was overwhelmed.

I have 5 battles at one settlement with the same army, each battle wore my men down, but they kept coming. The only advantage I had was the topography of the settlement, high up with narrow passages.

I defeated the first 4 waves by forcing the enemy into a narrow pass "think 300" and using my cavalry to keep their ranged units on the run.

My 2000 strong army was able to defeat about 9000 units before the 5th wave overwhelmed me.

I felt a sense of great loss when my leader a 5 star general was killed. This game really draws you in and makes you think carefully about your decisions.

What you do in battle and how you do it is a major factor, not just who has the most units wins.

The landscape and unit usage is very important.

The family tree is a welcomed change that makes it both useful and entertaining. I have never seen so many Bastards in my life.
Great game from a great franchize. Just wait until later updates arrive for better optomization.
